SNT.80188.1	Italy have defeated Portugal 31-5 in Pool C of the 2007 Rugby World Cup at Parc des Princes, Paris, France.
SNT.80188.2	Andrea Masi opened the scoring in the fourth minute with a try for Italy.
SNT.80188.3	Despite controlling the game for much of the first half, Italy could not score any other tries before the interval but David Bortolussi kicked three penalties to extend their lead.
SNT.80188.4	Portugal never gave up and David Penalva scored a try in the 33rd minute, providing their only points of the match.
SNT.80188.5	Italy led 16-5 at half time but were matched by Portugal for much of the second half.
SNT.80188.6	However Bortolussi scored his fourth penalty of the match, followed by tries from Mauro Bergamasco and a second from Andrea Masi to wrap up the win for Italy.
SNT.80188.7	Currently third in Pool C with eight points, Italy face a tough match against second placed Scotland on 29 September.
SNT.80188.8	New Zealand lead the group with ten points, ahead of Scotland on points difference.
SNT.80188.9	Portugal are bottom of the group with no points, behind Romania with one.
SNT.87564.10	Some personal details of 3 million British learner drivers who had applied for the 'theory test' component of their Driving licence have been lost in Iowa, in the USA.
SNT.87564.11	The data was lost on a hard drive that was owned by Pearson Driving Assessments Ltd, a private contractor to the UK driving standards agency.
SNT.87564.12	Details were given by the UK Transport Secretary, Ruth Kelly, in the House of Commons at 1730 UTC yesterday.
SNT.87564.13	It is the first major loss of data in the UK since information on 25 million people was lost by HM Revenue in October.
SNT.87564.14	In her statement to MPs, Ruth Kelly confirmed that no banking information was contained within the lost data, nor were individuals' dates of birth.
SNT.87564.15	She highlighted that security measures had been taken, and that the information that had been stored was not in a format "readily usable or accessible" by standard means.
SNT.87564.16	Political figures in the UK continue to raise concerns about both the specific loss of this information, and the nature of governments ability to safely gather and maintain information.
SNT.87564.17	Susan Kramer, representing the Liberal Democrats stated "This constant attempt to gather data, to get more data, to know more about you, to link it more together, all of that it seems to me is what comes into question."
SNT.37376.18	Criticism was targeted to Government efforts in the affair of the Jian Seng in the Australian Senate March 28 and 29 over the handling of the ghost ship, the tanker Jian Seng, which was found abandoned and unlit in the Gulf of Carpentaria.
SNT.37376.19	Senator Joe Ludwig (Labor, Queensland) asked of the Minister for Justice and Customs Senator Chris Ellison in Question Time whether he stood by his claim that he made yesterday that the discovery of the Jian Seng demonstrated that the Australian Government had in place "aerial and maritime surveillance to intercept a vessel in these circumstances, and that was done", and asked why it took the Government two weeks to intercept the vessel after it entered Australian waters.
SNT.37376.20	Senator Ellison responded that at the vessel's first sighting on March 8 "it was not doing anything illegal", and criticised the Opposition's claim that the ship was drifting for seventeen days, saying that "it was not stated as having drifted for the whole of the 17 days".
SNT.37376.21	Ludwig went on to note that it was not Customs that spotted the ship but a "passing Australian barge", but Ellison had defended this, stating that Ludwig "thinks that commercial vessels have absolutely no role in looking out for Australia" and that Ellison will "rely on reports to our hotline and go out and inspect vessels".
SNT.37376.22	Later, Senator Kerry O'Brien (Labor, Tasmania) criticised the Government's implementation of coastal defense, and highlighted the dangers of ignoring the ship for seventeen days, saying that "it posed and possibly still poses unknown environmental and quarantine risks" and that the Jian Seng "has been refused admission to Weipa harbour...It could have been carrying literally anything."
SNT.37376.23	Senator David Johnston (Liberal, Western Australia) went on to debate that there are no shipping lanes in the area where the Jian Seng was found, and that devoting resources to a harmless ship would leave gaps in the coastal defenses elsewhere.

SNT.83870.189	Two scientists working at McGill University in Canada, reporting on their research and the research of other scientists, state in Scientific American that Vitamin D may have many uses in the human body besides building strong bones.
SNT.83870.190	According to the scientists, Luz E. Tavera-Mendoza and John H. White, Vitamin D intake may also be beneficial in the prevention of cancer, multiple sclerosis, diabetes, and fighting tuberculosis, influenza and inflammatory bowel disease.
SNT.83870.191	The researchers say that there is an emerging "widespread consensus" among experts that a large part of the population has levels of Vitamin D in their bodies that is well below optimal concentrations for health, particularly in temperate regions, due to decreased sunlight and or less time outdoors, and during or just after the winter months.
SNT.83870.192	One study indicated that as many as 92% of adolescent girls in Northern Europe may have deficient levels of Vitamin D and 37% have severely deficient levels.
SNT.83870.193	The problem is far worse among African-Americans than Americans with lighter skin.
SNT.83870.194	Almost half of African-American women may be seriously Vitamin D deficient, with presumably still another fraction deficient.
SNT.83870.195	Furthermore, the authors say researchers at Harvard University and elsewhere believe the FDA minimum recommended daily allowance of Vitamin D is far too low.
SNT.83870.196	The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) ranges from 200 to 600 International Units (IU).
SNT.83870.197	The first author takes 1000 IU during wintertime and the second author takes 5,000 IU in wintertime.
SNT.83870.198	They do caution, however, that there is a level at which Vitamin D becomes toxic.
SNT.83870.199	Similar research has also been recently performed by researchers at the Queensland University of Technology who found that many elderly were likely not getting sufficient Vitamin D due in part to insufficient exposure to the sun.

SNT.48012.201	The boy was shot and a teenager injured at around 5pm local time yesterday when, while driving a motorcycle, they sped through a roadblock cordoning off the scene of a suicide bombing.
SNT.48012.202	A soldier fired a bullet which passed through the 17 year-old driver and killed the boy.
SNT.48012.203	"A motorcycle carrying two people broke through the Afghan National Police outer security cordon at high speed," said Colonel Fred Lewis, deputy commander of the Canadian contingent of NATO's International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan.
SNT.48012.204	"The driver failed to heed multiple warnings to stop as he headed towards the inner Canadian cordon. " 
SNT.48012.205	"A Canadian ISAF soldier then opened fire in a defensive application of our rules of engagement. " 
SNT.48012.206	"A single round struck both the driver and the passenger of the motorcycle."
SNT.48012.207	Lewis doubts soldiers had time to fire warning shots due to the speed of the oncoming motorcycle.
SNT.48012.208	He also said that while no explosives were found on the vehicle he had a "sneaking suspicion" that soldiers feared the motorcycle carried a second suicide bomber and acted defensively.
SNT.48012.209	He added that he was concerned that the Taliban would try to exploit the incident for propaganda purposes and that he was concerned about a possible backlash by locals.

SNT.48012.215	An Afghan child also died in the blast which occurred when a suicide bomber rammed his car into a Canadian convoy on patrol in Kandahar.
SNT.48012.216	Corporal Braun is the 27th Canadian soldier to die since Canadian military operations in Afghanistan began in late 2001 as part of the American led "War on Terror".
SNT.217859.217	Researchers at Japan's Kanazawa University announced the identification of a hormone produced by the liver, apparently a previously unknown cause of insulin resistance.
SNT.217859.218	The discovery may offer new research targets in treating insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes.
SNT.217859.219	Insulin resistance (IR) is a condition where the body's cells are unable to respond properly to insulin-based treatments.
SNT.217859.220	The pancreas continues insulin production but fails to prevent increases in glucose levels; in other words, the body becomes unable to respond to the insulin properly.
SNT.217859.221	The researchers found the liver expresses higher levels of the gene encoding "selenoprotein P" (SEPP1) in people with type 2 diabetes – those with more insulin resistance.
SNT.217859.222	This new connection between SEPP1 and adipokine is to be an area for further research.
SNT.217859.223	The discovery may help in understanding plaques associated with Alzheimer's disease.
SNT.217859.224	Researchers at Kyushu University in Fukuoka, Japan concluded in an earlier study that insulin resistance and the development of plaques found in Alzheimer's sufferers were likely linked.
SNT.217859.225	The World Health Organisation estimates 37 million people worldwide live with dementia and/or Alzheimer's.

SNT.431239.227	Judge James P. Gray of California was selected as his running mate.
SNT.431239.228	Johnson's association with the Libertarian Party stretches back to 1993, when he was a dues-paying-member for about a year.
SNT.431239.229	In 2000, the party recruited him to run as their presidential nominee, but he rejected the offer, saying, "I'm a Republican, and I'm not going to run for President."
SNT.431239.230	As a Republican, Johnson was elected and re-elected as governor of New Mexico in 1994 and 1998.
SNT.431239.231	During his governorship, he vetoed over 750 bills, more than all other then-governors combined, and left the state with a $1 billion budget surplus.

SNT.431239.234	In 2012, he chose to mount his own presidential campaign, seeking the Republican Party nomination on a platform of non-interventionism in foreign affairs and extensive cuts to the federal budget.
SNT.431239.235	Though he participated in two early Republican debates, Johnson was barred from most due to low poll numbers.
SNT.431239.236	As a result, in December, he decided to end his Republican campaign and return to the Libertarian Party.
SNT.431239.237	After months of campaigning, Johnson edged activist R. Lee Wrights on the first ballot with 70 percent of the 595 convention delegates.
SNT.431239.238	In contrast, former Congressman Bob Barr took six ballots to secure the 2008 nomination.
SNT.431239.239	Upon his victory, Johnson proclaimed, "I am honored and I just want to pledge that no one will be disappointed."
SNT.431239.240	He suggested the party nominate James P. Gray as his running mate, and they complied, choosing Gray as the vice presidential nominee.
SNT.431239.241	Gray is a jurist, who has served as a trial judge for Orange County, California since 1983.
SNT.431239.242	He ran for Congress as a Republican in 1998, and was the Libertarian Party's 2004 nominee for U.S. Senate in California.
SNT.431239.243	In his writings and media appearances, Gray has advocated against the War on Drugs.

SNT.431239.246	A PPP poll from December showed Johnson with 23 percent support in a three way race in New Mexico.

SNT.263509.260	At least three people were killed, at least fifteen injured.

SNT.744655.272	Friday, an undersea earthquake off the far east coast of Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula was felt in the capital city of Moscow, 10,000 kilometers away.
SNT.744655.273	The earthquake occurred 600km below sea level in the Okhotsk Sea and recorded an 8.2 magnitude on the Richter Scale, with the Moscow shock measured as 1.0 on the scale.
SNT.744655.274	Citizens in Moscow said that the tremors were not "really strong" but they were enough to shake things hanging on walls.
SNT.744655.275	The last time such a shock was felt in Moscow was in 1984.
SNT.744655.276	This is a so-called deep-focus earthquake, that's why it was felt at such a large territory.
SNT.744655.277	If an earthquake happens at such a low depth, the waves move along low layers, practically the mantle, but weaken significantly before reaching the earth surface.
SNT.744655.278	This is why there usually is no injuries or casualties in such cases.
SNT.744655.279	Sahkalin Island was under a tsunami warning on Friday, however, it was lifted soon after.

SNT.76292.341	The largest extrasolar planet or exoplanet has been discovered orbiting the star GSC 02620-00648, around 1,435 light years away.
SNT.76292.342	The planet, named TrES-4, after the Transatlantic Exoplanet Survey (TrES) is 1.7 times the size of the planet Jupiter.
SNT.76292.343	TrES-4 also has a lower mass than Jupiter and an extremely low density of 0.2 grams per cubic centimetre, which is less than a wine cork.
SNT.76292.344	TrES-4 orbits its star at a distance of only 7 million km (4.5 million miles), meaning that the temperature of the planet is estimated at 1,327°C (approximately 1,600K or 2,300°F).
SNT.76292.345	Mandushev went on to say, "Because of the planet's relatively weak pull on its upper atmosphere, some of the atmosphere probably escapes in a comet-like tail."
SNT.76292.346	Due to the planet's size, current theories about superheated giant planets find it hard to explain why it is so large.
SNT.76292.347	Francis O'Donovan, a graduate student in astronomy at the California Institute of Technology which operates one of the TrES telescopes said, "We continue to be surprised by how relatively large these giant planets can be.
SNT.76292.348	"But if we can explain the sizes of these bloated planets in their harsh environments, it may help us better understand our own Solar System planets and their formation."

SNT.363350.457	Three nations in three continents have seen attention focused on high suicide rates this week.
SNT.363350.458	A study found Scotland's suicide rate to be increasing away from neighbouring England, Russian press and politicians are examining the world's third-highest teen suicide rate, and new figures showed increasing Aboriginal children's suicides in Australia's Northern Territory.
SNT.363350.459	"Until the highest authorities see suicide as a problem, our joint efforts will be unlikely to yield any results," Boris Polozhy of Moscow's Serbsky psychiatric center said yesterday.
SNT.363350.460	Only fellow ex-USSR nations Belarus and Kazakhstan have higher teen suicide rates than Russia, which is at around 20 per 100,000 nationally.
SNT.363350.461	Tuva, Siberia, and nearby Buryatiya have rates of 120 and 77 per 100,000 respectively.
SNT.363350.462	Thursday saw national children's ombudsman Pavel Astakhov say 4,000 youths kill themselves each year.
SNT.363350.463	He said Russian schools, which are criticised for understaffing and perceived inattention to bullying, should teach psychology.
SNT.363350.464	"I have seen websites that offer a thousand ways of killing oneself," he claimed.
SNT.363350.465	Astakhov wanted schools to offer assistance via a social networking presence and tackle online bullying.
SNT.363350.466	The overall national suicide rate is decreasing — down from 42 per 100,000 in 1995 to 23.5 two years ago.
SNT.363350.467	The high rate amongst teens is attributed to both school problems and violence at home.
SNT.363350.468	Recent high-profile cases include yesterday's death of a twelve-year-old who hung himself at home in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, and two fourteen-year-olds who jumped hand-in-hand to their ends from a building in Lobnya, Moscow.
SNT.363350.469	Researchers from the Scottish cities of Edinburgh and Glasgow, and Manchester in England, have been looking at data from 1960 to 2008.
SNT.363350.470	Although Scotland had the lower rate until 1968, England and Wales has had the lower rate since.
SNT.363350.471	Both areas had increasing rates until the southern side started to fall in the '90s, and in recent years the gap has significantly increased.
SNT.363350.472	Data was sorted by age, gender, and method; marked increases were seen among Scotsmen aged from 25 to 54 with hanging increasing in popularity.
SNT.363350.473	"This study adds to our understanding about patterns of suicide in Great Britain by producing sound evidence on divergences in long-term trends in Scotland compared to England and Wales," said Professor Stephen Platt, a lead researcher from Edinburgh University's Centre for Population Health Sciences.
SNT.363350.474	"In a future companion paper we will suggest explanations for the persisting higher rate of suicide in Scotland."
SNT.363350.475	Fellow joint lead researcher Roger Webb of the Centre for Suicide Prevention of Manchester University said the high Scottish hanging rate was "of particular concern as hanging has high case-fatality and is difficult to prevent, except within institutional settings."
SNT.363350.476	He noted "a public information campaign about hanging" could be one way of reducing the rate.
SNT.363350.477	Paid for by the Scottish taxpayer, the results appeared in the British Journal of Psychiatry.
SNT.363350.478	In an incident with parallels to the recent Moscow deaths, in 2009 Scottish and British media publicised a high-profile case in which two teenagers leap together from the Erskine Bridge, a famed suicide spot over the where an estimated fifteen people kill themselves each year.
SNT.363350.479	This week also saw Howard Bath, Children's Commissioner for Australia's Northern Territory, suggest the area had the highest proportion of Aborignal girl suicides in the West.
SNT.363350.480	There has been a significant increase since an emergency intervention five years ago in response to a report titled Little Children are Sacred which documented widespread sexual abuse of Northern Territory children and failures by authorities to adequately respond.
SNT.363350.481	A national government-backed Northern Territory suicide inquiry is ongoing and due to report next month.
SNT.363350.482	The inquiry has heard clusters of deaths occurred around East and West Arnhem, Katherine, and the vicinity of Alice Springs.
SNT.363350.483	The Tiwi Islands had a very high rate from 2000 to 2005, but has now not had a suicide for a year.
SNT.363350.484	Female suicide rates have greatly increased to account for 40% of Northern Territory suicides amongst those aged less than eighteen.
SNT.363350.485	"We now have a situation in the territory where there are almost as many female as male suicides," said Bath.
SNT.363350.486	Lack of information is a problem; the all-party inquiry has heard evidence of much under-reporting and poor data collection.
SNT.363350.487	The Menzies School of Health's Gary Robinson called for a Queensland-style register of suicides.
SNT.363350.488	Robinson suggests cannabis-induced psychosis to be a contributing factor but laments "The big problem is nobody keeps any data."
SNT.363350.489	He also suggested bullying, as in Russia, is a problem while Bath notes violence against women may also take a role.
SNT.363350.490	"Aboriginal women are being hospitalised for assault at 80 times the rate of other women... "
SNT.363350.491	"Exposure to violence greatly increases the risk of a person taking their life."
SNT.363350.492	He also notes "I am concerned, as the commissioner, about children who are frequently exposed to violence in the home or in the immediate family."
SNT.363350.493	"The method chosen is usually hanging and it is a particularly lethal method, far more than an overdose," said Bath.
SNT.363350.494	New South Wales, with the nation's largest indigenous population, has a suicide rate of one per 100,000 but the Northern Territory rate is over 30 per 100,000.

SNT.182635.507	The plant will be built on the coast of the Mediterranean Sea, and construction will commence as soon as the deal is approved by both countries; the building process is expected to take around seven years.
SNT.182635.508	The reactor will also be owned by Russia, which will hold "no less than a controlling stake," according to Sergey Kiriyenko, who is the head of Rosatom, a Russian nuclear energy corporation.
SNT.182635.509	The reactor to be built is the second proposed power plant in the same location; a separate proposal for a four-reactor complex built by a Russian-led consortium was rejected by a Turkish court last year.
SNT.182635.510	Russia has attempted to build a nuclear power plant in Turkey, and the contract signed Wednesday "really looks rather impressive," according to Russian President Dmitry Medvedev.
SNT.182635.511	The contract for the reactor was one of 20 signed by the two countries today, expected to result in around US$25 billion of Russian investment in Turkey.
SNT.182635.512	Other major contracts signed include projects to transport Russian oil and natural gas through Turkey to ports on the Mediterranean Sea.
SNT.182635.513	One such project is a major pipeline between the Turkish ports of Samsun on the Black Sea and Ceyhan on the Mediterranean Sea, built in conjunction with an oil refinery in Ceyhan.
SNT.182635.514	In a press conference, Russian President Medvedev said that the agreements signal "a new page in our cooperation...Our talks today showed that Turkey and Russia are strategic partners not only in words but in deeds."
SNT.182635.515	Turkish President Abdullah Gul said that the two countries "share a determination to increase the trade volume from a current US$38 billion to US$100 billion in five years."

SNT.104797.698	Complex 40 was first used in 1965, for the maiden flight of the Titan IIIC rocket.
SNT.104797.699	Following the second Titan III launch, it was modified to serve as a launch pad for the US Air Force's Manned Orbiting Laboratory (MOL).
SNT.104797.700	In November 1966, a boilerplate MOL space station was launched on a Titan IIIC from the complex, along with a Gemini capsule, and four satellites.
SNT.104797.701	Following the cancellation of MOL, it was converted back to a regular Titan launch complex, and was used for 55 launches, of Titan IIIC, 34D, and IV rockets.
SNT.104797.702	Two planetary probes, two commercial satellites, a British military communications satellite, and numerous payloads for the American armed forces were launched from the complex, which ceased operations in April 2005, when the penultimate Titan IV launched the Lacrosse-5 spy satellite for America's National Reconnaissance Office.
SNT.104797.703	Along with Launch Complex 41, which was demolished in 1999, LC-40 was used for heavy-lift Titan rocket launches.
SNT.104797.704	The Mars Observer and Cassini-Huygens missions to Mars and Saturn respectively were launched from Complex 40.
SNT.104797.705	The launch pad is being demolished to make way for a new complex, which will be used by the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, currently scheduled to make its maiden flight in 2009.
SNT.104797.706	As well as being used for commercial launches, the new LC-40 will be used for cargo resupply missions to the International Space Station, under a Commercial Orbital Transportation Services (COTS) contract with NASA.
SNT.104797.707	It could eventually be used for manned missions using the SpaceX Dragon spacecraft.
SNT.104797.708	SpaceX currently has a five year lease on the site.

SNT.31094.716	The project includes the French and German governments along with a host of European technology companies such as Thomson, France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom.
SNT.31094.717	It is scheduled to be submitted to France's Agency of Industrial Innovation later this month.

SNT.31094.719	President Jacques Chirac announced the launch of Quaero during the French-German ministerial conference in April of last year.
SNT.31094.720	It is the latest in a series of initiatives by the Europeans to compete with US dominance in technology.
SNT.31094.721	Europe launched the Galileo satellite navigation system last month aimed at rivaling a similar system already available in the US.

SNT.62727.764	Although the United States experienced average temperatures for the December, 2006 to February, 2007 period, overall world temperatures were the warmest on record, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
SNT.62727.765	In a March 15, 2007 report, the NOAA indicated that a record warm January helped push the combined global land and ocean surface temperature for the past winter to its highest value since records began in 1880.
SNT.62727.766	The ocean-atmosphere system, El Niño, played a part in the season's record warmth, according to the report's authors, but its effects did not last long, as ocean temperatures in the central equatorial Pacific cooled more than 0.3 degrees C in February and were near average for the month.
SNT.62727.767	The global land-surface temperature was the warmest on record, while the ocean-surface temperature tied for second warmest in the past 128 year period, approximately 0.06 degrees C cooler than the record established during the strong El Niño episode of 1997-1998.
SNT.62727.768	During the past century, global surface temperatures have increased approximately 0.06 degrees C per decade, but since 1976 the rate of increase has been about 0.18 degrees C per decade.
SNT.62727.769	The greatest temperature increase occurred in the high latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere.
SNT.62727.770	In an interview with Reuters, Jay Lawrimore of NOAA suggested that the data does not show greenhouse gases had an influence on the recent temperature increases, but acknowledges that by "looking at long-term trends and long-term changes, we are able to better understand natural and anthropogenic (human-caused) climate change."
SNT.62727.771	A U.S. Commerce Department agency based in Washington, D.C., the NOAA conducts research and gathers data on oceans and atmosphere.
SNT.62727.772	The NOAA is a participant in the Group on Earth Observations, GEO, an intergovernmental effort to coordinate the collection of Earth observations worldwide.

SNT.56352.774	Litvinenko was a strong critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin and shortly before he died in London from radiation poisoning in late November, Litvinenko accused Putin of ordering his assassination.
SNT.56352.775	Putin and other Russian officials strongly denied any prior knowledge of a plot to kill Litvinenko.
SNT.56352.776	According to a report posted late Friday on the Russia Today TV web site, the Federal Agency for Press and Mass Media is gathering publications worldwide to be studied for libelous and offensive comments against Russia in their coverage of the Litvinenko's case.
SNT.56352.777	Russia Today TV reported that the Russian government intends to file law suits for libel against international media if there is evidence of journalistic misconduct.
SNT.56352.778	In a Voice of America interview shortly before he was poisoned by a radioactive substance polonium-210, former Russian spy Litvinenko had accused Putin of ordering the murder of Russian journalist Anna Politkovskaya to silence her and intimidate other independent journalists.
SNT.56352.779	She had been killed by an unknown assailant in Moscow in early October.
SNT.56352.780	Several senior Russian politicians have said that the deaths of Politkovskaya and Litvinenko were playing into the hands of Russia's enemies and, therefore, could not have been authorized by Moscow.
SNT.56352.781	The Russian government's warnings aimed at international journalists follow Putin's largely successful efforts to bring major media outlets in Russia under government control and to limit media criticism of his policies.
SNT.56352.782	Reporters Without Borders, a Paris-based nongovernmental organization, has called Putin one of the world's top "Predators of Press Freedom."
SNT.56352.783	FreeMediaOnline.org, a California-based nonprofit organization which monitors media and supports press freedom worldwide, said that the latest warnings issued by the Federal Agency for Press and Mass Media would prove a major embarrassment for Putin and for Russia if they were carried out.
SNT.56352.784	An article on the FreeMediaOnline.org web site claims that even if there is no direct link between the two assassinations and the Kremlin, Putin is ultimately responsible for the climate of lawlessness and suppression of free media that may have contributed to these murders.
SNT.56352.785	FreeMediaOnline.org also noted that uncovering the truth about the murders of Politkovskaya and Litvinenko would be difficult because independent journalists in Russia have been either silenced or intimidated by President Putin's media advisors, government regulators, and security services.
SNT.56352.786	Putin insists he is a strong supporter of democracy and press freedom.
SNT.56352.787	In a speech to Russian television broadcasters in late November 2006, Putin said that the development of Russian state and society would be unthinkable without independent media, without the possibility of listening to different points of view, and without television.
SNT.56352.788	Putin's critics point out that he has successfully placed under the Kremlin's control all major nationwide television channels.
SNT.56352.789	According to FreeMediaOnline.org, journalists working for these channels no longer dare to offer any significant criticism of Mr. Putin's policies.
SNT.56352.790	The organization warned that restrictions on media freedom in Russia have emboldened criminal elements to engage in illegal activities.

SNT.35116.842	Scientists forecast that up to five million species will be lost this century.
SNT.35116.843	"We are well into the opening phase of a mass extinction of species. "
SNT.35116.844	"If we carry on as we are, we could lose half of all those 10 million species," Myers said.
SNT.35116.845	"If we do not do more," Myers says, "the planet will continue to lose around 50 species per day compared to the natural extinction rate of one species every five years."
SNT.35116.846	He projected this rate in the late 1980s to much criticism, but the figure is now widely accepted by scientists.
SNT.35116.847	"The whole thing is taking place in what you might call a flickering of an evolutionary eye," said Myers.
SNT.35116.848	"It's hard to keep up with unless we damp down on some of the causes of the evolution."

SNT.109167.942	Viacom argued that since they claimed that copyright material is more popular than user-made videos, they needed access to the information to strengthen the case, in which US District Court judge Louis L. Stanton agreed and ordered Google to turn over such information.
SNT.109167.943	Google argued that this would cause privacy issues, but Stanton said it was just speculation.

SNT.41349.953	Serbia reluctantly agreed to the split, and the European Union approved.
SNT.41349.954	Despite expectations, there were no riots that night; however, early celebrations had occurred in the capital Podgorica based off of expected results.
SNT.41349.955	This is the first time Montenegro has been independent since 1916, when it became a part of Austro-Hungary.
SNT.41349.956	Soon Serbia, Croatia and Slovenia together formed "Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenians", which later changed the name into Kingdom Yugoslavia.
SNT.41349.957	In 1991 and 1992 four of six Yugoslavian republics declared independence but two, Serbia and Montenegro, remained together.
SNT.41349.958	Some analysts note that Serbia and Montenegro has not functioned as one state since the Belgrade agreement, signed three years ago.
SNT.41349.959	Each republic had separate anthems, laws, and currencies and their joint parliament did not meet very often.

SNT.29845.1042	The reason for the cave-in of the roof was most likely massive snowfalls.
SNT.29845.1043	Earlier that afternoon, measurements had been taken to determine its stability.
SNT.29845.1044	Update on 4 January, 15:42 GMT: So far, 14 bodies have been found.
SNT.86574.1045	In an investigation reported on first by Wikinews, Wikileaks today revealed another chapter in the story of the Standard Operations Procedure (SOP) manual for the Camp Delta facility at Guantanamo Bay.
SNT.86574.1046	The latest documents they have received are the details of the 2004 copy of the manual signed off by Major General Geoffrey D. Miller of the U.S. Southern Command.
SNT.86574.1047	This is following on from the earlier leaking of the 2003 version.
SNT.86574.1048	Wikileaks passed this document to people they consider experts in the field to carry out an analysis trying to validate it.
SNT.86574.1049	Following this, they set out to assess what had changed between 2003 and 2004; including attempts to link publicly known incidents with changes to the manual.
SNT.86574.1050	The American Civil Liberties Union had previously made a request to view and obtain copies of the same document, but was denied access to them.
SNT.86574.1051	One of the first notable changes to the document relates to the detainees themselves.
SNT.86574.1052	Rules are now posted around the camp in detainees' languages.
SNT.86574.1053	Of concern to groups such as Amnesty International who campaign for the camp's closure, or Human Rights Watch concerned about prisoner handling under the prisoner of war aspects of the Geneva Convention, is the fact that policy for newly admitted detainees still allows for up to 4 weeks where access to the detainee by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) may be denied.
SNT.86574.1054	In addition, guards are not to allow ICRC staff to pass mail to detainees.
SNT.86574.1055	A new process has been formed which allows guards to determine whether or not a detainee receives awards, or is punished.
SNT.86574.1056	The form is called a GTMO Form 508-1 (pictured to the right).
SNT.86574.1057	According to the manual, the form "is used to determine which rewards the detainee will lose or gain," but "special rewards" can also be earned, outside of the process.
SNT.86574.1058	Another special reward is a roll of toilet paper, but the detainee cannot share it with others.
SNT.86574.1059	Doing so will result in "punishment" and confiscation of the roll.
SNT.86574.1060	If the detainee already has a roll of toilet paper, he is not allowed to have another.
SNT.86574.1061	"Guards need to ensure that the detainee doesn't receive additional toilet paper when the detainee already has it."
SNT.86574.1062	"The amount given to the detainee will be the same amount as normally distributed to the detainee," states the manual.
SNT.86574.1063	No matter how bad a detainee may act, "haircuts will never be used as punitive action" against them, but they can have hair removed for health reasons.
SNT.86574.1064	"If a detainee has committed an offense that requires segregation time, even if a segregation cell is not available, the detainee will receive a shave and a haircut for hygiene and medical reasons."
SNT.86574.1065	"If the detainee is IRFed, the haircut and shave will follow the decontamination process," adds the manual.
SNT.86574.1066	Infractions such as spitting, throwing water at, or attempting to urinate on guards appear as explicitly listed cases where pepper spray may not be used.
SNT.86574.1067	Extensive decontamination procedures are included in the document, including immediately calling for a medical check on any detainee exposed to pepper spray.
SNT.86574.1068	As a counter to the clearer instructions on use of pepper spray, Wikileaks asserts that many of the stricter rules for guards (referred to as Military Police or MPs in the 2003 manual) aim to reduce fraternisation that may improve detainee morale and adversely influence any interrogation process.
SNT.86574.1069	Guards are informed in the manual not to take personal mail and parcels within the detention blocks or at any other duty stations.
SNT.86574.1070	All electronic devices except issued materiel are prohibited, and guards may face disciplinary action should they keep detainees apprised of current affairs or discuss issues in their personal lives.
SNT.86574.1071	Additional restrictions on the detainees' chaplain are included in the revised document.
SNT.86574.1072	Wikileaks speculated that many of these changes might have stemmed from the widely publicised case of James Yee.
SNT.86574.1073	Captain Yee, a West Point graduate, served at the Guantanamo Bay base as a Muslim chaplain to the detainees and received two Distinguished Service medals for his work.
SNT.86574.1074	Following discovery of a list of detainees and interrogators by U.S. Customs in Florida Yee was charged with sedition, aiding the enemy, spying, espionage, and failure to obey a general order.
SNT.86574.1075	Eventually all charges were dropped with national security concerns being raised should evidence be released.
SNT.86574.1076	The most notable changes surrounding the role of the chaplain include its removal as a permanent position on the facility's Library Working group and its exclusion from the decision process on appropriate detainee reading material.
SNT.86574.1077	Wikileaks contacted lawyers representing detainees in the camp to perform their own analysis.
SNT.86574.1078	Their opinion of the changes were that the library operation had been considerably tightened up.
SNT.86574.1079	Duplicate books are required for the individual four camps to prevent covert use of books to communicate between camps.
SNT.86574.1080	Periodicals, dictionaries, language instruction books, technology or medical update information, and geography were additions to the prohibited material.
SNT.86574.1081	Instructions indicate such books must be returned to the source or donor.
SNT.86574.1082	The revised SOP manual makes considerable progress on documenting procedures, even those that are remote possibilities.
SNT.86574.1083	A lengthy addition details rules to follow in the event of an escape or escape attempt.
SNT.86574.1084	Laced throughout this procedure is an emphasis on having any such incident fully documented and - wherever possible - filmed.
SNT.86574.1085	The procedure is explicit in how to recapture an escaped detainee with minimal use of force.
SNT.86574.1086	One additional procedure covers the admission of ambulances to the main base area.
SNT.86574.1087	A detailed security protocol to ensure only expected and authorised traffic gains access is included, as is a procedure streamlined to ensure the ambulance arrives on the scene as quickly as possible.
SNT.86574.1088	Unchanged from the 2003 manual is the set menu of four ready-to-eat meals (Meal, Ready-to-Eat or MRE) issued to detainees.
SNT.86574.1089	However, additional steps are to be taken for "MRE Sanitization"; supply personnel must remove anything that can damage waste disposal systems— presumably a military term for toilets.
SNT.86574.1090	Under normal camp conditions, detainees should be fed hot meals as opposed to MREs, but no details on the variety of menu are included.
SNT.86574.1091	US Southern Command passed a query on to Rick Haupt (Commander, U.S. Navy Director of Public Affairs, Joint Task Force at Guantanamo) who responded that "questions were forwarded along with a request to authenticate the leaked document; a response is pending."
SNT.86574.1092	At this time no response to emails has been received from the ICRC or Human Rights Watch.
SNT.86574.1093	The Pentagon has requested that the document be removed from Wikileaks because "information with the FOUO (For Official Use Only) label is not approved for release to the public."
SNT.86574.1094	They then state that the document can be "made available through a Freedom Of Information Act request through official channels."
SNT.98436.1095	Two weeks ago, on February 1st, it was the second day of the national environmental Focus the Nation teach-in.
SNT.98436.1096	One of these events, which took place at the same time at other educational institutions across the country, took place in the city of Lynn at the campus of North Shore Community College.
SNT.98436.1097	Wikinews accredited reporter Patrick Mannion was there in attendance along with Congressman John F. Tierney of Massachusetts's 6th congressional district and Lynn's State Senator Thomas McGee.
SNT.98436.1098	One of Lynn's two representatives, Robert Fennell, also attended; the other representative Steven Walsh sent an aide.
SNT.98436.1099	The representatives for the nearby cities of Salem and Beverly, John Keenan and Mary Grant along with various local area mayors and city councilors also attended the event.
SNT.98436.1100	John F. Kerry, the senator for Massachusetts was supposed to attend but could not due to voting on the economic stimulus package in Washington D.C..
SNT.98436.1101	However, Senator Kerry did record a video statement DVD for the event in which he addressed the gathered crowd.
SNT.98436.1102	Senator McGee started things off by talking about the need to recreate the North Shore Technical High School to include a focus on environmental jobs and the need to improve the Essex Agricultural and Technical High School which is deteriorating, but is known for it's agricultural teaching which would help to save the dwindling farming areas north of Boston.
SNT.98436.1103	McGee urged people that should get more involved with their local farming co-ops and that farmland needs to be recognized and redeveloped.
SNT.98436.1104	He noted that obesity in young people is a problem and that schools are developing partnerships with local farms to provide more healthy meals and to show students whats going on at their local farm.
SNT.98436.1105	Representative Keenan commended the college for holding this dialogue and Al Gore along with his movie, An Inconvenient Truth.
SNT.98436.1106	Keenan noted the need for Salem's coal-fired power station for the need to switch to clean coal.
SNT.98436.1107	Walsh aide's brought up the fact he is committed to ending paper waste at the Massachusetts State House.
SNT.98436.1108	The city council president from Chelsea, Roseann Bongiovanni, who is also the associate executive director of the local community organization, the Chelsea Collaborative, asked the various reasons for the crowd in why they became concerned about global warming.
SNT.98436.1109	The audience noted the melting of ice sheets, air quality, Hurricane Katrina and Al Gore.
SNT.98436.1110	Bongiovanni then noted that Chelsea and neighboring East Boston have no green space or waterfront due the industrialization of both areas, noting that 100% of the jet fuel for planes at Logan Airport, 70% to 80% of heating oil and that the trucks delivering the oil are spewing diesel.
SNT.98436.1111	She also noted the large salt pile in Chelsea used for the deicing of highways in the Commonwealth and said that it is located there "illegally."
SNT.98436.1112	She further noted the company, Energy Management Inc., behind the controversial Cape Wind project, proposed building a diesel power plant across the street from a Chelsea elementary school and that air quality in Chelsea is bad.
SNT.98436.1113	She closed her dialogue by noting that "Global warming does not recognize boundaries."
SNT.98436.1114	Mary Grant said she was interested in hearing ideas and noted the redeveloping of Beverly's high school to include more solar panels and a new wind turbine and that the school would be powered by 50% of it.
SNT.98436.1115	One person asked the need to lower the level of bureaucracy in government as she was "running around city government" in order to have a bee farm in her backyard.
SNT.98436.1116	Robert Fenell, the owner of Lynn's Capitol Diner who is notable for keeping chickens at the establishment located in downtown Lynn just two blocks away from the college noted that people should start going organic and going back to nature, that people should switch to more energy efficient lighting and grow gardens in their backyard.
SNT.98436.1117	After Fennell spoke it was time for questions and answers, and questions were given by various audiences members including Mannion himself, who asked about the MBTA's Blue Line and rapid transit and others asking various questions such wither or not to include a green curriculum in state education or asking for the politicians to talk more on some of their positions.
SNT.98436.1118	After questions and answers finished, the video statement from John Kerry began to play.
SNT.98436.1119	Kerry noted that there are still skeptics of global warming and climate change in Congress who "test the science" despite the efforts and research of Al Gore and the United Nations and noting that "the White House is the last place for change."
SNT.98436.1120	He then went on to say that the world needed a new international treaty on climate change and noted that America is horrendous when it comes to energy efficiency.
SNT.98436.1121	Kerry also noted that the Bush administration resisted the change and the points of the climate conference in Bali; "Luckily, time is almost up," added Kerry.
SNT.98436.1122	Kerry went on to mention the need for massive new research on new energy and capturing carbon and noted he was working with Alaska's senator, Ted Stevens on pushing for sequestering plants.
SNT.98436.1123	Kerry continued the theme of environmental conservation and change by topping off his statement by reminding the crowd of first Earth Day and how it lead to the creation of the Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, Endangered Species Act and the Environmental Protection Agency and it noted it happened because of people's actions.
SNT.98436.1124	Tierney finished off the speech by noting the need for high risk energy research in the style of DARPA so we can better compete against the "Chinas and Japans."
SNT.98436.1125	He also called for more green-collar jobs and noted his work on last year's Green Jobs Act.
SNT.123997.1126	The United Stated Department of Justice has asked for corruption charges against former Alaska Senator Ted Stevens to be dropped because evidence was withheld from the defense team by the original prosecutors.
SNT.123997.1127	The Justice Department has stated that they will not retry Stevens.
SNT.123997.1128	In a statement, US Attorney General Eric Holder said, "After careful review, I have concluded that certain information should have been provided to the defense for use at trial."
SNT.123997.1129	"In light of this conclusion, and in consideration of the totality of the circumstances of this particular case, I have determined that it is in the interest of justice to dismiss the indictment and not proceed with a new trial."
SNT.123997.1130	Stevens was convicted in October on seven felony counts of lying on senate disclosure forms about gifts, largely in the form of free renovations to his home, received from an oil service company; his conviction is thought to have been a large factor in his November electoral defeat to former Anchorage mayor Mark Begich, the current junior Senator from Alaska.
SNT.123997.1131	Stevens immediately appealed his conviction and has maintained his innocence.
SNT.123997.1132	The prosecution case has met with a number of procedural difficulties, with US District Court judge Emmet G. Sullivan holding the prosecution in contempt in March for failing to turn over documents concerning an FBI whistleblower's reports of mishandling of the case.
SNT.123997.1133	The Justice Department has since replaced the case's prosecutors, and the allegations of misconduct have held up sentencing from the original convictions.
SNT.123997.1134	The filed papers indicate that notes were never turned over from an interview that has the oil contractor estimated the house renovation for far less then he specified at trial.
SNT.123997.1135	The original trial team was removed, but in the end Attorney General Eric Holder thought it would be best if the case was dropped.
SNT.123997.1136	NPR's source indicate that Holder wish to forcefully transmit that prosecutorial misconduct will not be tolerated.
SNT.123997.1137	The trying prosecutors are under investigation by the Justice Department for their conduct in the matter.
SNT.123997.1138	Stevens, now 85, served as Alaska's Senator from 1968 to 2009.
SNT.111137.1139	On Saturday Mikheil Saakashvili, the President of Georgia, called for a ceasefire in the South Ossetia war.
SNT.111137.1140	"I call for an immediate ceasefire," said Saakashvili, speaking in Tbilisi.
SNT.111137.1141	"Russia has launched a full scale military invasion of Georgia."
SNT.111137.1142	After calling for the ceasefire Saakashvili continued by saying that "I am willing to have international mediation; I am willing to have international separation of forces; we have to establish normal regime under international supervision."
SNT.111137.1143	Russian President Dmitry Medvedev stated his position regarding the ending of the conflict in a phone call with Federal Chancellor of Germany Angela Merkel: "The only possible and reasonable way out of this situation is the withdrawal of Georgian troops to their initial positions and the immediate signing of a legally binding agreement on the non-use of force."
SNT.111137.1144	He reiterated much the same position in telephone conversation with the President of the United States, George W. Bush, today.
SNT.111137.1145	Saakashvili's call for a ceasefire comes soon after his declaration that Georgia is now in a state of war.
SNT.111137.1146	"I have signed a decree on a state of war."
SNT.111137.1147	"Georgia is under a state of total military aggression by the Russian navy, air force, large-scale ground operations," he said in a televised meeting that was broadcast on national television.
SNT.111137.1148	Alexandre Lomaia, the head of the Georgian security council, said that President Saakashvili's proposal states that the Georgian troops will withdraw from Tskhinvali, and will stop reacting to the Russian bombings.
SNT.111137.1149	The crisis broke out after days of heavy fighting in the region.
SNT.111137.1150	On August 7, Georgian troops launched an offensive against the Ossetian town of Tskhinvali.
SNT.111137.1151	Russia responded to these actions by sending their own troops into South Ossetia on August 8.
SNT.111137.1152	According to the Russian Presidents office, drinking water is no longer available in what constitutes South Ossetia's capital, Tskhinvali, because "the water and sewage treatment plants have been destroyed".
SNT.111137.1153	It is further stated that 30,000 people have left South Ossetia to seek refuge in Russia in the last 36 hours alone; and that preparations are underway to provide tented and permanent accommodation for these.
SNT.111137.1154	South Ossetia is a former province of Georgia that broke away from Georgia and declared its independence on November 28, 1991.
SNT.122440.1155	Investigators with the National Transportation Safety Board in the United States have issued an 'urgent safety recommendation' in connection to their role alongside the United Kingdom's Air Accidents Investigation Branch in investigating loss of power in Rolls-Royce engines on Boeing 777s, with the AAIB following suit.
SNT.122440.1156	One of them resulted in British Airways Flight 38 crashing short of the runway at London's Heathrow Airport last year.
SNT.122440.1157	The NTSB and the AAIB want Rolls-Royce to redesign the engines.
SNT.122440.1158	Both events occurred on Boeing 777-200ER airplanes powered by Rolls-Royce RB211 Trent 800 Series engines.
SNT.122440.1159	On January 17, 2008 British Airways Flight 38 experienced a dual engine rollback (reduction of engine power) on final approach to Heathrow and crashed, leaving one passenger seriously injured, eight passengers and four of the flight crew with minor injuries and the airplane written off.
SNT.122440.1160	The second event occurred on November 26, 2008, when a Delta Air Lines Boeing 777 experienced a single engine rollback during cruise flight over Montana, United States while en route from Shanghai to Atlanta.
SNT.122440.1161	Normal operations resumed after the flight crew followed Boeing's published procedure to recover engine performance and the airplane landed safely in Atlanta.
SNT.122440.1162	Boeing has already developed new procedures after the crash to prevent ice from building up within their 777 fuel systems after it became apparent that icing may have been a factor, and it was some of these that the Delta flight crew had followed.
SNT.122440.1163	As part of the recent releases by the NTSB and AAIB it has become apparent that investigators from both bodies, which are collaborating, have found ice buildup in the fuel system caused both rollbacks.
SNT.122440.1164	In both cases a build-up of ice (from water normally present in all jet fuel) developed on a component called the fuel/oil heat exchanger.
SNT.122440.1165	This restricted the flow of fuel to the engine, resulting in the uncommanded engine rollback.
SNT.122440.1166	Investigators initially struggled to produce enough ice under test conditions but have now found that at high concentration, fuel can form ice at very low temperatures in enough quantity to seriously restrict fuel flow, according to a new interim report by the AAIB.
SNT.122440.1167	This does not occur when fuel demand is lower, as the hot oil then becomes sufficient to entirely melt the ice.
SNT.122440.1168	The vigorous tests are thought to be the first of their kind.
SNT.122440.1169	They have also confirmed that while ice may have formed elsewhere in the airliner's fuel system fuel was probably not restricted at any other location.
SNT.122440.1170	Instead, it is thought 'soft' ice formed in the pipes and then broke off, travelling to the fuel/oil heat exchanger and restricting it.
SNT.122440.1171	The NTSB has now revealed that they have advised Rolls-Royce to redesign the fuel/oil heat exchanger, and Rolls-Royce have stated that they are indeed working on a replacement part that will be available within twelve months.
SNT.122440.1172	The AAIB advised Boeing and Rolls-Royce to jointly review the problem across the fuel system, and both companies responded that they 'accepted' this recommendation and repeated that a replacement part was being developed.
SNT.122440.1173	Both the NTSB and the AAIB also sent letters to the US Federal Aviation Administration and the European Aviation Safety Agency requesting the installment of the modified component be mandatory.
SNT.122440.1174	The NTSB suggested this should be either the next maintenance check or within six months.
SNT.122440.1175	There are 220 Boeing 777-200s - the only type using the affected engine - with Trent 800 series engines.
SNT.122440.1176	The fuel/oil heat exchanger is a dual purpose part designed to simultaneously melt fuel ice and cool down engine oil.
SNT.122440.1177	The AAIB further noted that it is unclear whether other aircraft designs are at risk, and advised the FAA and EASA to look into increased use of de-icing additives and investigate both the accumulation and sudden movement of ice in aircraft fuel systems and the actual formation of ice in the fuel itself.
SNT.27408.1178	A new advertising campaign in USA for the Sony PSP which looks like graffiti and is often sprayed on previously vandalized walls has come under attack from other graffiti artists.
SNT.27408.1179	A collective group of graffiti artists and street artists are now banding together, vandalizing the look-alike graffiti advertisements.
SNT.27408.1180	The campaign has offended a lot of graffiti artists and street artists, drawing responses like "keep your desperate corporate long arm out of a movement that is the only thing that is ours!"
SNT.27408.1181	But not all the responses have been negative, with many artists defending Sony saying they have the right.
SNT.27408.1182	"Sony and PSP have every right to use this type of media," Floyd Hayes, the head creative director at Cunning Work told Wired News.
SNT.27408.1183	"They have done it for (a) very long time very successfully and spoke the language of the streets without being patronizing."
SNT.27408.1184	Sony says it is paying the building owners like Casa Maria for the right to advertise on their walls.
SNT.27408.1185	Casa Maria was paid $100 for two weeks' use of its wall, co-owner Mario Arana told Wired News.
SNT.27408.1186	Tats Cru, the graffiti crew responsible for the designs, have also been targeted with insulting slogans on Sony's advertisements.
SNT.139522.1187	Six energy companies in the United Kingdom have announced that it is likely that the prices for energy bills could increase over the course of 2010.
SNT.139522.1188	The companies, which are nicknamed the "big six" in the United Kingdom, did not pass on information that there would be price cuts in energy bills despite increasing profits.
SNT.139522.1189	However, the companies have in fact sent a message in response saying that the prices of bills may even increase over the course of the next year.
SNT.139522.1190	Energy company watchdog the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (Ofgem) have estimated that energy companies will make gross margins of ￡170 ($276) per dual fuel customer over the course of the next twelve months, due to the recent fall in wholesale energy costs.
SNT.139522.1191	Ofgem have said: "Our analysis shows that based on an 18-month hedging strategy and assuming that retail prices remain unchanged, projected gross margin is set to increase by around ￡80 for dual fuel customers over the next six months."
SNT.139522.1192	The "big six" energy companies in the United Kingdom are British Gas, E-on, Npower, Scottish and Southern Energy, Scottish Power, and EDF Energy.
SNT.139522.1193	British Gas stated: "Prices [are] likely to remain at historically high levels, and in fact likely to increase as non-commodity costs rise ever upwards."
SNT.139522.1194	EDF Energy said: "[We] would of course be prepared to reduce tariffs if market conditions allowed."
SNT.139522.1195	Scottish Power stated: "There are no immediate signals that would indicate a fall in retail prices for this winter, and risks of an increase next year."
SNT.139522.1196	Scottish & Southern Energy commented: "With forward annual wholesale prices significantly higher, and with upward pressures in terms of distribution, environmental and social costs, seeking to avoid an increase between now and the end of 2010 is an important goal."
SNT.139522.1197	Meanwhile, a study by Consumer Focus in early September 2009 suggested that "energy companies were overcharging customers by ￡100 ($162) every year."
SNT.139522.1198	A spokesperson for Ofgem said that there was no evidence of any cartel in operation, or evidence of profiteering.
SNT.139522.1199	The spokesperson commented: "It is up to the companies themselves to decide whether to cut their bills."
SNT.139522.1200	"Consumer Focus data suggests that Scottish Power has increased dual fuel prices by the most since 2003 - up 148% - while decreasing prices by 0.6% so far this year."
SNT.139522.1201	"RWE's Npower has increased tariffs by 132% since 2003, but has reduced bills by 2.7% in 2009."
SNT.10709.1202	The University of California, Berkeley announced that one of its graduate students, Michael Park, rediscovered on May 24 the Mount Diablo buckwheat, a plant not sighted since 1936 and believed to have been extinct.
SNT.10709.1203	Found nearly 30 miles east of San Francisco, Park [aged 35] identified the small pink flowering plant said to resemble baby's breath during a routine visit to the mountain.
SNT.10709.1204	The significance of the find drew comparisons to the recent discovery of the Ivory-billed woodpecker in Arkansas earlier this year in April.
SNT.10709.1205	The exact location of the flowering plant is, for now, being kept secret.
SNT.10709.1206	Several botanists have confirmed it along with the nearly dozen or so other plants.
SNT.10709.1207	The property is being preserved by the Save Mount Diablo conservation group operating in the Mount Diablo State Park.
SNT.278552.1208	The United Nations (UN) on Friday called on the government of Pakistan to investigate numerous killings and abductions, particularly of journalists.
SNT.278552.1209	"In the past eight days alone we have received reports on the killing of one journalist, Munir Shakir, in Balochistan on August 14 2011, and the disappearance of another journalist, Rehmatullah Daparkhel, three days earlier in North Waziristan on August 11," said spokesperson for the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Rupert Colville.
SNT.278552.1210	According to the Committee to Protect Journalists, nine journalists have been killed in Pakistan this year, and at least 16 were killed in 2010.
SNT.278552.1211	None of the killings had been investigated satisfactorily, Colville said.
SNT.278552.1212	Colville said that the UN would like to see the government review all of the incidents.
SNT.278552.1213	"We call on all responsible parties to immediately stop such violations of human rights, and we urge the government to take immediate steps to independently investigate these cases," he said.
SNT.278552.1214	Amnesty International has also urged the government of Pakistan to ensure the protection of journalists and media workers in the country.
SNT.278552.1215	They have further called upon the Pakistani authorities to investigate attacks on journalists and to try those responsible in line with internationally recognised standards of human rights.
SNT.278552.1216	Colville said that the recent attacks on journalists were not uncommon in Pakistan and that many journalist groups regard the country as one of the most dangerous places to work.
SNT.278552.1217	Shakir was shot dead after covering a protest organized by a Baloch separatist organization.
SNT.278552.1218	Irshad Matsoi, the bureau chief for the Online News Network where Shakir worked, said that the killing was linked to the journalist’s work.
SNT.278552.1219	Journalism in Balochistan is becoming "an endangered profession," Matsoi said.
SNT.278552.1220	Reporters Without Borders (RWB) have appealed for punishment of those responsible for the murder.
SNT.278552.1221	According to RWB, journalists do not feel free to report in Balochistan, which has led to self-censorship in the region.
SNT.278552.1222	The whereabouts of Daparkhel, kidnapped on August 11, is still unknown.
SNT.278552.1223	The worldwide press freedom organization said that the government must do everything they can to find him immediately.
SNT.278552.1224	"It is unacceptable that local journalists have to do the job of the police and investigate on their own using their contacts," the organization said.
SNT.278552.1225	The Human Rights Commission of Pakistan (HRCP) has condemned the incidents.
SNT.278552.1226	"There is a growing sense of insecurity among media persons who increasingly interpret each attack on journalists as a warning to ‘behave,’" the HRCP said last Monday.
SNT.278552.1227	The HRCP also said that in almost all cases of violence against journalists in the last few years, those responsible have not been identified or punished.
SNT.278552.1228	"The HRCP calls upon the government to respond through effective action and not mere words in the next few days, sending a strong message to the mischief makers that it would no longer stand by as a mere spectator as journalists are killed and snatched," the Commission said.
SNT.16726.1229	Mohammed Bouyeri, a radical Islamist who was a member of the Hofstad Network, was sentenced to life in prison by a court in Amsterdam for the killing of the controversial filmmaker Theo van Gogh in November 2004.
SNT.16726.1230	Van Gogh was ambushed on an Amsterdam street and shot repeatedly in the chest before Bouyeri stabbed him and slit his throat.
SNT.16726.1231	The judgment said that Bouyeri showed "complete disregard for human life" and butchered Van Gogh "mercilessly".
SNT.16726.1232	Bouyeri, a 27 year who holds joint Dutch-Moroccan citizenship, claimed he acted on behalf of Islam.

SNT.119265.1237	The flooding is mainly in the western part of the country's main island, Viti Levu, where most of the resorts hosting international travellers are located.
SNT.119265.1238	Fiji's National Disaster Office has advised all tourists still in the country to prepare for more bad weather and possibly more flooding.
SNT.119265.1239	Fiji's chief of disaster management Aisea Qumihajelo said in a statement, "There's another depression heading toward Fiji within the next two days and that will bring an additional threat."
SNT.119265.1240	The government of Fiji's military dictator Frank Bainimarama declared a state of emergency in the city of Nadi, the country's tourist centre, and other parts of western Viti Levu.
SNT.119265.1241	Over 6,000 people have evacuated the area and are now in one of Fiji's 144 evacuation centers sheltered from the storm.
SNT.119265.1242	Government sources have reported that at least six people have been killed by floodwaters, and two people were crushed by a landslide.
SNT.119265.1243	The flood has affected many of the rural areas of the island, washing out sugar cane crops across the area and damaging roads and bridges.
SNT.119265.1244	"Widespread flooding, including severe flooding of major rivers and streams, is expected on Wednesday and Thursday."
SNT.119265.1245	"The western division is likely to be worse affected once again," said Fiji's director of meteorology, Rajendra Prasad.
SNT.119265.1246	Rescue efforts, led by the government and the Red Cross, have begun especially in rural and heavily-flooded areas.
SNT.119265.1247	Vetaia Dokonivalu, a local resident from Ba, a hard-hit town, commented, "It was really frightening."
SNT.119265.1248	"We watched as the doors of our homes were forced open by the water."
SNT.119265.1249	"We saw our belongings being swept out of the houses."
SNT.119265.1250	This flooding has also caused a food crisis in some parts.
SNT.119265.1251	Isimeli Tukana, a health official, said, "People need to collect as much rainwater as possible and drink as much of this as possible."
SNT.119265.1252	"Watch out for food from supermarkets especially from the towns of Ba, Nadi, Sigatoka and Rakiraki."
SNT.119265.1253	"Our health inspectors will be doing their rounds as soon as the water goes down."

SNT.190108.1339	Slovenians yesterday voted in a referendum in favour of a border deal with Croatia.
SNT.190108.1340	The Border Arbitration Agreement allows for international arbitrators to resolve a 20-year border dispute that dates back to the break-up of Yugoslavia.
SNT.190108.1341	Parliaments in both countries approved the deal, which will be binding on both countries.
SNT.190108.1342	In March, Slovenian Prime Minister Borut Pahor's centre-left government yielded to demands for a referendum on whether to accept a border deal.
SNT.190108.1343	"Solving the border dispute with Croatia is the basis for a lasting peace, security and friendship of both nations," Pahor said.
SNT.190108.1344	"If it is rejected, it is questionable how long I or my successor will need to reach another agreement which, I believe, could not be better."
SNT.190108.1345	The national Electoral Commission said that after 99.9 per cent of votes were counted, 51.5 per cent voted for the deal and 48.5 were against it.
SNT.190108.1346	It is impossible for the remaining 2,000 votes, cast by Slovenians living abroad, to change the outcome.
SNT.190108.1347	Slovenia is situated between Italy and Croatia, where the dispute involves land on the Istrian peninsula in the northern Adriatic and the small Bay of Piran in the Adriatic Sea.
SNT.190108.1348	A panel of five international experts will define the new land and maritime borders and could force Croatia to cede some of the sea it views as its own.
SNT.190108.1349	In the past, Croatia has called for the border to be drawn down the middle of the bay.
SNT.190108.1350	However, Slovenia, which has a much shorter coastline, feared that this would deny its ships direct passage to international waters.
SNT.190108.1351	Slovenia is the only former Yugoslav state to have joined the European Union (EU), while Croatia hopes to conclude EU accession talks this year and join the twenty-seven member union in 2012.
SNT.190108.1352	Slovenia has blocked Croatia's membership talks over the border issue in the past.
SNT.190108.1353	"Resolving this bilateral issue is an important signal for the region and the relations between Slovenia and Croatia."

SNT.96153.1368	The search continues for the other two children - Hannah Luong, 2, and Lindsey Luong, 1.

SNT.158544.1377	Actor, director, and artist Dennis Hopper has died today at the age of 74.
SNT.158544.1378	He was known to suffer from prostate cancer since October 2009.
SNT.158544.1379	He was born Dennis Lee Hopper on May 17, 1936 in Dodge City, Kansas.
SNT.158544.1380	As a young man, Hopper became interested in acting and eventually became a student of the Actors Studio.
SNT.158544.1381	He made his first television appearance in 1955, and appeared in two films featuring James Dean, Rebel Without a Cause (1955) and Giant (1956).
SNT.158544.1382	Over the next ten years, Hopper appeared frequently on television in guest roles, and by the end of the 1960s had played supporting roles in several films.
SNT.158544.1383	He directed and starred in Easy Rider (1969), winning an award at the Cannes Film Festival, and was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay as co-writer of the film's script.
SNT.158544.1384	Hopper was unable to build on this success for several years, until a featured role in Apocalypse Now (1979) brought him attention.
SNT.158544.1385	He subsequently received critical recognition for his work in Blue Velvet and Hoosiers, with the latter film garnering him an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor.
SNT.158544.1386	Hopper's more recent work included a leading role in the television series Crash.
SNT.158544.1387	Hopper was a prolific photographer, painter, and sculptor whose works have been exhibited worldwide.
SNT.158544.1388	On January 12, 2010, several months after the cancer diagnosis, Hopper had filed for divorce from his wife Victoria Duffy leading to an extended public feud between the couple over the course of the following months.

SNT.119974.1415	Martin Garbus, Esq. filed a shareholder derivative suit Monday against Marvel Entertainment and its Chief Executive Officer Isaac Perlmutter, as well as Stan Lee, the creator of Marvel superhero characters, and Lee's wife and former Marvel Studios head, Avi Arad.
SNT.119974.1416	The suit is for more than US$750 million (£528M) — about half of the estimated proceeds from Marvel's movies.
SNT.119974.1417	Plaintiff Stan Lee Media (SLM) has four shareholders who live in Florida, California and Canada, and include Jose Abadin and Nelson Thall.
SNT.119974.1418	The company is suing for recovery of civil damages representing one-half of film and book earnings from such blockbuster films as Spider-Man, Iron Man, X-Men, Hulk, and Fantastic Four franchises.
SNT.119974.1419	Defendants are accused of copyright violations over both the Marvel superhero characters and intellectual properties created by Stan Lee.
SNT.119974.1420	Spider-Man's three cinematic outings, starring Tobey Maguire, earned more than $1bn (￡702m).
SNT.119974.1421	"Most of Marvel's financial success, including from the films, comes out of assets created by Stan Lee that are the subject of this suit," the complaint states.
SNT.119974.1422	Lee, 86, has denied the allegations and has previously filed his own $50 million counter lawsuit against SLM, claiming the company has destroyed his name and reputation and prevented his effort to develop such properties as "The Accuser" and "The Drifter" and others via his first-look deals with Disney and Virgin Comics.
SNT.119974.1423	Former dot-com company STM further alleges that it has agreed to pay Lee a $250,000 annual salary plus $100 million in company stock in exchange for the rights to the superhero characters.
SNT.119974.1424	"That money should have gone to the corporation," said Garbus.
SNT.119974.1425	Lee's counsel, Mark Williams, replied: "We look forward to a positive resolution for Stan Lee and his family."
SNT.119974.1426	Marvel has said the court pleadings, which were filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, are filled with "ridiculous claims".
SNT.119974.1427	SLM ran out of operating capital during the dot-com meltdown in December 2000, closing operations entirely by December 19 of that year.
SNT.119974.1428	The company was placed into Chapter 11 Reorganization in Bankruptcy by Stan Lee in 2001.
SNT.119974.1429	During the insolvency proceedings, Lee assigned the major character franchises he had created to his new public company, POW! Entertainment, without the bankruptcy court's approval.
SNT.119974.1430	Two multi-billion dollar lawsuits for damages were filed against Lee, his new company, his new partner Arthur Lieberman and Marvel Entertainment for cybersquatting and failure to disclose the existence and value of the Rights Assignment Lee made to the company when he founded it.
SNT.119974.1431	The company remained under bankruptcy protection until the US Trustee for the Central District of California moved to dismiss the bankruptcy proceedings for failure of the company as debtor in possession to comply with basic requirements of filing monthly reports and paying quarterly fees to the Trustee.
SNT.119974.1432	SLM was taken back by the shareholders after its dismissal from bankruptcy and hired a legal and accounting forensic consultant to review all transactions that occurred during bankruptcy.
SNT.119974.1433	By November 2006, all of the officers and directors of the company had resigned or abandoned their positions and the company's lawyers for the debtors in possession attempted to obtain court authorization to destroy or dispose of the company's books and records.
SNT.119974.1434	This initiated a long-running legal battle between shareholders and the company's founder, Lee.
SNT.119974.1435	The plaintiffs in this most recent suit contend that Lee, Perlmutter, Arthur Lieberman and Avi Arad conspired in bad faith to conceal and misappropriate financial interests in Lee's creations assigned to Stan Lee Media in 1998.
SNT.119974.1436	SLM's meltdown involved its former President Peter F. Paul fleeing to Brazil, contributions made to Bill and Hillary Clinton, Paul's extradition and more.
SNT.119974.1437	In 2007, SLM filed a $5 billion lawsuit in which it claimed co-ownership of all of Stan Lee's creations for Marvel.

SNT.37837.1446	If Iran's claims are correct, it would make this missile the fastest underwater missile in the world.

SNT.127172.1458	State Secretary Rigmor Aasrud said that the activities in question might be prosecuted as fraud or as violations of existing healthcare regulations.
SNT.127172.1459	A Norwegian Member of Parliament (MP) whose daughter killed herself after taking such a test, supports the idea of prosecuting illegal practices rather than trying to ban the movement as a whole.
SNT.127172.1460	The statement was made after three journalists from the online edition of the newspaper Verdens Gang (VG) took the test.
SNT.127172.1461	The journalists wore hidden recording devices, and did not disclose that they were journalists; VG put the recordings on its website.
SNT.127172.1462	Scientology staff members told all three that they should buy a course to handle psychological issues.
SNT.127172.1463	Two of the journalists filled out the 200 questions with honest answers, while the third gave answers consistent with being depressed.
SNT.127172.1464	The "depressed" journalist was told that he should avoid traditional medicine, while one of the "normal" journalists was told that the course was her only hope for improvement unless she wanted to start taking "chemicals".
SNT.127172.1465	Matthias Fosse, spokesperson for the Church of Scientology in Norway, said that the staff members in question were acting individually.
SNT.127172.1466	He said that the Church of Scientology does not give medical advice, but that it encourages people to focus on the side effects of medications, and is critical of the "over-medication" of psychiatric patients.
SNT.127172.1467	Olav Gunnar Ballo, a Norwegian MP and medical doctor whose daughter Kaja suddenly killed herself after a negative experience with the Scientology test in France in March 2008, released a book about Kaja Ballo's life in April 2009.
SNT.127172.1468	The book debuted on 2nd place in the Norwegian best seller list.
SNT.127172.1469	Ballo listened to the recorded test result sessions from VG and said that he found the practice "horrible and harmful".
SNT.127172.1470	He told the newspaper Dagbladet that Norway could have something to learn from the current French prosecution of Scientology corporations and individuals, by prosecuting specific harmful practices rather than banning Scientology as a whole.
SNT.127172.1471	Matthias Fosse said that France is a far more secular society than Norway, and that France were going too far in their prosecution.
SNT.127172.1472	He said that France has a list of 165 organizations considered to be "sects", which not just included Scientology but also covered Baptists such as former U.S. president Bill Clinton.
SNT.127172.1473	The list which Fosse referred to is a list from the 1995 Parliamentary Commission on Cults in France.
SNT.127172.1474	Fosse said that the OSCE, the U.S. State Department and the UN had criticised French "violations of human rights".

SNT.111988.1539	Operation NANOOK 2008 was held from August 11 to August 25 by the Canadian Forces for the purpose of conducting mock emergency rescue operations for potential maritime disasters in the northeastern Canadian Arctic waters.
SNT.111988.1540	Two Canadian navy ships and two airforce planes, a CC-138 Twin Otter and a CP-140 Aurora, took part in the exercises in the Canada's Arctic.
SNT.111988.1541	The HMCS Toronto and the Canadian Coast Guard ship Pierre Radisson travelled along the Hudson Strait.
SNT.111988.1542	The Operation extended to Davis Strait, and Frobisher Bay during the annual NANOOK Operation.
SNT.111988.1543	As more Arctic ice melts, the ships sail through uncharted waters.
SNT.111988.1544	Emergency response times were tested for such potential disasters as oil spills, or rescue operations such as responding to cruise ship emergencies.
SNT.111988.1545	General Walter Natynczyk, Canada's chief of Defence staff, the Honourable Peter MacKay, Defence Minister as well as Minister of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency, and Steven Fletcher, Member of Parliament for Charleswood–St.James–Assiniboia and Parliamentary Secretary for Health, flew to Iqaluit, Nunavut to officially launch the exercise on August 19, 2008 and observe the process.
SNT.111988.1547	In addition to the military exercises, Veterans Affairs Canada held a commemorative event onboard the HMCS Toronto to honour the 55th Anniversary of the Cease Fire in Korea, the 65th Anniversary of the Battle of the Atlantic, and the start of the Last 100 days of the First World War.
