SNT.517748.2612	Following Hungary's release and repatriation of convicted Azeri axe-murderer Ramil Safarov, who Azerbaijan subsequently pardoned, Armenia announced it is "ready for war".
SNT.517748.2613	The declaration is in-response to Safarov's pardon and promotion, despite the Azeri officer having been given a life sentence — with a minimum jail term of 30 years, by Hungarian authorities in 2006.
SNT.517748.2614	Safarov was found guilty of the 2004 murder of Armenian officer Gurgen Margaryan in Budapest, when both Safarov and Margaryan were attending a NATO Partnership for Peace programme.
SNT.517748.2615	Safarov killed Margaryan in his sleep with an axe; the attack allegedly stemming from a desire to avenge Azeris killed during the Nagorno-Karabakh War and being mocked by Margaryan and another Armenian.
SNT.517748.2616	On his return home, Safarov was met with a hero's welcome, given a pardon by president Ilham Aliyev, promoted to the rank of major, awarded eight-years of back-pay and given a house.
SNT.517748.2617	Armenia sees these acts, when it was expected that Safarov would serve out his prison term in Azerbaijan, as highly provocative.
SNT.517748.2618	Armenian President Serzh Sarkisian declared: "We don't want a war, but if we have to, we will fight and win."
SNT.517748.2619	"We are not afraid of killers, even if they enjoy the protection of the head of state" .
SNT.517748.2620	Historically both Armenia and Azerbaijan lay claim to some of the same territories, an issue complicated by the intermingling of ethnic populations so some areas have no clearly demarcated Azeri and Armenian border; these potential sources of conflict remained quiescent whilst both nations were subsumed by greater powers.
SNT.517748.2621	However, the collapse of the Ottoman and Russian Empires in the wake of the First World War led to the Armenian–Azerbaijani War.
SNT.517748.2622	With the demise of the short-lived Armenian-Azerbaijan-Georgia Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic, fighting broke out which only ended when the two nations were annexed by the expanding Soviet Union.
SNT.517748.2623	With the USSR's collapse, Armenia and Azerbaijan re-emerged as independent states — as-did old rivalries over territory.
SNT.517748.2624	Between 1988 and 1994 over thirty thousand people died, and a million were displaced in bitter ethnic fighting between Armenians and Azeris over the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh; despite an Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe brokered ceasefire, no final armistice has been signed and intermittent violence between them the two states continues.
SNT.517748.2625	Nagorno-Karabakh remains legally part of Azerbaijan, but under effective Armenian control.
SNT.517748.2626	On multiple occasions president Ilham Aliyev has stated his willingness to resort to force in order to assert Azeri rule, with oil wealth tipping any local arms race in favour of Azerbaijan.
SNT.517748.2627	On Friday, The National Security Council of Armenia decided to break ties with Hungary during an emergency summit, describing the Hungarian actions as a "grave mistake".
SNT.517748.2628	In turn, the Azeri ambassador was summoned by Hungary on Monday regarding the breach of Azeri assurances that Safarov would serve out the remainder of his sentence in Azerbaijan.
SNT.108657.2629	The camp of Manny Pacquiao led by manager Freddie Roach claimed that Diaz will need a "fucking miracle" to stop 'The Pacman' from moving up to the 135 lbs. weight class where Diaz is top brass.
SNT.108657.2630	The side of Diaz led by Jim Strickland warned that tough Pacquiao has three belts in boxing, Diaz should not be discounted.
SNT.108657.2631	Boxing punters observed that Diaz has a lot of heft in the way he delivers his punches but Pacquiao's speed and strong punches are something Diaz should be wary about.

SNT.3336.2636	Bucharest, the capital of Romania, will become the first southeastern European city to host CowParade.
SNT.3336.2637	Between June 1 and the end of August this year, the city will be flooded by herds of decorated cow sculptures, exhibited at well-known landmarks, such as The Palace of the Parliament, Europe's largest building, as well as on the streets and outside metro stations.
SNT.3336.2638	Over 3000 local and international artists will participate in the event, decorating more than 100 life-sized fibreglass cows.
SNT.3336.2639	The decorated cows will feature Romanian and Bucharestean themes, as well as issues related to international city life.
SNT.3336.2640	After the event ends, all the cows will be auctioned off, with the proceeds donated to the Special Olympics Romania, a charity helping athletes with mental disabilities.
SNT.3336.2641	The Bucharest CowParade is organised by Event Horizon, a Romanian marketing consultancy.
SNT.3336.2642	CowParade, which was first held in Zurich in 1998, has been held in 22 cities in 5 continents and is today the world's largest public art event.
SNT.3336.2643	Bucharest was chosen from over 500 other candidate cities and has waited for the event for a couple of years.
SNT.3336.2644	The new local government in Bucharest wants to relaunch the city's image as a creative and colourful metropolis and have therefore enthusiastically supported the exhibition.
SNT.3336.2645	The high-profile event is expected to boost the image of Bucharest worldwide, especially in the artistic scene.
SNT.106553.2646	A controversial development training course called "Landmark Forum" is cited in religious discrimination lawsuits in United States federal courts in New York and Washington, D.C.
SNT.106553.2647	The seminars are run by a San Francisco, California-based for-profit training company called Landmark Education.
SNT.106553.2648	The company evolved from Erhard Seminars Training "est", and has faced criticism regarding its techniques and its use of unpaid labor.
SNT.106553.2649	The sperm bank and surrogacy company Los Angeles-based Growing Generations is named as a defendant in the New York lawsuit, and the Democratic political action committee Twenty-First Century Democrats is a defendant in the Washington, D.C. case.
SNT.106553.2650	In separate lawsuits filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in Manhattan, New York, and in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia in Washington, D.C., former employees are suing their employers for monetary damages and claiming religious discrimination after their employers allegedly mandated that they attend courses at Landmark Education.
SNT.106553.2651	In the US$3 million federal lawsuit filed in New York, Scott Glasgow is suing his former employer Growing Generations and its CEO Stuart Miller.
SNT.106553.2652	Growing Generations maintains sperm banks and also arranges surrogacy for gay couples who wish to have children.
SNT.106553.2653	The company has offices in New York and Los Angeles, and has done business with celebrities including actor B. D. Wong of Law & Order: SVU.
SNT.106553.2654	Glasgow was marketing director of Growing Generations, and claims he was fired in June 2007 after refusing to continue attending Landmark Education seminars.
SNT.106553.2655	Glasgow is also suing for sexual harassment, and claims Miller came on to him in September 2006.
SNT.106553.2656	He made approximately $100,000 per year as the company's marketing director, and was the company's only employee based out of New York City.
SNT.106553.2657	"I want them to stop imposing Landmark on the employees, and I want an apology," said Glasgow in a statement in The Village Voice.
SNT.106553.2658	Brent Pelton, one of Glasgow's attorneys, stated that: "The Landmark philosophy is deeply ingrained in the culture of the company".
SNT.106553.2659	Glasgow said that the Landmark Education training courses were "opposite" to his Christian beliefs.
SNT.106553.2660	According to Glasgow he was questioned by Miller in May 2007 after he walked out of a Landmark Education course, and was fired shortly thereafter.
SNT.106553.2661	We stand by the allegations contained in the complaint and we look forward to proving them at trial, said Pelton in a statement to ABC News.
SNT.106553.2662	Ian Wallace, an attorney who represents Growing Generations, claimed that Glasgow wasn't fired but walked away from his position.
SNT.106553.2663	Growing Generations and Mr. Miller are very confident that these claims will be dismissed ultimately, and there's no factual basis for them whatsoever, said Wallace in a statement to The Village Voice.
SNT.106553.2664	Lawyers representing Growing Generations and Stuart Miller declined comment to The New York Post, and did not immediately return a message from ABC News.
SNT.106553.2665	In Glasgow's complaint, entered into federal court record on April 18, he asserts that Landmark Education constitutes a "religion", and "perceived their philosophy as a form of religion that contradicted his own personal beliefs".
SNT.106553.2666	He states that when he was promoted to Director of Marketing, he asked Miller if he could stop attending the Landmark sessions but was told that they were mandatory for all of the company's executives and that Landmark is "very much the language of the company."
SNT.106553.2667	Glasgow said his performance at the company was assessed based on how he was "touching, moving and inspiring" others, a phrase from the Landmark philosophy, as opposed to his business accomplishments at the company.
SNT.106553.2668	The complaint claims that the actions of Miller and Growing Generations violated Federal, New York State and New York City civil rights laws.
SNT.106553.2669	The lawsuit filed in federal court in Washington, D.C. deals with a separate plaintiff and company, but the plaintiff in the suit also claims that religious discrimination took place for allegedly being mandated to attend Landmark Education courses.
SNT.106553.2670	Kenneth Goldman is suing the United States Democratic political action committee Twenty-First Century Democrats (also 21st Century Democrats) and its former executive director Kelly Young.
SNT.106553.2671	Goldman was formerly the communications director of 21st Century Democrats.
SNT.106553.2672	According to Goldman's complaint, three employees of 21st Century Democrats were fired after refusing to attend the Landmark Forum course.
SNT.106553.2673	The complaint asserts that Landmark Education has "religious characteristics and theological implications" which influenced the mission of 21st Century Democrats and the way the organization conducted business.
SNT.106553.2674	Goldman's complaint states that in addition to himself, a training director and field director were also fired after they made it clear they would not attend the Landmark Forum.
SNT.106553.2675	Goldman says executive director Young infused Landmark Education jargon terms into staff meetings such as "create possibilities", "create a new context", and "enroll in possibilities".
SNT.106553.2676	He also claims that Young "urged" staff members to participate in Landmark Education events outside of the workplace, drove employees to and from Landmark functions, and used funds from 21st Century Democrats to pay for employees to attend those functions.
SNT.106553.2677	Goldman's complaint asserts that he was discriminated against in violation of the District of Columbia Human Rights Act.
SNT.106553.2678	In a statement in The Washington Times, the executive director of 21st Century Democrats, Mark Lotwis, called the lawsuit "frivolous" and said: "we're going to defend our organization's integrity".
SNT.106553.2679	Landmark Education spokeswoman Deborah Beroset said that the Landmark Forum "is in no way religious in nature and any claim to the contrary is simply absurd," and stated: "While we are not a party to this lawsuit and have no firsthand knowledge of it, we can only assume that we are being used as a legal and political football to further the plaintiff's own financial interests."
SNT.106553.2680	The New York lawsuit was filed April 14, and is still in early filing stages.
SNT.106553.2681	A conference with the federal court judge in the case has been scheduled for June 17.
SNT.106553.2682	The Washington, D.C. suit began in November 2007, and entered mediation this past March.
SNT.106553.2683	As of April 15 the parties in the case were due back to court on July 11 to update the court on the mediation process.
SNT.106553.2684	Landmark Education is descended from Erhard Seminars Training, also called "est", which was founded by Werner Erhard.
SNT.106553.2685	est began in 1971, and Erhard's company Werner Erhard and Associates repackaged the course as "The Forum" in 1985.
SNT.106553.2686	Associates of Erhard bought the license to his "technology" and incorporated Landmark Education in California in 1991.
SNT.106553.2687	This is not the first time employees have sued claiming mandatory attendance at "Forum" workshops violated their civil rights.
SNT.106553.2688	In a lawsuit filed in December 1988 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, eight employees of DeKalb Farmers Market in Decatur, Georgia sued their employer claiming their religious freedom and civil rights were violated when they were allegedly coerced into attending "Forum" training sessions.
SNT.106553.2689	Many of these training programs, particularly at large corporations, claim to be purely psychological, aimed at improving productivity and morale and loyalty. 
SNT.106553.2690	 But in fact they are religious, said University of Denver religious studies professor Carl Raschke in a statement to The Wall Street Journal.
SNT.106553.2691	The DeKalb Farmers Market employees were represented by lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union.
SNT.106553.2692	Consulting Technologies Inc., an affiliate of Transformational Technologies Inc., was named as a party in the lawsuit.
SNT.106553.2693	Transformational Technologies was founded by Werner Erhard, and was not named as a party in the suit.
SNT.106553.2694	The "Forum" course that the employees claimed they were mandated to attend was developed by Werner Erhard and Associates.
SNT.106553.2695	Employees said that they were fired or pressured to quit after they objected to the Forum courses.
SNT.106553.2696	The workers claimed that the Forum course contradicted with their religious beliefs.
SNT.106553.2697	The plaintiffs in the suit included adherents of varying religious backgrounds, including Christianity and Hinduism.
SNT.106553.2698	"It's like brainwashing," said Dong Shik Kim, one of the plaintiffs in the case.
SNT.106553.2699	The plaintiffs said they lost their jobs after objecting to a "new age quasi-religious cult" which they said was developed by Werner Erhard.
SNT.106553.2700	The DeKalb Farmers Market denied the allegations, and an attorney for the company Edward D. Buckley III told The Wall Street Journal that employees were encouraged, not coerced, to attend the training sessions.
SNT.106553.2701	According to The Wall Street Journal, The Forum said it would not sanction workers being coerced to attend its training sessions.
SNT.106553.2702	The parties in the DeKalb Farmers Market religious discrimination case came to a settlement in May 1989, and the case was dismissed with prejudice in June.
SNT.106553.2703	The terms of the out-of-court settlement were not made public, but the employees' attorney Amy Totenberg told The Wall Street Journal that the case "has made employers come to grips with the legitimate boundaries of employee training".
SNT.106553.2704	According to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, employers must "reasonably accommodate" their employees' religious beliefs unless this creates "undue hardship".
SNT.106553.2705	In September 1988, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission issued a policy-guidance notice which stated that New Age courses should be handled under Title VII of the Act.
SNT.106553.2706	According to the Commission, employers must provide "reasonable accommodation" if an employee challenges a training course, unless this causes "undue hardship" for the company.
SNT.106553.2707	In October 2006, Landmark Education took legal action against Google, YouTube, the Internet Archive and a website owner in Queensland, Australia in attempts to remove criticism of its products from the Internet.
SNT.106553.2708	The company sought a subpoena under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act in an attempt to discover the identity of an anonymous critic who uploaded a 2004 French documentary of the Landmark Forum to the Internet.
SNT.106553.2709	The Electronic Frontier Foundation represented the anonymous critic and the Internet Archive, and Landmark withdrew its subpoena in November 2006 in exchange for a promise from the anonymous critic not to repost the video.
SNT.106553.2710	Landmark Education itself has come under scrutiny for its controversial labor practices.
SNT.106553.2711	The company has been investigated by the United States Department of Labor in separate investigations originating out of California, Colorado, and Texas.
SNT.106553.2712	Investigations focused on the heavy reliance of unpaid labor in the company's workforce, which Landmark Education calls "assistants" and deems volunteers.
SNT.106553.2713	Labor based out of Colorado found that activities performed by Landmark Education's "assistants" include: "office, clerical, telephone solicitation and enrollment, as well as greeting customers, setting up chairs, handling microphones during the seminars and making coffee."
SNT.106553.2714	"Additionally, a number of volunteers actually teach the courses and provide testimonials during and after the courses."
SNT.106553.2715	The Colorado investigation's 1996 report found that "No records are kept of any hours worked by any employees."
SNT.106553.2716	According to a 1998 article in Metro Silicon Valley: "In the end the Department of Labor dropped the issue, leaving Landmark trumpeting about its volunteers' choice in the matter."
SNT.106553.2717	Metro Silicon Valley reported that Landmark Education at the time employed 451 paid staff, and also utilized the services of 7,500 volunteers.
SNT.106553.2718	After an investigation into Landmark Education's labor practices by the U.S. Dept.Labor's offices out of California, the company was deemed to have overtime violations.
SNT.106553.2720	According to the Department of Labor's 2004 report on the investigation, back wages of $187,569.01 were found due to 45 employees.
SNT.106553.2721	Labor in Texas which concluded in 2005 stated: "Minimum wage violation found."
SNT.106553.2722	"Volunteers (Assistants) are not paid any wages for hours worked while performing the major duties of the firm."
SNT.106553.2723	"The assistants set up rooms, call registrants, collect fees, keep stats of classroom data/participants, file, they also are answering phones, training and leading seminars."
SNT.106553.2724	Landmark Education agreed to pay back wages for the overtime violation, but did not comply with the overtime violation found by the U.S. Dept.
SNT.106553.2725	Landmark Education denied that the "assistants" are employees, though the Department of Labor report concluded: "Interviews reveal that the employees are taking payments, registering clients, billing, training, recruiting, setting up locations, cleaning, and other duties that would have to be performed by staff if the assistants did not perform them."
SNT.106553.2726	According to the 2004 investigative report by Pièces à Conviction in the "Voyage au pays des nouveaux gourous" program, Landmark Education was investigated by the French government in 1995.
SNT.106553.2727	In the "Voyage au pays des nouveaux gourous" program volunteers were filmed through a hidden camera and shown performing duties for Landmark Education in France including manning phones, recruitment and financial work for the company, and one volunteer was shown cleaning a toilet.
SNT.106553.2728	Le Nouvel Observateur reported that after "Voyage au pays des nouveaux gourous" aired in France, labor inspectors investigated Landmark Education's use of unpaid volunteers.
SNT.106553.2729	According to Le Nouvel Observateur, one month after the labor investigation took place the French branch of the company had disbanded.
SNT.106553.2730	A former "Introduction Leader" to the Landmark Forum, Lars Bergwik, has recently posted a series of videos to YouTube critical of the company and its practices.
SNT.106553.2731	Bergwik appeared on a 2004 investigative journalism program on Sweden's Channel 4, Kalla Fakta (Cold Facts).
SNT.106553.2732	According to Bergwik, after the Kalla Fakta program on Landmark Education aired, "Landmark left Sweden".

SNT.149885.2771	A family of four were said to have been watching television together in the lounge when a large lump of rock, about 50 tons, broke off from a 50 foot cliff above the house.
SNT.149885.2772	The boulder fell from about 15 metres above the residence and landed on top of the house, crushing it.
SNT.149885.2773	The cause of the rock fall is unknown, but police have said that there had been no prior signs that the cliff was unstable.
SNT.149885.2774	The accident, which happened at approximately 1940 local time, killed a 45-year-old father and his 18-year-old daughter.
SNT.149885.2775	A 40-year-old mother and her 16-year-old son were seriously injured and were taken to hospital for treatment, after a rescue operation that lasted into the early hours of the following morning.
SNT.149885.2776	The task involved up to 250 rescue personnel, some with sniffer dogs.

SNT.74916.2787	The United States Geological Survey (USGS) reported that the first earthquake took place at 9:27 (-3 UTC) 165 kilometers from the city of Cruzeiro do Sul, in the Amazonian state of Acre and measured 6.1 degrees on the Richter scale.
SNT.74916.2788	According to Elio Murilo, sergeant of the fire brigade of Cruzeiro do Sul, the phenomenon was not felt and no injuries or property damages were reported.
SNT.74916.2789	The telluric movement took place at a depth of 632.9 kilometers.
SNT.74916.2790	At 12:34 (-3 UTC) another earthquake with an intensity of 6.2 degrees in Richter scale shook the north of Argentina, and the phenomenon was also felt in some Bolivian cities.
SNT.74916.2791	According to the USGS, the epicentre was the Jujuy region 140 kilometres east of Tarija (Bolivia) at a depth of 247 kilometers.
SNT.74916.2792	The authorities have not reported any injuries or property damage.

SNT.7824.2796	A Texas grand jury is taking a hard look at Delay’s fund raising practices, and has already indicted three of his close associates.

SNT.124345.2809	The European Space Agency (ESA) reported on Friday that the Wilkins Shelf, an enormous Antarctic ice shelf half the size of Scotland, could break away from the continent very soon.
SNT.124345.2810	According to reports, only a thin strip of ice connects it to the Charcot Island, and cracks are expanding rapidly.
SNT.124345.2811	This is the largest shelf of ice so far to have disintegrated in the Antarctic.
SNT.124345.2812	In February 2008, the shelf lost 425 square kilometres (164 square miles) of ice, followed by a loss of another 62 square miles in May 2008.
SNT.124345.2813	During the last year the ice shelf has lost about 1800 square kilometers (694 square miles), or about 14 percent of its size, said Angelika Humbert from the Institute of Geophysics at University of Münster in Germany.
SNT.124345.2814	Scientists say that the shelf, if it detaches from the mainland, won't cause an increase in sea levels, as it is already floating.
SNT.124345.2815	Most scientists believe that the incident is further evidence of global warming.

SNT.58207.2847	Apple Inc. today has introduced the much-anticipated iPhone at the Macworld Conference in San Francisco.
SNT.58207.2848	The iPhone is claimed to be "a revolutionary mobile phone" as stated on the Apple website.

SNT.58207.2857	This makes it substantially easier for users to organize their media content.
SNT.2003.2858	The global war on smoking passed a major milestone on 30 November 2004.
SNT.2003.2859	On that date, Peru became the 40th country to ratify an international treaty to reduce smoking, thus triggering activation of the treaty in 90 days.
SNT.2003.2860	According to the World Health Organization's World Health Report 2003, tobacco consumption is the single leading preventable cause of death.
SNT.2003.2861	It prematurely ends the lives of 5 million people a year, a figure which will double by 2020 if current trends are not reversed.
SNT.2003.2862	Tobacco is the only legal product that causes the death of one half of its regular users, more than many illegal drugs.
SNT.2003.2863	This means that of the current 1.3 billion smokers, 650 million people will die prematurely due to tobacco.
SNT.2003.2864	Another way to look at the effect of smoking is to measure the average reduction in life expectancy among smokers.
SNT.2003.2865	A study published in the British Medical Journal in June 2004 followed 34,439 male doctors since 1951 and showed that smokers died on average 10 years earlier than non-smokers.
SNT.2003.2866	Although the number of smokers has stabilized or fallen in developed areas, it is rising in developing or transitional regions, which contain more of the world's population and already 84% of the world's smokers.
SNT.2003.2867	To fight this increasing health threat, the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC) was unanimously adopted by the 56th World Health Assembly in May 2003 following almost three years of negotiations.
SNT.2003.2868	The treaty aims to reduce both the demand for and the supply of tobacco by setting standards on tobacco price and tax increases, tobacco advertising and sponsorship, labelling, illicit trade and second-hand smoke.
SNT.2003.2869	Studies show that increasing prices through taxes on tobacco products is the most cost-effective way to reduce smoking.
SNT.2003.2870	The World Bank estimated that a 10% increase in tobacco prices would, on average, result in a reduction of 4% of the demand in high-income countries and 8% in lower-income countries.
SNT.2003.2871	Thus the treaty suggests tobacco taxes or price controls, although it neither suggests specific levels nor requires any taxes or price controls.
SNT.2003.2872	The treaty requires all countries adopting it to ban, to the extent allowed by their constitutions, all tobacco advertising, promotion and sponsorship within five years.
SNT.2003.2873	Health warnings must occupy at least half of the principal display areas of a pack, but they must not be less than 30%.
SNT.2003.2874	These health warnings must be changed regularly and may include pictures.
SNT.2003.2875	The treaty aims to reduce smuggling by requiring adopting nations to mark all tobacco packages for tracing purposes and to indicate their country of destination, as well as to cooperate with each other in monitoring and controlling the movement of tobacco products and investigating their diversion.
SNT.2003.2876	The idea for an international instrument for tobacco control was initiated in May 1995 at the 48th World Health Assembly.
SNT.2003.2877	But it wasn’t until 1999, a year after the then WHO Director-General, Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, made global tobacco control a priority, that work on the present treaty began.
SNT.2003.2878	During the year after the FCTC was written, 167 countries signed and 23 countries ratified it, making it one of the most rapidly embraced UN treaties of all time.
SNT.2003.2879	The momentum growing around the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control seems unstoppable. 
SNT.2003.2880	It demonstrates the importance placed by the international community on saving many of the millions of lives now lost to tobacco, said Dr Lee Jong-wook, WHO Director-General.
SNT.2003.2881	I look forward to more countries joining the 40 states that are making it possible for this Treaty to become law.
SNT.2003.2882	Of the countries ratifying the treaty, the largest are (in order of decreasing population) India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Japan, Mexico, Thailand, France, and Burma.
SNT.2003.2883	Nations that have signed but not yet ratified include China, USA, Brazil, Nigeria, Philippines, Viet Nam, Germany, and Egypt.
SNT.2003.2884	The largest non-signers are Indonesia, Russia, Colombia, Tanzania, and Uzbekistan.
SNT.2003.2885	The Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan went beyond the treaty requirements when on December 17 it became the first country in the world to completely ban the sale of tobacco.
SNT.48141.2886	Israel has purchased two more Dolphin class submarines which have the capacity to carry nuclear warheads.
SNT.48141.2887	Israel already has three older nuclear weapons-capable Dolphin submarines but the new Dolphins have propulsion systems that allow them to remain submerged for longer periods of time, according to the Jerusalem Post, making it harder for them to be tracked by satellite.
SNT.48141.2888	Experts view the purchase as a clear signal to Iran that Israel can retaliate if subjected to a nuclear attack.
SNT.48141.2889	The Iranians would be very foolish if they attacked Israel, said Paul Beaver, a British based defence analyst, speaking to the Washington Post.
SNT.48141.2890	According to Beaver, the submarines would provide Israel with both first strike and second strike capability.
SNT.48141.2891	Israel already has land-based nuclear-capable ballistic missiles in the form of the Jericho I and II missiles.
SNT.48141.2892	German officials confirm that the contracts for the new submarines was signed July 6.
SNT.48141.2893	The Jerusalem Post reports that they will be operational shortly.
SNT.48141.2894	Israel has never confirmed nor denied that it has nuclear weapons but is believed to have the world's sixth largest stockpile of the devices, with most outside estimates putting their stockpile in the low hundreds.
SNT.48141.2895	Israel's possession of nuclear arms has often been a locus of bitter controversy in the Middle East, especially among countries who believe that the world community, and especially the United States, is hypocritical in its tolerance of Israeli nuclear arms while decrying the efforts of other Middle Eastern nations to develop their own nuclear capabilities.
SNT.48141.2896	Meanwhile, the Jerusalem Post reports there is a growing mood among Israel's defence establishment that the country will have to act independently to stop Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons as the United States is unlikely to do so.

SNT.48141.2899	"Israel would find it hard to live with a nuclear armed Iran and could take military action against Iranian nuclear facilities," the report states.
SNT.48141.2900	Iran has continually maintained that it seeks only to develop nuclear technology for the production of electrical power, though this has been disputed by many nations.
SNT.30046.2901	Thirty-four Indonesian fisherman have been jailed in Broome in northern Western Australia (WA) for illegal fishing offences.
SNT.30046.2902	Seven of the 34 have been jailed in Australia before for previous fishing offences.
SNT.30046.2903	Their vessels were found hiding in mangroves off the Kimberley coast.
SNT.30046.2904	The fisherman were found in possession of nearly two tonnes of trochus shell, a shell valued for fashioning into high quality buttons, beads and trinkets.
SNT.30046.2905	The WA Fisheries Department says the jail terms reflect the seriousness with which the offence is being viewed.
SNT.30046.2906	Department officer Chris Mitchell says the fishermen had traversed 200 miles of Commonwealth waters and were inside the three nautical mile state limit when they were caught.
SNT.30046.2907	He says their actions are a serious breach of fisheries laws.
SNT.30046.2908	"In the early days, the courts would have given a good behaviour bond for a first offender", he said.
SNT.30046.2909	That was more specifically for the traditional sail-powered vessels, not these motorised vessels that are coming down and because these are in state waters it is far more serious.
SNT.30046.2910	On Thursday, skippers of 11 Indonesian fishing boats were fined by a Perth court.
SNT.30046.2911	Three of the men, who had previous convictions, were fined $15,000 each, with 100 days to pay.
SNT.30046.2912	The remaining eight were fined $9000 each and given 60 days to pay.
SNT.30046.2913	The captains were fined between $9,000 and $15,000 for fishing and taking trochus shell from Australian waters off the north-west coast last month.
SNT.30046.2914	Three of the captains have been caught fishing in Australian waters before between 1997 and 2004.
SNT.30046.2915	Legal Aid lawyer David McKenzie, says the fishermen were very poor and it was highly unlikely they would be able to pay the fines.
SNT.30046.2916	The magistrate ordered that they spend between 60 and 100 days in jail in Western Australia if the fines were not paid.

SNT.26095.2923	The independent and nonpartisan US congressional watchdog, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) called the Food and Drug Administration's decision not to allow over-the-counter (OTC) sales of an Emergency Contraceptive pill, "unusual".
SNT.26095.2924	Emergency Contraceptive Pills or ECPs ("morning-after" or "next-day" pills ) are used to prevent an unintended pregnancy, following unprotected sexual intercourse.
SNT.26095.2925	They are objectionable for abortion opponents who consider their use to be a form of abortion, though scientific studies (including those by the FDA) classify them as contraceptives.
SNT.26095.2926	The pill, called Plan B is manufactured by Barr Laboratories and had been approved earlier by the FDA as a prescription drug.
SNT.26095.2927	Barr Laboratories requested that the drug be approved for OTC sale for adults and prescription-only sale for minors.
SNT.26095.2928	The decision to not approve went against the advice given by the FDA's Joint Advisory Committee and its Review staff and led to a GAO investigation into the decision making process.
SNT.26095.2929	The investigation was requested by 30 House members and 17 Senators.
SNT.26095.2930	The GAO found several anomalies in the decision making process.
SNT.26095.2931	The rationale used by Dr. Steven Galson, the acting director of the Centre for Drug Evaluation and Research for rejecting the application was novel and did not follow usual FDA practices.
SNT.26095.2932	The decision was not signed off by the director of the office responsible for the application and the director of the Office of New Drugs, as they disagreed with the "reject" decision.
SNT.26095.2933	The GAO also found that the FDA's high-level management more involved in reviewing this decision than in other change-to-OTC applications.
SNT.26095.2934	The Plan B decision was the only one of 67 proposed prescription to OTC changes to be disapproved, even after advisory committees approved the changes.
SNT.26095.2935	FDA review staff told the investigators that they were told early in the review process that the decision would be made by high-level management.
SNT.26095.2936	E-mail and other documents involving the then-FDA Commissioner Mark McClellan were found to have been destroyed "routinely".
SNT.26095.2937	The FDA has disagreed with the GAO's finding that the high-level management was more involved in processing this application and that the rationale offered was novel, despite acknowledging that the adolescent cognitive ability rationale was unprecedented in FDA practice.
SNT.26095.2938	The accounts as to whether the decision to reject was taken prior to the reviews being completed offered to the investigators were conflicting.
SNT.26095.2939	The acting director cited concerns about the potential behavioral implications for younger adolescents from OTC marketing of Plan-B, given their supposed lower cognitive ability, and that it was not valid to extrapolate data from older to younger audiences.
SNT.26095.2940	However, the FDA had not considered similar "potential behavioral implications" for younger users for other OTC-switches and had previously considered it appropriate to extrapolate data from older to younger audiences.

SNT.330067.2975	The senior journalist was shot in the face after arriving home from work at a radio station in Darayya, on the southern outskirts of the capital city Damascus.
SNT.330067.2976	According to Reporters Without Borders, he died three days after the shooting at Al Mouwsat Hospital.
SNT.330067.2977	Burghol, 56, was a journalist for about 21 years, working for the newspaper Al-Thawra (The Revolution) whilst also hosting a weekly show for Radio Damascus.
SNT.330067.2978	A source told the Xinhua news agency Burghol had received threats.

SNT.330067.2993	The CPJ reported that 45 journalists were killed worldwide in 2011, whereas — using differing criteria — Reporters Without Borders state that 66 journalists around the world died in 2011, and assert that, by almost every indicator, violence and censorship against international journalists was worse in 2011, up 16% on their 2010 figures.

SNT.106188.3102	Construction workers and next of kin of deceased workers filed a lawsuit in Tokyo, Japan Friday seeking damages of approximately 6.6 billion yen (about US$64 million) from the government and manufacturers related to illnesses stemming from exposure to asbestos.
SNT.106188.3103	178 plaintiffs; including construction workers and family members filed the suit in Tokyo District Court against 46 building manufacturers and the Government of Japan.
SNT.106188.3104	According to the Mainichi Daily News, the class action suit is the first that has been filed in Japan related to health damages caused by asbestos exposure at construction sites.
SNT.106188.3105	The plaintiffs hail from the Japanese prefectures of Tokyo, Saitama and Chiba.
SNT.106188.3106	The plaintiffs claim that the government and manufacturers knew of the dangers of asbestos inhalation but failed to take proper precautions, including ceasing to promote asbestos as a cheap fire retardant and banning production of the material.
SNT.106188.3107	They state that after inhaling asbestos in the workplace, 172 people have developed lung cancer or mesothelioma, and that almost half of those afflicted are now dead.
SNT.106188.3108	Plaintiffs argue that the government and health ministry did not act quickly enough after international organizations issued warnings in 1972 that asbestos could be a carcinogen.
SNT.106188.3109	Plaintiffs also place blame with the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry for sanctioning the use of asbestos under Japanese Industrial Standards, and with the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport for approving the use of materials comprised of asbestos and other substances under Japan's Building Standards Law.
SNT.106188.3110	”We will do our utmost until we win the suit”, said Kazuo Miyajima, 78, who heads the group of plaintiffs.
SNT.106188.3111	Lawyers for the plaintiffs released a statement saying: "We seek complete relief for the victims by clarifying the liability of the state and the manufacturers."
SNT.106188.3112	Approximately 40 construction workers from Kanagawa Prefecture plan to file a similar lawsuit in June in Yokohama District Court.
SNT.106188.3113	After a 2005 revelation that residents who lived near a factory in Amagasaki, Hyogo Prefecture developed diseases related to asbestos, the government implemented a law in 2006 which provides monetary assistance to asbestos victims and relatives of deceased family members.
SNT.106188.3114	The plaintiffs argue that the amount of financial assistance given to families and victims of asbestos-related diseases is not sufficient.
SNT.106188.3115	Asbestos has been used in Japan as a fire retardant, for sound absorption, and for insulation.
SNT.106188.3116	It was mixed in concrete and water and sprayed on walls and ceilings, but the practice of spraying asbestos in this manner was banned in Japan in 1975.
SNT.14383.3117	After a press conference in London from the Metropolitan Police and Transport for London, more details are emerging about the attacks in London on Thursday.
SNT.14383.3118	Data from the Underground system's power and control systems have revealed that all three bombs went off within 50 seconds of each other, at 8.50am, with the managing director of Transport for London, Tim O'Toole saying the bombs went "bang bang bang, very close together".
SNT.14383.3119	The first bomb to detonate was on the Liverpool Street train soon after it left for Aldgate on the Circle line, seconds before the others.
SNT.14383.3120	The blast tripped out the power system, visible in the control room.
SNT.14383.3121	The first call the police received that morning reported "a bang" at Aldgate East, coming within a minute of the blast.
SNT.14383.3122	The Edgware Road train, leaving for Paddington and also on the Circle, exploded opposite a train coming from the other direction, making people think at first that it was a derailment.
SNT.14383.3123	The first call to the Police spoke not of an explosion, but of a person falling under the wheels of the train.
SNT.14383.3124	The confirmation of a bomb did not come until 9.17am, but by that time the emergency services were already on scene.
SNT.14383.3125	Transport for London's new TrackerNet software is fully opertational on the Circle line, which allows for precise tracking of trains, but is not yet fully installed on the Piccadilly line.
SNT.14383.3126	The first indication of the Piccadilly line bomb was when the tunnel telephone system wires were cut by the blast, an event logged by other software.
SNT.14383.3127	The cutting of the lines then tripped out the track current.
SNT.14383.3128	The tunnel itself suffered only slight damage and is safe, but the train - which was packed with commuters heading for Russell Square - is very badly damaged.
SNT.14383.3129	London Underground declared a 'code Amber' within minutes, moving trains to platforms and opening all doors.
SNT.14383.3130	A 'code Red' - full evacuation - was set at around 9.15am.
SNT.14383.3131	O'Toole described the decision to evacuate as being "very grave, not taken lightly".
SNT.14383.3132	When questioned as to whether everything possible had been done on the day to save lives, the managing director of Transport for London was "very proud" of the choices made that morning.
SNT.14383.3133	As investigations continue, all bodies have been removed from the sub-surface Circle line trains, but the carriages themselves are still in situ while a painstaking forensic investigation takes place.
SNT.14383.3134	Currently, work is on-going to retrieve bodies and forensic evidence from the carriage of the train in the deep tunnel of the Piccadilly line near King's Cross.
SNT.14383.3135	Teams of rescue workers looking for human remains are working alongside forensics experts in a "meticulous" search to find evidence.
SNT.14383.3136	Conditions are described as being very difficult, with high temperatures and lots of dust.
SNT.14383.3137	Work was halted over Friday night when conditions became too bad, and resumed this morning.
SNT.14383.3138	The exact number of bodies still in the wrecked carriage is unknown.
SNT.14383.3139	Access from King's Cross is impossible, so workers are taking the longer route from Russell Square station to get to the front of the train.
SNT.14383.3140	Police have revealed that the bombs were 'high explosives' - not homemade.
SNT.14383.3141	However they are declining to be specific about their composition as the information could be useful when they interrogate suspects.
SNT.14383.3142	Police will not confirm or deny if any parts of a timer have been found, but have said that "any device will now be in a million pieces".
SNT.14383.3143	Police believe the use of timers more likely than suicide bombings as the blasts were so closely timed, but are not ruling out anything.
SNT.160790.3144	An investigation by the BBC has revealed that millions of dollars in famine relief aid money, including the money raised from the charity supergroup Band Aid and the Live Aid concert held by Bob Geldof, was "siphoned off" by Ethiopian rebels to buy weapons.
SNT.160790.3145	One rebel said that at least US$ 95 million (£63 million) from — Western governments and private charities — was diverted into rebel coffers.
SNT.160790.3146	This was also noted in a declassified Central Intelligence Agency assessment of the famine situation titled Ethiopia: Political and Security Impact of the Drought, in which the report states, "Some funds that insurgent organizations are raising for relief operations, as a result of increased world publicity, are almost certainly being diverted for military purposes."
SNT.160790.3147	During the 1984–1985 famine, Ethiopia was fighting Eritrean and Tigray rebels in those two northern provinces, although Eritrea has since gained its independence.
SNT.160790.3148	Since the countryside was out of the government's control, aid was brought in from neighboring Sudan.
SNT.160790.3149	Some aid came in the form of food, while other aid came as cash which would be used by the aid agencies to buy grain from Ethiopian farmers.
SNT.160790.3150	Rebels would disguise themselves as traders and merchants to get their hands on the currency.
SNT.160790.3151	I was given clothes to make me look like a Muslim merchant.
SNT.160790.3152	This was a trick for the NGOs, said Gebremedhin Araya, a senior member of the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF).
SNT.160790.3153	One such aid worker that brought the grain was Max Peberdy, who worked for the charity Christian Aid.
SNT.160790.3154	Peberdy is seen in a photo with Araya buying grain.
SNT.160790.3155	Araya said that only some of the sacks were filled with grain; the rest were filled with sand.
SNT.160790.3156	The transaction was overseen by a member of the Relief Society of Tigray (REST), the humanitarian wing of the TPLF.
SNT.160790.3157	The money was then given to TPLF leaders, including chairman Meles Zenawi, who has been Prime Minister of Ethiopia since 1991.
SNT.160790.3158	Peberdy disputes the claims that he was duped, saying, "As far as we were concerned and as far as we were told by REST, the people we were dealing with were merchants."
SNT.160790.3159	He added, "It's 25 years since this happened, and in the 25 years it's the first time anybody has claimed such a thing."
SNT.160790.3160	However, an exiled TPLF commander who lives in the Netherlands, Aregawi Berhe, is backing Araya's story.
SNT.160790.3161	He said the group got their hands on over US$100 million (£66 million) of which 95% went to buy weapons and build up a hardliner Marxist party inside the rebel movement.
SNT.160790.3162	Berhe told the BBC that the group would put on a "drama" to get the money.
SNT.160790.3163	In response to the allegations, the charity Christian Aid issued a statement saying, "There are allegations in the story which are against all of Christian Aid's principles and our initial investigations do not correspond to the BBC's version of events."
SNT.160790.3164	Nick Guttmann, who is director of emergency relief operations for the group, says the "story has to be put into context".
SNT.160790.3165	”We were working in a major conflict, there was a massive famine and people on all sides were suffering”, Guttmann said, adding, "Both the rebels and the government were using innocent civilians to further their own political ends."
SNT.160790.3166	Bob Geldof, the Irish rock star who help organized Live Aid, said, "We are talking about a disgruntled, exiled general.”
SNT.160790.3167	The essence of the report also is not just about Live Aid.
SNT.160790.3168	It's that all monies going into Tigray — that would be Oxfam, Save the Children, UNICEF and Christian Aid — somehow, we were all duped and gulled.
SNT.189131.3169	The 2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference negotiations continued this week in Bonn, Germany.
SNT.189131.3170	The 4,500 attendees include government delegates from 182 governments, representatives from business and industry, environmental organizations and research institutions.
SNT.189131.3171	Luis Alfonso de Alba, Mexico's special representative for climate change, told Reuters, "Mexico does not want to raise false expectations but we certainly are ambitious".
SNT.189131.3172	He criticised the outgoing head of the U.N.'s climate secretariat, Yvo de Boer, and the European Union's climate commissioner Connie Hedegaard for their scepticism.
SNT.189131.3173	Negotiating under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change , the next negotiating session is scheduled to take place in August, followed by another, final one-week intersessional meeting, before Cancún.
SNT.189131.3174	The talks were designed to discuss issues that were not resolved at the 2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen.
SNT.189131.3175	The two working groups are the Ad Hoc Working Group on Long-Term Cooperative Action and the Ad Hoc Working Group on Further Commitments for Annex .
SNT.189131.3176	These groups were specifically designed to negotiate a long-term response to climate change.
SNT.189131.3177	The AWG-LCA is the negotiating group tasked to deliver a new "COP16 negotiative text" ahead of the June negotiating session.
SNT.189131.3178	The AWG-KP is to focus on emissions reduction commitments for the 37 industrialised countries that have ratified the Kyoto Protocol for the period beyond 2012.
SNT.189131.3179	There are also two UNFCCC standing committees meetings, the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice and the Subsidiary Body for Implementation .
SNT.189131.3180	The conference is officially referred to as the 16th session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the 6th session of the Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol.

SNT.76299.3213	The strain of the disease had already been identified as an O1 BFS67-like virus, which was isolated in a 1967 outbreak and was being used at the labs for research and the production of vaccines.
SNT.76299.3214	It is not yet known whether the virus escaped from the Merial or the IAH lab.
SNT.76299.3215	Since foot-and-mouth was confirmed in cows at a Surrey farm, more than 200 cattle have been culled as a preventative measure.
SNT.76299.3216	A protection zone has been set up around the affected areas and rules preventing the movement of livestock have been introduced throughout the country, with the aim of stopping further spread of the contagious disease.
SNT.76299.3217	Restrictions on the import of English beef have already been imposed.
SNT.76299.3218	The last outbreak of foot-and-mouth in the UK, in the spring and summer of 2001, resulted in total losses estimated at £8bn.

SNT.23286.3231	Minutes after the flow of hot mud was visible from Lake Coatepeque, a huge cloud of ash appeared, which reached an altitude of 50,000 feet, then covering the northwestern part of the country which contains the largest concentration of coffee farms (main export).
SNT.23286.3232	The local authorities expect that this layer of ash burns the coffee plants of the affected area, decreasing the coffee production of the region considerably.
SNT.23286.3233	Along with the ash cloud, a large amount of hot rocks (some reaching three feet in diameter) flew on all directions, damaging roads, homes and vegetation.
SNT.23286.3234	According to the people living in the surroundings of the volcano, the rocks were released due to the huge amount of pressure released when the ash cloud appeared.
SNT.23286.3235	Authorities report the loss of two human lives due to this incident, the cause has not yet been revealed.
SNT.23286.3236	To prevent the loss of more lives, the government decreed a red alert in a radius of four kilometres of the crater, but yet, some people resist the evacuation proposals due to fear of losing their belongings, as they have to leave their homes without any surveillance.
SNT.23286.3237	In response to this, the army and the police agreed to patrol the areas evacuated in order to prevent robberies.
SNT.23286.3238	It is expected that this incident is only the beginning of a large eruptive process, which may result in a catastrophe for El Salvador.

SNT.9775.3291	For the Chesapeake Bay, the largest estuary in the United States, a first-time-ever “water quality forecast” was issued Monday for the upcoming summer season by the Chesapeake Bay Program.
SNT.9775.3292	The eastern mid-Atlantic region’s heavy spring rainfalls are predicted to increase nutrient levels in bay waters, leading to oxygen eating algae blooms and leaving deep water dead zones.
SNT.9775.3293-1	Project leader William Dennison, of the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Studies said, “The forecast indicates that recent weather conditions and heavy pollutant loads could lead to a bad summer for the Bay.” 
SNT.9775.3293-2	The prediction is for this to be the fourth-worst season for dissolved oxygen in two decades.
SNT.9775.3294	The Chesapeake Bay Program launched the new forecast to build on a base of environmental data gathered over the last two decades as water quality concerns have grown.
SNT.9775.3295	The forecast is meant to be a proactive tool that provides resource managers with information that can be used to guide policies for the bay’s protection and restoration.
SNT.9775.3296	Cars, fertilizer, human and animal wastes, industrial and agricultural pollutants all play a part.
SNT.9775.3297	"This means that we need to do a lot more to reduce phosphorus and nitrogen pollution from getting into the bay, said Beth McGee, of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.
SNT.9775.3298	"The biggest source of pollution in the bay is agriculture, and we've got to find a way to provide farmers with more resources to manage the land better."
SNT.9775.3299	Nutrient rich pollutants composed mainly of nitrogen and phosphorous come from far away places carried by rivers, and nearby the bay from farm and metropolitan runoff.
SNT.9775.3300	They collect in the huge bay and meet tidal flows from the ocean.
SNT.9775.3301	Algae feed off the nutrients, and they are either consumed by aquatic life or sink at the end of their life cycle.
SNT.9775.3302	With such an abundant food source, algae blooms can cover large surfaces of water and choke off sunlight to underwater plants.
SNT.9775.3303	Later when the plants die, the process of their decomposition on the bottom consumes oxygen to a state where the water becomes anoxic, and unable to support life.
SNT.9775.3304	As notorious as weather forecasters are for often being wrong, it should come as no surprise if this first forecasting step by the federally funded program misses its mark.
SNT.9775.3305	Forces such as heavy storms or hurricanes, which churn water, would have an effect.
SNT.9775.3306	Excessive wind and unexpected precipitation, or nutrient level jumps, would also contribute.

SNT.158893.3308	The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center said there was no "destructive threat" from the tsunami.
SNT.158893.3309	At its center, the depth of the earthquake had been measured at ten kilometers (6.2 miles).

SNT.149941.3382	Britain's Ministry of Defence (MoD) has admitted sixteen instances of sensitive information being leaked on social networking websites in the past eighteen months.
SNT.149941.3383	Ten employees have been disciplined for misuse of the sites.
SNT.149941.3384	The revelations follow a Freedom of Information request by Lewis PR and computer security company F-Secure.
SNT.149941.3385	The MoD would not comment on what disciplinary action was taken, or whether the leaks involved operational information.
SNT.149941.3386	The ministry's guidelines state that staff must obtain clearance to release any information that is related to sensitive, controversial or political matters, or military operations.
SNT.149941.3387	"It's worrying that employees in sensitive positions have been sharing confidential information via Twitter and other means", said Mikko Hypponen, of F-Secure.
SNT.149941.3388	According to Lewis PR, computers on the main MoD networks are blocked from visiting social networking sites.
SNT.149941.3389	However there are a small number within the department which have unrestricted Internet access.
SNT.149941.3390	Some personnel in Afghanistan and Iraq also have access through internet cafés on military bases.
SNT.149941.3391	The ministry's "online engagement guidelines", released in August last year, recognise the importance of social media such as Facebook for personnel keeping in touch with friends and family.
SNT.149941.3392	According to the document: "Service and MOD civilian personnel are encouraged to talk about what they do, but within certain limits to protect security, reputation and privacy."
SNT.111540.3393	On August 11, United States Senator and 2008 presidential Republican candidate John McCain gave a speech regarding the crisis between Georgia and Russia.
SNT.111540.3394	Following the speech, a regular Wikipedia editor noticed that his speech was very similar to an article on Wikipedia also regarding the crisis, in what could be considered plagiarism.
SNT.111540.3395	Wikinews was able to talk to that editor about how he found out about the similarities and what he did in response.
SNT.111540.3396	Wikinews also took a deeper look at the claim and investigated further.
SNT.111540.3397	McCain gave his speech in Erie, Pennsylvania and was speaking to citizens, giving a warning to Russia stating, "Russian President Medvedev and Prime Minister Putin must understand the severe, long-term negative consequences that their government’s actions will have for Russia’s relationship with the U.S. and Europe."
SNT.111540.3398	McCain continued his speech saying, "Georgia is an ancient country, at the crossroads of Eastern Europe and Central Asia, and one of the world’s first nations to adopt Christianity as an official religion.
SNT.111540.3399	After a brief period of independence following the Russian revolution, the Red Army forced Georgia to join the Soviet Union in 1922.
SNT.111540.3400	As the Soviet Union crumbled at the end of the Cold War, Georgia regained its independence in 1991, but its early years were marked by instability, corruption, and economic crises."
SNT.111540.3401	While reading the first few paragraphs, the Wikipedia editor Killing Vector, (who wishes to be called by his contributor name in fear of retribution for coming forward with the claim), noticed a striking similarity to McCain's speech and the Wikipedia article on the country of Georgia.
SNT.111540.3402	Not only did he notice the similarities, but after reading through the article's edit history, 'Killing Vector' noticed that his speech might have been lifted from Wikipedia, with some of the material in McCain's speech dating prior to the start of the Georgian and Russian crisis.
SNT.111540.3403	I began reading the text of McCain's address on the Georgia crisis, and as I was browsing it the irregularity jumped out almost immediately.
SNT.111540.3404	The paragraphs which discussed the history of Georgia simply didn't fit with the rest of the speech; the rhetorical style was jarringly different.
SNT.111540.3405-1	I figured, where's someone in a hurry going to get basic information on the Republic of Georgia?"
SNT.111540.3405-2	I opened up Wikipedia, went to the article, picked a recent but not current revision more or less at random (July 24th), and hit gold on the first try; McCain's speech and the Wikipedia article had significant strings of words in common, emphasized the same events, made largely the same word choices," Vector said to Wikinews.
SNT.111540.3406	Although other media outlets reported the alleged plagiarism, the two passages below were dated at least one week prior to the Georgian and Russian crisis.
SNT.111540.3407	The first two paragraphs of McCain's speech appear to resemble the Wikipedia article in the history dated July 24, 2008.
SNT.111540.3408	Two paragraphs, about an eighth of the full speech, contain material directly copied from Wikipedia or superficially modified from its text.
SNT.111540.3409	Those two paragraphs constitute the entire factual background of the speech, though — the rest is reaction and proposed policy, added Vector.
SNT.111540.3410	McCain's campaign denies they plagiarized Wikipedia, but also didn't state whether they used it as a source for his speech.
SNT.111540.3411	There are only so many ways to state basic historical facts and dates and that any similarities to Wikipedia were only coincidental," said a spokesman for the McCain campaign, Brian Rogers to The Politico.
SNT.111540.3412	Wikinews contacted McCain's campaign, but has yet to receive a response.
SNT.111540.3413	Wikinews e-mailed Jay Walsh, the director of communications for the Wikimedia Foundation to see what they thought of the situation, and what if anything they planned to do about it.
SNT.111540.3414	"We aren't particularly concerned with this", said Walsh who also added that "I'm only aware of this situation through media coverage I've seen, nor do we or I have any in-depth detail about the situation."
SNT.111540.3415	I would say it's a good practice to attribute text or content whenever possible.
SNT.111540.3416	Obviously when it's a matter of copyright then there are legal considerations, but the Foundation is not able to examine individual cases, added Walsh.
SNT.111540.3417	Wikinews attempted to contact Mike Godwin, the legal counsel for the Foundation, but has yet to receive a response.
SNT.111540.3418	Vector stands by his claim and also notes what he calls 'dishonesty' on the part of McCain's campaign.
SNT.111540.3419	What concerns me more, as a voter, is the ethical issue.
SNT.111540.3420	"Plagiarism comes from dishonesty and intellectual laziness on the part of an individual, but McCain's campaign's later denial adopts that individual's dishonesty", stated Vector.

SNT.18893.3438	A robotic system at Stanford Medical Center was used to perform a laparoscopic gastric bypass surgery successfully with a theoretically similar rate of complications to that seen in standard operations.
SNT.18893.3439	However, as there were only 10 people in the experimental group (and another 10 in the control group), this is not a statistically significant sample.
SNT.18893.3440	If this surgical procedure is as successful in large-scale studies, it may lead the way for the use of robotic surgery in even more delicate procedures, such as heart surgery.
SNT.18893.3441	Note that this is not a fully automated system, as a human doctor controls the operation via remote control.
SNT.18893.3442	There were concerns that doctors, in the future, might only be trained in the remote control procedure.
SNT.18893.3443	Ronald G. Latimer, M.D., of Santa Barbara, CA, warned "The fact that surgeons may have to open the patient or might actually need to revert to standard laparoscopic techniques demands that this basic training be a requirement before a robot is purchased.
SNT.18893.3444	We should not be seduced to buy this instrument to train surgeons if they are not able to do the primary operations themselves."
SNT.18893.3445	A previous "new technology", the electrocardiogram (ECG), has lead to a lack of basic education on the older technology, the stethoscope.
SNT.18893.3446	As a result, many heart conditions now go undiagnosed, especially in children and others who rarely undergo an ECG procedure.

SNT.54885.3461	The certificate alerts Ottawa about possible threats to the country.

SNT.118549.3535	The system is used to filter out child pornography, although Wikileaks points out it "can be used to censor anything" and claims "most sites on the list are still censored (i.e must be on the current list), even though many have clearly changed owners or were possibly even wrongly placed on the list."
SNT.118549.3536	We discussed the unusual leak with them, and the results are published here.
SNT.118549.3537	We asked if Wikileaks was worried about the criminal implications of linking to so much illegal content, but they were not.
SNT.118549.3538	They said that it was "politically untenable" to prosecute them, pointing out that Wikileaks is hosted in many different countries across the globe.
SNT.118549.3539-1	We asked them if they were "concerned about the possibility of censorship in the UK, Denmark, Finland etc.?" 
SNT.118549.3539-2	"No," Wikileaks told us "We welcome it."
SNT.118549.3540	Wikinews wondered if this was because of the Streisand effect, but Wikileaks said it was "because it will demonstrate how censorship systems are abused."
SNT.118549.3541	Wikinews asked Wikileaks why they didn't simply post a list of the sites which they felt were legal and add that all the others contained child porn, but Wikileaks felt "that would not be a fair representation of the material we obtained."
SNT.118549.3542	After seeking clarification, Wikinews was told "the question is not what we need to be told.
SNT.118549.3543	The question is what we need not to be told and who decides.
SNT.118549.3544	Wikinews then asked why they didn't leave the full list available, but mark which sites they felt should not be censored.
SNT.118549.3545	We have better things to do, was the response given.
SNT.118549.3546	It is not so easy to set up merchant accounts."
SNT.118549.3547-1	And what would due process be?
SNT.118549.3547-2	Due process would involve sending a letter to the owner of the merchant account with the accusation and giving them a right to be heard and an appeal process.
SNT.118549.3548	The banks are politically a lot more powerful than the internet industry so this hasn't happened."
SNT.118549.3549-1	And should funds in these accounts be seized straight away, or simply frozen until a judge or similar clears their release?
SNT.118549.3549-2	 "If the accounts are in-jurisdiction, they should be frozen and released or not at the end of the process.
SNT.118549.3550	There are plenty of existing mechanisms to do this for drug trafficking, for example."
SNT.118549.3551	Wikileaks then added "As an analogy, one might argue that everyone should have a loaded gun in the house to protect themselves against home invasions.
SNT.118549.3552	This seems perfectly reasonable; however experience has shown that once the gun is in the house, it will find other targets."

SNT.32410.3554	The suit, filed in San Francisco, alleges that AT&T violated federal laws by collaborating with government to eavesdrop on U.S. citizens.
SNT.32410.3555	The Bush Administration and NSA have come under fire over the issue.
SNT.32410.3556	They defend the program by saying they are only listening in on suspected terrorists.
SNT.32410.3557	The EFF claims that AT&;T turned over 2 databases consisting of their subscribers' communication and internet usage records.
SNT.32410.3558	Attorney Kevin Bankston representing the EFF said the government could not conduct their surveillance without the help of companies like AT&T.
SNT.32410.3559	He also said their goal is to tell AT&T that it is not in their fiscal best interests, along with not being legal, to cooperate with the President's wiretap program.
SNT.32410.3560	According to the class action suit, AT&T granted "access to all or a substantial number of the communications transmitted through its key domestic telecommunications facilities, including direct access to streams of domestic, international and foreign telephone and Internet communications."
SNT.32410.3561	The lawsuit is seeking damages of $22,000 for each AT&T customer in addition to punitive fines.
SNT.32410.3562	AT&T is also facing scrutiny from the Federal Communications Commission and possibly fines for failing to properly certify that customer records were safeguarded.

SNT.101852.3578	Members of Australia's Health Services Union (HSU) will go on strike in Victoria next week in a dispute over stalled wage and career structure negotiations.
SNT.101852.3579	Over 5000 physiotherapists, speech pathologists and radiation therapists will walk off the job next week, effectively closing the state's 68 largest health services.
SNT.101852.3580	The strike will force the closure of intensive care units and emergency departments across the state.
SNT.101852.3581	National secretary of the HSU, Kathy Jackson said admissions would be crippled, while intensive care patients would have to be evacuated to New South Wales, Tasmania and South Australia as hospitals will not be able to perform tests or administer treatment.
SNT.101852.3582	When an ambulance shows up you can't admit a patient without an X-ray being available, you can't intubate them and you can't operate on them, she said.
SNT.101852.3583	If something goes wrong in an ICU you need to be able to X-ray, use nuclear medicine or any diagnostic procedure, said Ms Jackson.
SNT.101852.3584	Ms Jackson said the HSU offered arbitration last year, but the state government refused.
SNT.101852.3585	They're not interested in settling disputes, they hope that we are just going to go away.
SNT.101852.3586	We're not going away, we've gone back and balloted the whole public health workforce in Victoria, those ballots were successful, 97 percent approval rating, she said.
SNT.101852.3587	The HSU is urging the government to commence serious negotiations to resolve the dispute before industrial action commenced.
SNT.101852.3588	The government has offered the union a 3.25 per cent pay increase, in line with other public sector workers but the union has demanded more, but stopped short of specifying a figure.
SNT.101852.3589	Victorian Premier John Brumby said the claim would be settled according to the government's wages policy.
SNT.101852.3590	The Government is always willing and wanting to sit down and negotiate with the relevant organisations .
SNT.101852.3591	we have a wages policy based around an increase of 3.25 per cent and, above that, productivity offset, he told parliament.
SNT.101852.3592	The union claims it is also arguing against a lack of career structure, which has caused many professionals to leave the health service.
SNT.101852.3593	Ms Jackson said wages and career structures in Victoria were behind other states.
SNT.101852.3594	Victorian Opposition Leader Ted Baillieu said he was not in support of the proposed strike and called on the government to meet with unions.
SNT.101852.3595	There could not be a more serious threat to our health system than has been announced today.
SNT.101852.3596	We now have to do whatever is possible to stop this strike from proceeding, he said.
SNT.101852.3597	The opposition leader will meet with the union at 11:30 AM today.
SNT.101852.3598	Victorian Hospitals Industry Association industrial relations services manager Simon Chant said hospitals were looking at the possible impact and warned that patients may have to be evacuated interstate if the strike goes ahead.

SNT.123935.3606	An act signed into law by Afghan President Hamid Karzai last month dramatically rolled back the rights of women in that country, according to human rights groups and a United Nations report on the bill by the United Nations Development Fund for Women.
SNT.123935.3607	The Afghan government has not provided a copy of the text of the Shia Family Law to the UN or to other outside groups requesting it, citing "technical problems", however, the UN and opposition politicians say that the bill contains numerous provisions restricting the rights of women, such as giving their husbands priority in court; requiring the husband's permission to leave the house, obtain education or employment, or to see a doctor; and reserving the custody of children to male relatives.
SNT.118771.3608	The Belgian parliament on Friday approved the new Van Rompuy I Government consisting of the same five political parties that formed the last ruling coalition, temporarily ending the country's political crisis.
SNT.118771.3609	Lower house deputies approved the Motion of Confidence by a majority of 88 votes to 45, with no abstentions.
SNT.118771.3610	Don't judge the government... by its intentions but by its results, but no results in the very short-term, judge us in 2011, Van Rompuy told the lawmakers.
SNT.118771.3611	In his declaration, he urged the passage of bills to rejuvenate an ailing economy heading into deep recession and sought to resolve the 18 months political crisis after the country spent over nine months in caretaker rule.
SNT.118771.3612	He also asked for full restoration of confidence amid the near-collapse of the country’s two largest banks.
SNT.118771.3613	The previous government proposed such a plan (pumping 2 billion euros or $2.84 billion, into the economy next year, part of a 200 billion euro EU-wide stimulus package).
SNT.118771.3614	It must be enacted as soon as possible, Van Rompuy said.
SNT.118771.3615	It is clear that in the coming weeks and months the government will take new initiatives to cope with the challenges that the crisis poses for the economy and employment, he added.
SNT.118771.3616	Van Rompuy, age 61, is a conservative Belgian Flemish politician and member of the CD&V (formerly called CVP) who succeeds Yves Leterme.
SNT.118771.3617	On December 28, 2008, he was asked by King Albert II to form a new Government after he was reluctant to take up the role of Prime Minister after the Leterme I government had fallen on 22 December 2008 due to the bank bailout scandal.
SNT.118771.3618	The Van Rompuy I Government became the new federal government of Belgium on December 30.
SNT.118771.3619	Eighteen of the 22 ministers served in the same posts in Prime Minister Yves Leterme's government.
SNT.118771.3620	Prime Minister Yves Leterme offered the resignation of his government on December 18 to King Albert after a crisis erupted surrounding the sale of troubled Fortis bank to BNP Paribas.
SNT.118771.3621	Leterme, Justice Minister Jo Vandeurzen, and Didier Reynders were accused of violating the separation of powers and exerting improper influence by trying to influence the Court of Appeals; this accusation was made by the First Chairman of the Court of Cassation.
SNT.118771.3622	Three days later the resignation was accepted by the king.
SNT.118771.3623	Meanwhile, the Flemish opposition led by Flemish nationalist NVA party, Jan Jambon, challenged the legitimacy of Van Rompuy's government, calling it "a government which does not represent a majority of the Flemish people".

SNT.109490.3669	One of the missiles launched was an upgraded version of the Shahab-3, capable of reaching Eastern European countries like Bulgaria and Greece as well and Middle Eastern countries such as Israel, Egypt and the Arabian Peninsula.
SNT.109490.3670	Eight shorter range Zelzal and Fateh missiles were also launched.
SNT.109490.3671	The Iranians have been under international pressure to withraw from their plans of achieving nuclear proficiency, but have rejected putting a hold on their programme and have also been moving forward with their rocketry programme.

SNT.109490.3673	In addition to these tests, Iran's first indigenous satellite launch attempt, which will place the Omid spacecraft into low Earth orbit, is expected immanently.
SNT.109490.3674	A successful satellite launch would demonstrate that Iran's missiles have global reach.
SNT.109490.3675	The tests have been widely criticised by the international community.
SNT.109490.3676	The British government stated that it "underlines the need for Iran to comply with its international obligations on the nuclear issue", and that the test was "unwelcome".
SNT.109490.3677	The French ministry of defence suggested that "these missile tests can only reinforce the concerns of the international community", and the German government described the exercise as "regrettable".
SNT.109490.3678	The United States government claims that the test was "evidence that the missile threat is not an imaginary one".

SNT.109490.3680	Russia, however called for diplomacy, stating that they believe Iran to be "ready for negotiations", and Israel's Prime Minister issued a statement saying that he had "no desire for conflict or hostilities with Iran".

SNT.79846.3760	And when they do happen, then they need to be sorted out between the countries in question.

SNT.79846.3763	Russia apologised to Finland last year following a large number of similar incidents over the space of two years, but only after Finland had protested.
SNT.79846.3764	According to officials, such violations as this latest one were still to be expected, due to a combination of international airspace being limited to a narrow strip off the South coast of Finland, and a high level of Russian air force activity over the Gulf of Finland.

SNT.155778.3810	The inflation rate for the country has also now reached its highest level since November 2008.
SNT.155778.3811	The causes of this inflation rise include a 70% rise in oil prices, and value added tax recently being increased to 17.5%.

SNT.155778.3813	Meanwhile, the underlying rate of RPI increased from 3.8% to 4.6% over the same period.
SNT.155778.3814	The British Government has an inflation target of 2%, which was surpassed by more than 1%.
SNT.155778.3815	For this reason, Mervyn King, who is the Governor of the Bank of England has written a required explanatory letter to Chancellor of the Exchequer Alistair Darling.
SNT.155778.3816	In the letter, King wrote: "Although it is likely to remain high over the next few months, inflation is more likely than not to fall back to the target in the second half of this year."
SNT.155778.3817	Alistair Darling then wrote a letter in response, which said that the future expectations of the inflation was "subject to some uncertainty" as countries around the world continue to recover from what he called the "deepest downturn in modern times".
