SNT.189935.6387	Reports suggest the World Health Organisation's declaring a swine flu pandemic was an error driven by drug companies, and lead to unjustified fear.
SNT.189935.6388	A year after the swine flu pandemic was declared, stocks are left unused and governments try to abandon contracts, pharmaceutical companies have profited at least £4.6billion from the sale of vaccines alone.
SNT.189935.6389	Reports by the British Medical Journal (BMJ), the Bureau of Investigative Journalism (BIJ) and the Council of Europe claim that The World Health Organisation reaction to H1N1 was influenced by pharmaceutical companies and that key scientists behind advice had financial ties with firms Roche and GlaxoSmithKline (GSK).
SNT.189935.6390	These conflicts of interest have never been publicly disclosed by WHO, an apparent violation of its own rules.
SNT.189935.6391	The World Health Organisation issued H1N1 guidelines in 2004, recommending countries to stockpile millions of doses of antiviral medication.
SNT.189935.6392	The advice prompted many countries around the world into buying up large stocks of Tamiflu, made by Roche, and Relenza manufactured by GSK.
SNT.189935.6393	A joint investigation with the BMJ and the BIJ, found that scientists involved in developing the WHO 2004 guidance had previously been paid by Roche or GSK for lecturing and consultancy work as well as being involved in research for the companies.
SNT.189935.6394	"The WHO's credibility has been badly damaged," BMJ editor Fiona Godlee said in an editorial.
SNT.189935.6395	A report by the health committee of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, a 47-member human rights watchdog, found that the WHO's reaction was influenced by drug companies that make H1N1 antiviral drugs and vaccines.
SNT.189935.6396	It criticised WHO lack of transparency around the handling of the swine flu pandemic and says the public health guidelines by WHO, EU agencies and national governments led to a "waste of large sums of public money and unjustified scares and fears about the health risks faced by the European public."
SNT.189935.6397	A spokesman for WHO said the drug industry did not influence its decisions on swine flu.
SNT.189935.6398-1	Margaret Chan, the organisation's director, had dismissed inquiries into its handling of the A/H1N1 pandemic as "conspiracy theories" earlier this year, 
SNT.189935.6398-2	she had said: "WHO anticipated close scrutiny of its decisions, but we did not anticipate that we would be accused, by some European politicians, of having declared a fake pandemic on the advice of experts with ties to the pharmaceutical industry and something personal to gain from increased industry profits."
SNT.189935.6399	Yesterday, a 16-member "emergency committee" consisting of advisors from the World Health Organisation said that the H1N1 pandemic is not yet over.
SNT.189935.6400	The WHO has refused to identify committee members, arguing that they must be shielded from industry pressure, so possible conflicts of interest with drug companies are unknown.
SNT.189935.6401	The BMJ report also reveals that at least one expert on the "emergency committee" received payment during 2009 from GSK.
SNT.189935.6402	In related news, Reuters reported, Pfizer Inc, the world's biggest drugmaker, is selling its swine vaccine business to Chinese Harbin Pharmaceutical Group for $50 million.

SNT.23683.6466	A red tide continues along South Padre Island and into Mexico, according to officials with the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.
SNT.23683.6467	Effects include stinging eyes, respiratory difficulties, and dead marine life.
SNT.23683.6468	Red tide is caused by a higher than normal concentration of Karenia brevis, a naturally-occurring single-celled marine organism.
SNT.23683.6469	Natural factors can intersect to produce ideal conditions, allowing this algae to increase in number dramatically.
SNT.23683.6470	The algae produces a neurotoxin that can disable nerves in both humans and fish.
SNT.23683.6471	Fish often die because of the high concentrations of the toxin in the waters.
SNT.23683.6472	Humans can be affected by breathing affected water taken into the air by wind and waves.
SNT.23683.6473	Also, South Padre officials are investigating a paralyzed cat and deceased coyote who may have consumed fish killed by the red tide.
SNT.23683.6474	This bloom has lingered almost three weeks, and affects waters parallel to South Padre Island for about 25 miles, and may extend as far as 10 miles along Mexico beaches.

SNT.253693.6483	Treasury documents released today under the Freedom of Information (FOI) act reveal that Australians could face up to an A$863 rise in household costs per annum if the government proceeds with its plans to put a tax on carbon emissions.
SNT.253693.6484	The documents reveal an a annual price rise of $218.40 for electricity, $114.40 for gas, $187.20 for petrol and $88.40 for food for the average household.
SNT.253693.6485	The treasury modelling was based on a $30 carbon tax, but also estimated other prices such as a $40 tax which predicted a rise of over $1,100 to the average household's annual budget.
SNT.253693.6486	However, they do not take into account the compensation deals and offsets promised by the government if a price is put on carbon.
SNT.253693.6487	After viewing the treasury modelling, Treasurer Wayne Swan and Climate Change Minister Greg Combet released a joint statement saying without the finalization of compensation packages it is too early to predict price rises.
SNT.253693.6488	"No final decisions on the starting price or assistance have been taken and therefore it is far too early to speculate on any potential price impacts," the statement said.
SNT.253693.6489	"Until the final design and modelling have been settled, anyone who uses these figures to scare families about prices is engaging in a dishonest, misleading scare campaign."
SNT.253693.6490	Opposition Leader Tony Abbott said the figures demonstrated the toll a carbon tax would have on Australian families.
SNT.253693.6491	"This just demonstrates that the Government has known all along that its carbon tax won't clean up the environment but it will clean out your wallet," he said.
SNT.253693.6492	"That's right and this is $863 a year in extra burden that the Australian people shouldn't have to pay."
SNT.253693.6493	"This is an $863 a year hit on families' cost of living."
SNT.253693.6494	"They don't need a bad situation made much, much worse by Julia Gillard's carbon tax."
SNT.253693.6495	The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) has also officially opposed the adoption of a carbon tax.
SNT.253693.6496	A resolution was passed by all 30 members at their general meeting to reject the Federal government's plan.

SNT.142339.6516	His letter to Davis was posted Saturday on the blog of former high-ranking Scientology official Marty Rathbun.
SNT.142339.6517	Haggis received Academy Awards for writing and producing the 2004 film Crash, which he also directed.
SNT.142339.6518	Rathbun confirmed the authenticity of the letter by Haggis, and The Hollywood Reporter also confirmed it with a friend of the director.
SNT.142339.6519	At his blog, Rathbun has been critical of Scientology's current leader David Miscavige.

SNT.142339.6522	He criticized the manner in which the Church of Scientology attempted to smear the former officials after they spoke out against the organization.
SNT.142339.6523	Well-known celebrity Scientologists include actors Tom Cruise and John Travolta.

SNT.142339.6526	Proposition 8 removed the rights of same-sex couples to marry in California.
SNT.142339.6527	The San Diego Church of Scientology was listed along with other groups on a Proposition 8 supporters website, but it was later removed.
SNT.142339.6528	Haggis said that Davis initially told him he would do something about the San Diego Church of Scientology's support for Proposition 8, but in the end Davis did not take action about this.
SNT.142339.6529	Haggis called the inaction by Davis with regard to the San Diego Church of Scientology's stance on homosexuality "cowardly".
SNT.142339.6530	Actress Deborah Rennard, wife of Haggis, was introduced to Scientology by her parents.
SNT.142339.6531	According to Haggis, the Scientology practice of "disconnection" was imposed on Rennard and her husband, and they were ordered to disconnect from her parents because Rennard's parents had violated a rule of the organization.
SNT.142339.6532	Due to having undergone a personal experience with regard to Scientology's practice of disconnection, Haggis was surprised to hear Davis deny the policy existed in an interview with CNN journalist John Roberts.
SNT.142339.6533	He concluded his letter to Davis by noting that his Scientologist friends might disassociate from him due to his words, writing, "...I am fully aware that some of my friends may choose to no longer associate with me, or in some cases work with me."
SNT.142339.6534	I will always take their calls, as I always took yours.
SNT.142339.6535	However, I have finally come to the conclusion that I can no longer be a part of this group.
SNT.142339.6536	Frankly, I had to look no further than your refusal to denounce the church's anti-gay stance, and the indefensible actions, and inactions, of those who condone this behavior within the organization.
SNT.142339.6537	I am only ashamed that I waited this many months to act.
SNT.142339.6538	"I hereby resign my membership in the Church of Scientology."

SNT.142339.6540	Friedman wrote that "Haggis has taken an enormous step here, and one that should resonate among all celebrity Scientologists."

SNT.114683.6639	Police quickly closed off the area and declared an emergency in all hospitals.
SNT.114683.6640	Those injured were taken to the nearby PIMS and Holy Family hospitals.

SNT.114683.6642	The attack was only six miles from the Pakistani Parliament, where intelligence and military chiefs were briefing lawmakers on the campaign against terrorism.

SNT.12365.6646	More than 300 "citizen reporters" hailing from countries as far apart as Chile and Norway are coming together at the OhmyNews International Citizen Reporters' Forum from June 23 to June 26, 2005 in Seoul.
SNT.12365.6647	OhmyNews is one of the most popular South Korean news websites, and it has played an important role in the election of reformist President Roh Moo-hyun.
SNT.12365.6648	Unlike traditional news sources, OhmyNews allows any individual with an Internet connection to contribute stories.

SNT.101539.6653	Almost exactly one year ago, on March 7, Garuda Indonesia Flight 200 crashed during landing at Adisucipto International Airport, near Yogyakarta, after a scheduled domestic Indonesian passenger flight.
SNT.101539.6654	21 people - 16 Indonesians and five Australians - were killed when the Boeing 737-400 overshot the runway, crossed a road, struck an embankment and burst into flames in a rice paddy.
SNT.101539.6655	Overall, the plane had traveled 252m beyond the extreme end of the runway.
SNT.101539.6656	The final report, released in October, blamed pilot error for the disaster.
SNT.101539.6657	The report stated that the aircraft had approached at a speed far exceeding that at which the wing flaps could properly operate, and attempted to execute a landing at 408 kph (254 mph), which is 160 kph (100 mph) above the safe speed.
SNT.101539.6658	It also found that captain Marwoto Komar had ignored fifteen activations of the Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS) informing Mr Komar that the aircraft was flying at a speed beyond that at which it could safely land, but he failed to abort.
SNT.101539.6659	It also commented that he missed one further opportunity for emergency evasive action when the airliner struck the runway and bounced into the air, at which point co-pilot Gagam Rochmana requested a 'go-around' procedure be initiated, but was also ignored.
SNT.101539.6660	It further criticised Mr Komar for singing during final approach, a direct violation of the Garuda Basic Operations Manual, which calls for activation of the Sterile Cockpit Rule at 10,000 feet and below.
SNT.101539.6661	Mr Rochmana was also criticised for his failure to take control away from Mr Komar when it became apparent that the aircraft was being operated in an unsafe manner.
SNT.101539.6662-1	However, the report did note that Garuda Indonesia had failed to give him any simulator training replicating a situation whereby the co-pilot would take over control duties from the pilot in charge due to unsafe handling of the plane.
SNT.101539.6662-2	 in fact, training was found to be inadequate for both members of the cockpit crew.
SNT.101539.6663	Further criticisms were also leveled at airport and governmental authorities for failures in their respective roles to provide safety features and to enforce regulations.
SNT.101539.6664	However, the Indonesian authorities have recently generated intense controversy by deciding to prosecute Mr Komar for his role in the disaster.
SNT.101539.6665	The move has been pushed for by some, but met with opposition by others.
SNT.101539.6666	Alexander Downer, Australian foreign minister at the time of the crash, immediately said "...I am very glad that they have reached a point now where they have charged the captain of the aircraft."
SNT.101539.6667	The unusually high number of Australians amongst the 140 passengers on board was attributable to a visit by Mr Downer.
SNT.101539.6668	One of those was Morgan Mellish of the Australian Financial Review, who died in the crash.
SNT.101539.6669	His sister, Caroline Mellish, had specifically called for prosecution to be avoided, saying "I think having 21 deaths on your conscience is probably enough."
SNT.101539.6670	"I don't think prosecuting the man is going to make any difference."
SNT.101539.6671	There were fierce calls for prosecution of both pilots immediately after the report's release, with Downer himself pressuring the Indonesian authorities, citing the "very credible report" and saying "I've asked our ambassador today (October 24) to make it absolutely clear to the Indonesians that we want people prosecuted for this accident."
SNT.101539.6672	"I want to see people who have negligently allowed Australians … to be killed."
SNT.101539.6673	Australian Opposition Leader Kevin Rudd also made clear a desire for prosecutions, saying he had telephoned secretary-general of Indonesia's foreign affairs department and former ambassador to Australia Imron Cotan, telling him that he wanted those responsible "prosecuted to the absolute full".
SNT.101539.6674	"This is a serious matter," he said.
SNT.101539.6675	National Transport Safety Committee chairman Tatang Kurniadi said at the time that no information from the report could be used in any criminal or civil liability investigations.
SNT.101539.6676	"I would like to go back to the objective of this", he said.
SNT.101539.6677	"If any institution wants to ... follow up that accident, that's their own decision."
SNT.101539.6678	"The report contained the results from the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder, but according to international regulations on aviation these black boxes are not allowed to be used for... liability purposes."
SNT.101539.6679-1	"We will not give police or any institution (information) other than for safety purposes only."
SNT.101539.6679-2	"it's in international regulations and we want to follow those regulations."
SNT.101539.6680	He also confirmed that investigators cannot speak to the police, with the only permitted testimony under the legislation being to testify at a court hearing, and pointed out that the document does not actually appoint any blame.
SNT.101539.6681	The international legislation he was referring to is probably the Convention on International Civil Aviation, which stipulates that accident reports and related material, specifically transcripts of interviews, communications with crew and cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder (collectively known as black boxes) readouts, must not be used for any purpose other than determining the cause of an accident or incident.
SNT.101539.6682	The only possible exception to this is where potential benefit would outweigh the "adverse domestic and international impact" on the investigation in question or any other either in progress or in the future.
SNT.101539.6683	This legislation is in place to provide protection to witnesses on the basis that without it they may be less likely to cooperate with investigational procedures.
SNT.101539.6684	Aridono Sukman, the police member in charge of the criminal investigation, said that the contents of the black box were vital evidence.
SNT.101539.6685	Officials commented that some relatives had expressed their frustration over the legal challenges involved in the prosecution effort.
SNT.101539.6686-1	Early in February Mr Komar was arrested;
SNT.101539.6686-2	 he has subsequently been charged with manslaughter charges which carry a maximum sentence of five years' imprisonment.
SNT.101539.6687	The London-based International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations (IFALPA) issued a press release condemning this move, saying that further investigations are needed into the crash, and that criminal proceedings could prevent an accurate version of events from ever being known.
SNT.101539.6688	Specifically, the release said that "IFALPA believes that the circumstances of the accident as set forth in the final report of the Indonesian investigation authority leaves many serious questions concerning the crew actions prior to the accident."
SNT.101539.6689	"Central to these concerns are the underlying reasons for the reported behavior of Captain Marwoto Komar."
SNT.101539.6690	"Experienced pilots have considerable difficulty in attempting to explain what is reported in the context of normal airline operations."
SNT.101539.6691	"The Federation believes that the explanations proffered by the report do not square with the collective experience of our members."
SNT.101539.6692	The release went on to state the opinion that prosecution may bring total foreclosure to the case and could only be counterproductive.
SNT.101539.6693	It also said "He remains a professional who was involved in an unfortunate tragedy."
SNT.101539.6694	One possible explanation had previously been suggested by the head of the Garuda pilots association, Stephanus Geraldus.
SNT.101539.6695	He said that marital problems between Mr Komar and his wife Norma Andriani were "common knowledge" and was backed up by an industry analyst and pilot who said he believed the couple had been arguing late into the night, and expressed concern that the report had not addressed psychological issues.
SNT.101539.6696	Mr Geraldus also said sleep deprivation could have contributed, with the flight crew reporting for duty at 4:30 am and the flight departing an hour and a half later.
SNT.101539.6697	The report had hinted at problems, saying "The pilot was probably emotionally aroused because his conscious awareness moved from the relaxed mode "singing"to the heightened stressfulness of the desire to reach the runway by making an excessively steep and fast, unstabilised approach,"
SNT.101539.6698	It is also known that Mr Komar had been under police surveillance, during which time he was receiving psychological treatment.
SNT.101539.6699	The Indonesian Pilot's Association has also said that the criminal prosecution should be avoided, arguing that the only people who can judge whether mistakes were made in aviation are those professionally involved and not the police.
SNT.101539.6700	There were protests in Jakarta demanding his release and dozens of pilots across the nation also campaigned.
SNT.101539.6701	Meanwhile, two survivors, Adrianus Meliala and Retno Gunowati, went to the House of Representatives (DPR) to challenge those opposed to legal processes against the pilot.
SNT.101539.6702	Mr Komar was released on police bail on February 15, and is currently awaiting trial.
SNT.101539.6703	He was forced to resign late in February with being fired his only alternative, and his licence has been suspended.
SNT.101539.6704	He is believed to be the only man ever prosecuted in Indonesian history over an airliner crash.

SNT.73263.6737	The aims of the ban are to reduce the risks associated with passive smoking and to reduce the number of smokers overall.
SNT.73263.6738	The government estimates that 600,000 of the 10 million smokers in Britain will give up as a result.
SNT.73263.6739	Health Secretary Alan Johnson welcomes the ban, saying that "A smoke-free country will improve the health of thousands of people, reduce the temptation to smoke, and encourage smokers to quit."

SNT.60304.6761	The first large-scale trial of a vaccine for HIV has been launched in South Africa.
SNT.60304.6762	About 3,000 HIV-negative people will be administered the test vaccine MRKAd5 HIV-1 created by the pharmaceutical company Merck.
SNT.60304.6763	The study will examine if the vaccine prevents infection or lowers HIV levels in those who do get infected.
SNT.60304.6764	A parallel study will also be conducted in the United States and South America, to compare the vaccine's effectiveness on various strains of HIV.
SNT.60304.6765	The vaccine's functioning in a heterosexual population and its effectiveness among women will also be studied.
SNT.60304.6766	Preliminary trials for the vaccine have been conducted in the Americas and Australia as well as in Africa.
SNT.60304.6767	AIDS is estimated to have killed 25 million people worldwide since 1981, and between 33 and 46 million more are estimated to be infected with HIV, more than half of them in Sub-Saharan Africa.
SNT.60304.6768	Between three and six million people are thought to have been infected in 2005.
SNT.60304.6769	The trial, named the Phambili ("Going forward") Trial, is being conducted by the International HIV Trials Network and the South African AIDS Vaccine Initiative (SAAVI).
SNT.60304.6770	The vaccine has been developed from an adenovirus, a type of virus that causes the common cold.
SNT.60304.6771	The virus has been genetically engineered to prevent it from causing the flu or from passing on from person to person.
SNT.60304.6772	Instead, three genes of the HIV virus have been introduced into the adenovirus.
SNT.60304.6773	When the vaccine containing these genes is injected into the body, it is hoped that the body's immune system will learn to recognise and kill cells that contain the vaccine, thereby also developing an immune response against the HIV virus, which also contains these three genes.
SNT.60304.6774	The three genes, called gag, pol and env contain information needed to make the structural proteins for the capsid, the "shell" of the HIV viron.
SNT.60304.6775	The vaccine does not contain the remaining six HIV genes that cause HIV to infect cells, replicate and cause disease.
SNT.60304.6776	"The vaccine does not contain any live HIV and therefore cannot cause any infection", SAAVI said in a press release, adding that the vaccine was found to be safe and produced an immune response against HIV in earlier trials.
SNT.60304.6777	SAAVI has expressed its commitment to the "highest level of preventive care" for those who take part in the trial, promising "extensive, state-of-the-art" counselling as well as some forms of medical care and for those taking part, through the duration of the trial.
SNT.60304.6778	The trial starts a week after a different trial, involving a microbicide gel called Ushercell was stopped after more women who used the gel were found to be infected compared to those who were given a dummy gel as placebo.
SNT.60304.6779	Eleven previous trials of the gel had not shown any problems.
SNT.60304.6780	The trial is expected to cost $35 million and SAAVI will be supported by Eskom and the South African government.

SNT.3331.6812	As much as 200 mm (8") of rain have been recorded in portions of British Columbia, on the west coast of Canada since Monday.
SNT.3331.6813	The heavy and sustained precipitation across the lower mainland regions have caused mudslides and flooding, with roads and highways being closed and families evacuated.
SNT.3331.6814	In Port Coquitlam, a retaining wall burst, throwing concrete and rubble tens of metres and covering an arterial road with mud to a depth of two metres.
SNT.3331.6815	Further inland and north, where colder temperatures have prevailed, the precipitation has been falling as freezing rain and sleet, or heavy snowfalls.
SNT.3331.6816	Terrace, BC, was isolated as highways north and south of the city were closed due to a heavy glaze of ice.
SNT.3331.6817	The Trans-Canada Highway and most other roads through the mountains were closed due to heavy and sudden snow accumulations which created severe avalanche hazards.
SNT.3331.6818	"The avalanche danger is at high or extreme in all of our six forecast areas," according to John Kelly at the Canadian Avalanche Centre in Revelstoke.
SNT.3331.6819	"If the rain continues at the same magnitude and according to the forecast, then some of the rivers could reach flood stage either later [Tuesday] or Wednesday morning," said Allan Chapman, a hydrologist with the River Forecast Centre in Victoria.
SNT.3331.6820	The source of the wet weather is a large system reaching the coast from the Pacific Ocean tropics, a type of system nicknamed by meteorologists a "Tropical Punch".
SNT.3331.6821	A similar system caused severe flooding and precipitation in 2003.
SNT.3331.6822	Environment Canada expects the system, which lies southwest of Vancouver Island, to continue to develop "waves" of weather which will strike the mainland and head inland over the next several days to a week, possibly dropping 50-100 mm (2"-4") of additional rain per day at least until the end of the weekend.

SNT.64692.6854	Cambridge University have defeated Oxford University by 1¼ lengths to win the 153rd Boat Race.
SNT.64692.6855	The Light Blues won with a time of 17 minutes and 49 seconds to record their first win in three years.
SNT.64692.6856	Oxford finished with a time of 18 minutes and 2 seconds.
SNT.64692.6857	Oxford won the toss and chose to row on the Surrey side of the river, with Cambridge rowing on the Middlesex side.
SNT.64692.6858	Oxford had the stronger start and were ahead for much of the first half of the race.
SNT.64692.6859	They had a slight advantage over Cambridge at Hammersmith Bridge, where they would be favoured by racing the inside of the upcoming bend.
SNT.64692.6860	However Cambridge never lost touch and pulled ahead at Chiswick steps, maintaining their lead for the remainder of the race.
SNT.64692.6861	Before the race, Cambridge were strong favourites, being 9lb heavier per man on average.
SNT.64692.6862	The Cambridge crew had 5 returning blues compared to Oxford's one.
SNT.64692.6863	Furthermore the international achievement of Cambridge's rowers far exceeded that of Oxford: the World Champion stern pair of Germans Thorsten Engelmann (the heaviest ever oarsman at 110.8kg) and Sebastian Schulte, Olympic Gold medallist Kieran West MBE and GB medal winner Tom James.
SNT.64692.6864	The heavily fancied Cambridge crew did not win by the margin expected by many, thanks in part to a strong row from Oxford, and the sagging stern containing the heaviest Cambridge oarsmen.
SNT.64692.6865	Also of note, only a week before, Cambridge were victorious at the prestigious Head of the River Race (raced on the same course, but from Mortlake to Putney).
SNT.64692.6866	However the race was abandoned due to weather conditions with only 29 out of 420 crews finishing.
SNT.64692.6867	The race, first held in 1829, is currently held on a 6,779 m (4 miles and 374 yards) stretch of the River Thames in London from Putney to Mortlake.
SNT.64692.6868	Overall, Cambridge lead Oxford by 79 wins to 73 with one dead heat.
SNT.64692.6869	In the earlier race for reserve crews, Goldie (Cambridge) beat Isis (Oxford).
SNT.64692.6870	Racing for the women's and lightweight crews took place at Henley on April 1st, where Cambridge won the Women's Boat Race and Oxford won the reserve women's, lightweight women's, lightweight men's and reserve lightweight men's races.

SNT.79026.6877	The UK currently holds responsibility for the Nato airspace, and launched four F3 Tornados from RAF Leeming in North Yorkshire, UK, to identify the bombers.
SNT.79026.6878	The bombers eventually left the Nato zone, under tracking by UK aircraft and RAF radar in Northumberland.
SNT.79026.6879	An MoD spokesman confirmed that Russia was entitled to its long-range patrols, adding 'The motivation behind any Russian military activity is a matter for the Russian government.'
SNT.79026.6880	Lt Col John Inge Oegland, spokesman for the Norwegian armed forces, said there had been several similar incidents in recent months, but that the Russian flights were not causing alarm in Norway.

SNT.79026.6882	Relations with Russia would "continue as normal outside the unresolved extradition request", a UK Foreign Office spokesman said.

SNT.145695.6889	In a release issued this morning, Tony Clement, Minister of Industry is quoted as saying "Globalive is a Canadian company, and meets Canadian ownership and control requirements under the Telecommunications Act," differing with the CRTC's decision, where they ruled that control-in-fact of Globalive was with Cairo-based Orascom Telecom Holding S.A.E., the corporation holding much of Globalive's equity and debt.
SNT.145695.6890	A decision had been rendered under Canadian Ownership and Control regulations by Industry Canada at the time of the Advanced Wireless Spectrum (AWS) auction held in 2007-2008, at which time they had ruled that Globalive did meet the tests of ownership and control under the same regulation, as referenced by the Order-in-Council included with the government's announcement this morning.
SNT.145695.6891	With the decision by the government, Globalive is now permitted to launch their wireless service, which is expected to occur in the Calgary and Toronto markets in time for the busy holiday shopping season.
SNT.145695.6892	"This holiday season we will start to provide Canadians with the competitive choice that they want and deserve," said Anthony Lacavera, Chairman and CEO of Globalive Communications Corporation, in a release sent out today.
SNT.145695.6893	Not everyone was quite as enthusiastic however, with Michael Hennessey, Senior VP of Regulatory and Government Affairs for TELUS Communications quoted as saying "If Wind is Canadian then so was King Tut," in a comment posted to Twitter, according to the CBC.
SNT.145695.6894	TELUS had led the charge in requesting the CRTC review the ownership structure of Globalive/WIND, and had received support from Shaw Communications, along with new entrant Public Mobile, all of whom were reported to have signed an open letter to Industry Minister Clement published in Parliament Hill newspaper The Hill Times upon the announcement that he would be reviewing said decision by the CRTC.
SNT.145695.6895	There is no word yet on whether TELUS or other carriers will attempt to appeal the ruling.

SNT.54065.6917	The traditions of Bonfire Night peculiar to the Sussex area were once again observed in Lewes on November 4.
SNT.54065.6918	Consistent with the town traditions in the East Sussex county of England, effigies of various figures were carried through the town, and later burnt.
SNT.54065.6919	The effigies this year included George Bush, Condoleezza Rice (as Wonder Woman) and Crocodile Hunter Steve Irwin.
SNT.54065.6920	As per tradition and local fame, effigies were carried through the town and burned on huge fires.
SNT.54065.6921	These include The Pope, Guy Fawkes and other unpopular figures.
SNT.54065.6922	One of this year's unfortunate guest appearances was also rendered as a hugely grotesque likeness of the U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.
SNT.54065.6923	The unflattering effigy clutched a tattered U.S. flag in one hand, and a miniature Tony Blair in the other.
SNT.54065.6924	Smaller scale effigies, and so called 'enemies of bonfire', were also represented.
SNT.54065.6925	This year's enemies included British Transport Police, whose attitude and handling of Bonfire night is an issue of local contention.
SNT.54065.6926	Transport police were quietly represented by a pig head wearing a police helmet.
SNT.54065.6927	Six arrests occurred in respect of criminal damage and public order offences, but the event was less rowdy than in previous years and eras in the history of the Bonfire.
SNT.54065.6928	Superintendent Cliff Parrot of the Sussex Police said, "The event passed safely and was a resounding success with fewer arrests than last year, People were well behaved and acted responsibly, which in turn allowed everyone else to enjoy the celebrations."
SNT.54065.6929	The steep streets of the small town, located one hour south of London, were filled during the chilly winter evening with crowds carrying burning torches, with police, and with alcohol consumption accompanied by loud deafening bangs.
SNT.54065.6930	In addition to effigies, flaming crosses were carried in recognition of the town's 17 Protestant Martyrs.
SNT.54065.6931	These preceded elaborate costumed parades where participants dressed as Vikings, Antique firemen, Mongol warriors, and Zulus (including for the first time at Lewes, a female chieftain).
SNT.54065.6932	The pirates towed a cannon which they fired and shocked the crowds.
SNT.54065.6933	The traditional striped jerseys worn by various Bonfire Society members were also in evidence.

SNT.42041.6966	Taken in 2002 and 2006, the photos starkly contrast the previous built-up area with the empty scrubland that remains.
SNT.42041.6967	According to Amnesty International, residents of Porta Farm were given less than 24 hours notice to leave their homes.
SNT.42041.6968	Human rights monitors reported that several people died in the chaotic environment of the ensuing demolitions and forced evictions.
SNT.42041.6969	Zimbabwe's forced evictions programme (called Operation Murambatsvina) has been widely condemned both within Zimbabwe and beyond.
SNT.42041.6970	A 2005 report on Operation Murambatsvina by United Nations Special Envoy Anna Tibaijuka estimated that it has cost 700,000 people their homes or livelihoods.
SNT.42041.6971	She was present at Porta Farm during the second day of its demolition, and was shocked by the brutality of the evictions.
SNT.42041.6972	Residents of Porta Farm had fought eviction in the past, winning judgements from the High Court of Zimbabwe that they should not be evicted unless the government provided suitable alternative accommodation.
SNT.42041.6973	However the High Court dismissed a contempt of court action that attempted to stop the 2005 evictions, giving no reason.
SNT.42041.6974	The Zimbabwean government (led by President Robert Mugabe) says that the programme is in the public interest and was not against the law.

SNT.247914.6977	The National Statistics Office and the TCSI investigated claims by bemobile that it had covered 64% of the Islands, but found the claims were incorrect.
SNT.247914.6978	As a result, the TCSI have now issued a fine of to the company for breaking its operating license.
SNT.247914.6979	This is the second time bemobile failed to meet its contractual obligations, and the Telecommunications Commissioner, Nicholas Williams, made it clear that they had fallen short of the target, despite being given time to sort the issue out.
SNT.247914.6980	Williams said, "TCSI has found that bemobile has failed to meet its third coverage threshold of 75% of the population that commenced on 1 February 2011, as well as during the 14-day rectification period that was provided for under the licence."
SNT.247914.6981	Commissioner Williams also stated he could have raised the fine to US$2.5M, but he hoped that bemobile would use the extra money to meet its September deadline.
SNT.247914.6982	In a statement to the Commission, bemobile admitted it had not built any new transmitter masts since the latter part of 2010.

SNT.63718.7002	At Wilfrid Laurier University in Waterloo, Ontario, Canada, students are finding that popular MP3 players, such as Apple's iPod, are very convenient devices for listening to music at the gym, while traveling on foot, and in the car.
SNT.63718.7003	In a recent ad-hoc survey conducted by Wikinews contributor Darren Mar, 150 students were randomly pulled aside in the hallways of the university, and asked if they own an MP3 player.
SNT.63718.7004	94 of the 150 students (62.66%) did in fact own MP3 devices, most of who were found to be carrying it on them when questioned.
SNT.63718.7005-1	There was one simple follow up question for those who had a player: "If it were possible to have complete and safe control of the device on the steering wheel of a car, would you rather listen to your device, or the radio?" 
SNT.63718.7005-2	 There were three answers possible, yes, no or both.
SNT.63718.7006	Of the 94, 78 (82.98%) said yes, eleven (11.70%) said no, and five (5.32%) said both.
SNT.63718.7007	The reasons for those who would listen to their device were commercial free music, personalized choice of music, and complete control of what you are listening to.
SNT.63718.7008	This study was motivated by the new design of 2006+ model cars.
SNT.63718.7009	Many are being built with auxiliary jacks for the stock radio, allowing the driver to easily connect any audio playing device to the car's sound system with a simple 3.5mm plug.
SNT.63718.7010	What's more, cars in the upper price echelon are being built with (1) a custom made area in the dash for MP3 players (iPod's being the most popular), and (2) implementing audio device control right onto the steering wheel.
SNT.63718.7011	A good example of this is the Ford Fusion or the 2007 Lexus IS250: "The centre console input port allows an iPod, MP3 or Windows Media Audio player to be plugged into the IS audio system."
SNT.41713.7012	Seniors who haven't been credited with passing the California High School Exit Exam won't be getting diplomas when graduation ceremonies are held next month because the First District Appellate Court won't hear the court case about the test until July 25.
SNT.41713.7013	The attorney for the students suing to block use of the test says he still expects to prevail.
SNT.41713.7014	"This case is far from over," said Arturo Gonzalez, the lead attorney in Valenzuela vs. O'Connell, in which Liliana Valenzuela, a Richmond High School student, and others sued to block the state's use of the test as a graduation requirement, "We think there is a strong chance that students in the Class of 2006 will receive their diplomas, even if it is after commencement ceremonies."
SNT.41713.7015	"They have to stay in school and pass their classes."
SNT.41713.7016	On May 12, Alameda County Superior Court Judge Robert Freedman agreed with Gonzalez' argument that the state's use of the test as a graduation requirement was unconstitutional because poor and minority students don't have access to equal educational resources, and therefore don't have equal protection under the law.
SNT.41713.7017	He issued an injunction against the use of the test.
SNT.41713.7018	That injunction seemed to pave the way for those of the 47,000 seniors statewide who haven't yet passed the test, but have completed all other requirements, to receive diplomas with their classmates at upcoming graduation events.
SNT.41713.7019	But State Superintendent of Schools Jack O'Connell quickly filed an appeal of Freedman's ruling and asked the State Supreme Court to issue a stay of Freedman's injunction.
SNT.41713.7020	Earlier this week, the Court granted O'Connell's request for a stay, allowing schools to deny diplomas to students who haven't passed the test.
SNT.41713.7021	The Court also ordered the Appellate court to hear O'Connell's appeal of Freedman's ruling against the test.
SNT.41713.7022	On Thursday, Gonzalez petitioned the Appellate Court to expedite their hearing of the case to as soon as next week, but today the court denied Gonzalez' request and scheduled the case for a hearing on July 25.
SNT.41713.7023	In an email to the James Logan Courier, Gonzalez said he thinks his case is strong enough to withstand the appeal.
SNT.41713.7024	"We intend to vigorously defend Judge Freedman's ruling," he said, "The record strongly supports his decision."
SNT.41713.7025	"If the court of appeals upholds Judge Freedman's ruling, students in the Class of 2006 may still receive their high school diplomas," he said.
SNT.41713.7026	About 70 seniors at James Logan High School in Union City, Ca., mostly minorities and those who are learning English, still need to pass the test.
SNT.41713.7027	O'Connell, an avid defender of the test, which is required by a law he wrote and championed when he was in the state legislature, said this week that he would make sure school districts knew that they had to require the test be passed in order to hand out diplomas to students.
SNT.41713.7028	"I will communicate with districts today to ensure they are aware that the exit exam is a graduation requirement" he said, "Students who have worked hard to pass this exam will be given a diploma that signifies their mastery of essential skills in reading and math."
SNT.204805.7029	BP released their report into the causes of the Deepwater Horizon disaster earlier this year on Wednesday, and shifted much of the blame for the explosion and subsequent oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the largest accidental marine oil spill in the history of the petroleum industry, onto , the company managing the rig.
SNT.204805.7030	The report concludes by stating that decisions made by "multiple companies and work teams" contributed to the accident which it says arose from "a complex and interlinked series of mechanical failures, human judgments, engineering design, operational implementation and team interfaces."
SNT.204805.7031	The report, the product of a four-month investigation conducted by BP's Head of Safety Operations, Mark Bly, criticizes the oil rig's fire prevention systems, the crew of the rig for failing to realize and act upon evidence that oil was leaking from the surface of the ocean, and describes how BP and Transocean "incorrectly accepted" negative pressure test results.
SNT.204805.7032	The document goes on to note that the blow-out preventer failed to operate, likely because critical components were not operational.
SNT.204805.7033	Bob Dudley, who will become chief executive of BP, described the accident as "tragic".
SNT.204805.7034	He said, "we have said from the beginning that the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon was a shared responsibility among many entities."
SNT.204805.7035	"This report makes that conclusion even clearer, presenting a detailed analysis of the facts and recommendations for improvement both for BP and the other parties involved."
SNT.204805.7036	"We have accepted all the recommendations and are examining how best to implement them across our drilling operations worldwide."
SNT.204805.7037	The report included 25 recommendations, according to a press release, "designed to prevent a recurrence of such an accident."
SNT.204805.7038	The oil company has previously blamed Transocean and Halliburton, the well contractor, for the disaster and BP executives feel they have been unfairly blamed by US politicians for the disaster, and the report continues this view.
SNT.204805.7039	Tony Hayward, who was fired from the position of BP's chief executive following multiple public relations issues, squarely places the blame for the disaster on Halliburton.
SNT.204805.7040	"To put it simply, there was a bad cement job," he said in a statement, also claiming that BP should not be the only company to take the blame for the explosion.
SNT.204805.7041	"It would appear unlikely that the well design contributed to the incident," he argues.
SNT.204805.7042	The report blames the type of cement used by Halliburton, designed to prevent harmful hydrocarbons from reaching the seabed, as well as criticizing the crew of Deepwater Horizon, for failing to realize for forty minutes that oil had started to leak from the well, and once it was realized, the crew "vented" the hydrocarbons "directly onto the rig".
SNT.204805.7043	Describing how the explosion, which killed eleven rig personnel, occurred, the report states that "the heating, ventilation and air conditioning system probably transferred a gas-rich mixture into the engine rooms," where the hydrocarbons ignited and a fireball engulfed the rig.
SNT.204805.7044	But, the report states, the blowout preventer, the ultimate failsafe on the Deepwater Horizon failed, likely due to the fire on the rig.
SNT.204805.7045	An automated system was not operational because the batteries powering it, located in a control pod, had gone flat, and another control pod contained a faulty solenoid valve.
SNT.204805.7046	The report was likely, however, written with the company's legal liability for the disaster in a prominent position, since they are facing hundreds of lawsuits and criminal charges as a result of the spill.
SNT.204805.7047	The executive summary is four and a half pages long and the first page is made up entirely of legal disclaimers saying if BP was found to be negligent in their operations of the rig, they could be fined a good deal more.
SNT.204805.7048	Questions have also been raised as to why BP has chosen to release their report before authorities examine the blowout preventer.
SNT.204805.7049	The energy editor of The Guardian, Terry Macalister, wrote that the "catalogue of errors - both human and mechanical" in the report "demolish" the oil industry's "much quoted mantra" of safety first.
SNT.204805.7050	"It may come first in the board room but it does not down at the wellhead where the real dangers are faced," he wrote.
SNT.204805.7051	"It is worth remembering that BP, its rig operator Transocean and the main well contractor Halliburton are the blue chip companies in the wider oil and gas sector."
SNT.204805.7052	"If the shoddy work practices highlighted here are what the best-in-class do, then what is happening in the lower reaches of this industry?"
SNT.204805.7053	Transocean described the report as a "self-serving" attempt to "conceal the critical factor that set the stage for the Macondo incident: BP's fatally flawed well design."
SNT.204805.7054	"In both its design and construction, BP made a series of cost-saving decisions that increased risk - in some cases, severely."
SNT.204805.7055	In a statement, the company listed five issues they felt had contributed to the disaster that were no fault but BP's.
SNT.204805.7056	"Transocean's investigation is ongoing, and will be concluded when all of the evidence is in, including the critical information the company has requested of BP but has yet to receive."
SNT.204805.7057	Members of Congress, who are also carrying out a review into the disaster, also dismissed the report.
SNT.204805.7058	Ed Markey, the Massachusetts democrat who has been investigating the spill in Congress, said that he felt the report was simply a lengthy defense of the oil company's handling of the spill.
SNT.204805.7059	"BP is happy to slice up blame, as long as they get the smallest piece," he said.
SNT.204805.7060	Bly acknowledged during a press conference in Washington that the report did not detail the charges raised against the company in Congress and that BP permitted a culture of recklessness to flourish.
SNT.204805.7061	He did, however, reject suggestions that cost-cutting had put lives at risk and the rig was a disaster waiting to happen.
SNT.204805.7062	"What we see instead is, where there were errors made they were based on poor decision-making process or using wrong information," he said.
SNT.204805.7063	The Guardian reported that "the report is narrowly focused on the final days before the explosion rather than on earlier decisions about well design and safety procedures."
SNT.204805.7064	"No BP officials have been sacked for their role in the explosion, and Bly said there was no indication of any blame beyond the well-site managers."
SNT.204805.7065	The Associated Press reported that Bly "said at a briefing in Washington that the internal report was a reconstruction of what happened on the rig based on the company's data and interviews with mostly BP employees and was not meant to focus on assigning blame."
SNT.204805.7066	"The six-person investigating panel only had access to a few workers from other companies, and samples of the actual cement used in the well were not released."
SNT.204805.7067	The report continued, "Steve Yerrid, special counsel on the oil spill for Florida Gov. Charlie Crist, said the report clearly shows the company is attempting to spread blame for the well disaster, foreshadowing what will be a likely legal effort to force Halliburton and Transocean, and perhaps others, to share costs such as paying claims and government penalties."
SNT.204805.7068	Head of Greenpeace's energy campaign Jim Footner said that it was "highly likely that a truly independent report would be even more damning for BP."
SNT.204805.7069	However, he said, "the real problem is our addiction to oil, which is pushing companies like BP to put lives and the environment at risk."
SNT.204805.7070	"The age of oil is coming to an end and companies like BP will be left behind unless they begin to adapt now."
SNT.204805.7071	"The time has come to move beyond oil and invest in clean energy."
SNT.204805.7072	Alfred R Sunsen, whose oyster company operating in the Gulf of Mexico is facing the prospect of going out of business after 134 years, reacted angrily the the report.
SNT.204805.7073	"The report does not address the people, businesses, animals, or natural resources that have been impacted by the disaster and will be dealing with the consequences of their inadequate and slow response to the disaster," he said.
SNT.204805.7074	The New York Times said that the report is "unlikely to carry much weight in influencing the Department of Justice, which is considering criminal and civil charges related to the spill," and described it as "a public relations exercise" and a "probable legal strategy as it prepares to defend itself against possible federal charges, penalties and hundreds of pending lawsuits."
SNT.204805.7075	Wayne Pennington, head of the geological engineering department at Michigan Technical University, also alleged that BP was wrong to blame other parties involved with the disaster.
SNT.204805.7076	"The blowout and subsequent explosion and spillage appear to the result of an overall attitude that encouraged unwarranted optimism in the quality of each component of the job, allowing the omission of standard testing procedures, and the misinterpretation of other tests in the most-favorable light."
SNT.204805.7077	He continued: "Instead, skepticism should reign on any drilling job, and testing and evaluation at each stage of the drilling and completion would then be routine; instead of questioning the need for such things as the cement bond log, the companies involved should insist on checking and double-checking quality at each step of the process."
SNT.204805.7078	"This was clearly not done, repeatedly, in the case of the Macondo well, and disaster resulted."
SNT.204805.7079	4.9 million barrels of crude oil leaked into the Gulf of Mexico, causing damage to marine and wildlife habitats as well as the Gulf's fishing and tourism industries.
SNT.204805.7080	Extensive measures were used to prevent the oil from reaching the coastline of Louisiana, including skimmer ships, floating containment booms, anchored barriers, and sand-filled barricades.
SNT.204805.7081	Scientists have also reported immense underwater plumes of dissolved oil not visible at the surface.
SNT.204805.7082	The U.S. Government has named BP as the responsible party, and officials have committed to holding the company accountable for all cleanup costs and other damage.
SNT.204805.7083	Dudley went on to say that BP "deeply regret" the disaster.
SNT.204805.7084	"We have sought throughout to step up to our responsibilities."
SNT.204805.7085	"We are determined to learn the lessons for the future and we will be undertaking a broad-scale review to further improve the safety of our operations."
SNT.204805.7086	"It will be incumbent on everyone at BP to embrace and implement the changes necessary to ensure that a tragedy like this can never happen again."

SNT.1002218.7133	According to CNN in an article published yesterday, presidents generally restrict requests for lowering the flag to major national figures, US governors, and foreign dignitaries.
SNT.1002218.7134	Presidents of the United States have previously ordered the flag lowered in honor of non-Americans including Pope John Paul II who died in 2005, King Hussein of Jordan who died in 1999, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin who died in 1995, Egyptian President Anwar Sadat who died in 1981, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill who died in 1965, and United Nations Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold who died in 1961.
SNT.1002218.7135	While President Obama expressed condolences regarding the death of Margaret Thatcher upon her death earlier this year, he did not issue an executive order that flags be lowered in her honour.

SNT.55354.7172	An ongoing struggle in Kazakhstan between the authorities and a local Hindu village has turned serious.
SNT.55354.7173	Forum 18 has been documenting the alleged human rights abuse regarding the Hare Krishna village for some time, but as of 21st November events took a drastic turn.
SNT.55354.7174	The following was seen and written by Ninel Fokina, president of the Almaty Helsinki Committee, and Andrei Grishin, official member of the International Bureau of Human Rights and Law Observance:
SNT.55354.7175	On November 21, 2006 at 1 pm the information was received that according to the court decision to evict the members of the religion organization International Society for Krishna Consciousness from the occupied land near Sri Vrindavan Dham farm, and the demolition of 13 country houses will begin immediately.
SNT.55354.7176	Heavy equipment was brought to the suburban community: trucks, demolition machines, three busses with riot policemen, a bus with demolition squad and the local authorities including the Hakim.
SNT.55354.7177	Electricity was disconnected in the morning of the same day.
SNT.55354.7178	She had a conversation with B. Baikadamov, the only person she could reach at that time, who promised to communicate to the Committee of Religious Affairs at the Ministry of Justice, the Supreme Court, and the Court Administration Committee which includes the department of court decision execution.
SNT.55354.7179	At 3 pm representatives of human rights organizations: Ninel Fokina, Andrei Grishin, and Maxim Varfolomeev, press-secretary of the Society for Krishna Consciousness, plus, a journalist and representative of Astana TV channel left for the village which is located 40 km from Almaty.
SNT.55354.7180	All the roads to village were closed and patrolled by police.
SNT.55354.7181	The human rights representatives and the journalist took detour through the fields.
SNT.55354.7182	It was snowing, but they were able to reach the border of the village because of the four-wheel-drive jeep they were traveling in.
SNT.55354.7183	The jeep was not allowed to drive into the village.
SNT.55354.7184	When Grishin and the jeep driver tried to pass by walk they were stopped and threatened to be put in handcuffs.
SNT.55354.7185	Lieutenant colonel, who came with another patrol car, explained that they are not allowed to the village for their own safety.
SNT.55354.7186	He said that at that time the electric line was being dismounted in the area.
SNT.55354.7187	The driver of the jeep had his wife and two months old daughter in the village.
SNT.55354.7188	He was begging to let him go through, but his request was denied.
SNT.55354.7189	He was told that safety is guaranteed to his family.
SNT.55354.7190	They approached it from the other detour road, and leaving the car on the sidewalk, one by one they entered the village.
SNT.55354.7191	As they approached the village they met two small groups of young people who were not drunk but unnaturally exited.
SNT.55354.7191-1	They held hammers, big dumb-bells, metal crow-bars and sticks.
SNT.55354.7192	Two of them politely greeted the group, and one said gaily, "Your houses are finished."
SNT.55354.7193	Four big busses with toned windows and two cars of ambulance were parked at the entrance of the village in the grove.
SNT.55354.7194	30-40 policemen stood by the houses, and 20-30 people in civil clothes including the leaders of the district with the Hakim, the head of local executive authority stood on the street, watching the demolition.
SNT.55354.7195	Residents’ household stuff such as mattresses, blankets, utensils cookware, and furniture were laying outside on the lawns by their houses.
SNT.55354.7196	People in construction outfits (labor people) got inside the houses and started crushing windows and doors, destroying walls.
SNT.55354.7197	The bulldozer was demolishing the buildings and the big stone fencing with cast iron openwork lattice which separated the houses from the driving area.
SNT.55354.7198	A small group of inhabitants (20-30 people, mostly women) did not offer physical resistance.
SNT.55354.7199	One of the women felt dizzy, fell down and was picked up by the ambulance.
SNT.55354.7200	Police was bringing down those few (basically women) who tried to interfere with the destruction of their property.
SNT.55354.7201	Two men tried to prevent the entrance of destroyers into a house, but were brought down by 15 policemen who twisted their hands and took them away to the police car.
SNT.55354.7202	During all these events none of the representatives from the Office of Public Prosecutor were present at the place of the event, even though both Krishna people and legal service people demanded meeting with representatives of the Office of Public Prosecutor who are obligated to be present during this type of actions.
SNT.55354.7203	The Hakim of the Yetisu district who was personally responsible for this action noticed A. Grishin photographing the destruction of the houses using a digital camera and commanded the policemen to detain him.
SNT.55354.7204	A. Grishin is an officer of the Human Rights Bureau and a journalist.
SNT.55354.7205	To avoid confiscation of the camera A. Grishin tried to escape.
SNT.55354.7206	He ran away by 200 meters and was caught by the police.
SNT.55354.7207	Police officers confiscated his digital camera and took away his journalist certificate.
SNT.55354.7208	Then he was let free, but police refused to return the camera, saying that they would give it to the Hakim.
SNT.55354.7209	The camera was indeed found in the car of the Hakim, but the flash card and the batteries were confiscated.
SNT.55354.7210	When Grishin approached the Hakim to find out for what reason his camera and his journalist ID were confiscated, the Hakim told in front of the witnesses, “If I see you here again, I will personally crash Your eyes, even though I am the Hakim.”
SNT.55354.7211	No one of the policemen, who took part in the camera and ID confiscation, wanted to reveal their names.
SNT.55354.7212	The envoy of human rights E. Baikadamov, who was also contacted, said that the president of the Court Administration Committee Z. Makashev confirmed that he would contact immediately the provincial department and would give the appropriate instructions.
SNT.55354.7213	All the attempts of the representatives of the human rights organizations to find the people in charge of the operation and give them any information were unsuccessful.
SNT.55354.7214	All the present officials refused to speak and declared that they were not responsible for the action.
SNT.55354.7215	The OSCE representatives in Almaty Eugenia Benigni and Lisa Zhumakhmetova did not make it to the village.
SNT.55354.7216	When the darkness fell, at around 6 pm, everything was finished: 13 houses destroyed, people thrown to the snowbound street, the village left without electricity, without heat and water.
SNT.55354.7217	The condition of the witnesses can be described as shock.
SNT.55354.7218	The condition of the people who were thrown from their destroyed houses to the dirt and snow cannot be described.
SNT.55354.7219	 When all the 13 buildings were destroyed as was planned ... while the adjacent houses of other people who do not belong to the Society for Krishna Consciousness were left untouched even though their title deeds have the same status ... the bailiffs decided to give an interview to the TV channel “to avoid one-sided opinion.” 
SNT.55354.7219-1	However no one of them introduced himself.

SNT.142047.7357	The majority of the 1,986 murders this year remain unsolved, and most involve drug gang members who have come from elsewhere to fight for control of the drug smuggling route into neighbouring El Paso, Texas, as well as the lucrative local trade in drugs.

SNT.142047.7362	In late 2006 authorities launched a crackdown on Mexican drugs cartels, with Ciudad Juarez receiving 45,000 troops during that time.
SNT.142047.7363	However, this has failed to prevent the gangs battling to control the cocaine-smuggling trade run from the city.

SNT.24382.7384	OpenOffice.org today released version 2.0 of their free software office suite.
SNT.24382.7385	This release marks over three years of continuous development and boasts many features over version 1.0 which was released in May 2002.
SNT.24382.7386	The latest release may be downloaded from the OpenOffice.org web site free of charge.
SNT.24382.7387	The suite is intended to be a replacement for Microsoft's popular office suite, containing near-identical functionality without the price tag.
SNT.24382.7388	Site administrators from OpenOffice.org say the suite has been downloaded an average of over 400,000 times per week from the official site alone.
SNT.24382.7389	When taking into account that the suite is freely redistributable, and that it is distributed with many versions of GNU/Linux, the total number of copies in distribution is larger still.
SNT.24382.7390	One of the reasons for its significant popularity is the inclusion of several features not found in competing office suites, including in-built export to the PDF format and compatibility with Windows, Linux and Mac OS X operating systems.
SNT.24382.7391	Distributed under the terms of the GNU Lesser General Public License, the OpenOffice.org office suite can be run, studied, modified, and redistributed by anybody that receives a copy.
SNT.24382.7392	This means that any person, group, or company can publish an alternative version - which makes problems such as vendor lock-in impossible.
SNT.24382.7393	It also guarantees that the development will roughly follow with the wants of the userbase - instead of just the business model of one company.
SNT.24382.7394	A lot of work has gone into making this release more visually compatible with the look of Microsoft Office on computers running Windows XP, however, some users were not happy with the effects these changes had on the look of OpenOffice.org when using a dark theme (colour settings).

SNT.5639.7396	Jackson is under indictment there on seven counts of lewd and lascivious acts on a child under 14, and two counts of administering an intoxicating agent.
SNT.5639.7397	Jackson, held briefly under the threat of jail by authorities on Nov. 20, 2003 when charges brought against him were formalized, gained his freedom later that day by posting a $3 million bail.
SNT.5639.7398	Judge Melville, apparently frustrated with Jackson who had in two earlier instances caused delays in his court room, issued the warrant just 5 minutes after noting the singer’s conspicuous absence at the scheduled 8:30 a.m. proceedings.
SNT.5639.7399	Jackson's defense lawyer, Tom Mersereau Jr., advised the judge that Jackson awoke earlier that morning with severe back pain and was under treatment at an area hospital at the time.
SNT.5639.7400	The judge moved to give the celebrity one hour to appear or face arrest for contempt of court.
SNT.5639.7401	As word of the warrant threat traveled to the large news presence gathered outside, a media countdown began.
SNT.5639.7402	During the countdown, live televised reports recounted how Jackson had arrived for court 20 minutes late on his own arraignment for these charges, only to be met by a stern lecture from Judge Melville for that transgression.
SNT.5639.7403	There was also another occasion where Jackson, while recovering from flu symptoms, delayed the trial's jury selection for a week until he was well enough to return.
SNT.5639.7404	The glaringly clear message sent by the judge was: bad back or not, Jackson was to appear in court! And fast! Only the televised scene of Jackson's expectant defense lawyer Mersereau with his assistant Susan Yu, both busy on cells phones while tensely waiting curbside beside the court house for the Jackson motorcade, seemed to undermine a feeling that Jackson would make it in time to avoid having his bail revoked.
SNT.5639.7405	As the deadline came and passed without Jackson’s arrival, live reports were busy with speculation on the superstar persona of Michael Jackson then taking on newer aspects of super-bizarre.
SNT.5639.7406	But Jackson’s flair for tardiness showed itself with an arrival that was a mere 3 minutes after the judge was being forced to make good on his threat.
SNT.5639.7407	Dressed in a blue blazer over a light weight undershirt, the star's recent departure from the hospital was evident by the pajama bottom pants and open-heeled bedroom slippers he wore into the court room.
SNT.5639.7408	Jackson had the assistance of his father and a body guard at each side to keep him steady as he gingerly walked into the Santa Maria court house.
SNT.5639.7409	He listed slightly to the right and kept a fixed, distant face that was surrounded by uncombed strands of his long hair.
SNT.5639.7410	The summons issued by the judge forced Jackson from his hospital bed to show the world he was not above the law.
SNT.5639.7411	In private chambers, Judge Melville met with both the prosecution lawyer, Tom Sneddon, and Jackson’s defense lawyer to verify the defendant’s claims of back pain.
SNT.5639.7412	After re-taking the bench in the court room, the judge announced to the jury they would proceed with the docket as planned.
SNT.5639.7413	Mr. Jackson narrowly escaped prison, and the trial would continue where it left off on the previous day with direct testimony from the now 15 year old boy who accuses him.

SNT.149645.7423	Authorities have said that 48 whales near Christchurch, New Zealand were beached yesterday.
SNT.149645.7424	Fifteen of them died, although the other 33 were re-floated out to sea, according to a conservation official.
SNT.149645.7425	The pilot whales beached themselves at Port Levy on South Island, but dozens of volunteers helped to try and get them back out to the open water out of the inlet, which is muddy and shallow.
SNT.149645.7426	An alarm was called out at about 06.30 local time.
SNT.149645.7427	This is the third mass stranding on the country's coast this summer; 125 pilot whales died in the two other beachings earlier, and another 43 were re-floated out to the ocean.
SNT.149645.7428	"It's a very, very shallow bay in Port Levy, very muddy, so whether they were chasing food and got caught in the shallows, we don't know," remarked department community relations manager Grant Campbell to the Associated Press.
SNT.149645.7429	"We thought everything was OK, we checked them in the boat and then we woke up this morning and saw a whole lot on the beach here."
SNT.149645.7430	Campbell also commented that the whales were up to five metres (seventeen feet) long, and some of the calves were between a metre and a metre and a half (three to five feet) long.
SNT.149645.7431	"We really just stood with them and as the tide came in and started floating, we were just able to push them out and away they went," said a local, Ted Haowden, as quoted by United Press International.
SNT.149645.7432	Locals are expected to bury the dead whales this afternoon.
SNT.149645.7433	According to Campbell, autopsies will be performed on two of the fifteen dead whales.
SNT.149645.7434	Whales are frequently stranded on the beaches of New Zealand each summer, as they travel en route from Antarctica to breeding grounds.

SNT.100527.7452	The European Union (EU) competitions commission has announced its decision to fine the Microsoft Corporation €899 million (US$1.35 billion), approximately 1/10th of the company's gross yearly earnings, for failing to comply with the 2004 antitrust order.
SNT.100527.7453	It is the highest ever fine charged by the EU (also being the largest fine of its kind ever imposed upon a company), and the first time that the EU has fined a company because of non-compliance with an antitrust decision.
SNT.100527.7454	The first decision in this antitrust case was given in 2004 citing that Microsoft withheld needed interoperability information from rival software companies which prevented them from making software compatible with Windows.
SNT.100527.7455	Microsoft agreed to this, providing the information for royalty fees of 6.5% of the licensee's revenues for the product on grounds of innovation (specifically, 3.87% for the patent license and of 2.98% for the information license).
SNT.100527.7456	The EU found these royalty fees unreasonable and Microsoft was ordered to lower them.
SNT.100527.7457	Microsoft complied with this, adjusting the royalty rates to 1.2% (changing the rates for the licenses to 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively) in the European Union, while keeping the rate the same for the rest of the world.
SNT.100527.7458	 The EU still saw this as an unreasonable rate, and Microsoft, two month after lowering the rates, reduced the rates yet again to a flat rate of €10000 or a royalty of 0.4% applicable worldwide. 
SNT.100527.7459	Microsoft's royalty rates, which were deemed unreasonable for the period of 15 months between June 21, 2006 and October 21, 2007 are the cause for the fine.
SNT.100527.7460	So far, the EU has fined Microsoft €1.68 billion in 3 separate fines in this case. 
SNT.100527.7461	This fine will go towards the European Union annual budget.
SNT.100527.7462	The European Anti-trust commissioner Neelie Kroes stated that the fine was "reasonable and proportionate", as the figure could have gone up as high as €1.5 billion, the maximum that the EU commission can impose. 
SNT.100527.7463	She also said that it should act as "a signal to the outside world, and especially Microsoft, that they should stick to the rules" and that "Talk is cheap."
SNT.100527.7464	Although she also expressed hope that "today's decision closes a dark chapter in Microsoft's record of non-compliance with the Commission".
SNT.100527.7465	There is no certainty whether Microsoft will appeal this decision, a Microsoft Spokesperson has stated that Microsoft will review this latest fine, citing that "The commission announced in October 2007 that Microsoft was in full compliance with the 2004 decision, so these fines are about the past issues that have been resolved."
SNT.100527.7466	Microsoft's General Counsel Brad Smith commented "It's clearly very important to us as a company that we comply with our obligations under European law."
SNT.100527.7467	"We'll study this decision carefully, and if there are additional steps that we need to take in order to comply with it, we will take them."
SNT.100527.7468	Microsoft had appealed to fines by the EU before, but all the charges were defeated.
SNT.100527.7469	If Microsoft does not appeal the decision, the company will have 3 month (starting February 27th) to pay the fine in full.
SNT.100527.7470	Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer stated that the company had news that the fine was pending.
SNT.100527.7471	"We didn't know it was this week, but we knew it was coming at some point."
SNT.100527.7472	This may not be the end of Microsoft's troubles with the European Union yet, as the commission is currently investigating two other complaints about the company's anti-competition practices.
SNT.100527.7473	The decisions came after Microsoft announced they were disclosing 30,000 pages of previously secret software code last Thursday (February 21st).
SNT.100527.7474	The EU competition commissioner's commented that this move "does not necessarily equal a change in business practice."
SNT.100527.7475	Microsoft was set to launch three new products: Windows Server 2008, SQL Server 2008 and Visual Studio 2008 at its "Heroes Happen Here" event today.
SNT.100527.7476	Microsoft shares slipped 12 cents to $28.26 on NASDAQ after news of the fine.

SNT.62056.7499	The law is, as the Associated Press dubs it, a "clumsy effort" to curb the urban youth activity known as happy slapping in which an act of violence, such as kicking a helpless victim, is filmed by the attacker's friends for entertainment purposes.
SNT.62056.7500	The new law was tucked inside a much larger anti-crime bill put before the Council, and has been chastised for being "deliberately" vague and allowing the prosecution of non-guilty parties who simply videotape events of police brutality, urban riots or other violence.
SNT.62056.7501	Under the new legislation, written by Minister of the Interior Nicolas Sarkozy, convicted "citizen journalists" could face up to five years in prison.
SNT.62056.7502	Media freedom group Reporters Without Borders has called the act "dangerous", and warned that it can be used to target "regular citizens" who film acts of violence.
SNT.62056.7503	The group has also attacked proposed French legislation that would designate certain media outlets as "government-approved sources of information", citing the dangers of censorship.

SNT.119156.7615	A trio of Canadian trekkers said Friday they completed the fastest unaided on-foot trek using the traditional route from Hercules Inlet on the Ronne Ice Shelf to the South Pole in a record time of 33 days, 23 hours and 30 minutes.
SNT.119156.7616	Ottawa ultra-runner Ray Zahab, age 39, adventure journalist and architect Kevin Vallely, age 44, of Lynn Valley, North Vancouver and North Pole expeditionist Richard Weber, age 49, said they completed the 700-mile (1,130-kilometer) journey, at 10,000 feet altitude, finally arriving early Wednesday morning.
SNT.119156.7617	They endured a white-out but survived on a 7,000-calorie-a-day diet of pemmican, Gatorade drink powder, outdated salami, deep-fried bacon, cheese and butter.
SNT.119156.7618	"If you took a cloud, wrapped it around your head and then duct-taped it, that's what a white-out is like," Mr Zahab, explained.
SNT.119156.7619	The trio also suffered altitude sickness, vertigo, massive, painful blisters, and temperatures as low as minus 40.
SNT.119156.7620	Zahab had to pull 170-lb (77-kg) sleds of equipment, traveling on foot and on snowshoes while the other two men skied.
SNT.119156.7621	According to ExplorersWeb.com's founder, Tom Sjogren, the trio erased the previous record of 39 days, 7 hours and 49 minutes, which was set by American Todd Carmichael, the first American to cross Antarctica to the South Pole alone, on foot and with no assistance.
SNT.119156.7622	Guinness World Records spokesman, Damian Field, in London, however, said that "Guinness monitors a category for fastest unsupported trek to the South Pole, but it has no record currently listed."
SNT.119156.7623	Prior to Carmichael, the record was held by Briton Hannah McKeand.
SNT.119156.7624	In the fastest journey to the South Pole (600 nautical mile journey), she completed solo and in just 39 days, 9 hours and 33 minutes.
SNT.119156.7625	In March 2008 she attempted to reach the North Pole alone and unsupported but had to abandon the trip after falling through the ice and badly damaging her shoulder.
SNT.119156.7626	Ray Zahab is a Canadian ultramarathon runner, personal trainer, and motivational speaker.
SNT.119156.7627	He lives in Chelsea, Quebec, and is famous for his 4,300-mile (6,920-kilometer) epic run across the Sahara Desert in 2007, which was the subject of a documentary narrated by actor Matt Damon's "Running the Sahara."
SNT.119156.7628	He heads Impossible2Possible, a nonprofit organization which advocates planet protection.
SNT.119156.7629	"I started looking at impossible places on the planet in the past year, and I said Antarctica is one of those impossible places, and if we can create an expedition, perhaps we can inspire a bunch of young people to realize they can achieve," Zahab said.
SNT.119156.7630	Richard Weber, M.S.M. (born June 9, 1959 in Edmonton, Alberta) is a world-renowned Canadian Arctic and polar adventurer, from Alcove (near Wakefield).
SNT.119156.7631	From 1978 to 2006, he participated in, lead and organized more than 45 Arctic expeditions.
SNT.119156.7632	Richard is the only person to have completed six full North Pole expeditions.
SNT.119156.7633	He has therefore trekked to the North Pole more than anyone in history.
SNT.119156.7634	The trio were waiting out a storm before boarding a flight to Chile for Ottawa.
SNT.119156.7635	"I'm pretty tired, actually," said Kevin Vallely, calling from Patriot Hills, Antarctica.
SNT.119156.7636	During the saga, Vallely was solely burdened with carrying the high-tech gear in his sled consisting of video cameras, satellite phones, hand-held computers, different kinds of solar panels, batteries and wires chargers.
SNT.119156.7637	"Had we not brought all that stuff we probably would have got it done faster because we wouldn't have had to carry all that weight, but then it doesn't matter as much," he explained.
SNT.119156.7638	Vallely said he also intends to produce a documentary of the expedition.

SNT.122930.7680	If the measure passes, New Jersey may become the only US state to ban the practice outright.

SNT.122930.7683	Waxing on the face, neck, abdomen, legs and arms would continue to be permitted in the state under the proposed ban.

SNT.122930.7685	As a result, many salons from around the state have offered bikini waxing for years.
