SNT.110057.7718	The news comes as legal action against the airline and associated companies begins over the September crash of Flight 269, which killed 90 people, mostly foreigners.
SNT.110057.7719	Udom Tantiprasongchai, founder of the airline, has said conditions were hard for airlines with fuel prices having doubled within a year.
SNT.110057.7720	He says 70% of operating costs are taken up with fuel, and the airline has already raised fuel surcharges again by 100 baht to 850 baht per leg.
SNT.110057.7721	"In this kind of environment, anyone can go (bankrupt) anytime," said Urdom, who declined to comment on the impact the present financial situation has had on his airline, saying only that they "are financially sustainable."
SNT.110057.7722	He also said that the airline could return to service with ease if prices dropped, noting that, "if the situation improved with fuel prices being lowered and the profitability outlook was better, we could be airborne again."
SNT.110057.7723	The airline began operations in 2003; it is a subsidiary of Orient Thai Airlines.
SNT.110057.7724	Orient Thai, which will continue to operate as normal, recently opened Thailand's first freight-only airline, Orient Thai Cargo, with a pair of Boeing 747-200Fs bought from Japan Airlines.
SNT.110057.7725	Urdon said that a major part of the problem is that eight of the company's aircraft are MD-11s, which consume large volumes of fuel.
SNT.110057.7726	He also said that a collapse of a damage limitation scheme with rivals Nok Airlines and Thai AirAsia had affected his decision.
SNT.110057.7727	The news comes as the first families of victims of Flight OG269 launch legal action against the airline, as well as parent airline Orient Thai and lessor Grandmax Group.
SNT.110057.7728	Already confirmed to be involved in the action are Richard and Margaret Collins as well as Steve and Jean Jones, parents of Alex Collins, 22, and Bethan Jones, also 22, an unmarried Welsh couple who, a few days into a round-the-world trip, were among the 123 passengers on board.
SNT.110057.7729	Alex was reported missing but quickly confirmed to have died, while Bethan died ten days after the accident with her family at her bedside, bringing the final death toll to 90.
SNT.110057.7730	"We believe the air crash was completely avoidable and those responsible should be held to account."
SNT.110057.7731	"While we accept that nothing can bring Alex and Bethan and the other people who lost their lives back, we are keen to make sure we prevent this from happening again," said the families in a joint statement.
SNT.110057.7732	"We will be forcing One-Two-Go Airlines to prove in court that they are not a low cost, low safety airline," said James Healy-Pratt, head of aviation at Stewarts Law in London.
SNT.110057.7733	He also said that the action will be brought before courts in the United States.

SNT.75987.7742	The second 5.1 quake was recorded at 47 km (29 miles) east, northeast of Santo (Luganville), Vanuatu with a depth of 149.3 km (92.8 miles) and it struck nearly one hour later at 5:07 a.m.

SNT.8453.7759	Australian officials have impounded 27 Indonesian boats and 240 crew off the country's north coast, in what it says is the biggest operation against illegal fishing so far.
SNT.8453.7760	Fisheries Minister, Ian Macdonald, told the nation's ABC Radio that a number of boats caught fishing for shark fin and reef fish had been taken to Gove and Darwin.
SNT.8453.7761	The nine-day joint navy, customs and army "Operation Clearwater" was continuing, and had taken months to plan.
SNT.8453.7762	"I think all of the illegal vessels up there, because of their inter-vessel communication will now be aware that there is a major sting on by the Australian authorities and those that haven't been arrested, I think will be hightailing it back to Indonesian ports as we speak," said Senator MacDonald.
SNT.8453.7763	Intelligence indicated what he called "organised transnational criminal activity", including some Asian connections beyond the Indonesian village ports where the vessels originated, but the activity was apparently limited to illegal fishing, and did not include smuggling.
SNT.8453.7764	"We are talking about large-scale commercial operations rather than simply subsistence fishing," Macdonald said in a statement, indicating that fifteen of the boats were large vessels with ice for storage.
SNT.8453.7765	Two boats each had one tonne of fish, and shark fin.
SNT.8453.7766	Fishing by some Indonesian peoples has occurred legitimately in the area between the two nations for hundreds of years before European colonization.
SNT.8453.7767	A 1906 Australian claim on as much as 80% of the waters has since been softened by a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the two governments, recognizing some traditional fishing rights.
SNT.8453.7768	However analysts say the Australian government strategy is flawed, since it is based on the fishing technology employed, rather than catch numbers.
SNT.8453.7769	At time of writing, it has not been ascertained whether the currently detained vessels were fishing in such "traditional" waters or not, or whether they were operated by crews who would have traditional fishing rights, if they had been in compliance with the MOU.
SNT.8453.7770	Senator MacDonald told the ABC Radio programme AM that he expected in the case of those thought to have been fishing in Australian waters illegally, the captain and perhaps the senior fishing master would be charged, with other crew being immediately repatriated to Indonesia.
SNT.8453.7771	As for the boats, "We're required by international law to offer them to bond them back to the owners, but as the crew are immediately repatriated the ability of the owners to get them back to Indonesia ... is fairly limited," the Senator explained.
SNT.8453.7772	"I would expect that most of these boats apprehended in operation Clearwater will actually be forfeited to the crown and will be destroyed."
SNT.8453.7773	The fishermen were expected to appear in court next week, reported Reuters news agency.
SNT.8453.7774	An Indonesian fisherman was last week fined $A130,000, setting a new record, after his boat was caught off with over 100kg of dried reef fish, 300kg of fish on ice and 10kg of dried shark fin.
SNT.8453.7775	The Northern Territory Fisheries Minister, Kon Vatskalis, on ABC Radio asked the Federal Government to commit the same level of resources permanently.
SNT.8453.7776	"Provide the extra funding, provide the extra resources to the Navy and the Customs and then they will be able to stop the illegal boats, not only when they run an operation but every day, every week, every month," Mr Vatskalis told the ABC.

SNT.10355.7802	The World Health Organization (WHO) announced Wednesday that an outbreak of viral hemorrhagic fever, caused by Marburg virus, in Angola has claimed the lives of 311 Angolans.
SNT.10355.7803	The great majority of cases have originated in Uige Province.
SNT.10355.7804	WHO estimates that 75% of the cases have occurred in children under the age of 5 years old.
SNT.10355.7805	From the WHO: :'Marburg virus disease has no vaccine or curative treatment, and can be rapidly fatal.'
SNT.10355.7806	In the present outbreak, most deaths have occurred between 3 to 7 days following the onset of symptoms.'
SNT.10355.7807	Past outbreaks indicate that close contact with bodily fluids of infected people, as may occur in health care settings or during burial practices, increases the risk of infection.'
SNT.10355.7808	This is the largest recorded outbreak of Marburg viral hemorrhagic fever in history.
SNT.10355.7809	The risk to international travelers is low, according to the WHO, because the disease requires close personal contact to be transmitted.

SNT.502180.7811	Following their release, the students told the media they were required to remove their clothes at the police station.
SNT.502180.7812	The students, seven men and three women, took control of the building of the school early yesterday morning in response to the long delay in re-construction of the liceo, following the earthquake of 2010.
SNT.502180.7813	At around 08:00 local time (1200 UTC), Leonardo Fuentes, general secretary of the Municipal Educational Corporation of Rancagua, authorized the police to clear out the students.
SNT.502180.7814	Student leader Jennifer Olivares told Diario VI Región the police "stripped off [their] clothes" upon their arrival at the police station, Comisaría de Rancagua, something which Lieutenant Colonel of Carabineros Iván Guajardo did not deny.

SNT.62412.7869	Scientists at NASA say that new satellite images of Saturn's moon Enceladus taken in 2005, has shown that the moon has begun to spew geysers which contain liquid water, and that the internal heat produced by the moon's core may be able to host life below the icy surface, but scientists also stress that life has not yet been found on the moon.
SNT.62412.7870	Scientists say that the heat source producing the geysers is "organic" and that the material used to spew them is caused by the decaying of radioactive material from inside the moon.
SNT.62412.7871	"Deep inside Enceladus, our model indicates we've got an organic brew, a heat source and liquid water, all key ingredients for life."
SNT.62412.7872	"And while no one is claiming that we have found life by any means, we probably have evidence for a place that might be hospitable to life," said Dennis Matson, a scientist for the Cassini project.
SNT.62412.7873	In a new model created by NASA scientists, data shows that Enceladus might have been created by aluminum and iron isotopes which have begun to decay causing large amounts of heat to build up in the moon and over billions of years later, the icy mass has began to melt near the moon's core, causing the water to spew into outer space.
SNT.62412.7874	"Enceladus is a very small body, and it's made almost entirely of ice and rock."
SNT.62412.7875	"The puzzle is how the moon developed a warm core."
SNT.62412.7876	"The only way to achieve such high temperatures at Enceladus is through the very rapid decay of some radioactive species," said Dr. Julie Castillo, the lead scientist developing the new model at the Jet Propulsion laboratory or JPL.
SNT.62412.7877	"The decomposition of those isotopes - over a period of about 7 million years - would produce enormous amounts of heat."
SNT.62412.7878	"This would result in the consolidation of rocky material at the core surrounded by a shell of ice."
SNT.62412.7879	"According to the theory, the remaining, more slowly decaying radioactivity in the core could continue to warm and melt the moon's interior for billions of years, along with tidal forces from Saturn's gravitational tug," said a statement on NASA"s website.
SNT.62412.7880	Data from Cassini's ion and neutral mass spectrometer further shows that the natural building blocks of life are also present within Enceladus.
SNT.62412.7881	The results show that carbon dioxide, acetylene, methane, propane and nitrogen, the basic building blocks for life, are all present within the moon.
SNT.62412.7882	"The team concludes that so far, all the findings and the hot start model indicate that a warm, organic-rich mixture was produced below the surface of Enceladus and might still be present today, making the moon a promising kitchen for the cooking of primordial soup," added the statement.
SNT.62412.7883	Cassini will make a flyby on Enceladus in march of 2008.
SNT.62412.7884	The mission will "measure the gas emanating from the plume," ended the statement.

SNT.260312.7931	State officials in Queensland, Australia, have begun working on a draft protocol to use security cameras to record conversations in taxis.
SNT.260312.7932	The new draft proposes to change a current policy which allows for cameras in taxis which do not record sound for privacy reasons, in the hope that audio recordings will make some investigations easier.
SNT.260312.7933	The paper, which says audio recordings would "provide greater certainty with regard to investigations, particularly in situation of conflicting statements," is currently at the Transport and Main Roads department.
SNT.260312.7934	The proposal also suggests extending the time taxi companies can keep recordings downloaded from security cameras from the current 30–35 days.
SNT.260312.7935	The chairman of one taxi company said the proposed measure would increase the safety of his drivers.
SNT.260312.7936	"In 2006 the government introduced the security cameras and most cabs now have GPS units," he said.
SNT.260312.7937	"What we've got now is an improvement over having nothing at all and as a result there has been a fair improvement in the reduction of assaults on taxi drivers."
SNT.260312.7938	Queensland Taxi Advisers Incorporated, a union of taxi operators, said they supported the introduction of audio recording because it would create "greater transparency and certainty in investigations where there were conflicting statements from drivers and passengers."
SNT.260312.7939	To address privacy concerns, the paper proposes to add stickers to the entry points at the taxis.
SNT.260312.7940	Scott Emerson, a spokesperson for the Liberal National Party of Queensland, objected to the measure on privacy grounds.
SNT.260312.7941	"We need to know how these recordings are going to be used," he said.
SNT.260312.7942	Michael Cope, the president of the Queensland Council of Civil Liberties said he opposed the measure because the recordings might be used by taxi companies in civil cases concerning driver complaints.
SNT.260312.7943	"We're swapping from saying it's about safety to saying it's about setting fare disputes," he said.
SNT.260312.7944	"We don't think that justifies collecting ... intensely personal information that audio recordings collect."
SNT.260312.7945	Queensland's privacy commissioner Linda Matthews reacted said the recordings would be used for genuine law enforcement purposes.
SNT.260312.7946	Annastacia Palaszczuk, Queensland's Transport Minister, said the ideas within the proposal would be heavily considered before being implemented.
SNT.260312.7947	She said: "If people think it's a good idea then we go to full consultation."
SNT.260312.7948	"I would be meeting with the privacy commissioner, I'd be meeting with the taxi industry, I'd be consulting with members of the public in a much more formal way."

SNT.123643.7950	According to the Federal Aviation Administration, the Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport was shut down after ash reached the airport.

SNT.123643.7955	These are the latest in a series of eruptions from Mount Redoubt, which started on March 22.
SNT.123643.7956	The volcano had not erupted since a four-month period in 1989-90.

SNT.9292.7958	The animated series Family Guy returned to the FOX television network with a new episode Sunday for the first time since it was taken off the schedule three years ago.
SNT.9292.7959	Although the show kept most of its audience that lead-in The Simpsons gave, FOX was still fourth out of five major broadcast networks in the half-hour, losing most notably to ABC's hit Desperate Housewives (UPN, the other major American broadcast network, does not air original programming on Sundays).
SNT.9292.7960	However, the season premiere of Family Guy and the series debut of American Dad (which helped usher in what the network termed "The New FOX Sunday") helped bring FOX to the #2 spot out of five networks in the crucial 18 to 49 demographic, one of the most important to advertisers in the key May sweeps period.
SNT.9292.7961	"Sweeps" occurs four times a year and helps networks and independent affiliates determine how much a fixed amount of time for commercial advertisement will cost (the higher the ratings, the more revenue for the networks selling the time to advertisers).
SNT.9292.7962	On the whole, Family Guy averaged a 6.3 rating in the overnights as posted by Zap2It.
SNT.9292.7963	While the overnight ratings are fairly accurate, the numbers are preliminary and are subject to minor change.
SNT.9292.7964	One ratings point is equal to 1,096,000 households, as there are now 109,600,000 households in the United States with at least one television.
SNT.9292.7965	This translates into a little more than 6.9 million households whose sets were tuned into Family Guy, as recorded by the sample of "Nielsen families," who record their viewing habits and contribute to the ratings process the US uses.
SNT.9292.7966	The use of the word "share" in the article means that it is the rough percentage of viewers with their sets on at that hour tuning into a certain program.
SNT.9292.7967	For example, nine percent of viewers in the United States with their televisions on at 9 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time were tuned to Family Guy.
SNT.9292.7968	This only added up to a 9 household share for the hour, compared to an 11 share for Law & Order: Criminal Intent on NBC, a 14 share for a CBS Hallmark Hall of Fame movie of the week (traditionally only aired during the key sweeps periods), and a 23 share for the aforementioned Desperate Housewives.
SNT.9292.7969	Averaged with the performance of American Dad, a cartoon produced by Family Guy creator Seth MacFarlane, FOX earned a mere 5.8 rating/9 share for the hour.
SNT.9292.7970	The episode revolved around a big scheme Peter Griffin, the main character of the series, conjured.
SNT.9292.7971	To give his wife Lois (who no longer finds him sexually attractive) a second honeymoon in order to "spice up" their love life, he pretends to be actor Mel Gibson so they can stay in a new luxury hotel for free.
SNT.9292.7972	Peter stumbles upon a sequel to the film The Passion of the Christ, and vows to keep the movie from ever seeing the light of day.
SNT.9292.7973	To get the movie back, Gibson kidnaps Lois and keeps her captive on top of Mount Rushmore, which leads to a scene in which the three battle on top of the monument, in a homage to the film North by Northwest.

SNT.147073.8007	Of twenty two members of the party presidency, 16 voted for expulsion, three were against (Luka Bebić, Mario Zubović and Damir Polančec) and two abstained (Bianca Matković and Petar Selem).

SNT.102146.8013	Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd announced today that the HSK Kormoran has been located approximately 112 nautical miles off Steep Point Western Australia.
SNT.102146.8014	Sonar imagery of the Kormoran shows the site consists of two main pieces at a depth of 2560 metres.
SNT.102146.8015	A debris field 4 nautical miles south of the wreck believed to be the site of the battle.
SNT.102146.8016	The Kormoran (HSK 8) was a German auxiliary cruiser of Kriegsmarine during World War II.
SNT.102146.8017	On November 19, 1941, the Kormoran encountered the HMAS Sydney.
SNT.102146.8018	The resulting battle saw the Sydney sunk with the loss of all 645 hands, the Kormoran was scuttled by the crew with the loss of 60, 320 survivors including three Chinese prisoners of war were rescued.
SNT.102146.8019	The loss of the Sydney has been the subject of much controversy, speculation and conspiracy theory.
SNT.102146.8020	There have been many searches for the two vessels, this latest search is by the "Finding Sydney Foundation".
SNT.102146.8021	"Finding the Kormoran is one big step forward," said Prime Minister Rudd.
SNT.102146.8022	"This is an important part in resolving a 65 year old puzzle."

SNT.139598.8027	Friday marks the 50th anniversary of a mining disaster which occured in Lanarkshire, Scotland on September 18, 2009, killing 47 miners.
SNT.139598.8028	Scotland's First Minister Alex Salmond MSP unveiled a bronze statue and a memorial garden in Moodiesburn on Sunday in front of a crowd of approximately 600.
SNT.139598.8029	At roughly 0700 BST on September 18, 1959, 47 men who were working in Auchengeich Collery in North Lanarkshire, Scotland were overcome by smoke as they were walking down to start work.
SNT.139598.8030	They were subsequently killed after being trapped by a fire in the mine which prevented them from escaping.
SNT.139598.8031	At the time, a decision had been made to flood the pit after attempts to rescue the men failed.
SNT.139598.8032	It transpired that the fire was caused by an electrical fault 1,000 ft below the surface.
SNT.139598.8033	First Minister Salmond unveiled a memorial garden and a bronze statue which had been placed to mark the 50th anniversary of the incident.
SNT.139598.8034	A religious service was carried out from Bishop Joseph Devine.
SNT.139598.8035	Tom Clarke, MP for Chryston and Bellshill, also attended the event.
SNT.139598.8036	Memorial committee chairman Daniel Taylor read out the names of the late 47 people while another person was playing bagpipes in the background.
SNT.139598.8037	When the service came to a close, First Minister Salmond commented on the tragedy, saying "The tragedy at Auchengeich Colliery left barely a town, village or mining family in North Lanarkshire unaffected."
SNT.139598.8038	"Fifty years on, the memories of the fateful day which claimed the lives of so many husbands, fathers, brothers and sons endure and I am honoured to pay tribute to them."
SNT.139598.8039	"Scotland is fortunate enough to have been blessed with rich natural resources, from the abundant coal seams of the central belt to the oil and gas reserves off our shores and the emerging renewable energy sources we are just beginning to feel the benefits of."
SNT.139598.8040	"But we should never forget the human cost which has come with that."
SNT.139598.8041	"Just as the Piper Alpha tragedy more than two decades ago underlined the hazards of North Sea exploration, the Auchengeich disaster showed all too starkly the dangers and risks which miners all over Scotland took for granted as part of their job every time they descended the pits."
SNT.139598.8042	"The excellent work of the people of North Lanarkshire and Auchengeich Miners' Welfare has provided this new memorial garden and magnificent bronze sculpture."
SNT.139598.8043	"Together, they are a truly fitting tribute to those 47 brave men who died in Auchengeich half a century ago."
SNT.61021.8044	NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope made news this week when it was announced that the space observatory had, for the first time, captured enough light to detect molecules in the atmospheres of planets outside the solar system.
SNT.61021.8045	The planets are too far away to be observed directly with current technology, but by measuring the spectra of each planet when visible with its star, and again when the planet was hidden behind its star, the teams were able to determine the measurements of the planets spectra.
SNT.61021.8046	In a paper published in the February 22 issue of Nature, Dr. Jeremy Richardson of NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center presented measurements of HD 209458 b, a hot, Jupiter-like planet located 153 light-years from Earth, in the constellation Pegasus.
SNT.61021.8047	Richardson's team found a peak in the infrared spectra and was able to determine that the atmosphere of HD 209458 b likely consisted of clouds of silicate dust.
SNT.61021.8048	Dr. Mark Swain of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory led another study of HD 209458 b, and found similar results.
SNT.61021.8049	Another team, led by Dr. Carl Grillmair of Spitzer Science Center at Caltech, performed a similar study of HD 189733b, 63 light-years away, in the constellation Vulpecula.
SNT.61021.8050	Dr. Grillmair discusses the results: “It was believed to be fairly straightforward that these planets would have a lot of water in them, for one thing, very hot water."
SNT.61021.8051	"These planets, these hot Jupiters very, very close in to their parent stars are 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit or so, so it's not a pleasant place to live."
SNT.61021.8052	"And what we found instead and what the other group found for this completely different planet around another star, is that the spectrum is essentially flat."
SNT.61021.8053	"It really doesn't show any of the features we would have expected from water."
SNT.61021.8054	"The theorists' heads were spinning when they saw the data," adds Dr. Richardson.
SNT.61021.8055	"It is virtually impossible for water, in the form of vapor, to be absent from the planet, so it must be hidden, probably by the dusty cloud layer we detected in our spectrum."
SNT.61021.8056	Dr. Grillmair: "The observations are showing us that things are not the way we expected them."
SNT.61021.8057	"And so there'll be a big push to get a lot more data while Spitzer is still alive."
SNT.61021.8058	"I think this will ultimately be one of the most important legacies of the Spitzer Space Telescope, unanticipated as it was before launch."
SNT.61021.8059	"I think it will become extremely important in the future."
SNT.61021.8060	The telescope was launched in August of 2003 with a maximum expected life cycle of 5 years.
SNT.61021.8061	"With these new observations, we are refining the tools that we will one day need to find life elsewhere if it exists," said Swain.
SNT.61021.8062	Dr. Swain's and Dr. Grillmair's studies are pending publication in Astrophysical Journal Letters.

SNT.124267.8106	Adam is a robot developed by Welsh Aberystwyth University researchers which combines artificial intelligence (AI), robotics and automation to independently conduct and analyse biological laboratory research.
SNT.124267.8107	"What's new and exciting about Adam is [it is] the first time we've managed to show that a computer can not only think up new scientific ideas, but experimentally test them and decide whether they're true," said Ross King, a computer science professor and lead researcher at Aberystwyth University, "Adam makes up its own mind what to do.
SNT.124267.8108	He says that for other lab experiments the hardware is already in place, the only step needed is to change the software.
SNT.124267.8109	The artificial intelligence alone spans three computers which holds the databases and analytical software to enable Adam to think.
SNT.124267.8110	For the yeast experiment, Adam was loaded with databases which hold known information relating to yeasts and organisms.
SNT.124267.8111	Adam compared all fields in the database to find the areas of missing information from which he devised 20 hypotheses.
SNT.124267.8112	Adam's AI is connected to robotic arms, sensors, incubators and cameras which enable Adam to start over 1,000 individual experiments every day and follow their progress over a week.
SNT.124267.8113	A part of the process is that Adam's AI can cycle and analyze the results of the experiments as well doing routine repetitious lab work.
SNT.124267.8114	Following Adam's testing, King's team manually tested three of Adam's hypotheses and found that the robot's conclusions were correct, and each was a breakthrough to the scientific community.
SNT.124267.8115	William Melek, an assistant professor of mechanical engineering at Ontario's University of Waterloo, has noted that to set up the AI needed for subsequent experiments involving new biological variables and criteria, the human expertise would be time consuming to customize it.
SNT.124267.8116	The usefulness would be limited therefore to the allotment of human input needed to set up Adam.
SNT.124267.8117-1	David Waltz of Columbia University and Bruce Buchanan of the University of Pittsburgh say that "For the foreseeable future, the prospect of using automated systems as assistants holds vast promise as these assistants are becoming not only faster but much broader in their capabilities -- more knowledgeable, more creative, and more self-reflective," 
SNT.124267.8117-2	They note the potential of such lab assistants which may more efficiently process the research data.
SNT.124267.8118	It was reported that Adam cost about $1million in production costs and this was weighed against the costs of hiring lab techs.
SNT.124267.8119	King said, We made many mistakes and learned from Adam.
SNT.124267.8120	Eve is the second AI computer under development by Professor King's research team.
SNT.124267.8121	Eve's artificial intelligence will be enhanced to analyze compounds needed for medicinal drugs which may treat killer diseases such as malaria.

SNT.9058.8160	Wildlife scientists confirmed on Thursday that a bird long thought extinct, the Ivory-billed woodpecker, has been found in Arkansas.
SNT.9058.8161	The remarkable birds have a 30-inch wingspan and stand nearly 20 inches high.
SNT.9058.8162	The birds inhabited a wide swath of American bottomlands and mountain pine forests until the latter part of the 1800s.
SNT.9058.8163	They require a large feeding ground, and it is thought the expansion of towns and cities closed off their domain.
SNT.9058.8164	Ornithologists say each mating pair of Ivory-billed woodpeckers needs three square miles of forest to survive.
SNT.9058.8165	There were thought to be only 22 of them left in 1938.
SNT.9058.8166	There have been several independent sightings of the bird in Arkansas over the last year, and even a videotape.
SNT.9058.8167	In an effort to support the birds, the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, The Nature Conservancy, and other groups have joined to form the Big Woods Conservation Partnership to conserve 200,000 acres of forest habitat and rivers in the area during the next 10 years.
SNT.9058.8168	John Fitzpatrick, director of the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology told the Associated Press, "the bird captured on video is clearly an ivory-billed woodpecker.
SNT.9058.8169	Amazingly, America may have another chance to protect the future of this spectacular bird and the awesome forests in which it lives."
SNT.9058.8170	The story premiered Thursday in the online version of Science magazine.
SNT.24133.8171	Spanish police believe they are close to capturing Aribert Heim, the 91-year-old known as "Dr. Death".
SNT.24133.8172	Dr. Heim, described by The Times as "the most wanted Nazi still believed to be alive", is thought to be living in the town of Palafrugell in the Costa Brava area of Spain.
SNT.24133.8173	Heim worked as a doctor in a number of Nazi Germany concentration camps (Mauthausen, Sachsenhausen and Buchenwald) carrying out a series of experiments on the camp's Jewish inmates.
SNT.24133.8174	His experiments reportedly included operating on a patient without anaesthetic to see how much pain a human being could endure, and injecting petrol into the bloodstream, then timing how long it took for the victim to die.
SNT.24133.8175	Hundreds of people are believed to have died as a result of these experiments.
SNT.24133.8176	The Times reports that Heim led a normal civilian life after the end of the Second World War, but fled Germany in 1962, when the authorities were about to issue a warrant for his arrest.
SNT.24133.8177	Nazi hunters, including researchers from the Simon Wiesenthal Center, have been looking for him ever since.
SNT.24133.8178	The center's founder, Simon Wiesenthal, was himself active in pursuing Heim prior to his death last month.
SNT.24133.8179	German police received a tip six weeks ago by an Israeli citizen who met a man in Ibiza with characteristics similar to Heim.
SNT.24133.8180	Other evidence pointing the trail to Palafrugell involve banking transfers and tax filings.

SNT.51653.8344	The US Army Corps of Engineers decision to place restrictions on issuance of nationwide pollution permits has been upheld by a federal court.
SNT.51653.8345	In National Association of Home Builders v. Army Corps of Engineers, the District Court for the District of Columbia found that the Corps of Engineers had not acted in an "arbitrary" or "capricious" manner in changing the terms and conditions for issuance of a national pollution permit, including reducing the size of area into which pollutants may be discharged from 10 acres to 1 acre, raising the threshold for requiring additional permits from 1 acre to 1/10 acre,
SNT.51653.8346	A nationwide permit allows an organization to engage in certain industrial activities on a national basis (such as mining and construction), reducing the amount of paperwork and filings needed for otherwise minor environmental impacts, as opposed to an ordinary permit for a specific location which will engage in activities which generate water pollution.
SNT.51653.8347	Due to concerns over the amount of discharge taking place in waterways, the Corps of Engineers began in the 1980s to reduce the authority granted by nationwide permits and to bar use of the permits in certain ecologically sensitive areas.
SNT.51653.8348	Some industry groups, including the plaintiff in the above case, The National Association of Home Builders, sued the Corps of Engineers in 2000 over the change in an attempt to block its implementation.
SNT.51653.8349	Environmental groups, including the Sierra Club, were given permission to intervene in the case in support of the actions of the Corps.
SNT.51653.8350	Environmental groups were pleased with the decision, but are concerned over other actions of the Bush Administration, such as the attempts to weaken provisions of the 2002 Clean Water Act to allow additional dumping of construction and mining waste into waterways as fill material.

SNT.74315.8409	Two minutes after the break, Australia equalised through striker Mark Viduka.
SNT.74315.8410	The Australian captain managed to head a curling cross by midfielder Brett Emerton back across Iraqi Noor Hassan's goal and into the top corner.
SNT.74315.8411	However, Iraq scored twice to win the match, the former through a defensive error by Australia.
SNT.74315.8412	Hawar Mulla Mohammed was played through with a lovely ball from a teammate, who had attracted the Australian central defence out-of-position.
SNT.74315.8413	Mohammed slotted the ball home from 15 yards to re-take the lead.
SNT.74315.8414	Iraq sealed the three Group A points when Karrar Jassim Mohammed scored in the eighty-sixth minute.
SNT.74315.8415	He managed to get on the end of a deflected shot and calmly tap the ball into an empty net, after goalkeeper Schwarzer had dived to defend the initial shot.

SNT.74315.8418	Australia must defeat Thailand to remain any chance of progressing through to the next stage.
SNT.74315.8419	In the event that Australia win (ie. are on four points) and Iraq win or draw (ie. are on seven or five points), Australia will progress through to the next stage on head-to-head rather than Thailand despite having a possibly-worse goal difference.
SNT.74315.8420	Goal difference (goals for minus goals against) is only used to separate two teams if they drew in their head-to-head match in the group stage.
SNT.74315.8421	If Iraq lose to Oman and Australia win, all four teams will end up on four points.
SNT.74315.8422	It is unclear how the head-to-head rule will be applied by the AFC in this situation, and it is probable that goal difference will be used.

SNT.109914.8447	Julian Assange, an investigative editor on Wikileaks, claimed that the information in the documents "adds weight to Cuban statements that the United States economic embargo of the island has forced it to rely on slow and expensive satellite links for Internet connectivity."

SNT.149903.8458	The Iraq Inquiry in London has revealed that United Kingdom justice secretary Jack Straw ignored the advice of Sir Michael Wood, the Foreign Office's most senior legal adviser until his resignation in 2006, that the 2003 invasion of Iraq was illegal under international law.
SNT.149903.8459	This is the first time that Wood has publicly expressed an opinion on the war.
SNT.149903.8460	Wood advised Straw, then Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs, that invading Iraq without the backing of the United Nations Security Council in the form of a specific mandate—which the resolution the government used to support the war lacked—would "amount to the crime of aggression", to which Straw responded that he was being "dogmatic and international law was pretty vague".
SNT.149903.8461	Wood disputes this, saying, "Obviously there are some areas of international law that can be quite uncertain.
SNT.149903.8462	This, however, turned exclusively on the interpretation of a specific text and it is one on which I think that international law was pretty clear."
SNT.149903.8463	He says that it was unprecedented for the government to ignore his advice, and told the inquiry that he "considered that the use of force against Iraq in March 2003 was contrary to international law," since the Security Council had not met to approve the use of force, nor to agree that Iraq was committing a "material breach" of existing disarmament resolutions.
SNT.149903.8464	He believed that regime change was the reason for the British interest in the nation, and that it was not a valid reason for war.
SNT.149903.8465	He told the inquiry, "I made it clear that, in my view, the draft that they were working toward did not authorize the use of force without a further decision of the Security Council".
SNT.149903.8466	Recently declassified letters prove that Wood raised these concerns directly with Jack Straw.
SNT.149903.8467	In one of these letters, dated January 24, 2003, Wood said that the "UK cannot lawfully use force in Iraq in ensuring compliance" with UN resolutions (including resolution 1441, which gave Saddam Hussein a "final opportunity" to comply with the UN's mandates on weapons of mass destruction by November 2002).
SNT.149903.8468	In his reply, Straw "noted", but "did not accept" Wood's advice.
SNT.149903.8469	Straw said he was "as committed as anyone to international law and its obligations".
SNT.149903.8470	In this case, the issue is an arguable one, capable of honestly and reasonably held differences of view."
SNT.149903.8471	He said he wanted a new UN resolution "for political reasons", but said that there was a "strong case" that existing resolutions would "provide a sufficient basis in international law to justify military action".
SNT.149903.8472	Instead of following Wood's advice, government ministers used the advice of Lord Goldsmith, who was then the Attorney General for England and Wales.
SNT.149903.8473	Goldsmith—who is scheduled to appear before the Inquiry this Wednesday—advised Straw that a second UN resolution would not be required to invade, based on a series of UN resolutions reaching back to the end of the Gulf War, despite having told the prime minister—only then days before—to wait for another UN resolution, the passing of which they had pushed other Security Council members for in the weeks running up to the invasion.
SNT.149903.8474	Wood makes it clear, however, that the final decision regarding the legality of war lay with the Attorney General, rather than with himself.
SNT.149903.8475	The inquiry, chaired by Sir John Chilcot, was told that there were concerns about how the decision was made among the Foreign Office's senior legal advisors.
SNT.149903.8476	Elizabeth Wilmshurst, then Deputy Legal Adviser to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, resigned in protest only days before the invasion.
SNT.149903.8477	She criticised the decision-making process for its lack of transparency, and called it "lamentable".
SNT.149903.8478	She also called the fact that Goldsmith gave his opinion only days before the invasion "extraordinary".
SNT.149903.8479	Wood said that Straw had "often been advised things were unlawful and gone ahead anyway and won in the courts" when he was home secretary.
SNT.149903.8480	Last week, Straw—when questioned by the inquiry—called the decision to support the war a "profoundly difficult political and moral dilemma", and said it was the "most difficult" decision of his entire career.
SNT.149903.8481	Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman Ed Davey called Wood's statement "the final nail in the coffin of the case for a legal war."
SNT.149903.8482	He asks if the advice reached then prime minister Tony Blair or Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown, "And if not, why not?"
SNT.149903.8483	Wood's statement is expected to cause problems for Tony Blair when he appears before the inquiry on Friday.
SNT.149903.8484	The war has provoked protests, and much outrage among politicians who believe that Blair was wrong to support then United States President George W. Bush by sending 45,000 British soldiers—179 of whom died in combat—to fight in Iraq.
SNT.149903.8485	The Prime Minister at the time, Tony Blair, is due to appear before the inquiry on Friday, and Gordon Brown, the current prime minister, is scheduled before the general election (which is expected to occur in May).
SNT.149903.8486	Brown said yesterday that he "think[s] the mistake in the war was not to do the reconstruction and plan it in the way that was necessary so that Iraq could recover quickly after Saddam Hussein fell," and is expected to come under fire from the inquiry, which he himself set up, for his role in the war.
SNT.127713.8487	]After holding an emergency meeting, the World Health Organisation (WHO) officially declared a worldwide swine flu pandemic on Thursday.
SNT.127713.8488	The agency increased its pandemic alert level to the sixth level, its highest.
SNT.127713.8489	"On the basis of available evidence, and these expert assessments of the evidence, the scientific criteria for an influenza pandemic have been met.
SNT.127713.8490	I have therefore decided to raise the level of influenza pandemic alert from phase 5 to phase 6," said the the WHO's director Margaret Chan in a press conference earlier today.
SNT.127713.8491	According to Reuters, Chan earlier sent out a letter to WHO staff saying, "With today's announcement, WHO moves from an emergency to a longer-term response.
SNT.127713.8492	Based on past experience, this pandemic will be with us for some months, if not years, to come."
SNT.127713.8493	Chan, however, stressed the move does not indicate that the influenza has become more deadly or severe.
SNT.127713.8494	"Moving to pandemic phase six does not imply we will see increases in deaths or serious cases," she said.
SNT.127713.8495	The WHO says that many of the severe cases of the virus are reported in people with prior chronic illnesses.
SNT.127713.8496	Of those infected, the WHO says the majority are aged from 30 to 50 years old.
SNT.127713.8497	Currently, the WHO's official tally says there were almost thirty thousand confirmed cases of the H1N1 virus so far, with about 141 fatalities from the disease.
SNT.59591.8498	Scientists have uncovered the largest Neolithic settlement in the United Kingdom at the Durrington Walls and believe that the village was inhabited by the people who built the Stonehenge monument.
SNT.59591.8499	Scientists say that the village was built around 2,600 B.C., roughly when Stonehenge was believed to have been constructed, and housed over 100 people.
SNT.59591.8500	Inside the areas which would have been the interior of houses at the time, scientists also found outlines of what they think were beds and cupboards or dressers.
SNT.59591.8501	Animal bones, arrowheads, stone tools and other relics were also discovered.
SNT.59591.8502	"We've never seen such quantities of pottery and animal bone and flint.
SNT.59591.8503	In what were houses, we have excavated the outlines on the floors of box beds and wooden dressers or cupboards," said Sheffield University archaeologist, Mike Parker Pearson.
SNT.59591.8504	So far, the dig has revealed at least 8 houses roughly 14-16 feet square, but scientists say that they think there may have been at least 25 altogether.
SNT.59591.8505	The site was likely to have been occupied only seasonally rather than year-round and evidence suggests that a lot of "partying" went on at the location.
SNT.59591.8506	This is where they went to party - you could say it was the first free festival.
SNT.59591.8507	There's a lack of craft-working equipment for cleaning animal hides and no evidence for crop-processing," added Pearson.
SNT.59591.8508	The Durrington Walls are approximately 2 miles from the Stonehenge site.

SNT.23751.8521	Five Italians were arrested and twenty-eight others are now being investigated.

SNT.5008.8529	A compound in the common daisy-like plant feverfew kills human leukemia stem cells and could form the basis for newer, more effective drugs for the disease.
SNT.5008.8530	American researchers at the University of Rochester Medical Center in New York say that it could take months to develop a useable drug from the compound, parthenolide.
SNT.5008.8531	However, they are working to do so with chemists at the University of Kentucky who have identified a water-soluble molecule with the same properties.
SNT.5008.8532	The US National Cancer Institute has also accepted the work into its rapid access program, which aims to speed experimental drugs into human clinical trials.
SNT.5008.8533	"This research is a very important step in setting the stage for future development of a new therapy for leukemia," says Rochester researcher Craig Jordan.
SNT.5008.8534	"We have proof that we can kill leukemia stem cells with this type of agent, and that is good news."
SNT.5008.8535	Parthenolide appears to target the roots of myeloid leukemia, stem cells, while current treatments including the relatively new drug Gleevec don't.
SNT.5008.8536	So, "You're pulling the weed without getting to the root," says Jordan.
SNT.5008.8537	Used for centuries to fight fevers, inflammation and arthritis, feverfew earned interest from the Rochester researchers after other scientists showed that it could prevent skin cancer in animal models.
SNT.5008.8538	So the researchers investigated how a concentrated form of the plant component parthenolide would affect leukemia cells and normal cells.
SNT.5008.8539	Comparing the impact of parthenolide to the common chemotherapy drug cytarabine, they found that parthenolide selectively killed leukemia cells while sparing normal cells better.
SNT.5008.8540	While the findings suggest that parthenolide is a good starting point for new drugs, people with leukemia aren't being encouraged to take high doses of feverfew as they could not take enough of the remedy to halt the disease.

SNT.112124.8589	Included in the cuts were the Illinois Department of Natural Resources (IDNR), which operates the state parks, the Department of Children and Family Services (IDCFS), slated to have 179 employees cut, the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency (IHPA) and the Department of Human Services, which is expected to lose 79 positions.
SNT.112124.8590	The IHPA, which operates the state historic sites slated for closure will cut some 38 positions.
SNT.112124.8591	The closures and job cuts will save the state money over the next fiscal year.
SNT.112124.8592	Cuts in the IDNR will save an estimated US$19.5 million and cuts at the IDCFS will save around US$2 million.
SNT.112124.8593	The closures are considered indefinite but will last at least through the end of the fiscal year, July 1, 2009.
SNT.112124.8594	Each site will have one employee on site for security and maintenance.

SNT.47013.8617	Super Typhoon Saomai made landfall in the eastern province Zhejiang in China around 5:30 p.m. Thursday afternoon.
SNT.47013.8618	By Friday evening Saomai had left a path of destruction in Zhejiang and neighboring province Fujian.
SNT.47013.8619	Over 100 people have been reported dead with even more missing.
SNT.47013.8620	An estimated 3.5 million people were affected by the storm, some 1.6 million of whom were evacuated.
SNT.47013.8621	Reports from the civil affairs bureau tell of large-scale material destruction.
SNT.47013.8622	In Zhejiang, 18,000 houses were destroyed and in Fujian, 32,000.
SNT.47013.8623	Phone and power lines were knocked down and outages were wide-spread.
SNT.47013.8624	With wind speeds of 216 km/h (135 mph) at the time of landfall it is the strongest typhoon to hit China since August 1, 1956, when a storm with wind speeds of 244 km/h killed 4,900 people.
SNT.47013.8625	Emergency plans have been implemented and supplies are being sent in from other provinces.
SNT.47013.8626	The central government has allocated 166 million yuan to assist the affected region.

SNT.60500.8639	During a press conference yesterday, United States military and intelligence officials presented material they say link weapons used by Iraq fighters to Iran.
SNT.60500.8640	Defense Secretary Robert Gates told reporters in Madrid on Friday that the there was "pretty good" evidence that Iranians are supplying either weapons or technology to Iraqi militants.
SNT.60500.8641	No recording devices of any kind were allowed during the press conference.
SNT.60500.8642	Reacting to the U.S. claims, Iran's President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said in a television interview that the allegations were "excuses to prolong the stay" of the U.S. military in Iraq, and that the U.S. was pointing fingers at others in an effort to "hide its defeats and failures"; however in an interview with Diane Sawyer on February 12th, Ahmadinejad refused to address accusations that his country was supplying weapons to insurgents in Iraq.
SNT.60500.8643	Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Mohammad Ali Hossein termed the accusations baseless propaganda and said that the U.S. had a long history of "fabricating evidence".
SNT.60500.8644	American officials displayed weaponry including Explosively Formed Penetrators (EFPs) and thermal detectors used for remotely exploding bombs.
SNT.60500.8645	Some of the weapons parts bear the markings that the officials associated with Iranian manufacture.
SNT.60500.8646	The officials claimed that such sophisticated weaponry could not have been assembled by the Shia militia and said that it must have been supplied from neighbouring Iran.
SNT.60500.8647	The U.S. view is that only a state arms company would have the ability to manufacture weapons of this kind and the officials maintained that the weapons were smuggled in to Iraq by the Qods Force of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) and have estimated that such an operation was known to the Iranian government and encouraged by it, but did not present any evidence to support the claims.
SNT.60500.8648	The U.S. evidence is being met with close scrutiny, after the experience of pre-Iraq war U.S. intelligence estimates of Saddam Hussein's weapons capability and links with Al-Qaeda, which were found to be inaccurate.
SNT.60500.8649	When asked why this information was being released at this specific moment, even though the information had accumulated since 2004, the officials explained that they saw a near doubling of EFP attacks in 2006.
SNT.60500.8650	The U.S. claims that the such weapons have killed at least 170 troops and a much higher number of Iraqi civilians.
SNT.60500.8651	Secretary Gates said that the EFPs did not form a large proportion of roadside bombs but that they were "extremely lethal".
SNT.60500.8652	Improvised explosive devices have been a big killer of both Iraqi civilians and Allied forces in Iraq.
SNT.60500.8653	Tens of thousands of civilians and over 3000 Allied troops have died in the nearly four-year-old Iraq war.
SNT.60500.8654	The exchanges come during a period of heightened tension between Iran and the U. S. over Iran's nuclear programme.
SNT.60500.8655	The U.S. deployed a second aircraft carrier strike force in the Persian Gulf last month.

SNT.32490.8767	The House IP address was briefly banned from editing Wikipedia articles in the wake of the initial controversy, but the ban was lifted on January 30 after Wikipedia administrators decided that there have been a number of valuable contributions made through the House and Senate IP addresses in addition to the controversial edits.
SNT.32490.8768	On January 31 and February 1, however, the U.S. House of Representatives' common IP address, 143.231.249.141, were banned again for three hours due to vandalism.
SNT.32490.8769	Because the IP address is shared by House staff members, it is uncertain whether or not the same person(s) responsible for the previous vandalism are also responsible for the latest.
SNT.32490.8770	After the block from Wikipedia expired, the House of Representatives user continued to edit the article on Chris Shays.
SNT.32490.8771	Chris Shays had co-sponsored a bill with Marty Meehan, whose staffers had previously been found to have been negatively editing Wikipedia entries, The American Civil Liberties Union said of the bill "key elements of Shays-Meehan violate the First Amendment right to free speech because the legislation contains provisions that would violate the constitutionally-protected right of the people to express their opinions about issues through broadcast advertising if they mention the name of a candidate."
SNT.32490.8772	All mentions of the bill were removed from the article.
SNT.32490.8773	Also removed was a paragraph about Chris Shays raising $70,000 with House Speaker Dennis Hastert at a country club event.
SNT.32490.8774	Again, the IP address was blocked for an eight-hour period.
SNT.32490.8775	Wikipedia edits in Congress are not coming from the House of Representatives alone.
SNT.32490.8776	An edit from the Senate in July removed references to a plagiarism scandal with Senator Joe Biden, who has informally said he may seek a Democratic nomination for president in 2008.
SNT.32490.8777	As of February 4, 2006, the edit has not been fixed by Wikipedia users.

SNT.323136.8800	The British government have vowed to ban payment fees and other hidden and excessive credit card charges.
SNT.323136.8801	They hope to do so by the end of 2012, following a consultation in the new year.
SNT.323136.8802	Hidden fees are often not shown until the end of an ordering process on the web which prevents consumers from making an informed choice and comparing the actual prices of different products and services according to the Office of Fair Trading.
SNT.323136.8803	Plans are also underway to bring in Europe-wide regulation of credit card fees in 2014.
SNT.323136.8804	Mark Hoban, a Treasury Minister, said consumers "have a right to understand the charges they may incur up front and not be hit through a hidden last-minute payment surcharge."
SNT.323136.8805	He said the plans announced today will increase "transparency" for consumers, and that consumers currently "feel ripped off".
SNT.323136.8806	The Office of Fair Trading have listed some examples of particularly high charges: with EasyJet charging £8, Ryanair £6, and thetrainline.com £3.50 extra to pay for tickets with credit cards.
SNT.323136.8807	The consumer group Which? claimed that these surcharges were increasing the cost of air travel by £265,000 a day (or about £97 million per year).
SNT.323136.8808	The OFT stated that the figure was £300m a year.
SNT.323136.8809	A Wikinews reporter contacted Which? about this disparity but they had not responded at the time of publication.

SNT.102990.8821	The Cassini–Huygens spacecraft has discovered "organic material" and water spewing from a geyser on one of Saturn's moons, Enceladus.
SNT.102990.8822	According to NASA, the discovery was made when Cassini flew by the moon on March 12.
SNT.102990.8823	"A completely unexpected surprise is that the chemistry of Enceladus, what's coming out from inside, resembles that of a comet.
SNT.102990.8824	To have primordial material coming out from inside a Saturn moon raises many questions on the formation of the Saturn system," said Hunter Waite, principal investigator for the Cassini Ion and Neutral Mass Spectrometer at the Southwest Research Institute located in San Antonio, Texas.
SNT.102990.8825	The Ion and Neutral Mass Spectrometer saw a much higher density of volatile gases, water vapor, carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide, as well as organic materials, some 20 times denser than expected.
SNT.102990.8826	This dramatic increase in density was evident as the spacecraft flew over the area of the plumes.
SNT.102990.8827	New high-resolution heat maps of the south pole by Cassini's Composite Infrared Spectrometer show that the so-called tiger stripes, giant fissures that are the source of the geysers, are warm along almost their entire lengths, and reveal other warm fissures nearby.
SNT.102990.8828	These more precise new measurements reveal temperatures of at least minus 93 degrees Celsius (minus 135 Fahrenheit.)
SNT.102990.8829	That is 17 degrees Celsius (63 degrees Fahrenheit) warmer than previously seen and 93 degrees Celsius (200 degrees Fahrenheit) warmer than other regions of the moon.
SNT.102990.8830	The warmest regions along the tiger stripes correspond to two of the jet locations seen in Cassini images.
SNT.102990.8831	"Enceladus has got warmth, water and organic chemicals, some of the essential building blocks needed for life.
SNT.102990.8832	We have quite a recipe for life on our hands, but we have yet to find the final ingredient, liquid water, but Enceladus is only whetting our appetites for more," said Dennis Matson, Cassini project scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California.
SNT.102990.8833	At closest approach, Cassini was only 30 miles from Enceladus.
SNT.102990.8834	When it flew through the plumes it was 120 miles from the moon's surface.

SNT.77620.8836	India, having won the toss and elected to bat first, raced to 113 runs after the first twenty overs.

SNT.62043.8873	Milan had the first chance of the game early when Kaka found room and flashed a shot towards the bottom corner, but keeper Artur Boruc got down well to make the stop.

SNT.62043.8875	Celtic's defense continued to play well, and they limited Milan's chances to long ranged shots.

SNT.62043.8883	Maldini then had a header at the Celtic net, but Boruc was again in the right place to make the stop.
SNT.62043.8884	Celtic had another claim for a penalty when Nakamura was brought down in the area, but the Austrian referee again waved away all appeals.
SNT.62043.8885	Boruc was again forced into action from a Seedorf free kick, which he was able to deflect out with a hand.
SNT.62043.8886	Kaka then shot towards the goal, but the crossbar saved Celtic from going a goal down.

SNT.62043.8888	It took Milan little time to go ahead in the extra period, and the scorer would be no other than the Brazilian Kaka.
SNT.62043.8889	The youthful striker put on a burst of speed to beat out the tired Celtic defenders and blasted the ball through Borucs legs to give the homeside the lead.

SNT.659688.8895	Residents of Santa Clara County, California expressed their opposition at a public hearing Thursday January 31 to a local detainment provision of the Secure Communities program of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
SNT.659688.8896	Secure Communities includes a provision that ICE can ask state and local detention facilities to hold anyone arrested who might be in the US without adequate documentation until ICE has time to review their case.
SNT.659688.8897	The comments came in a public hearing of a policy working group of the Public Safety and Justice Committee, convened to discuss a November 7 recommendation by District Attorney Jeff Rosen to honor ICE detainer requests for serious and violent offenders.
SNT.659688.8898	Since October 18, 2011, Santa Clara County has refused ICE requests to detain individuals who would otherwise be released.
SNT.659688.8899	Another opportunity for public comment on this occurred this Thursday, at the monthly meeting of the Public Safety and Justice Committee of the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors.
SNT.659688.8900	Supporters of DA Rosen's proposal had earlier asked their people to email the supervisors and attend this meeting and the Board of Supervisors' Meeting next Tuesday, February 12.
SNT.659688.8901	The January 31 hearing began with comments by approximately 25 of the audience of roughly 35–40, all of which opposed the DA's proposal.
SNT.659688.8902	They said public safety was enhanced under the current policy because many in the immigrant community have less reason to fear that they or people they care about would be deported if the police were called.
SNT.659688.8903	Sheriff Laurie Smith then described an individual who is now in prison with a rape conviction for an event that would have been prevented if the detention request from ICE had been honored.
SNT.659688.8904	Several in the audience replied by asking how many other criminals would go free because people refused to report or testify as a result of increased fear of deportation.
SNT.659688.8905	Comments supporting the current policy have been made by people who did not attend.
SNT.659688.8906	The San Jose Mercury News for January 31 includes an op ed by Supervisor Dave Cortese, acting Public Defender Molly O'Neal, and Director of the Domestic Violence Advocacy Consortium Cynthia Hunter.
SNT.659688.8907	They wrote, "There is nothing more valuable to public safety than community trust in local law enforcement because it establishes residents' willingness to report crimes and cooperate with police.
SNT.659688.8908	But that trust will break down immeasurably in immigrant communities if residents face the debilitating fear of deportation.
SNT.659688.8909	This is especially true in Santa Clara County, where two-thirds of residents live in immigrant households."
SNT.659688.8910	Since the January 31 hearing, support for the position of the Sheriff and the DA has begun to materialize with at least one conservative group asking their followers to email the supervisors and attend public meetings such as the one this Thursday and the Board of Supervisors' meeting next Tuesday, February 12.
SNT.659688.8911	The policy adopted October 18, 2011 stated Santa Clara County would honor ICE detention requests "for individuals who have been convicted of a serious or violent felony," provided ICE agreed in writing to reimburse the county for the additional expense.
SNT.659688.8912	DA Rosen's November 7 presentation claimed honoring ICE holds would "produce an undetermined amount of cost savings by reducing probation costs", as individuals otherwise on probation would be transferred to federal detention.
SNT.659688.8913	Reports from Colorado and Los Angeles have claimed that ICE holds averaged over 20 days.
SNT.659688.8914	ICE claims an official limit of at most two days.
SNT.659688.8915	Los Angeles is currently being sued over questionable detentions of a number of individuals including a British filmmaker named Duncan Roy, who was held for 89 days.
SNT.659688.8916	If Los Angeles loses, it appears local taxpayers may be liable.
SNT.659688.8917	After DA Rosen's presentation on November 7, the Santa Clara County Public Safety and Justice Committee referred this issue to its policy review working group, which held various private meetings, failed to reach a consensus, and then organized the public meeting of January 31.
SNT.659688.8918	The next official action on this issue is currently scheduled for the March 7 meeting of the Public Safety and Justice Committee.
SNT.248695.8919	United States soldier Bradley Manning, accused of leaking US state secrets to WikiLeaks and detained under restrictive conditions at the Marine base at Quantico, Virginia since July 2010, was ordered Wednesday to sleep stripped of all clothing.
SNT.248695.8920	According to his attorney, this condition was imposed because Manning made a "sarcastic quip" about the harsh conditions of his confinement.
SNT.248695.8921	For most of the eight months he has been held there, Manning has been required to sleep only in his boxer shorts because he has been under "prevention of injury watch," according to First Lieutenant Brian Villiard, a spokesman for the Quantico facility.
SNT.248695.8922	David Coombs, Manning's legal representative for the upcoming court marshal, said that on Wednesday Manning complained of his clothing restrictions and joked that if he wanted to, he might be able to harm himself "with the elastic waistband of his underwear or with his flip-flops."
SNT.248695.8923	On Wednesday night, the brig commander determined that Manning must give up his boxer shorts also.
SNT.248695.8924	Villiard said, "The intention is to ensure the safety and security of the detainee and make sure he is able to stand trial."
SNT.248695.8925	Villiard, citing privacy rules designed to protect the detainees, did not explain how Manning could harm himself if allowed to wear his underwear.
SNT.248695.8926	Coombs said Manning was not put under a suicide watch because that would have required the decision of a mental health professional.
SNT.248695.8927	As a result of the tightening of Manning's conditions, he will be required for the indefinite future to sleep naked in his cell, and endure, according to Coombs, the "humiliation of standing naked at attention for the morning roll call".
SNT.248695.8928	In a statement, Senator John Kerry suggested recent publicity will cast light on Manning's situation and the balance between humane treatment and suicide prevention: "I think that a lot of people are now reviewing this very, very closely, people have weighed in, myself included, I think that analyses are being made.
SNT.248695.8929	And I'm convinced that there will be real scrutiny with respect to that issue."

SNT.39106.8950	Major distributors of the operating system Linux have agreed on a new standard that includes common elements for desktop software, in a move to make Linux a more effective competitor to Microsoft Windows.
SNT.39106.8951	The Free Standards Group (FSG) will unveil the Linux Standard Base (LSB) 3.1 on Tuesday at the Desktop Linux Summit in San Diego.
SNT.39106.8952	The first distribution to include LSB 3.1 support, Xandros, is expected to be released on May 1, followed shortly by versions by Red Hat, Novell, and others.
SNT.39106.8953	The status of Ubuntu's upcoming version is still unclear .
SNT.39106.8954	The standards aim to resolve difficulties that programmers face in developing software for Linux.
SNT.39106.8955	Because Linux, developed by Finnish programmer Linus Torvalds, defines the kernel or core of the operating system, there is a wide variety of graphical interfaces for it and differing software libraries.
SNT.39106.8956	LSB 3.1 standardizes core pieces of Linux to make development easier.
SNT.39106.8957	"One of the big things that's difficult is consistency, and that's Windows' biggest strength," Jim Zemlin, executive director of the Free Standards Group, told the Associated Press.
SNT.39106.8958	"If you buy a Windows program, you know it will run on a Windows computer, and Linux needs to work the same way.
SNT.39106.8959	If you really want to become a broadly adopted and used technology, you have to have that degree of standardization," he said.

SNT.1039242.8962	Hundreds of people came to welcome him home and celebrate his release, despite an Israeli order given to his family not to have a public party for his arrival.

SNT.1039242.8965	He was sentenced to more than 25 years in prison.
SNT.1039242.8966	In 2011, during a prisoner exchange deal Israel made with Hamas, Issawi was released along with over a thousand other Palestinian prisoners.
SNT.1039242.8967	He was released under restrictive conditions and forbidden to go outside of Jerusalem, his residence.
SNT.1039242.8968	However, after only nine months from his release date he was arrested again for breaking the conditions.
SNT.1039242.8969	He was required to serve the rest of the 2002 sentence and stay in prison till 2029.
SNT.1039242.8970	As a protest against the punishment, Issawi began a publicized hunger strike.
SNT.1039242.8971	For more than 260 days he was fed water, vitamins, and additional materials only by infusion.

SNT.1039242.8973	In the end, Issawi agreed to stay in the Israeli prison for an additional eight months to serve the administrative arrest he was under and in exchange he stopped his hunger strike.

SNT.55919.8975	His running-mate Julia Gillard was elected unopposed to the deputy leadership.
SNT.55919.8976	The vote was called on Friday after Kevin Rudd challenged former leader Kim Beazley for the leadership.
SNT.55919.8977	Rudd becomes the party's third leader since the 2004 election, where the Howard government won a fourth consecutive term in government.
SNT.55919.8978	Long-serving deputy leader Jenny Macklin did not contest the deputy leadership following the defeat of Mr Beazley.

SNT.55919.8983	"I'd urge everyone to get behind Kevin - having a Queenslander as the alternative prime minister is good for the state and good for Australia."
SNT.55919.8984	Labor MP Dick Adams said even though he voted for Beazley to remain as leader, he supports the party's new leadership.
SNT.55919.8985	"There'll be a lot more harmony and a lot more opportunity of ideas," he said.
SNT.55919.8986	"I think the new ideas need to flow and I think if it's opened up, as some people have said, they want those ideas to come forward, but I think we'll have some interesting policy direction to take to the people."
SNT.55919.8987	Sharan Burrow, the president of the ACTU - the peak union body in Australia said Mr Rudd will be a strong leader.
SNT.55919.8988	"I have no doubt that Kevin Rudd will say that these laws have to go, that they will be replaced by a policy that reinstates rights," Ms Burrow has told Sky News.
SNT.55919.8989	Government MP, Christopher Pyne said that the new leadership was a poor choice for the party.
SNT.55919.8990	"The combination of Kevin Rudd and Julia Gillard will have all the hallmarks of the mongoose and the cobra.
SNT.55919.8991	It shows Labor is obsessed about leadership rather than policy and strategy," Mr Pyne said.

SNT.117104.8999	At 10:30pm on November 23, 2008, near the airport in McGregor, Texas, Space Exploration Technologies Corporation (SpaceX) tested their new Falcon 9 rocket at full thrust for nearly 3 minutes (160 seconds).
SNT.117104.9000	The engineers then shut down two of the nine engines — in order to limit potential damage to the launch pad — and continued the test for 18 more seconds before finally shutting the rocket down.
SNT.117104.9001	"We ran the engines just like they would run during flight, but instead of being up in the air, they were held down.
SNT.117104.9002	They weren’t moving," said Lauren Dreyer, SpaceX's manager for business development.
SNT.117104.9003	This was the Falcon 9's first major test firing, and it marks a milestone for the company in its plans to capture a section of the commercial launch market.
SNT.117104.9004	The test reportedly shook the windows of houses 5 miles away, causing agitation among residents who felt that they had not received adequate warning.
SNT.117104.9005	"I appreciate the fact that the company notified [the City of] McGregor, but did they not think the test would affect the surrounding communities?" asked commenter Lorena Resident on the website for the Waco Tribune-Herald.
SNT.117104.9006	The Falcon 9 rocket, and its smaller sibling the Falcon 1, are the first rockets capable of entering Low Earth Orbit (LEO) to have their design be privately funded in its entirety.
SNT.117104.9007	According to SpaceX the Falcon 9 can generate 4 times the maximum thrust of a Boeing 747 while firing in a vacuum, and will eventually be able to perform interplanetary missions in addition to its initial role as an orbital launch vehicle.
SNT.117104.9008	SpaceX is also designing a crew and cargo capsule for the Falcon 9, which it has named the "Dragon".
SNT.117104.9009	SpaceX is a contender for future commercial contracts from various government run space agencies, with NASA expressing particular interest.
SNT.117104.9010	NASA will be retiring their fleet of Columbia Class Space Shuttles in 2010, but will not have the Shuttles' replacements (the Ares I and Ares V rockets) ready until at least 2014.
SNT.117104.9011	NASA hopes to fill some of this gap using commercial launches from companies such as SpaceX.
SNT.117104.9012	SpaceX has already reached an agreement with NASA to conduct three test flights of the Dragon capsule in conjunction with the Falcon 9.
SNT.117104.9013	Elon Musk, CEO and CTO of SpaceX, said, "The full mission-length test firing clears the highest hurdle for the Falcon 9 first stage before launch.
SNT.117104.9014	In the next few months, we will have the first Falcon 9 flight vehicle on its launch pad at Cape Canaveral, preparing for lift-off in 2009."
SNT.11728.9015	French police are holding a 31-year-old who managed to convince social workers and fellow students that he was a 15-year-old Spanish orphan and spent a whole month attending school.
SNT.11728.9016	Frederic Bourdin's alias was discovered when a teacher watched a television program about his exploits and his numerous identities.
SNT.11728.9017	Claire Chadourne, headmistress at the College Jean-Monnet, said, "He seemed a little older than his classmates, two or three years at the most.
SNT.11728.9018	Bourdin, who speaks at least five languages, told social workers and classmates that his name was Francisco Hernandez-Fernandez and that his parents had been killed in a car crash in 2000 and that he'd spent three months in a coma.
SNT.11728.9019	He claimed that after being placed into foster care, he was sexually abused and that he escaped to France.
SNT.11728.9020	He told his teacher that he had horrible scars that he wished to hide and was given special permission to wear a cap to hide his balding.
SNT.11728.9021	In 1997, Bourdin was arrested and imprisoned for six years in the United States for posing a Texas couple's 14-year-old son, who disappeared three years earlier.
SNT.11728.9022	He managed to convince the couple that he was their son even though he had brown eyes and a heavy French accent.
SNT.11728.9023	Bourdin lived with the couple for three months before a journalist exposed him and his lies were confirmed by a DNA test.
SNT.11728.9024	Returning from the United States in 2003, Bourdin showed up in the southeastern Alps, where he claimed to be Leo Balley, who went missing in 1996 when he was seven-years-old and camping with his father.
SNT.11728.9025	He says he assumes other identities as a way of receiving the attention he never got as a child.
SNT.8821.9026	Children who spend more time playing with other children are less likely to end up getting childhood cancers, a UK study published today in the British Medical Journal has found.
SNT.8821.9027	The finding supports the researchers' theory that reduced exposure to common infections in the first year of life increases the risk of developing acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL).
SNT.8821.9028	A total of nearly 10,000 children took part in the study, located in 10 regions across the UK.
SNT.8821.9029	Amount of time spent in daycare and social activity, during the first year of life, were used to gauge the level of exposure of the infants to common infections such as cold and flu.
SNT.8821.9030	Day care in the first year of life for at least two days a week, with at least three other kids, halved a child's chance of contracting ALL.
SNT.8821.9031	Those who were rated in the category "any social activity" still had an improvement over the children rated as "no social activity": they had about 3/4 the chance of getting the disease.
SNT.8821.9032	The study describes that effect was "more striking" for acute lymphoblastic leukaemia — a cancer affecting blood and the immune system — than it was for the set of all other cancers.
SNT.8821.9033	Increasing levels of activity saw decreasing chances of childhood cancers, when compared against children who during their first year had no regular social activity outside the home.
SNT.8821.9034	Theories have been around since the 1940s that childhood exposure to infection was related to the development of childhood leukaemia — one, like the working theory of the UK study, said that lack of immune challenge was a factor, another that leukaemia developed as a delayed result of some type of infection.
SNT.8821.9035	The research was conducted by the Institute of Cancer Research in London and in Sutton, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, University of York, Christie Hospital and Central Manchester and Manchester Children's University Hospitals NHS Trusts, and the University of Edinburgh.

SNT.117257.9055	No additional passengers were on board for the flight, which was part of a maintenance test procedure.

SNT.37974.9069	The plan follows a commitment made at the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) meeting in February.
SNT.37974.9070	The federal government will improve access to clinical and health services, increase the number of mental health professionals in Australia, create mental health work teams consisting of GPs, psychiatrists, psychologists and mental health nurses, provide respite services for people suffering mental illness and their carers, and introduce new programs for community awareness.
SNT.37974.9071	Mr Howard said the plan addresses issues which fall into its area of responsibility.
SNT.37974.9072	He hopes that the states and territories will complement the federal government's package by investing in supported accommodation, hospital and emergency services, crisis care services and the provision of mental health care in gaols.
SNT.37974.9073	Under the federal government's plan, psychologists will play a greater role in the mental health system.
SNT.37974.9074	From November, Patients will be able to claim a rebate from Medicare (Australia's universal healthcare scheme) for the services of psychologists if they have been referred by a GP or psychiatrist.
SNT.37974.9075	At present patients pay around $100 for a standard 30 minute consultation.
SNT.37974.9076	Mr Howard claims that there is an issue for mental health professionals in treating patients with a substance abuse problem and mental illness.
SNT.37974.9077	To address this the government will provide extra funding for drug and alcohol rehabilitation services.
SNT.37974.9078	The government will increase the mental health workforce by funding an additional 400 mental health nursing and 200 clinical psychology places.
SNT.37974.9079	The government has promised increase funding for telephone counselling and suicide prevention services, living skills programs and additional support for those with a mental illness who are having difficulty finding or keeping work.
SNT.37974.9080	The government will also provide 900 personal helpers and mentors, increase funding for living skills programs and provide additional employment assistance to those who have difficulty finding or retaining employment due to their illness.

SNT.141897.9131	Marie-Helene Senay, communications director for France Terre d'Asile, said she opposed the deporting of Afghans back to their country, which has been torn by conflict, even if they do not meet asylum requirements in France.

SNT.141897.9133	Immigration Minister Besson defended the decision, saying that "if France never sends people back, it becomes the target for people traffickers."
SNT.141897.9134	He added that the three men put on the flight were from the Afghan capital of Kabul, "where there is no risk for them", and would be given monetary assistance to help them settle back into Afghanistan.
