SNT.160269.12033	Apple sued HTC, a Taiwanese manufacturer of mobile phones, on Tuesday, in a lawsuit claiming 20 different patent infringements, largely relating to the user interface of the iPhone, which is manufactured by Apple.
SNT.160269.12034	According to the lawsuit, filed with both the United States District Court in Delaware and the United States International Trade Commission, HTC violated Apple patents pertaining to both multi-touch gestures, which allow users to interact with a device's touchscreen using multiple fingers, as well as patents involving more general touch features.
SNT.160269.12035	Devices mentioned in the suit are all phones manufactured by HTC that use Google's Android software.
SNT.160269.12036	The lawsuit says that HTC, in selling the phones, knowingly induced those using the mentioned products to violate patents owned by Apple, some of which were filed in the mid-1990s.
SNT.160269.12037	Although the lawsuit named only HTC as a defendant, many viewed the action as an indirect challenge to Google, as the lawsuit only covered HTC devices running Google's Android software.
SNT.160269.12038	The operating system has seen increasing popularity in the last year, and has increasingly included multi-touch input of the type mentioned in the lawsuit.
SNT.160269.12039	One analyst, from Kaufman Brothers, said, "I think this is kind of an indirect lawsuit against Google."
SNT.160269.12040	Others said that Apple was suing HTC instead of Google because the phone manufacturer was an easier target than Google.
SNT.160269.12041	Another analyst from MKM Partners said that "HTC is an optimal target for Apple-it's a relatively small vendor with a weak brand."
SNT.160269.12042	In the documents, Apple said that their goal was to permanently block HTC from importing and selling devices that had the offending qualities, as well a significant cash payment in damages.
SNT.77454.12043	Researchers say that new, ten million-year-old fossils found in Ethiopia, prove that the theory that humans may have evolved from a species of great apes eight million years ago, may not be true, but that humans may have split from apes as long as 10.5 million years ago.
SNT.77454.12044	At least nine fossilized teeth, one canine tooth and eight molars, of a previously unknown species of apes found in Africa were discovered by a team of researchers from Ethiopia and Japan who then compared the 3-D make up of the teeth to other fossils that date back as far as 8 million years and found that the fossils are likely a "direct ancestor" of apes currently living in Africa and that the new ape fossils were that of a species of gorilla who ate mostly plants high in fiber.
SNT.77454.12045	Current fossils and research say that the evolutionary split from apes to humans occurred at least eight million years ago.
SNT.77454.12046	The new fossils say that the split may have happened as long as 10.5 million years ago.
SNT.77454.12047	"Based on this fossil, that means the split is much earlier than has been anticipated by the molecular evidence."
SNT.77454.12048	"That means everything has to be put back," said researcher at the Rift Valley Research Service in Ethiopia and a co-author of the study, Berhane Asfaw.
SNT.77454.12049	Despite the finds, other researchers are not convinced that the findings are correct.
SNT.77454.12050	"It is stretching the evidence to base a time scale for the evolution of the great apes on this new fossil."
SNT.77454.12051	"These structures appear on at least three independent lineages of apes, including gorillas, and they could relate to a dietary shift rather than indicating a new genetic trait," said a Professor at the London Natural History Museum in the United Kingdom, Peter Andrews who also added, "but the fossil evidence for the evolution of our closest living relatives, the great apes, is almost non-existent.
SNT.77454.12052	Researchers have named the newly discovered species Cororapithecus abyssinicus whose remains were found in the Afar Region of Ethiopia, the same place where the remains of Lucy were discovered in 1974.
SNT.144555.12053	The Large Hadron Collider, a vast scientific experiment to smash together sub-atomic particles, moved a step closer to its goal on Friday night.
SNT.144555.12054	Physicists announced they had sent protons all the way round the 27 km ring beneath the France–Switzerland border, for the first time since a major failure 14 months ago.
SNT.144555.12055	The experiment, the largest of its kind in the world, was first switched on with great fanfare in September 2008, but suffered an electrical fault just nine days later.
SNT.144555.12056	This caused a leak of ultra-cold liquid helium, resulting in severe damage.
SNT.144555.12057	Repairs have cost approximately £24 million, on top of the £6 billion spent originally.
SNT.144555.12058	Particles were injected into the ring at around 1500 GMT on Friday, and just after 1930 GMT the first completed circuit was confirmed.
SNT.144555.12059	"We've still got some way to go before physics can begin, but with this milestone we're well on the way," stated Rolf Heuer, director-general of CERN, the European research group running the collider.
SNT.144555.12060	The Large Hadron Collider is designed to smash together particles at almost the speed of light, creating conditions similar to those only moments after the Big Bang.
SNT.144555.12061	By studying these collisions, scientists hope to shed light on theories such as supersymmetry and the Higgs boson.
SNT.144555.12062	The six physicists Guralnik, Hagen, Kibble, Higgs, Brout, and Englert who predicted this particle in 1964 were recently awarded the 2010 J. J. Sakurai Prize for Theoretical Particle Physics for this work.
SNT.144555.12063	Barring further problems, the first collisions are scheduled to take place in January next year.

SNT.702576.12073	A package of six media reform bills introduced last week before Australia's Parliament — including one proposing appointing a Public Interest Media Advocate (PIMA) to monitor print and online sectors — was shelved yesterday by the Australian Labor Party, with only two passed before a seven week break for the country's legislative body.
SNT.702576.12074	Stephen Conroy, the Minister for Broadband, Communications and the Digital Economy, had hoped to see the legislation package passed by the end of the week.
SNT.702576.12075	The Parliament of Australia summarized Public Interest Media Advocate Bill 2013 as, "Part of a package of six bills in relation to the media sector, the bill: creates the independent statutory office of the Public Interest Media Advocate (PIMA); provides for the functions, appointment, and terms and conditions of PIMA; and requires an annual report to be prepared on PIMA’s activities and other specified matters."
SNT.702576.12076	Other bills in the package delineate what PIMA's role would be.
SNT.702576.12077	Broadcasting Legislation Amendment (Convergence Review and Other Measures) Bill 2013 and Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill 2013 both had their second reading on Tuesday in the House and were the only bills to pass both houses of parliament.
SNT.702576.12078	Unlike the other bills in the package which have not had a third reading before being shelved, the former bill deals primarily with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Special Broadcasting Service, while the latter bill increased licensing fees for television stations.
SNT.702576.12079	On Monday, the Australian Associated Press (AAP) released a statement saying such government oversight is not required.
SNT.702576.12080	Australia's The Daily Telegraph is quoted by the Brisbane Times describing this legislation as an "aggressive attempt to silence your media."
SNT.702576.12081	Speaking before a Senate committee about media reform, AAP chief Bruce Davidson said, "We simply do not believe that there is a problem with the conduct of the media in Australia, and certainly not that of AAP, that warrants further oversight by a minister-appointed body [...]"
SNT.702576.12082	"Any hidden perception, I believe, of government interference is simply a dangerous precedent that may lead to control, may lead to interference [...]"
SNT.702576.12083	"The aims may be noble, Mr Chairman, but the potential for potential misuse and changes of that legislation as presented to us, I think, is a dangerous thing to contemplate."
SNT.702576.12084	Former federal court judge Ray Finkelstein oversaw an inquiry into the Australian print media in 2011.
SNT.702576.12085	He told a government inquiry, "There are no powerful groups in society that can come along to governments or anybody and say 'we can do what we like when we like and there's nothing you should do about it'."
SNT.702576.12086	Finkelstein is also on the record as stating that self regulation by the industry through their own organization has failed.

SNT.362699.12112	A judge in Germany has ordered a man from Kosovo to be jailed for life for carrying out the "first Islamic-motivated terror attack" within the country.
SNT.362699.12113	Arid Uka, 22, killed two US (USAF) men and wounded two more in a gun attack on their bus in Frankfurt.
SNT.362699.12114	Uka, a Kosovan who has lived in Germany since he was four, worked in Frankfurt Airport's mail room.
SNT.362699.12115	He became attracted to Islamic radicalism in a matter of months and would later cite a video appearing to show US soldiers raping women in Afghanistan as his motive for the attack.
SNT.362699.12116	Uka approached a USAF bus at the airport, asking a serviceman for a cigarette.
SNT.362699.12117	Upon learning the group was bound for Afghanistan he fatally shot the man in the head before boarding the bus with a cry of (God is Great).
SNT.362699.12118	There, he opened fire upon more USAF airmen, killing a second and injuring two others.
SNT.362699.12119	The remaining eleven passengers escaped injury when his 9mm pistol jammed.
SNT.362699.12120	The team had been loading their bus in front of the airport during a trip that began in the United Kingdom.
SNT.362699.12121	The fatalities were Nicholas Alden, 25, and Zachary Cuddeback, 21.
SNT.362699.12122	Edgar Veguilla received arm and jaw wounds while Kristoffer Schneider was left requiring reconstructive surgery for his face.
SNT.362699.12123	Uka's weapon failed whilst pointed at a fifth man's head.
SNT.362699.12124	Schneider has ongoing pain, blindness in one eye, a missing section of skull and a face rebuilt from titanium.
SNT.362699.12125	Schneider testified via videolink from a USAF base in his homeland.
SNT.362699.12126	Prosecution evidence included songs and text from Uka's computer, phone, and music player.
SNT.362699.12127	He was said to have radicalised alone through access to material such as the fake rape film, which was actually a scene from the anti-war movie .
SNT.362699.12128	In sentencing Uka for murder Judge Thomas Sagebiel agreed with prosecutors there were aggravating circumstances that amounted to "particularly severe guilt," a move likely to prevent parole after fifteen years as is normally possible with German life sentences.
SNT.362699.12129	The judge said the attack was aggravated by its ambush nature, that unarmed men were attacked and Alden was also attacked from behind, and that the wounds inflicted were serious.
SNT.362699.12130	Sagebiel also noted Uka's refusal to explain how he acquired the gun.
SNT.362699.12131	There was no drug or alcohol use involved, and no evidence Uka had been trained for the attack.
SNT.362699.12132	The killer described himself to the court as spending much of his time on computers, with few friends and a largely non-religious family background.
SNT.362699.12133	He sat motionless with his eyes down and arms folded during the 70-minute verdict and sentencing hearing.
SNT.362699.12134	Uka had not joined any radical organisations and the defence claimed he was not a terrorist.
SNT.362699.12135	Last year he blamed inaccurate propaganda for having influenced him and apologised, claiming not to understand his own actions.
SNT.362699.12136	His defence lawyer, Michaela Roth, also sought to have his youth, admissions, and a troubled childhood considered.
SNT.362699.12137	Roth had suggested sexual abuse when Uka was six had led to a return of trauma when he saw the falsified rape video.
SNT.362699.12138	This was undermined by psychiatric expert opinion, a report finding the abuse — and the video — of no "decisive relevance".
SNT.362699.12139	He was aware when he killed, and did not have a personality disorder although he was of "an immature personality," it concluded.
SNT.362699.12140	"The attack was not only cowardly and perfidious, but also damaged Germany's reputation," said Sagebiel, telling victims and their relatives he "hoped that by our bringing the perpetrator to justice swiftly, you can find some comfort... and will not harbour any rancour towards Germany."
SNT.362699.12141	Alden's brother Joe was in court and later said "justice has been served."
SNT.19964.12142	News agency AAP reported last Thursday that George H. W. Bush would be attending the Forbes Global CEO Conference, which starts this Tuesday.
SNT.19964.12143	These reports have now been revealed to be a hoax.
SNT.19964.12144	They were based on a media release and associated website, and reported in Wikinews, as well as a number of print publications in Australia.
SNT.19964.12145	The president and publisher of Forbes Asia, William Adamopoulos, has confirmed that Mr Bush will not be attending.
SNT.19964.12146	"Mr Bush, Sr. is definitely not attending the conference," he said.
SNT.19964.12147	Mr Adamopoulos said that he is considering pursuing legal action against the originators of the hoax.
SNT.19964.12148	According to reports, the media release and website used the Forbes name.
SNT.19964.12149	"While we would not wish to oppose free speech in any way - for free speech is one of the things that unites both Australia and the United States - we are investigating what legal action could be open to us," he said.
SNT.19964.12150	Two Australian broadsheets fell for the hoax put out by the 30A protest network.
SNT.19964.12151	The network sent out a press release purporting to be from the organisers of the Annual Forbes Conference, claiming that former US President George H. W. Bush was to attend the conference.
SNT.19964.12152	Bruce Knobloch of the 30A network indicated that the purpose of the hoax was to show how shallow the media coverage of the conference and the protest is.
SNT.19964.12153	The hoax was originally reported by AAP, who checked the claim with a telephone number provided on the press release before publishing it.
SNT.19964.12154	The hoax was then picked up by several internet news sites, including this one.
SNT.19964.12155	AAP quickly published a retraction, however that didn't stop the hoax making its way into the paper versions of two of Australia's most respected broadsheets, The Sydney Morning Herald, and The Australian.
SNT.19964.12156	The Forbes conference will take place at the Sydney Opera House, and will be attended by hundreds of CEOs from around the world, as well as Australian Prime Minister John Howard, former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, and Steve Forbes himself.
SNT.19964.12157	There is a protest planned to coincide with the conference.
SNT.19964.12158	Protest organisers have called for people to assemble at Customs Square at Circular Quay at 5pm on Tuesday 30 August.
SNT.19964.12159	The protest was originally planned for the Opera House forecourt, however police have declared this area to be an exclusion zone.

SNT.128287.12187	The number of hungry people in the world is projected to reach an all-time high of 1.02 billion this year, according to a report published by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO).
SNT.128287.12188	The report blames this latest spike in world hunger chiefly on the global economic recession, which has increased unemployment and reduced incomes among the poor, leading to greater food insecurity.
SNT.128287.12189	The report, published on Friday, estimates that over 1 billion people will go hungry each day in 2009, a first in human history.
SNT.128287.12190	This is a significant increase over last year's estimate of 915 million hungry people.
SNT.128287.12191	According to the FAO, this increase of around 100 million people is not a result of poor harvests, as in the past, but rather a poor economy.
SNT.128287.12192	"A dangerous mix of the global economic slowdown combined with stubbornly high food prices in many countries has pushed some 100 million more people than last year into chronic hunger and poverty," said Jacques Diouf, Director-General of the FAO.
SNT.128287.12193	"The silent hunger crisis — affecting one sixth of all of humanity — poses a serious risk for world peace and security."
SNT.128287.12194	Although food prices have declined from their record high levels in mid-2008, the report states that global food prices are still high compared to previous years, and that domestic prices remain prohibitively high in developing countries.
SNT.128287.12195	In Mauritania, for example, a staple food such as wheat still costs over 600 USD per tonne, whereas in the United States the price has fallen below 300 USD.
SNT.128287.12196	The current economic situation has intensified the problem created by high food prices.
SNT.128287.12197	Many sources of income for developing countries, including remittances, foreign direct investment, foreign aid, and international trade, are expected to undergo severe declines.
SNT.128287.12198	In addition, because of the global nature of the economic crisis, previously-used mechanisms such as currency depreciation and borrowing from international credit markets are more limited in their scope, according to the FAO.
SNT.128287.12199	In developing countries, the report says, the urban poor are likely to be most affected by the economic slowdown, as their ability to find work is most dependent on factors like foreign investment and export demand.
SNT.128287.12200	However, rural areas could also be affected, as an urban back-migration to the farms would put more pressure on an already strained rural job market.
SNT.128287.12201	Budget constraints would lead families to purchase more grain products, which are cheaper than meat, dairy products, and other foods rich in protein.
SNT.128287.12202	Investment in agriculture, according to Director-General Diouf, is the key to overcoming poverty and hunger in poorer countries.
SNT.128287.12203	These countries "must be given the development, economic and policy tools required to boost their agricultural production and productivity", he said.
SNT.128287.12204	Kanayo F. Nwanze, President of the International Fund for Agricultural Development, says that investment in agriculture is not only essential for overcoming hunger, but also for promoting economic growth in developing countries.
SNT.128287.12205	"To unleash this potential and reduce the number of hungry people in the world," he said, the international community must ensure that farmers "have access not only to seeds and fertilisers but to tailored technologies, infrastructure, rural finance, and markets."
SNT.128287.12206	However, the economic slowdown has forced the UN’s World Food Programme to shut down some of its operations, as it receives less financial aid from donor countries.

SNT.251538.12242	The election follows months of political turmoil after the corrupt first round election in November caused a crisis requiring international intervention.
SNT.251538.12243	Haiti is still struggling to recover from the devastating January 2010 earthquake, with about one million people remaining in squalid, temporary shelters and a recent cholera epidemic which threatens to break out again with the return of the rainy season.
SNT.251538.12244	Observers are hoping the new president will restore enough stability so rebuilding efforts can begin with international help.
SNT.251538.12245	In Haiti’s first round of balloting in November, names were missing from voter rolls, ballot boxes were stuffed or trashed, voters were blocked from the precincts by supporters of candidates, among other irregularities.
SNT.251538.12246	Haitians rioted, plunging the process into chaos that was quelled by the determined efforts of foreign monitors.
SNT.251538.12247	Out of the original 19 candidates, two remained after the first round: Mirlande Manigat, age 70, a sedate, reserved university professor and wife of former president Leslie Manigat, and pop star "Sweet Micky" Martelly, age 50, who the The Washington Post described as being "a popular kompa singer [...] famous for dropping his pants on stage, mooning audiences, and dressing in drag — or sometimes a diaper."
SNT.251538.12248	However, Martelly has waged an energetic, well financed campaign with pink campaign posters picturing his smiling face and bald head, cultivating a populist image with Haiti’s poor.
SNT.251538.12249	He has been successful at marketing himself as an unpretentious outsider who will shake up the political system and yank the country out of its paralysis.
SNT.251538.12250	At the same time, he has courted the upper class with a platform containing pro-business promises and support for the return of the Haitian army.
SNT.251538.12251	The sedate personality of Manigat contrasts starkly with that of Martelly.
SNT.251538.12252	She portrays herself as a dignified, mature mother figure able to nurture Haiti through its troubles.
SNT.251538.12253	The determining factor may be the popular former president Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who returned two days ago to Haiti from South America after seven years in exile.
SNT.251538.12254	Aristide has not endorsed either candidate, but Aristide supporters, among those Haitians most desperately poor, have voiced support for Manigat.
SNT.251538.12255	Upon Aristide's arrival, there were banners saying, "My mother is here already.
SNT.251538.12256	Pierre-Marie Boisson, a private-sector economist in Haiti, sees the candidates as having similar platforms, promising jobs, housing and free education, even if their personal styles are so different.
SNT.251538.12257	"They have both promised the moon to the voters," he said.
SNT.251538.12258	He noted that this puts tremendous pressure on the winner to produce results quickly in a world where the price of food and fuel is rising.
SNT.251538.12259	As voting concluded, despite some irregularities such as missing ballots and late starts, authorities concluded the voting went well, without the pervasive fraud that marked the November election.
SNT.251538.12260	Colin Granderson, head of Organization of American States (OAS) observer mission, said the runoff election was a great improvement over the previous one.

SNT.80308.12275	The Fed hopes that by making it cheaper to borrow, people will start spending and investing more.

SNT.122591.12313	NASA has successfully launched Space Shuttle Discovery after over a month of delays.
SNT.122591.12314	Discovery lifted off at 7:43 p.m. (EDT) from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida in the United States after NASA declared the weather to be "100% go for launch".
SNT.122591.12315	"The clouds broke up and that's why we were go for launch," stated mission control on NASA TV.
SNT.122591.12316	A crystal clear blue sky could be seen in Discovery's background about 40 minutes before launch.
SNT.122591.12317	NASA earlier had made jokes about a small black bat attached to the rear of the external fuel tank delaying launch, but NASA assured it would not be a problem for launch.
SNT.122591.12318	NASA also said that there was a bat on STS-72 which managed to fly away just before the shuttle launched.
SNT.122591.12319	The current scheduled mission, STS-119, is set to fly the Integrated Truss Structure segment ("S" for starboard, the right side of the station, and "6" for its place at the very end of the starboard truss) and install the final set of power-generating solar arrays to the International Space Station.
SNT.122591.12320	The arrays consist of two 115-foot-long arrays, for a total wing span of 240 feet, including the equipment that connects the two halves and allows them to twist as they track the sun.
SNT.122591.12321	Altogether, the four sets of arrays can generate 84 to 120 kilowatts of electricity – enough to provide power for more than 40 average homes.
SNT.122591.12322	Commander Lee Archambault will lead Discovery's crew of seven, along with Pilot Tony Antonelli, and Mission Specialists Joseph Acaba, John Phillips, Steve Swanson, Richard Arnold, and Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency astronaut Koichi Wakata.
SNT.122591.12323	The next change scheduled the liftoff date for February 12, 2009.
SNT.122591.12324	It was then delayed until February 27, but was then delayed indefinitely on February 20 after NASA discovered an issue with the hydrogen control valves.

SNT.19121.12350	The country's state-owned energy monopoly, PLN, has not determined the immediate cause, and the country's president has ordered the national intelligence agency and police to investigate.
SNT.19121.12351	The blackout appears related to deficiencies in Indonesia's power generation capacity.
SNT.19121.12352	The power failure follows attempts to deal with the country's growing energy crisis, including conservation and trying to allow private companies to provide energy, which was ruled unconstitutional in 2004.
SNT.19121.12353	In January, the Indonesian government held a special energy summit to attract investment in their energy infrastructure.
SNT.19121.12354	At the summit they set the goal of adding 22,000 megawatts to Indonesia's present capacity of 23,000 megawatts, in order to support the country's growth.
SNT.19121.12355	The World Bank and others have warned that without more investment in the country's energy infrastructure an energy deficit will result.
SNT.19121.12356	"The power outage has resulted in worries over an energy crisis which could hurt the nation's industrial sector," said a trader on Indonesia's stock market.
SNT.19121.12357	The outage began at 10:23 a.m. local time, August 18, 2005, when power failed along the electrical system that connects Java, Bali, and Madura, causing outages in Java and Bali.
SNT.19121.12358	Almost half of the country depends on the electrical grid that experienced failures.
SNT.19121.12359	The blackout caused traffic jams in Jakarta, forced cancellation of several international and domestic flights at Jakarta's Soekarno-Hatta International Airport, shut down Jakarta's electric train service, and disrupted hospital operations.
SNT.19121.12360	Some larger hospitals were forced to delay surgeries while many smaller hospitals could not receive patients.
SNT.19121.12361	About 1,800 officers were called into action by Jakarta's metropolitan police to deal with short-term problems caused by the power failure.
SNT.19121.12362	Candles used in place of electric lighting started six fires in Jakarta alone.
SNT.19121.12363	Mulyo Aji, a PLN official, said more power failures are likely in the future as energy demand increases, without any corresponding new supplies of electricity scheduled to come online soon.

SNT.10942.12386	"After a thorough review of all aspects of the case, the Secretary General has decided that Mr. Joseph Stephanides be summarily dismissed for serious misconduct in accordance with UN staff regulations," relayed spokesman Stephane Dujarric.
SNT.10942.12387	"Mr Stephanides was advised accordingly yesterday and separated from service with immediate effect.
SNT.10942.12388	This is a disciplinary action for a breach of staff rules regarding procurement."
SNT.10942.12389	The investigation concluded that Stephanides infringed on regulations by helping the British company, Lloyds Register Inspection Ltd., win a contract under the UN programme for Iraq.
SNT.10942.12390	Mr. Stephanides acted as the head of the Security Council Affairs Division when he allegedly told the company how much to lower its price to be awarded a contract.
SNT.10942.12391	He denies any wrong-doing and hired a lawyer to defend himself.
SNT.10942.12392	Aged 59, Stephanides worked for the UN for 25 years, and was due to retire in September this year.
SNT.10942.12393	After a first food-for-oil interim report was released in February, Mr. Stephanides along with Benon Sevan were suspended.
SNT.10942.12394	Sevan, the former head of the oil-for-food programme for 6 years, was also accused of breach of procurement rules in the report co-written by Paul Volcker.
SNT.10942.12395	However, disciplinary measures against Sevan will not be carried out because of his status of diplomatic immunity.
SNT.10942.12396	A final report is scheduled for publication in three months which should further clarify whether Mr. Sevan received Iraqi oil allocations for a friend's company.
SNT.10942.12397	In the meantime, he remains suspended from all UN duties, and is being given only a symbolic salary of one dollar a year.
SNT.10942.12398	A central and unanswered question, is whether either Stephanides or Sevan profited directly by their actions in executing and implementing the complex programme.

SNT.158756.12482	Johnson died in a hospital at 0211 BST the next day from said wound.

SNT.158756.12484	He was told that the friend had no intention of shooting Johnson.
SNT.158756.12485	Therefore, no legal action has been taken against Johnson's friend accordingly.

SNT.158756.12487	As he turned he felt the gun to be heavy.
SNT.158756.12488	As it fell away he pulled it towards him and accidentally fired the trigger.
SNT.158756.12489	Rhys was holding himself to the chest—he thought he was joking then he thought he's shot Rhys in the hand.
SNT.158756.12490	He saw no blood and Rhys ran to the house."
SNT.158756.12491	The detective stated that the friend "was crying and apologizing for what happened."

SNT.158756.12493	Rhys would have shown interest in it from when he was about eight-years-old."

SNT.54576.12608	Students in hundreds of schools around New Zealand are given NCEA (National Certificate of Educational Achievement) credits for simple, everyday tasks, an investigation by The New Zealand Herald on Sunday shows.
SNT.54576.12609	The simple standards include: applying for a benefit, keeping healthy, talking and listening to a friend, wrapping a gift, dressing appropriately, washing clothes, working in a group, understanding the concept of friendship, ordering groceries either over the phone or in person.
SNT.54576.12610	One of the standards include coming to school on time and good behaviour for 20 days, it appears on the students records as: "Work and Study Skills: Demonstrate Care and Timeliness as an Employee".
SNT.54576.12611	Bill English, Member of Parliament for National and the education spokesman for National, said: "The easy credits demotivated students.
SNT.54576.12612	Take someone who's struggling with maths and works hard to get four or five credits - and then they see their mate getting three credits for holding a conversation...
SNT.54576.12613	That's something that children learn when they're 2, 3, 4...
SNT.54576.12614	All those standards are available to any student who goes to a school which is accredited to assess the standard internally.
SNT.54576.12615	The standards are not made up by the school but are real standards written by the New Zealand Qualifications Authority (NZQA).
SNT.54576.12616	The NZQA said, on Friday, that the standards would be marked down as "special supported learning" but recently they went back on that and said that now the credits are "mainstream and not differentiated on NCEA records."
SNT.54576.12617	The chief executive of NZQA, Bali Haque, said: "Level one was absolutely basic and the delivery of unit standards was a developing process.
SNT.54576.12618	The intention here is to recognise the learning that people have done, and give them credit for it."
SNT.54576.12619	Mr Haque admits that this system "is not perfect" but is adamant that schools will not exploit the imperfect system as to boost pass rates, unlike in 2004 when Cambridge High School used legitimate standards to boost pass rates.
SNT.54576.12620	The school used one standard that was titled "Interpersonal Communications: Participate in a team or group to complete routine tasks," and all the student had to do was pick up rubbish in a group.
SNT.54576.12621	The dean of education at the University of Auckland, John Langley, said: "The other standards are meaningless.
SNT.54576.12622	I turned 51 last week and I still can't gift wrap a parcel - and actually, it doesn't matter.
SNT.54576.12623	The authority needed to look at what the NCEA standards were and how they were applied."
SNT.54576.12624	"It is better to offer people those sorts of simple, unsophisticated qualifications than not to - as long as people understand the purpose," Mr Haque said.
SNT.54576.12625	The secondary principals' association head, Graham Young, said: "The NCEA system put pressure on schools to accumulate credits - and the easiest way to do that was to encourage students into internally assessed unit standards.
SNT.54576.12626	There are some very low-level unit standards which are extraordinarily easy to pass...
SNT.54576.12627	For people with above-average or average abilities to be using those unit standards is absolute nonsense."
SNT.54576.12628	Spokesman, Gilbert Peterson, for the employers and manufacturers association, said: "The titles of particular standards meant nothing to employers faced with a big grab bag of assessments.
SNT.54576.12629	Getting credits for doing the washing or talking to your mate is just amazing.
SNT.54576.12630	However Mr Haque said that he was confident employers would recognise the standards as basic, and that they were not misleading.

SNT.96450.12632	Australia took the remaining four wickets before the lunch break.

SNT.146935.12640	A suicide bomber at a volleyball game in northwestern Pakistan detonated a vehicle full of explosives Friday, killing at least 75 people and injuring scores more.
SNT.146935.12641	Some reports placed the number of dead as high as 88.
SNT.146935.12642	The explosion occurred in the town of Lakki Marwat in the North West Frontier Province, located nearby to the South and North Waziristan provinces, an area where Pakistani Taliban members are known to be active.
SNT.146935.12643	Reportedly, the attacker drove his car onto a volleyball field, where a game, being watched by many people, was being played.
SNT.146935.12644	Locals set up a militia and expelled the militants from this area.
SNT.146935.12645	This attack seems to be reaction to their expulsion," said, Ayub Khan, a local police chief, to media.
SNT.146935.12646	According to him, the attacker's vehicle contained 250 kilograms of highly intensive explosive material.
SNT.146935.12647	Buildings in the vicinity of the field, including a mosque were collapsed or damaged by the force of the blast.
SNT.146935.12648	"[W]e fear that some ten or so people might have been trapped in the rubble", Khan said.
SNT.146935.12649	Another security official, Khabib Khan, said that there were around three hundred people attending at the volleyball competition when the explosion happened.
SNT.146935.12650	We had it for the meeting, and for the tournament," he said to the Associated Press news agency over the telephone.
SNT.146935.12651	Malik Naveed, the provincial police chief, said to Voice of America that the attack may have been a retaliatory move against the residents of the town.
SNT.146935.12652	According to him, the village where the attack occurred was once considered a hub of Taliban fighters; however, he says, locals, with the help of authorities set up a militia force and either killed or expelled them from their area.
SNT.146935.12653	"These insurgents, they were not very happy about it and they were cut off because the people had risen against them.
SNT.146935.12654	So this was one way of taking revenge from these people," Naveed said.
SNT.146935.12655	This incident is the deadliest attack in Pakistan since October 28 of last year, when 112 people were killed by a car bomb in the city of Peshawar.
SNT.268775.12656	NASA's Cassini–Huygens spacecraft has discovered evidence for a large-scale saltwater reservoir beneath the icy crust of Saturn's moon Enceladus.
SNT.268775.12657	The data came from the spacecraft's direct analysis of salt-rich ice grains close to the jets ejected from the moon.
SNT.268775.12658	The study has been published in this week's edition of the journal Nature.
SNT.268775.12659	Data from Cassini's cosmic dust analyzer show the grains expelled from fissures, known as tiger stripes, are relatively small and usually low in salt far away from the moon.
SNT.268775.12660	Closer to the moon's surface, Cassini found that relatively large grains rich with sodium and potassium dominate the plumes.
SNT.268775.12661	The salt-rich particles have an "ocean-like" composition and indicate that most, if not all, of the expelled ice and water vapor comes from the evaporation of liquid salt-water.
SNT.268775.12662	When water freezes, the salt is squeezed out, leaving pure water ice behind.
SNT.268775.12663	Cassini's ultraviolet imaging spectrograph also recently obtained complementary results that support the presence of a subsurface ocean.
SNT.268775.12664	A team of Cassini researchers led by Candice Hansen of the Planetary Science Institute in Tucson, Arizona, measured gas shooting out of distinct jets originating in the moon's south polar region at five to eight times the speed of sound, several times faster than previously measured.
SNT.268775.12665	These observations of distinct jets, from a 2010 flyby, are consistent with results showing a difference in composition of ice grains close to the moon's surface and those that made it out to the E ring, the outermost ring that gets its material primarily from Enceladean jets.
SNT.268775.12666	If the plumes emanated from ice, they should have very little salt in them.
SNT.268775.12667	"There currently is no plausible way to produce a steady outflow of salt-rich grains from solid ice across all the tiger stripes other than salt water under Enceladus's icy surface," said Frank Postberg, a Cassini team scientist at the University of Heidelberg in Germany.
SNT.268775.12668	The data suggests a layer of water between the moon's rocky core and its icy mantle, possibly as deep as about 50 miles (80 kilometers) beneath the surface.
SNT.268775.12669	As this water washes against the rocks, it dissolves salt compounds and rises through fractures in the overlying ice to form reserves nearer the surface.
SNT.268775.12670	If the outermost layer cracks open, the decrease in pressure from these reserves to space causes a plume to shoot out.
SNT.268775.12671	Roughly 400 pounds (200 kilograms) of water vapor is lost every second in the plumes, with smaller amounts being lost as ice grains.
SNT.268775.12672	The team calculates the water reserves must have large evaporating surfaces, or they would freeze easily and stop the plumes.
SNT.268775.12673	"We imagine that between the ice and the ice core there is an ocean of depth and this is somehow connected to the surface reservoir," added Postberg.
SNT.268775.12674	The Cassini mission discovered Enceladus' water-vapor and ice jets in 2005.
SNT.268775.12675	In 2009, scientists working with the cosmic dust analyzer examined some sodium salts found in ice grains of Saturn's E ring but the link to subsurface salt water was not definitive.
SNT.268775.12676	The new paper analyzes three Enceladus flybys in 2008 and 2009 with the same instrument, focusing on the composition of freshly ejected plume grains.
SNT.268775.12677	In 2008, Cassini discovered a high "density of volatile gases, water vapor, carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide, as well as organic materials, some 20 times denser than expected" in geysers erupting from the moon.
SNT.268775.12678	The icy particles hit the detector target at speeds between 15,000 and 39,000 MPH (23,000 and 63,000 KPH), vaporizing instantly.
SNT.268775.12679	Electrical fields inside the cosmic dust analyzer separated the various constituents of the impact cloud.
SNT.268775.12680	"Enceladus has got warmth, water and organic chemicals, some of the essential building blocks needed for life," said Dennis Matson in 2008, Cassini project scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California.
SNT.268775.12681	"This finding is a crucial new piece of evidence showing that environmental conditions favorable to the emergence of life can be sustained on icy bodies orbiting gas giant planets," said Nicolas Altobelli, the European Space Agency's project scientist for Cassini.
SNT.268775.12682	"If there is water in such an unexpected place, it leaves possibility for the rest of the universe," said Postberg.

SNT.125160.12783	The expedition has found amulets, 22 bronze coins cast with Cleopatra's image and her name, a royal statue, an alabaster mask resembling Marc Antony, and a statue bust of Cleopatra.
SNT.125160.12784	"If you look at the face of Mark Antony, many believed he had this cleft on his chin and that's why I thought this could be Mark Antony," said Hawass.
SNT.125160.12785	"In my opinion, if this tomb is found, it will be one of the most important discoveries of the 21st century because of the love between Cleopatra and Mark Antony, and because of the sad story of their death.
SNT.125160.12786	This is the perfect place for them to be hidden," said Hawass.
SNT.125160.12787	Recently, outside the temple colourful mummies of nobles were excavated at a neighbouring necropolis.
SNT.125160.12788	These discoveries have lead the archaeologists to believe that a ruler or person of royalty is interred within the temple itself.
SNT.125160.12789	It was the practice of the Greco-Roman era to assemble the tombs of persons of status and other high ranking officials near their rulers.
SNT.125160.12790	"The discovery of the cemetery this week really convinced me that there is someone important buried inside this temple.
SNT.125160.12791	No one would be buried outside a temple without a reason.
SNT.125160.12792	We saw that in the pharaonic days, they were always buried beside pyramids," explained Hawass.
SNT.125160.12793	"She needed a place to be protected in the afterlife.
SNT.125160.12794	If she had used the other burial site, she would have disappeared forever," said Kathleen Martinez, a Dominican archaeologist.
SNT.125160.12795	She feels that "it could be Taposiris Magna because it was the most sacred temple of its time."

SNT.125160.12797	The temple was constructed about 300 BC by Ptolemy II.

SNT.107895.12852	Police in Indonesia have forwarded a 200-page brief concerning the Garuda Indonesia Flight 200 disaster to prosecutors.
SNT.107895.12853	The move comes as an indication that the trial of pilot-in-command Captain Marwoto Komar is set to commence within weeks.
SNT.107895.12854	The March 7, 2007 crash of a Boeing 737-400 at Yogyakarta International Airport killed 21 people.
SNT.107895.12855	119 others were able to escape the burning wreckage after the plane overshot the runway, going through the perimeter fence and crossing a road and an embankment to come to rest in a paddy field.
SNT.107895.12856	Most of the deceased were Indonesians, with five from neighbouring Australia also killed.
SNT.107895.12857	A final report was later issued after an investigation by Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee (NTSC) in October 2007.
SNT.107895.12858	The report blamed pilot error for the crash, finding that the airliner had touched down at roughly twice the accepted safe landing speed, and that Komar was "fixated" on landing and "probably emotionally aroused".
SNT.107895.12859	The Cockpit Voice Recorder indicated that he ignored fifteen activations of the Ground Proximity Warning System and a call from his co-pilot for a 'go-around' as the plane touched down.
SNT.107895.12860	A number of other criticisms were also leveled at the airport, the airline and transport politicians for contributing factors.
SNT.107895.12861	Komar is to be prosecuted over the crash for negligence.
SNT.107895.12862	His earlier arrest - which he was subsequently released from pending full charges - sparked protests from Indonesian aviation groups and criticism from international groups, including IFALPA, a powerful international airline pilots' association.
SNT.107895.12863	Evidence in his trial is set to include documentational evidence and aircraft wreckage, but it is unclear whether it will include the NTSC report.
SNT.107895.12864	Much controversy was caused by the suggestion it may be used, since international regulations limit the use of materials intended for safety investigations as evidence to prove liability in criminal or civil cases.
SNT.107895.12865	Kamal Firdaus, council for the pilot, explained what this means for his client: "Today the documentation has been officially accepted by the prosecutor," adding, "I suspect from this it will be two to three weeks until it is handed over to the court - that's the usual practice.
SNT.107895.12866	Firdaus commented that it would be "difficult" for liability to be established and that, "we are ready and it will be a very interesting legal case, so let's see what will happen in the court."
SNT.107895.12867	Komar, 45, is believed to be the first pilot prosecuted over an air accident in Indonesia despite the country's poor aviation safety record.
SNT.107895.12868	He is being charged with three counts of negligence, but the potential sentence is unclear, as Aero-News reports that he could face life imprisonment while The Age says he can face up to seven years' imprisonment.
SNT.107895.12869	His case is considered a landmark, with aviation groups believing his trial may set the precedent for pilots involved in future accidents.

SNT.16671.12888	The £1 million project will consist of a series of under-water turbines to be installed at Romney Weir in the nearby River Thames.
SNT.16671.12889	The system will generate 200kW, enough to meet approximately one third of the castle's electricity needs.
SNT.16671.12890	The electricity from the four turbines will not be sold into the local electricity grid, but will instead be directly connected to Windsor Castle's electrical system.
SNT.16671.12891	It will save 600 tonnes of carbon dioxide from being released into the atmosphere every year.
SNT.16671.12892	The scheme was announced after it gained planning permission from the local council, the plans having been submitted in February of last year.
SNT.16671.12893	A feasibility study will now be conducted, with construction scheduled to start next year.

SNT.768597.13023	Passengers were seen using emergency slides to escape the wreckage.
SNT.768597.13024	There have been no reports stating that the airplane pilot made distress calls before the accident.
SNT.768597.13025	Law enforcement does not believe the accident was the result of terrorism or criminal activity.
SNT.768597.13026	The National Transportation Safety Board will be investigating the crash.
SNT.768597.13027	The airport was closed to all incoming and outgoing air and vehicle traffic until 3:30 PM local time, when it opened 2 runways.

SNT.1203.13034	Romania's ruling Social Democrat Party (PSD) has emerged ahead in yesterday's legislative and presidential elections.
SNT.1203.13035	The voter turnout was around 57% of all eligible voters, which number 18 million people in a country of 21.7 million.
SNT.1203.13036	However the PSD did not gain the vote majority needed to declare an outright victory, and it will now proceed to a run-off election against the centre-left opposition.
SNT.1203.13037	Called the Truth and Justice Alliance, the main opposition is a union of candidates from the National Liberal Party and the Democrat Party.
SNT.1203.13038	While PSD+PUR is currently leading, the most hotly-contested election in Romania's post-Communist history may come down to the run-off, to be held on December 12.
SNT.1203.13039	The winning presidential candidate of the run-off will not only become the country's president but will also appoint a prime minister to lead the government.
SNT.1203.13040	In the presidential election, Adrian Năstase, the PSD's presidential candidate, won approximately 42% of the vote, while Traian Băsescu of Truth and Justice obtained around 35%, according to exit polls.
SNT.1203.13041	Năstase led the exit polls due to greater support in rural Romania, as well as support from the urban poor, due to his policy of boosting the economy.
SNT.1203.13042	Năstase's PSD+PUR coalition was also supported because they are credited with saving Romania from economic collapse during their presidential and legislative term from 2000 until the present time.
SNT.1203.13043	During his term of prime-minister of Romania, from 2000 to 2004, Năstase not only boosted the economy but ensured that Romania entered NATO and progressed towards its accession to the European Union, expected to occur in 2007.
SNT.1203.13044	In 2004, the economy is expected to grow by 8.6%, the highest rate in Europe.
SNT.1203.13045	Băsescu won a majority in Bucharest, Romania's capital, as well as in the wealthier cities of Transylvania.
SNT.1203.13046	Băsescu is supported by the educated middle-class, who take a favourable view upon his policy of stamping out corruption in one of the region's most corrupt countries.
SNT.1203.13047	Băsescu has also received a boost due to his liberalist policies and his proposal for tax reform and the introduction of a flat tax.
SNT.1203.13048	In the legislative election, the PSD+PUR coalition obtained 40% of the vote, while the Truth and Justice alliance trailed with 35%.
SNT.1203.13049	Because the PSD+PUR coalition did not gather the majority of the votes (50%+1), it will have to form a governing coalition with the minor parties, a process which is expected to be tedious given the fact that both of the major parties have ruled out entering into a coalition with ultra-nationalist The Greater Romania Party, which obtained around 12% of the vote.

SNT.143104.13051	A 22-year-old man has now been arrested by the police and taken away for questioning, so as to assist police with their enquiries.

SNT.257407.13069	A document revealed by Wikileaks, dated July 20, 2007, shows that Mr. Netanyahu, leader of the Likud party, urged an attack on Iran in exchange for joining the government at the time, led by Ehud Olmert.
SNT.257407.13070	Mr. Netanyahu's request was made as part of discussions to form a government of national unity between Likud and Mr. Olmert's Kadima party, according to the leaked cable, classified as "confidential" and penned by Marc.J. Sievers, who was at the US embassy in Tel Aviv as a political counselor.
SNT.257407.13072	An advisor to Mr. Netanyahu told American officials at the time that the Likud leader was willing to take the post of foreign minister, while Mr. Olmert would have become prime minister.
SNT.257407.13073	However, Mr. Netanyahu demanded military action against Iran as the price for his participation in the proposed coalition.
SNT.257407.13074	According to the advisor cited in the US cable, Mr. Netanyahu urged the Kadima leader to "galvanize Israel for action against Iran."

SNT.143568.13079	The government of Saudi Arabia removed an eleven-year ban on livestock imports from Somalia after fears of Rift Valley Fever were allayed, senior Somali officials said on Thursday.
SNT.143568.13080	The decision was well received across Somalia, as hundreds of thousands of farmers heavily rely on animal exports to the oil-rich Middle East.
SNT.143568.13081	Under the new arrangement, Saudi officials will closely examine animals before they are shipped off to Saudi soil.
SNT.143568.13082	"This is a tremendous decision for Somalis across the Horn of Africa," said Idiris Ibrahim Abdi, the livestock minister of Somaliland, the self-declared republic in northern Somalia, which has developed one of the most sophisticated animal processing plants in its port town of Berbera.
SNT.143568.13083	According to news accounts, the Saudi agricultural ministry said the decision is based on years of cross-examination and monitoring of animal farms in Somalia.
SNT.143568.13084	Animal trade is one of the few surviving economic engines of Somalia's largely destroyed economy.
SNT.143568.13085	Business leaders and animal farmers have largely welcomed the Saudi decision.
SNT.62298.13086	The National Hockey League (NHL) has handed down a season-long suspension, including the playoffs, to Chris Simon of the New York Islanders.
SNT.62298.13087	The suspension, for a minimum of 25 games, is a ruling for a hit Simon laid on Ryan Hollweg of the New York Rangers during a March 8 game at Nassau Veterans' Memorial Coliseum.
SNT.62298.13088	In a press release earlier today, the NHL indicated that they considered Simon's hit on Hollweg, with a stick to the face, to be a deliberate intent to injure.
SNT.62298.13089	"The National Hockey League will not accept the use of a stick in the manner and fashion in which Mr. Simon used his Thursday night," said Colin Campbell, NHL Senior Executive Vice President and Director of Hockey Operations.
SNT.62298.13090	After receiving a hard check from Hollweg, Simon swung his stick and delivered a two-handed blow to Hollweg's upper body, causing a cut on Hollweg's chin.
SNT.62298.13091	Based on his $1-million contract, which expires at the conclusion of the 2006-07 season, Simon forfeits a minimum of $80,213.90.
SNT.62298.13092	The suspension could carry over into the 2007-2008 hockey season, depending on how far the Islanders advance into the playoffs.
SNT.62298.13093	According to the NHL press release, if the Islanders do not qualify for the 2007 playoffs, or play fewer than 10 playoff games in the 2007 playoffs, Simon would serve additional games at the start of the 2007-08 regular season to satisfy the minimum term of the suspension.
SNT.62298.13094	Garth Snow, General Manager of the Islanders, indicated his support for Simon in a brief press release.
SNT.62298.13095	"I spoke with Colin Campbell this morning and he informed me of his decision.
SNT.62298.13096	Chris Simon has played a major role in our success this season and we will miss his presence in our lineup.
SNT.62298.13097	His regret is clearly evident in the statement he released last night.
SNT.62298.13098	Our entire organization supports Chris every step of the way."
SNT.62298.13099	In a statement March 10, prior to the verdict, Simon expressed regret for his actions.
SNT.62298.13100	"After watching the tape the morning after Thursday's game, I was disgusted.
SNT.62298.13101	There is absolutely no place in hockey for what I did.
SNT.62298.13102	I was grateful to learn that Ryan is okay and that he returned to the game.
SNT.62298.13103	My hope is to reach out to him in the near future."
SNT.62298.13104	Simon explains that his behavior may have been influenced by a hit he received less than a minute before his stick swinging incident.
SNT.62298.13105	When I saw the tape on Friday morning, it explained a lot to me when I saw the look on my face after being hit into the boards.
SNT.62298.13106	Simon didn't appear to let it excuse his hit on Hollweg.
SNT.62298.13107	"I need to make clear that this is not justification for the danger I put Ryan Hollweg in and the damage I have caused the game.
SNT.62298.13108	The Associated Press indicated that criminal charges against Simon are being considered.
SNT.62298.13109	According to a spokesperson for Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice, "no decision has been reached" on bringing charges, but that "prosecutors would review the tape."
SNT.131531.13110	Astronomers have discovered an extrasolar planet that may eventually collide into its sun.
SNT.131531.13111	The planet, called WASP-18b, orbits its star in under one day, and is 10 times larger than Jupiter.
SNT.131531.13112	The planet's name is derived from the group that discovered it, WASP (Wide Angle Search for Planets).
SNT.131531.13113	Tidal interactions between the planet and its star are pulling them together, and it will likely crash into its star in under one million years.
SNT.131531.13114	The planet is relatively much closer to its star than Earth is to the Sun.
SNT.131531.13115	Earth is a distance of 93 million miles from the sun, whereas WASP-18b is only 1.4 million miles from its star.
SNT.131531.13116	Professor Andrew Collier Cameron of St. Andrew's University commented on the inherent problems with the planet: "The problem with this planet is that it's very massive and very close to its star."
SNT.131531.13117	"It should be creating tidal bulging that makes it spiral into its star."
SNT.131531.13118	Coel Hellier of Keele University led a group of researchers that discovered the planet.
SNT.131531.13119	Their study of WASP-18b was published in the August 27 issue of the journal Nature.
SNT.131531.13120	Scientists had a 1 in 2,000 chance of discovering the planet.
SNT.131531.13121	There are 300 planets which are known to orbit stars other than the Sun.

SNT.33276.13138	The protesters consider that these caricatures insulted their prophet, and thus, they contend, their religion and themselves.

SNT.33276.13140	Some banners claimed that freedom of speech should not imply the possibility of insulting religious figures.
SNT.33276.13141	Other banners claimed that French society was applying dual standards.

SNT.33276.13143	Many of the female protesters wore a scarf to hide their hair, and some wore a hijab or veil.
SNT.33276.13144	The French government enacted a law prohibiting conspicuous religious symbols in government-operated schools, a move widely considered to be targeting the veil and scarf, which many consider a sign of subordination of females.
SNT.33276.13145	The protest was followed at a distance by a large complement of CRS and other police forces.
SNT.83139.13146	Libertarianz party president, Craig Milmine, and the party leader, Bernard Darnton, spoke exclusively to Wikinews journalist Gabriel Pollard about the political philosophy, libertarianism in New Zealand.
SNT.83139.13147	This article follows on from interviews with republican, Lewis Holden; and monarchist, Noel Cox.
SNT.83139.13148	The idea of libertarianism is where consent is required for all actions between people, and that these interactions are voluntary.
SNT.83139.13149	Over four million people will be given freedom to run their own lives as Mr Milmine said.
SNT.83139.13150	He says the Government doesn't follow this generally accepted principle.
SNT.83139.13151	"They take money without consent, order us around, and tell us what we can and cannot put in our bodies."
SNT.83139.13152	Their party website states, "We will put paid to bloated government bureaucracy and its authoritarian inclinations."
SNT.83139.13153	Mr Darnton said that one of the biggest jobs of Libertarianz is to show New Zealanders how their lives could be better.
SNT.83139.13154	"We just smile and get on with the next thing."
SNT.83139.13155	Libertarianz is, as Mr Milmine says, "principled opposition to the idea of a large nanny-state government in New Zealand."
SNT.83139.13156	"A burglar stealing your TV is in the wrong because they are taking without permission."
SNT.83139.13157	"The government steals a proportion of your wealth every year, the fact that they allow a minor amount of input from you into how they are going to distribute the stolen loot does not change the fact that they stole it in the first place."
SNT.83139.13158	Mr Darnton also describes the current system of governance as a game.
SNT.83139.13159	"What's right or wrong doesn't really matter as long as the red team or the blue team or whoever is scoring more points."
SNT.83139.13160	"The reason this political philosophy, underpinned by objectivism, isn't well accepted in the New Zealand culture is because New Zealanders are generally wary of major change, vote for the party they always have, and vote for the party they think will win, not the one they want to win," Mr Darton believes.
SNT.83139.13161	"These sorts of behaviour reinforce the big parties, even though neither have much to offer," Mr Darton said, "What Libertarianz is proposing is something quite different to anything any other party is putting forward."
SNT.83139.13161-2	Mr Milmine sees New Zealanders accepting libertarianism because, "Slowly people see that the government doesn’t solve their problems, it caused them in the first place." 
SNT.83139.13161-3	And when this is followed by a significant minority, Mr Milmine says, the change will happen very quickly.
SNT.83139.13162	Although Mr Milmine does say that he cannot predict what will happen to New Zealand if it were to change to a libertarianism state, "because it is asking me to predict the interactions of over four million people when they are given freedom to run their own lives."
SNT.83139.13163	As well as changing the system of Government, Libertarianz also propose New Zealand becoming a republic and removing the constitutional monarchy.
SNT.83139.13164	Mr Darnton said, "The monarchy is so distant in New Zealand that I don't think becoming a republic would make a big difference in many people's lives." 
SNT.83139.13164-2	Mr Milmine says, "A head of state has a valid role to play as a check on the power on the government, but it cannot perform this role if it is toothless."
SNT.83139.13165	Although Mr Darnton believes that New Zealand will eventually become a republic, he is wary of making a push to it too quickly.
SNT.83139.13166	He cites anti-prosperity and the governmental interference as issues that could make it into a written constitution and making it harder to shift later.
SNT.83139.13167	While Mr Milmine says they would run into problems with people disagreeing with the Treaty of Waitangi if it were placed into a written constitution.
SNT.83139.13168	And the final question asked to both Craig Milmine and Bernard Darnton was whether they were a Holden or a Ford fan.
SNT.83139.13169	Mr Milmine said he preferred "Subaru – I prefer the rallies – they allow more freedom" while Mr Darnton bluntly said, "No, I'm not."

SNT.81747.13191	He was Carrie Bradshaw, replete with a prodigious use of puns, before Sex and the City was a thought.

SNT.81747.13194	Musto, a Columbia University graduate, is a rarity in today's celebrity world: he is accessible.

SNT.187350.13198	According to Democratic Senator Mark Begich from Alaska, the U.S. Department of the Interior has decided to halt all new Arctic exploratory oil drilling applications until 2011.
SNT.187350.13199	The response is believed to be caused in part by the two current oil spill disasters (that of the Deepwater Horizon Incident and more recently the Alaska oil pipeline malfunction).
SNT.187350.13200	However, Begich is not happy about the actions taken by the White House.
SNT.187350.13201	"I am frustrated that this decision by the Obama administration to halt offshore development for a year will cause more delays and higher costs for domestic oil and gas production to meet the nation's energy needs," Begich claims.
SNT.187350.13202	Last September, the state of Alaska made a public notice about Shell's desire to drill off the coast of the Beaufort Sea, placing experimental drilling rigs at two drill site location: "Torpedo" and "Sivulliq".
SNT.187350.13203	"Shell is committed to undertaking a safe and environmentally responsible exploration program in the Chukchi Sea and Beaufort Sea in 2010," said Shell Oil Company President Marvin E. Odum to the U.S. Department of the Interior's Mineral Management Service (MMS).
SNT.187350.13204	Odum follows with, "I am confident that we are ready to conduct the 2010 Arctic exploratory program safely and, I want to be clear, the accountability for this program rests with Shell."
SNT.187350.13205	Chuck Clausen, director of the Alaska project at the National Resources Defense Council is not so optimistic:
SNT.187350.13205-2	"Hazards present in the Arctic can include frigid temperatures, presence of sea ice, gale-force winds, intense storms and heavy fog ..."
SNT.187350.13206	Odum believes that the climate in the arctic will make any spill easier to clean up because, "Arctic conditions create differences in responding to oil in cold and ice conditions."
SNT.187350.13207	"Differences in evaporation rates, viscosity and weathering provide greater opportunities to recover oil."
SNT.187350.13208	"In Arctic conditions, ice can aid oil spill response by slowing oil weathering, dampening waves, preventing oil from spreading over large distances, and allowing more time to respond."
SNT.187350.13209	However, Clausen believes that there are no current systems to remove oil from icy ocean waters.
SNT.187350.13210	This is not the first time that President Obama's administration has taken the environmentally cautious path in Alaska.
SNT.187350.13211	The President put Bristol Bay off limits to oil and gas exploration until 2017.
SNT.187350.13212	Bristol Bay currently is one of the top salmon fishing grounds in the state.
SNT.187350.13213	Interior Secretary Ken Salazar is expected to give a speech at Thursday's White House address, regarding the suspension of Arctic oil drilling projects.

SNT.34427.13225	Regional Partnerships program provides government assistance for projects in regional areas.
SNT.34427.13226	According to a government media release, there is $360.9 million available under this program for the period 2005-06 to 2008-09.

SNT.34427.13232	"I think the time will come when we will move on to new technology and some of those systems that were more important in the past will be less important in the future but there are still many Australians who still depend on payphones and community telephone systems."

SNT.149697.13234	A court martial got underway today accusing a Canadian soldier of murder for shooting a member of the Taliban on an Afghan battlefield.
SNT.149697.13235	Captain Robert Semrau's case is believed to be a military and legal first.
SNT.149697.13236	Semrau, 38, is facing four charges for the 2008 death.
SNT.149697.13237	He is accused of second-degree murder, attempted murder, behaving in a disgraceful manner, and negligently performing a military duty.
SNT.149697.13238	It is alleged that he shot the man twice despite him being an unarmed and "seriously wounded" prisoner.
SNT.149697.13239	Court documents set a scene in which 36-year-old Semrau was in charge of a small group of soldiers caught in an ambush on October 19 last year.
SNT.149697.13240	The Canadians were mentoring some new Afghan recruits, who were under British command.
SNT.149697.13241	A United States Apache assault helicopter provided assistance to the group, who were in Lashkar Gah, Helmand, strafing the area.
SNT.149697.13242	After beating back their attackers the soldiers discovered a fighter with injuries deemed to be so severe that medical aid would be ineffective, along with a dead man.
SNT.149697.13243	Shortly afterwards, with only Semrau near the man, two gunshots were heard.
SNT.149697.13244	At least one eyewitness claims to have watched Semrau shooting the militant with his field rifle.
SNT.149697.13245	Troops then moved on and the man's body was never recovered.
SNT.149697.13246	Captain Semrau was not investigated for two months, when his superiors heard of the alleged killing.
SNT.149697.13247	He was ultimately arrested by the Canadian Forces National Investigation Service a month later and charged.
SNT.149697.13248	He is now set to go on trial before Colonel Mario Duti, a military judge, and a five-member panel.
SNT.149697.13249	The Canadian Press contacted Michel Drapeau, a retired lawyer and colonel.
SNT.149697.13250	He says he believes it to be the first time Canada has launched a court martial for the death of a prisoner on the battlefield.
SNT.149697.13251	"I can't remember any such incidents in the past 50 years and in the Second World War, I don't believe there was such a court martial."
SNT.149697.13252	"There are a few recorded instances of alleged extra-judicial killing by Canadian soldiers, but no court martials for murder."
SNT.149697.13253	Two Canadian soldiers faced a murder charge for the death of a teenager in Somalia in 1993 but the case was dropped; some evidence emerged during the inquiry that suggested another man may also have been killed illegally.
SNT.149697.13254	More anecdotally, Canadians have been accused of similar murders in Korea and of shooting German prisoners for revenge during the second world war.

SNT.161255.13278	The United Nations and international aid agencies plan to immunize 85 million children under five.
SNT.161255.13279	More than 400, 000 volunteers and health workers will take part in the campaign, visiting children in their homes.
SNT.161255.13280	The current polio epidemic has been going on for a year and there have been outbreaks in the last six months in Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Chad, Guinea, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Senegal and Sierra Leone.
SNT.161255.13281	These countries will be the focus of the campaign, along with Benin, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Côte d'Ivoire, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea-Bissau, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.
SNT.161255.13282	Efforts last year failed to halt the disease because not enough children were vaccinated.
SNT.161255.13283	The program failed in part because local religious leaders told parents that the vaccines would sterilize their children, or cause AIDS.
SNT.161255.13284	As well as targeting more children, today's campaign features better training for volunteers.
SNT.161255.13285	Vaccinations will be repeated on 26 March in the six key countries, and again on 24 April for all 19 countries involved.

SNT.107318.13324	Doctors performing a Caesarian delivery in a Darwin, Australia hospital were stunned to discover a rare ovarian ectopic pregnancy.
SNT.107318.13325	According to Robin Cahill, general manager of the Darwin Private Hospital, ovarian pregnancies occur in only 1 in every 40,000 fertilisations.
SNT.107318.13326	An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilised egg implants in a woman's body in a location other than the uterus.
SNT.107318.13327	The most common place for an ectopic pregnancy to occur is the Fallopian tubes, accounting for roughly 95% of all ectopic pregnancies.
SNT.107318.13328	Ectopic pregnancies are generally discovered early, especially as they tend to cause bleeding in the mother, and tend to miscarry or be terminated due to the health risks they pose.
SNT.107318.13329	The mother, Meera Thangarajah, however, suffered no complications during her pregnancy, and an ultrasound performed mid-way through the pregnancy did not discover the complication.
SNT.107318.13330	The hospital's obstetrician Andrew Miller says that having an ovarian pregnancy survive to full-term is "unheard of".
SNT.107318.13331	The British Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists agrees, with a representative saying the odds of a successful ovarian pregnancy are "no more than one in a million", taking into account both the difficulty of bringing such a pregnancy to term and the tendency for the pregnancy to be terminated when it is discovered early.
SNT.107318.13332	The baby, a girl, was named Durga, a Hindu name meaning "goddess", and weighed 6 pounds 3 ounces (2.8 kg).
SNT.107318.13333	The father, Ravi Thangarajah, says that doctors told him he was "one of the luckiest men in the world".

SNT.175926.13413	This is the first time that the one hundred dollar note has been redesigned since 1996.

SNT.175926.13415	The Bureau of Engraving and Printing redesigned the series 2006 5, 10, 20, and 50 dollar notes previously.
SNT.175926.13416	The new one hundred dollar note will contain new security and design features.
SNT.175926.13417	Along with a new stylized portrait of Benjamin Franklin, the note also features a quill pen and inkwell on the obverse.
SNT.175926.13418	On the reverse it has a new larger printed '100' in gold lettering.
SNT.175926.13419	The new security features include a EURion constellation, a new more secure watermark, and a new feature called 'motion' which uses 650,000 micro lenses to create a moving image.
SNT.175926.13420	The note was originally slated for release in 2008 although budget constraints pushed the release date back to late 2009 or early to mid 2010.
SNT.175926.13421	The note will go into general circulation by early 2011.

SNT.113974.13423	The videos have been reported to be of anti-Scientology protests, recorded by various members of the group Anonymous.
SNT.113974.13424	In early September, an entity named American Rights Counsel LLC -- which has described itself as a 'rights group', but without provision of contact details -- requested the removal from YouTube of over 4,000 anti-Scientology videos.
SNT.113974.13425	Many of these videos consisted entirely of self-made content by anti-Scientology protesters; others were quite explicitly extracts from official Church of Scientology footage.
SNT.113974.13426	Users had initially speculated that Schaper was responsible for these requests; no evidence, however, has been obtained to this effect, nor has official comment been obtained from American Rights Counsel.
SNT.113974.13427	Wikinews contacted Schaper to find out why he made the new requests.
SNT.113974.13428	According to him, the videos were not of protests against Scientology, but instead were videos of alleged hate-crimes and hate-speech, which were allegedly attacking Schaper personally.
SNT.113974.13429	"The videos in question have been produced by an YouTube (U.K.) user to directly attack me and my companies."
SNT.113974.13430	"I made the requests in accordance with YouTube’s terms and condition, after confirming directly with YouTube and the local ECTF office in Los Angeles, to remove material that infringes on my copyright."
SNT.113974.13431	"None of the videos removed by YouTube fall under the fair use guidelines or can be considered news-worthy."
SNT.113974.13432	"The content of the videos has been classified by law-enforcement as hate-speech and frivolous attack."
SNT.113974.13433	"The producers of these videos are based in the U.K. and local law-enforcement has been contacted by the FBI," said Schaper to Wikinews.
SNT.113974.13434	When Wikinews asked Schaper if he was acting on behalf of the Church, Schaper denied any such involvement.
SNT.113974.13435	He also stated that he was not attempting to remove videos critical of him, or the Church, but also emphasizes other videos still on YouTube that are "a personal attack against me and my beliefs."
SNT.113974.13436	"Despite the fact that I am a Scientologist, none of the videos removed, where removed on behalf of the Church of Scientology or any organization associated with the church."
SNT.113974.13437	"In addition I like to point out that I have not removed any video, critical of me personally which does not violate my copyrights and I have no intention to do so," said Schaper.
SNT.113974.13438	In addition, Wikinews invited Dr. Schaper to comment on the apparent discrepancy between his actions and his advocacy of free speech.
SNT.113974.13439	Dr. Schaper feels that that the two stated aims are not in conflict, stating, "I believe the First Amendment but I also see how Anonymous tries to abuse these liberties."
SNT.113974.13440	"Not everything is protected under the free speech clause and laws have been enacted to protect each citizen from abuse."
SNT.113974.13441	Schaper also stated that Anonymous is "breaking the law" by uploading material to YouTube which could be considered hate crimes.
SNT.113974.13442	He also states that he would not mind a one-on-one conversation with some members of Anonymous, but "these guys don’t have the balls for a direct sit-down because they should get their facts straight."
SNT.113974.13443	"Anonymous is overstating a case and claims that their abuse and online bullying would be protected under the First Amendment forgetting the fact that they indeed are breaking the laws," added Schaper.
SNT.113974.13444	Schaper does not plan on enforcing the Church's copyrights saying, "they can handle their own content" and that he "will continue to enforce my copyrights and seek full prosecution in cooperation with federal law-enforcement."
SNT.113974.13445	Wikinews has contacted YouTube for a statement regarding this incident, but has yet to receive a response.
SNT.101427.13446	An exchange of handshakes at a Latin American summit Friday marked the end of the bitter dispute that had taken place between the nations of Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela over the past week.
SNT.101427.13447	The presidents of each country agreed to end the conflict, and said political ties would be reinstated.
SNT.101427.13448	"With the commitment of never attacking a brother country again and by asking forgiveness, we can consider this very serious incident resolved," said Ecuadorian president Rafael Correa, as the other Latin American leaders applauded.
SNT.101427.13449	The dispute was over Colombia's air strike against FARC rebels, which Ecuador accused of entering their territory.
SNT.101427.13450	As a result, Ecuador and their ally Venezuela had sent troops to their borders and severed ties with Colombia.
SNT.101427.13451	At the summit, Uribe charged Correa's government of having links with the FARC rebels, a charge that Correa quickly denied.

SNT.101427.13453	Uribe insisted that Ecuador has not done enough to fight the rebels, which was the reason the operation had to remain a secret, he said.
SNT.101427.13454	"We have not gotten cooperation from President Correa in the fight against terrorism."
SNT.101427.13455	Correa then advocated the creation of an international peacekeeping force to control the border, saying that Ecuador has become a victim of the fighting in Colombia.
SNT.101427.13456	Finally, it was Dominican president Leonel Fernandez plea for peace that ended the feud.
SNT.101427.13457	He requested that the presidents shake hands with each other, which they did, in a televised gesture viewed live across Latin America.
SNT.101427.13458	Nicaragua's president, Daniel Ortega, also agreed to reinstate diplomatic ties with Colombia after shaking hands with their president.
SNT.101427.13459	The leaders at the summit later approved a declaration in which Uribe apologized for the military operation and vowed never again to violate another nation's sovereignty.
SNT.101427.13460	It also mentioned a commitment to fight against threats posed by "irregular or criminal groups."

SNT.113699.13462	Improvements have been made in women health and education, according to the study.
SNT.113699.13463	The study calls for investments totaling over US$13 billion a year to achieve gender equality and women empowerment.
