SNT.113699.13467	These goals are eight international development goals that 189 United Nations member states and at least 23 international organizations have agreed to achieve by the year 2015.
SNT.113699.13468	They include halving extreme poverty, reducing child mortality rates, fighting disease epidemics such as AIDS, and developing a global partnership for development.
SNT.113699.13469	Education has improved in 82 countries out of 122 and are on track to meet their MD goals.
SNT.113699.13470	However, 19 countries, 13 of which are in Sub- Saharan Africa, are seriously off track to meet their target.

SNT.49452.13507	The panel's recommendation to allow women to inherit the throne was met with fierce criticism from conservatives.

SNT.45174.13525	This enables users of the two services to communicate with each other using their existing IM client, Microsoft's Windows Live Messenger (formerly MSN Messenger) and Yahoo! Messenger with Voice.
SNT.45174.13526	Users wishing to use the new feature can go to a special page on the service's website, where they have to review and accept an agreement.
SNT.45174.13527	After signing out and signing in again, the interoperability is enabled without downloading any new software.
SNT.45174.13528	The service is designed to allow users to see each others' online presence, view personal status messages, share select emoticons, view offline messages and add new contacts from either service.
SNT.45174.13529	However, more advanced features, like voice calls and shared folders are not interoperable between the two services.
SNT.45174.13530	The program is available internationally in more than 15 markets.

SNT.13427.13544	A reporter's notes subpoenaed by the U.S. District Court in Washington may show United States President George W. Bush's chief political advisor Karl Rove as one of the two sources behind the leaking of the identity of undercover CIA agent Valerie Plame, according to one or more anonymous sources cited by MSNBC.
SNT.13427.13545	However, Rove's lawyer, Donald Luskin, acknowledged that although Rove had communicated with Cooper shortly before Plame's identity was leaked, denied any wrongdoing on the part of his client, saying that "Rove absolutely did not identify Valerie Plame."
SNT.13427.13546	The notes are those of TIME magazine White House correspondent Matthew Cooper.
SNT.13427.13547	They were released by Norman Pearlstine, editor-in-chief of TIME Inc., by order of the court, in ruling that, in the case of leaking the identity of CIA agents, reporters must reveal the identity of their sources.
SNT.13427.13548	The court's ruling was based on the clause in Constitutional law summarized popularly with the phrase "Crying fire in a crowded theater": that when the degree to which the speech puts the safety of others at risk outweighs the degree to which it benefits others, so does their right to safety and security outweigh one's right to free expression.
SNT.13427.13549	The Supreme Court on Monday refused to hear the reporters' appeal of the case.
SNT.5454.13550	Nobel Laureate in Physics Hans Bethe died in his home in Ithaca, New York on March 6, 2005, according to Cornell University, where he was professor emeritus of physics.
SNT.5454.13551	Bethe, whose mother was Jewish, fled Germany in 1933 when the Nazi Party came to power.
SNT.5454.13552	Bethe, along with hundreds of other Jewish academics, were fired from their posts as a result of one of Adolf Hitler's first anti-Semitic acts.
SNT.5454.13553	Bethe moved first to England and in 1935 to the USA where he taught at Cornell University.
SNT.5454.13554	Between 1935 and 1938, he studied nuclear reactions and reaction cross sections.
SNT.5454.13555	This research was useful to Bethe in more quantitatively developing Niels Bohr's theory of the compound nucleus.
SNT.5454.13556	During World War II, he served as a prominent member of a special summer session at the University of California, Berkeley at the invitation of Robert Oppenheimer, which outlined the first designs for the atomic bomb and served as the beginning of the Manhattan Project.
SNT.5454.13557	When Oppenheimer started the secret weapons design laboratory, Los Alamos, he appointed Bethe as Director of the Theoretical Division.
SNT.5454.13558	After the war, Bethe argued that a crash project for the hydrogen bomb should not be attempted, though after President Truman announced the beginning of such a crash project, and the outbreak of the Korean War, he signed up and played a key role in the weapon's development.
SNT.5454.13559	In 1968, he reflected upon the choice, noting that "It seemed quite logical."
SNT.5454.13560	"But sometimes I wish I were more consistent an idealist."
SNT.5454.13561	Though he would see the project through to its end, in Bethe's account he was primarily hopeful that the weapon would be impossible to produce.
SNT.5454.13562	He later characterized Stanislaw Ulam was the "father" of the hydrogen bomb, and Edward Teller as its "mother," and himself as its "midwife."
SNT.5454.13563	Among his many honors, Bethe received the Max Planck medal in 1955, and in 1961 he was awarded the Eddington Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society for his work in identifying the energy generating processes in stars.
SNT.5454.13564	In 1967, Bethe was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for his studies of the production of solar and stellar energy, stellar nucleosynthesis.
SNT.5454.13565	He postulated that the source of this energy are thermonuclear reactions in which hydrogen was converted into helium.
SNT.5454.13566	During the 1980s and 1990s, Bethe campaigned for the peaceful use of nuclear energy, arguing against the nuclear arms race and against nuclear testing.
SNT.5454.13567	In 1995, at the age of 88, Bethe wrote an open letter calling on all scientists to "cease and desist" from working on any aspect of nuclear weapons development and manufacture.
SNT.5454.13568	In 2004, he signed a letter along with 47 other Nobel laureates endorsing John Kerry for president of the United States citing Bush's apparent misuse of science.

SNT.116776.13593	The European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) said on Monday that repairing the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) will cost up to €16.6 million or US$21 million.
SNT.116776.13594	The LHC, which is the world's largest and highest-energy particle accelerator, is located near the border of France and Switzerland and crosses the border four times.
SNT.116776.13595	It is designed to simulate the conditions shortly after the Big Bang, but it broke down on September 19 due to an electrical failure.
SNT.116776.13596	Most of the repair time is covered by previously scheduled maintenance time, and CERN originally hoped to have the machine up and running again by early May.
SNT.116776.13597	However, CERN officials now believe that it may take until the end of July or longer.
SNT.116776.13598	CERN spokesman James Gillies said:
SNT.116776.13598-2	 "If we can do it sooner, all well and good."
SNT.116776.13599	"But I think we can do it realistically by early summer."
SNT.116776.13600	The machine operates at temperatures colder than outer space and must be gradually warmed up for experts to assess the damage, causing much of the delay.
SNT.116776.13601	CERN expects the repair cost to fall within the annual budget for the project.

SNT.25863.13693	The U.S. Senate has adopted an amendment, proposed by Senator Lindsey Graham (R-SC), to a defense bill limiting detainees' court privileges.
SNT.25863.13694	The amendment would make the Combat Status Review Tribunal (CSRT) statutory law, the Annual Review Board (ARB) statutory law, require the designated civilian officer to be a government official who is appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, not allow the preponderance of evidence against a detainee be derived from undue coercion, and remove Guantanamo prisoners' right to file habeas corpus petitions in federal courts.
SNT.25863.13695	In regards to the habeas corpus provision, the amendment specifically states, "No court, justice, or judge shall have jurisdiction to hear or consider an application for a writ of habeas corpus filed by or on behalf of an alien outside the United States (as that term is defined in section 101(a)(38) of the Immigration and Naturalization Act (8 U.S.C. 1101(a)(38)) who is detained by the Department of Defense at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba."
SNT.25863.13696	Five Democrats jumped party lines to vote for and four Republicans jumped party lines to vote against the amendment.
SNT.25863.13697	Nine Senators, seven Republicans and two Democrats, did not vote on the amendment.
SNT.25863.13698	Kent Conrad, Mary Landrieu, Joseph Lieberman, Ben Nelson, and Ron Wyden were the Democrats who voted for the amendment.
SNT.25863.13699	Arlen Specter, Lincoln Chafee, Gordon Smith, and John Sununu were the Republicans who voted against the measure.
SNT.25863.13700	Senator Graham is quoted as saying, "The president has established procedures to determine who is an enemy combatant and to annually review their status."
SNT.25863.13701	"It’s now time for Congress to sign-off on these procedures and turn them into a statute, a move the courts will give great deference to."
SNT.25863.13702	It should be noted that under Graham's amendment, detainees would be able to challenge only the narrow question of whether the procedures established by the Secretary of Defense at the time the military determined their status as an enemy combatant were followed.
SNT.25863.13703	The Court of Appeals for the DC circuit would still retain the ability to rule on that question.
SNT.25863.13704	Civil liberties groups as well as human rights groups issued statements opposing the amendment.
SNT.25863.13705	"The Graham amendment will create a thousand points of darkness across the globe where the United States will be free to hold people indefinitely without a hearing and beyond the reach of U.S. law and the checks and balances of the courts enshrined in our Constitution," the Center for Constitutional Rights said in a statement.
SNT.25863.13706	"The Graham amendment would strip all courts, including the Supreme Court, of jurisdiction to consider habeas corpus petitions or any other action challenging any aspect of the detention of foreign detainees held at Guantanamo Bay, except for the narrow question of whether status review boards follow their own rules," said a press release from the American Civil Liberties Union.

SNT.107249.13741	At least three fire companies started battling the blaze, which engulfed the entire warehouse, sending a plume of smoke into the air which could be seen for several miles, at one point darkening the sky.
SNT.107249.13742	All 12 firefighters are being treated at Erie County Medical Center, but their conditions are not known.
SNT.107249.13743	At least 80 firefighters were reported to be on scene along with a total of nine of the 19 fire companies in Buffalo.
SNT.107249.13744	Firefighters were still on scene as of 9:15 a.m. EDT (UTC-4) today, nearly 24 hours after the fire started.
SNT.107249.13745	The fire started at the Leisure Living Pool Supplies warehouse at 1130 Niagara street between West Ferry and Albany streets behind the Rich Products building at around 10:30 a.m. Monday and was not brought under control until 6:30 a.m. today.
SNT.107249.13746	Firefighters had the fire under control just before 12:00 p.m. Monday, but wind off Lake Erie reignited the fire at around 3:00 p.m.
SNT.107249.13747	At around 7:00 p.m., most of the blaze was under control, but smoke could still be seen coming from the building.
SNT.107249.13748	All employees from both Rich's and the chemical company have been sent home for the day and made it out safely.
SNT.107249.13749	The building is owned by PoolSupplies.com which is a division of Leisure Living, selling supplies, recreation and chemicals for swimming pools.
SNT.107249.13750	At 9:00 p.m., firefighters reported that most of the fire was contained under the collapsed portions of the building, but around 10:00 p.m. firefighters reported that more thick black smoke started to rise from the building.
SNT.107249.13751	Black smoke usually indicates burning, whereas white smoke often indicates water putting out a fire.
SNT.107249.13752	Firefighters are using a helicopter, courtesy of the Erie County Sheriff's Department, that is equipped with infrared cameras in order to see the areas of the building which still contain a significant amount of heat or fire.
SNT.107249.13753	After having fought the fire for over 24 hours, fire officials stated that the fire was mostly extinguished and ordered fire companies to start shutting down the hoses and pack up their equipment.
SNT.107249.13754	Just before 1:00 p.m. the fire command post stated that fire investigators were on scene and that "they can call us (firefighters) back if they need anything."
SNT.107249.13755	Officials have urged all residents near the blaze to stay indoors and to shut all windows and doors due to the smoke which has been blowing close to the ground.
SNT.107249.13756	At least one civilian who was inside a park at the foot of Ferry was also taken to the hospital for smoke and chemical inhalation.
SNT.107249.13757	Officials were able to evacuate the park and no other injuries were reported.
SNT.107249.13758	At one point, the sun was blocked by the black smoke rising from the building.
SNT.107249.13759	It appears it reignited due to the earlier collapse of the roof and the winds off the lake.
SNT.107249.13760	"Right now, one thing fire officials would like to get out and stress is anyone in and around the Niagara and Ferry area, if you could please go indoors, and shut your doors," stated Michael DeGeorge, a spokesman for the Buffalo Police Department, to reporters.

SNT.107249.13762	At 11:15 p.m., firefighters stated they would begin to reopen the lane.

SNT.107249.13765	Temperatures were quite warm, in the upper 70's (F), with winds gusting to nearly 15-20 MPH, coming out of the southwest.
SNT.107249.13766	Although the wind assisted in reigniting the fire, it also assisted firefighters by quickly clearing the area of smoke.
SNT.107249.13767	The warehouse is a storage and distribution facility for pool chemicals, especially chlorine.
SNT.107249.13768	Chemical drops could be felt flying through the air, which also had the smell of bleach.
SNT.107249.13769	According to a source who spoke to Wikinews on condition of anonymity, the warehouse contained over US$8 million in supplies and chemicals.
SNT.107249.13770	Earlier tests performed on the air by firefighters and Haz-mat officials had shown that the smoke and fumes rising from the fire are not dangerous or toxic.
SNT.107249.13771	Further tests were performed, but those results are not yet known and officials don't believe there was any danger to the air.

SNT.107249.13773	The warehouse is located just down stream from a drinking water pumping station with several more scattered along the River from Buffalo to Niagara Falls.
SNT.107249.13774	The cause of the fire is not known and is under investigation.

SNT.107249.13776	Smoke from that fire was seen over 40 miles away.

SNT.2948.13806	Rabies is a disease that has no cure and nearly everyone it infects is dead just two weeks after the symptoms show.
SNT.2948.13807	And yet, last week a teenage girl named Jeanna Giese was released from a hospital having been successfuly treated.
SNT.2948.13808	She became the first known person to recover from the disease without vaccination.
SNT.2948.13809	On September 12, 2004, Jeanna — a 15 year old from Fond du Lac, Wisconsin— was bitten by a bat while attending church.
SNT.2948.13810	By the time she saw a doctor about fatigue and numbness, it was October 18, and the bat incident was not brought up until several days later.
SNT.2948.13811	Usually when there is a possibility of rabies, doctors will vaccinate patients: the vaccine has a chance to act before the symptoms appear.
SNT.2948.13812	In Jeanna's case it was too late to try to vaccinate, and her doctors at the Children's Hospital of Wisconsin devised a new treatment.
SNT.2948.13813	Jeanna was put into a drug-induced coma for a week, and doctors began an intensive treatment to prop up her nervous system until her natural immunity recovered enough to fight the disease.
SNT.2948.13814	By surviving and recovering, Jeanna became the only person known in medicine to overcome rabies without a vaccine.
SNT.2948.13815	She is not yet fully recovered: the effects of the coma are still apparent, and she has difficulty with movement.
SNT.2948.13816	Yet the doctors believe that she is getting well much faster than they expected, and feel that Jeanna will be able to return to her high school studies, needing only physical and occupational therapy.
SNT.2948.13817	The novel treatment is hailed by doctors as promising, but needs analysis and verification on another human.
SNT.2948.13818	Jeanna's is the sixth case of human recovery from a rabies infection, but the other five people were vaccinated against rabies either before infection, or before the symptoms appeared.

SNT.26984.13820	Along with his wife, Jan Berenstain, Stan and Jan Berenstain published over 200 books aimed at teaching children to read and helping them with lessons such as sharing, new siblings.
SNT.26984.13821	The first Berenstain Bears book was published in 1962 and titled "The Big Honey Hunt".
SNT.26984.13822	With the help of head of children's publishing at Random House, author Theodor Geisel, better known as Dr. Seuss, the Berenstains created a franchise that drew millions of young readers.
SNT.26984.13823	Until 1997, when they hired an employee to run the company's computer, Mr. Berenstain and his family managed the entire ursine enterprise, which has branched out into two television series, videos, stage musicals, toys, cereal and other products.
SNT.26984.13824	According to an interview of the Berenstain Bears official website, Papa Bear is based on Stan, Mama on Jan; Stan clarifies that he's "not as stupid" as Papa.
SNT.26984.13825	Stan fed his interest in drawing as a child, by drawing on paper bags and cardboard.

SNT.65593.13827	He was studying English and lived on the university campus.
SNT.65593.13828	The President of Virginia Tech, Charles Steger said in an interview that the "possibility exists" that more than one gunman was involved.
SNT.65593.13829	"It appears that the second shooter was a resident in our dormitory... it appears he was an on-campus resident," Steger said.
SNT.65593.13830	Ballistic reports confirm that the same gun was used in both instances of the campus shootings, but police could not confirm if the shooter was the same.
SNT.65593.13831	The shootings on Monday were in two separate locations, and occurred two hours apart.
SNT.65593.13832	The first took place at 07:15 (12:15 UTC), at West Ambler Johnston Hall dormitory.
SNT.65593.13833	Then, at about 09:15 (14:15 UTC), 30 people were killed in the second shooting, about half a mile (800 metres) from the first at the Norris Hall classroom building, on the same campus.
SNT.65593.13834	Bodies were found in four classrooms and a stairwell, according to Virginia state police superintendent Col. Steve Flaherty.
SNT.65593.13835	Some students complained that they had received no warning from the university until an e-mail alert sent more than two hours after the first incident.
SNT.65593.13836	The university has suspended classroom courses for one week, and Norris Hall will remain closed for the rest of the semester.
SNT.65593.13837	University officials have expressed an interest in developing a text messaging alert system where persons can add their phone number to a list for notification in the event that incidents may warrant the use of caution or extra attention.
SNT.65593.13838	In a reaction to the school massacre, the gun control group Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence asks for "common-sense actions to prevent tragedies like this from continuing to occur".
SNT.65593.13839	The New York Times ran an editorial with a similar message for gun control.
SNT.104603.13840	In a unanimous 95-0 vote Thursday, the United States Senate passed a bill that would forbid employers and health insurance companies from discriminating against someone based on information learned through genetic testing.
SNT.104603.13841	The Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act, described by Massachusetts Senator Ted Kennedy as "the first major new civil rights bill of the new century," will now be sent back to the House of Representatives, where it could be approved as early as next week.
SNT.104603.13842	President George W. Bush, who would have to sign the bill for it to become law, has voiced his support for the legislation.
SNT.104603.13843	The bill forbids employers from firing, refusing to hire, or otherwise discriminating against employees based on genetic information, such as a family history of a hereditary disease.
SNT.104603.13844	It also makes it illegal for employers to request genetic information of an employee or the employee's family.
SNT.104603.13845	Health insurance companies are also addressed in the bill, which forbids them from requesting genetic information or using such information to set premium rates or determine enrollment eligibility.
SNT.104603.13846	However, insurance companies would still have the right to base one's health coverage on the actual presence of a genetic disease.
SNT.104603.13847	"For the first time we act to prevent discrimination before it has taken firm hold and that's why this legislation is unique and groundbreaking," said Maine Senator Olympia Snowe, who sponsored the bill along with Sen. Kennedy and Sen. Mike Enzi.
SNT.104603.13848	Snowe fears the threat of discrimination may discourage people from undergoing genetic testing, which can help to diagnose a wide range of diseases and lead to lifesaving therapy.
SNT.104603.13849	Kathy Hudson, director of the Genetics and Public Policy Center, reports that 92 percent are worried that information gained in genetic testing may be used against them.
SNT.104603.13850	"After a very long wait," she says, "Americans can now be confident that their genetic information cannot be used by health insurers or employers in harmful or hurtful ways."
SNT.104603.13851	"Federal legislation establishing a national and uniform basic standard is necessary to fully protect the public from discrimination and allay their concerns about the potential for discrimination," the bill reads, "thereby allowing individuals to take advantage of genetic testing, technologies, research, and new therapies."
SNT.104603.13852	Oklahoma Senator Tom Coburn initially blocked Senate action on the bill, warning that it could potentially lead to excessive lawsuits against employers and insurers.
SNT.104603.13853	But after changes were made to the bill to ease his concerns earlier this week, he supported the legislation and allowed the Senate to vote on it.
SNT.104603.13854	"We certainly improved the bill from a liability standpoint," said Coburn, an obstetrician.
SNT.104603.13855	Similar bills were unanimously passed by the Senate in 2003 and 2005, but in both years the bill stalled in the House.
SNT.104603.13856	The current bill was passed in the House of Representatives a year ago by a 420-3 vote.
SNT.104603.13857	A genetic nondiscrimination bill was first introduced 13 years ago by New York Representatives Louise Slaughter, who says the House will "get it out to the White House as quickly as we can."

SNT.18583.13859	The former assistant deputy replaces Comey as the acting boss of Patrick Fitzgerald, the lead prosecutor of the Plame CIA leak case.

SNT.28359.13881	Survivors of the London Bombings have urged the British public to write to their MPs, and set up an online petition calling for an independent Public Inquiry into the attacks.
SNT.28359.13882	52 people were killed and hundreds more injured on July 7th 2005 when four suicide bombers blew themselves up on three separate London Underground trains and a public bus.
SNT.28359.13883	Earlier this week the British government rejected calls for a Public Inquiry, arguing that such an investigation would be too expensive, take too long, and be a distraction from their efforts to combat terrorism.
SNT.28359.13884	Instead, the government has offered to put together a "narrative of events".
SNT.28359.13885	But survivors of the attack argue that a fully comprehensive investigation could teach valuable lessons which may help reduce the likelihood of future attacks, and improve the response capabilities of the emergency services.
SNT.28359.13886	Some survivors, such as Rachel North (a pseudonym), who has been active in organising a support group for her fellow victims, have been angered by the government's alternative proposal of a "narrative".
SNT.28359.13887	Writing on the weblog she started to help her, and others, come to terms with the aftermath of July 7th, Ms North says:
SNT.28359.13888	"Even if you don't like the questions, don't like the answers, think you know the answers already, Mr Blair, it is us, not you, who are paying the cost for this…"
SNT.28359.13889	"If the cost of answering questions makes you squirm, then too bad..."
SNT.28359.13890	"We run the risks on the trains, the buses, the streets each day…"
SNT.28359.13891	"How dare you presume you know our questions and how dare you presume that they can be answered by a 'narrative of what happened', as if we are children to be placated with a story."
SNT.28359.13892	"We are constantly reminded that this is the worst peace time bombing London has ever seen, for something that bad there should be an inquiry."
SNT.28359.13893	"People died, families lost someone they loved and hundreds are still suffering."
SNT.28359.13894	"You can't put a price on that but apparently the government can."
SNT.28359.13895	"If nothing else, an enquiry would make sure some of these lessons were learnt in case, God forbid, anything like this happened again."
SNT.28359.13896	"I thought there were plans in place for emergencies such as this."
SNT.28359.13897	"Whilst the emergency services did a fantastic job on the day, I have been stunningly underwhelmed by the support offered to victims since."
SNT.28359.13898	"An anonymous survivor, writing on the 'Yorkshire lass' website, says:"
SNT.28359.13899	"'When I watched the Al-Qaeda video declaring Jihad against the UK I was haunted by the familiarity of the voice, it was my voice, my accent, my dialect."
SNT.28359.13900	"This is not a man who was recruited and trained in some far off country that I have barely heard of, this was a man who was recruited and trained while he lived 20 minutes from my mother's home where I was born and raised."
SNT.28359.13900-2	"The words he spoke of are words similar to what I have heard many times from disillusioned young men that I studied for my A Levels with."
SNT.28359.13901	"They are the words of hatred I overheard when I worked as a support worker at my local college."
SNT.28359.13902	"They were words of students who were educated... when someone follows through with the actions of those opinions to the detriment of others, questions need to be asked why preventions were not put in place and this needs to be done by public inquiry for peace of mind."
SNT.28359.13902-2	"I have been told that I am looking for justice in the wrong place and in some way that is right."
SNT.28359.13903	"However, I want some sort of justice, some manner of peace of mind, some questions answered and resolutions made."
SNT.28359.13904	"I don't want others to have to go through what myself and hundreds of other commuters did on that Summer's day."

SNT.28359.13906	"The families will be campaigning for there to be a full public inquiry..."

SNT.46351.13908	The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution today demanding Iran halt all "enrichment-related and reprocessing activities, including research and development" before August 31.
SNT.46351.13909	The resolution was passed under Article 40, Chapter VII of the UN Charter, which sets the stage for possible economic sanctions if Iran does not comply with the resolution, but does not authorise military action.
SNT.46351.13910	The resolution, number 1696, was drafted by the permanent five members of the council and was passed by a 14-1 vote, with Qatar, the only Arab member of the council voting against.
SNT.46351.13911	The resolution expressed "serious concern" at Iran's non-compliance with the IAEA's demand to halt enrichment and other activities and asked the IAEA director to report on Iran's compliance by the end of August.
SNT.46351.13912	This is the first legally binding demand on Iran to halt enrichment work, and the first to suggest possible sanctions.
SNT.46351.13913	The resolution says that "appropriate measures" will be taken if Iran does not comply, but does not explicitly state any threat of sancions.
SNT.46351.13914	Iran's ambassador to the UN, Javad Zarif told the Reuters news agency, "Iran's peaceful nuclear programme poses no threat to international peace and security and therefore dealing with this issue in the Security Council is unwarranted and void of any legal basis or practical utility,"
SNT.46351.13915	Valery Churkin, Russia's ambassador to the UN said the deadline was meant to meet Iran's request to allow it to consider an offer made in June by the permanent five and Germany, offering Iran a "package" of sops in return for giving up enrichment activities.
SNT.6188.13916	The trial against internet file-sharing network Kazaa in Sydney, Australia, is coming to an end, as closing arguments began today.
SNT.6188.13917	Kazaa pleaded it could not be held responsible for the copyright infringements perpetrated by its users, as it cannot control how the software is used.
SNT.6188.13918	The peer-to-peer distribution software and its owner, Sharman Networks Ltd. and its directors were sued by a group of Australian record labels for copyright infringements by the network's estimated 100 million members worldwide.
SNT.6188.13919	Members of the software share music files with each other, and download up to three billion songs and music files monthly.
SNT.6188.13920	The music industry claims it has lost millions of dollars in unpaid royalties as a result.
SNT.6188.13921	Lawyer Tony Meagher argued that Sharman is no more responsible for the uses of its software than the designers of the photocopiers and video recorders were responsible for the illegal copying of materials on those machines.
SNT.6188.13922	The remaining question is whether Kazaa authorises its users to download files illegally.
SNT.6188.13923	"We tell these users in our Web site and we tell them in our license that they cannot use this (software) for infringing copyright," Meagher told Judge Murray Wilcox.
SNT.6188.13924	By consenting to this license by users, Kazaa is exempted from responsibility.
SNT.6188.13925	The record industry claims Kazaa not only enables but encourages copyright infringement.
SNT.6188.13926	Record industry lawyer Tony Bannon argued that as Kazaa collected information from its users through spyware and sold it to advertisers, the company's claim that it had no control over the software was "completely mind boggling."
SNT.6188.13927	This is not the first trial against Kazaa, and other programs of its kind.
SNT.6188.13928	In August last year, Judge Stephen Wilson ruled that the distribution by Grokster and Morpheus of peer-to-peer software does not violate U.S. copyright law.
SNT.6188.13929	Rod Dorman, lead trial council for Sharman Networks in the U.S., said, "As a result of this decision, Sharman Networks will be filing a motion for summary judgement, nearly identical to the successful motions filed by Grokster and Morpheus, and we are confident that Judge Wilson will find that our product, Kazaa, is a lawful product as well."
SNT.6188.13930	However, the ruling held no precedential effect in the Australian trial, as the principles differed.
SNT.6188.13931	Kazaa and the FastTrack protocol are the brainchild of the Scandinavians Niklas Zennström and Janus Friis, and were introduced in March 2001 by their Dutch company Consumer Empowerment.
SNT.6188.13932	It appeared during the end of the first generation of P2P networks.

SNT.7922.13944	In July 2004, Romania will revalue its currency, the leu, so that 10,000 old lei will equal 1 new leu, with 1 euro being equal to approximately 3.6 new lei.
SNT.7922.13945	Dual pricing, in both the old leu and the new leu, has already been introduced from March 2005.
SNT.7922.13946	The transition to the new leu is expected to stabilise the Romanian currency and prepare the country for euro adoption.
SNT.7922.13947	In Romania's case, the adoption will take place 5-7 years after accession in 2007.

SNT.39901.13957	For countries where the MM/DD/YY convention is more common, the event happened a month ago on 5th April.
SNT.39901.13958	The date attracted numerous comments when posted to the news website Digg, and the special date has been mentioned by hundreds of thousands of websites, according to a Google search.
SNT.39901.13959	Whilst 01:02:03, 04/05/06 won't happen again for another hundred years, those who missed out might want to celebrate 06:06:06, 06/06/06 in just over a month's time, unless you're a hexakosioihexekontahexaphobic.

SNT.115160.13973	The memos were issued to the CIA in 2003 and 2004 as classified documents in response to the department's former director George Tenet's request for White House approval.
SNT.115160.13974	"The CIA believed then, and now, that the program was useful and helped save lives," commented a former CIA official, explaining the memos.
SNT.115160.13975	"But in the agency's view, it was like this:"
SNT.115160.13975-2	We don't want to continue unless you tell us in writing that it's not only legal but is the policy of the administration'.
SNT.115160.13976	In private meetings led by then-National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice, top administration officials Vice President Cheney, Attorney General Ashcroft and several former members of the administration discussed the endorsement of the programs.
SNT.115160.13977	No one at the meetings had questioned the methods because the CIA had them "boxed in", a former official noted.
SNT.115160.13978	"They were saying, 'It's the only way to get the information we needed, and — by the way — we think there's another attack coming up'."
SNT.115160.13979	Another official, however, called the idea that the CIA had coerced the Bush administration into approving the torture methods "ridiculous".
SNT.115160.13980	The CIA, he said, understood the methods were "controversial and would be widely criticized if it became public".
SNT.115160.13981	Tenet said that in a 2001 meeting with top administration officials, Rice had warned those attending of an impending attack by a top Al-Qaeda suspect, Abu Zubaydah.
SNT.115160.13982	Bush had asked a CIA staffer if the methods really worked.
SNT.115160.13983	Ashcroft had commented during the meetings that "history will not judge us kindly".
SNT.115160.13984	Last month, Rice stated that there was concern over the legality of the program and that she was investigating if any laws had been broken.
SNT.53142.13985	The annual Living Planet Report compiled by the Zoological Society of London and the Global Footprint Network, published this week by WWF International, assessed "the health of the planet's ecosystems" and measured the demands people make on the planet's resources.
SNT.53142.13986	The Living Planet Index is based on population trends between 1970 and 2003 of over 3 600 populations of more than 1 300 vertebrate species from around the world.
SNT.53142.13987	There has been an overall decline of around 30 per cent over the 33-year period.
SNT.53142.13988	Tropical species populations declined by around 55 per cent on average from 1970 to 2003, while temperate species populations, have shown little overall change.
SNT.53142.13989	The Ecological Footprint measures the area of biologically productive land and sea required to sustian humanity.
SNT.53142.13990	In 2003 this was 14.1 billion global hectares, or 2.2 global hectares per person (a global hectare is a hectare with world-average ability to produce resources and absorb wastes).
SNT.53142.13991	The total supply of productive area, or biocapacity, in 2003 was 11.2 global hectares, or 1.8 global hectares per person.
SNT.53142.13992	Demand overshot supply first in the 1980s and has been increasing every year since.
SNT.53142.13992-2	By 2003 the overshoot was about 25 per cent.
SNT.53142.13993	Thus, it took approximately a year and three months for the Earth to produce the ecological resources humanity used in that year.
SNT.53142.13994	The Living Planet Index and the Ecological Footprint, along with other measures, have been adopted as indicators for the 2010 targets of the Convention on Biological Diversity.
SNT.53142.13995	The report concludes with a description of the roles of the various disciplines required to "shift humanity's current trajectory on to a path that will remain within the biological capacity of the planet".
SNT.53142.13996	James P. Leape, the Director General of WWF International summarises: 
SNT.53142.13996-2	"The message of these two indices is clear and urgent:"
SNT.53142.13996-3	"we have been exceeding the Earth's ability to support our lifestyles for the past 20 years, and we need to stop."
SNT.53142.13997	"We must balance our consumption with the natural world's capacity to regenerate and absorb our wastes."

SNT.147433.13999	The highlighted comment made by Reid was calling Obama a "light-skinned" black man "with no Negro dialect unless he wanted to have one."
SNT.147433.14000	The remarks were released in a book co-written by Time magazine reporter Mark Halperin, and New York magazine reporter John Heileman.
SNT.147433.14001	Reid has since apologized for "using such a poor choice of words."
SNT.147433.14002	Reid has been a partner with the Obama Administration on issues such as health care reform.

SNT.147433.14004	Members of the Republican Party have called on Reid to resign over his comments.
SNT.147433.14005	Party chairperson Michael Steele told Fox News Sunday "There is this standard where the Democrats feel that they can say these things and they can apologize when it ... comes from the mouths of their own."
SNT.147433.14006	Having appeared alongside Kaine, where the Democrat Party chairman stated the case was closed, Steele argued that there was a double standard, on the basis of then-Senator Obama calling in 2002 calling for Trent Lott, at that time the majority leader, to be ousted for supporting the views of Strom Thurmond, who stood as a segregationist Presidential candidate in 1948.

SNT.32173.14013	Early reports indicate that both men sustained head injuries in the blast.
SNT.32173.14014	Woodruff was evacuated to the Balad Airbase, 68 kilometers north of Baghdad and is currently undergoing surgery.
SNT.32173.14015	"Bob and Doug are in serious condition and are being treated at a U.S. military hospital in Iraq," ABC said in a statement.
SNT.32173.14016	Reports say Woodruff was taping a report inside an Iraqi mechanized military vehicle near Taji, Iraq when the vehicle ran over and detonated an improvised explosive device.
SNT.32173.14017	ABC also reports that exchanges of small arms fire took place shortly after the explosion.

SNT.32173.14021	ABC also said that both Woodruff and Vogt were wearing body armor and helmets.

SNT.48582.14050	The software watchdog group StopBadware.org, run by the Berkman Center for Internet & Society of Harvard Law School and the Oxford Internet Institute, has opened a dialogue with AOL about concerns over the presence of badware, also known as malware, in the now-free AOL 9.0 software.
SNT.48582.14051	Badware refers to software applications that try to download additional software with very little or no explanation.
SNT.48582.14052	StopBadware.org decided to investigate after their users have sent in complaints regarding the operation of the software.
SNT.48582.14053	According to the "open inquiry" on StopBadware.org, the preliminary tests conclude that AOL 9.0 installs software and Internet Explorer extensions without the consent of the user, requires users to take certain actions, and it doesn't completely uninstall itself.
SNT.48582.14054	The page then warns readers not to use the AOL software unless they're prepared to handle the risks involved.
SNT.48582.14055	The report clarifies its charges; for example it lists "RealPlayer, QuickTime, AOL You've Got Pictures Screensaver, Pure Networks Port Magic, and Viewpoint Media Player" as the software that is installed without notification.
SNT.48582.14056	Additionally, the AOL toolbar, a bookmark to AOL.com, as well as extra icons are added to Internet Explorer without consent.
SNT.48582.14057	The report continues by noting that AOL coerces users into upgrading the software by a popup window that does not allow refusal, as well as automatically upgrades the software without allowing that option to be disabled.
SNT.48582.14058	AOL spokesman Andrew Weinstein claims that these problems are going to be addressed in an upgrade available next month.
SNT.48582.14059	In the meantime, Weinstein claims that the problems are not malicious.
SNT.48582.14060	"No one has done more to protect users from malware than AOL," Weinstein said.
SNT.48582.14061	John Palfrey agrees that the findings of AOL are not the worst he's seen, but they should disclose more information about the software to users.
SNT.48582.14062	When AOL was issued with an advance copy of the report, StopBadware.org was "very impressed" with their response, and that they look forward to working with AOL.

SNT.10317.14069	An International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) spokesman in Washington revealed Wednesday it had documented and reported to the United States credible information concerning desecration of the Koran by Guantanamo Bay personnel between January 2002 and January 2003.
SNT.10317.14070	The ICRC rarely discloses publicly the contents of the confidential reports it gives to governments.
SNT.10317.14071	Simon Schorno, Red Cross spokesman, said the ICRC's concerns were mentioned multiple times to Pentagon officials in their reports.
SNT.10317.14072	ICRC delegates have had access to Guantanamo Bay detainees since 2002 and have compiled and corroborated independent reports from detainees about desecration of the Koran numerous times to Guantanamo Bay commanders and Pentagon officials, said Mr. Schorno.
SNT.10317.14073	The ICRC representatives never observed any such incidents themselves, however.
SNT.10317.14074	Pentagon spokesman Bryan Whitman, acknowledged that allegations were made on "rare occasions" but were uncorroborated.
SNT.10317.14075	Mr. Schorno disputed the Pentagon's denial saying, "All information we received were corroborated allegations."
SNT.10317.14076	He added that, "We certainly corroborated mentions of the events by detainees themselves," and that "the ICRC considers such reports very seriously, and very carefully, and [we] document everything."
SNT.10317.14077	The reports ceased after January 19, 2003, when the Defense Department issued three pages of guidelines on proper treatment of Korans, according to Mr. Schorno.
SNT.10317.14078	On Wednesday Mr. Schorno gave credit for addressing the issue, saying, "We brought it up to the attention of the authorities, and it was followed through."
SNT.10317.14079	Some Muslim news agencies are still reacting to last week's Newsweek article alleging Korans had been thrown into Guantanamo Bay toilets.
SNT.10317.14080	The Jordanian newspaper Al-Dustur reported that some Middle Eastern TV stations were broadcasting images of Korans shredded by US forces in one Iraqi mosque.

SNT.10317.14082	However, Scott McClellan explained in a press conference last Tuesday that the White House is not trying to tell Newsweek what to print.
SNT.10317.14083	McClellan said, "Look, this report caused serious damage to the image of the United States abroad."
SNT.10317.14084	"We appreciate the step that they took by retracting the story."
SNT.10317.14085	"Now we would encourage them to move forward and do all that they can to help repair the damage that has been done by this report."
SNT.10317.14086	"But, no, you're absolutely right, it's not my position to get into telling people what they can and cannot report."

SNT.31755.14089	Marty reported, "Individuals have been abducted, deprived of their liberty and transported to different destinations in Europe, to be handed over to countries in which they have suffered degrading treatment and torture."
SNT.31755.14090	The report estimates the rendition of "more than a hundred persons."

SNT.64528.14120	The MHI requested that the public avoid its emergency department and find alternate care, if possible.
SNT.64528.14121	It did indicate that acute care emergency patients would not be turned away.
SNT.64528.14122	The notice was to be in place for 24 hours from Wednesday.
SNT.64528.14123	On Thursday, the MHI issued a extension to the public notice for an additional 24-hour period.
SNT.64528.14124	The number of patients that visited the MHI over the past few months had been abnormally high and reached a peak in the past two weeks, according to the head of emergency services.
SNT.64528.14125	Alain Vadeboncoeur indicated that it was unusual for the MHI to put out such an advisory, but assured the public that the hospital would "always take the big emergencies."
SNT.64528.14126	The hospital treats 45 to 50 emergency patients per day, typically, but that number jumped to as many as 70 patients per day in the past two weeks.
SNT.64528.14127	The MHI maintains 153 beds, including 42 in medical intensive care and 29 in surgical intensive care and performs 1,850 cardiac surgeries yearly.
SNT.64528.14128	It was suggested by the MHI that people requiring non-emergency care contact their regional Info-Santé for telephone-based advice, or visit a local clinic.

SNT.132043.14132	Late Thursday, Amazon emailed owners of Kindle readers who had previously lost copies of these novels, offering a new copy of the deleted books, or a gift certificate or check for US$30.
SNT.132043.14133	In the email, the company's chief executive, Jeff Bezos apologised again, and described the earlier actions as "stupid, thoughtless and painfully out of line with our principles."
SNT.132043.14134	Initially, the two works of Orwell were made available to Kindle owners by a third-party company which did not have the rights to distribute them.
SNT.132043.14135	When Amazon was alerted to this by the actual rights holder, the company removed the books from their online store then, far more controversially, remotely deleted the books from their customers' devices before issuing refunds.
SNT.132043.14136	In the aftermath of significant press coverage of Amazon's actions to remove content, legal action was started against them in Washington alleging violations of the company's published terms of service, the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, and Washington's consumer protection legislation.
SNT.132043.14137	A Michigan student named as a plaintiff in the case explained that the deletion of his copy of 1984 had rendered his annotations and notes worthless.

SNT.156506.14140	The Nigerien embassy in London has issued a statement saying that both the president and ministers in his company were "safe and well," although officials said that the company was most likely imprisoned in military barracks outside of Niamy.
SNT.156506.14141	According to an announcement by the representative of the group responsible for the coup, a Nigerien Army colonel, the country's constitution has been suspended and all government institutions have been dissolved.
SNT.156506.14142	It is not clear who the leader of the coup is, although several military sources said that Major Adamou Harouna of the Nigerien Army was responsible.
SNT.156506.14143	The coup apparently took place during a cabinet meeting in the capitol building, and was preceded by a several-hour long gun battle in the capital, Niamy.
SNT.156506.14144	The battle began at about 13:00 local time (12:00 UTC), ending about four hours later, with both foot soldiers and tanks involved, although no significant deployment of the military was reported.
SNT.156506.14145	The morning after the battle, the streets were relatively quiet, and the only significant military presence is heavy artillery around the presidential palace.
SNT.156506.14146	The battle led to at least ten deaths, four of which were soldiers.
SNT.156506.14147	Additionally, a curfew has been imposed, and the military has closed Niger's borders.
SNT.156506.14148	Despite the crisis, the government has yet to release an official statement as to its status.
SNT.156506.14149	The actions of the military prompted condemnations of the coup from both the African Union and the nation of France, both of which called for negotiations to resolve the situation.
SNT.156506.14150	The West African group of countries Ecowas has already dispatched a delegation to talk to the group responsible for the coup.
SNT.156506.14151	The coup came after an extended political crisis in which President Tandja has dissolved both the National Assembly and Niger's High Court, as well as extending his presidential term by three years, and removing all further limits on his term.
SNT.156506.14152	These actions have led to increasing pressure against him and the government, culminating with a thousands-strong demonstration against the government last week.

SNT.2345.14154	If executed, Ross will be the first person put to death in Connecticut in over 40 years.
SNT.2345.14155	Ross admitted to killing eight women in Connecticut and New York in the 1980s, and to raping several of them.
SNT.2345.14156	The hearing considered whether Ross, who holds a degree in economics from Cornell University, was mentally competent to waive his appeals.
SNT.2345.14157	Dr. Michael Norko, appointed by the court to examine Ross, testified that Ross is a sexual sadist and is prone to depression.
SNT.2345.14158	Ross had attempted suicide three times in the past, Norko told the court, but he is not suicidal now.
SNT.2345.14159	Norko further testifed that Ross is taking medication to control his psychiatric problems.
SNT.2345.14160	Norko testified that Ross made a rational decision in electing to waive his appeals, and the court agreed, finding Ross clear headed and well educated.
SNT.2345.14161	"This decision is his right to make," Judge Clifford said from the bench.
SNT.2345.14162	However, Ross' father and the Connecticut Public Defender's Office have filed motions in Rockville Superior Court claiming that Ross suffered from mental delusions at the time of his orignial trial, and that his previous attorneys did a poor job defending him.
SNT.2345.14163	There is no word when the Rockville court will rule.

SNT.250055.14181	The tsunami caused by Japan's magnitude 8.9 quake on Friday destroyed the commercial fishing harbor of Crescent City, California, a coastal town still recovering from a devastating tsunami in 1964.
SNT.250055.14182	Although most of the fishing boats were removed in advance, the 198 docking slips that the harbor had provided for boats, enabling the livelihoods of the fishing crews, were lost.
SNT.250055.14183	"We're facing not only physical but financial disaster," he said during a briefing.
SNT.250055.14184	"Our business activity came to a screeching halt yesterday, and that affects the entire community."
SNT.250055.14185	Councilwoman Kelly Schellong said, "This is going to have a trickle-down effect beyond the lost jobs."
SNT.250055.14186	Crescent City's unemployment rate was 13 percent before Friday's tsunami destroyed its commerical fishing industry.
SNT.250055.14187	The 1964 tsunami that hit Crescent City killed 11, demolished the harbor and heavily damaged large portions of the business district.
SNT.250055.14188	Although the city subsequently rebuilt, another tsunami again damaged the harbor in 2006.
SNT.250055.14189	The city was in the midst of reconstructing the harbor when Friday's tsunami hit.
SNT.250055.14190	The harbor is surrounded by land and a breakwater built after the 1964 disaster.
SNT.250055.14191	The tsunami's huge waves entered through a small opening provided for the entrance and exit of boats.
SNT.250055.14192	Lori Dengler, director of the Humboldt Earthquake Education Center, says Friday's tsunami was one of as many as 38 tsunamis to strike Crescent City within the last 78 years.
SNT.250055.14193	She calls the city a "tsunami magnet" because of the topography of the ocean floor that contributes to its vulnerability.
SNT.250055.14194	She also blames the breakwater built after the 1964 tsunami because it traps tsunami waves in the harbor, causing them to boil and churn.
SNT.250055.14195	A county supervisor found the view painful on Saturday as she surveyed the wreckage accompanied by state officials.
SNT.34512.14196	The Centre for Independent Studies has released a paper calling for reform of university student fees system.
SNT.34512.14197	The paper, authored by Andrew Norton, argues that the cap on loans to full fee paying students is too low.
SNT.34512.14198	The current cap allows for loans during a lifetime of AU$50,950.
SNT.34512.14199	"Setting the FEE-HELP limit at this amount biases the market against courses that are long or have high per year costs, or both," argues Norton in the paper.
SNT.34512.14200	"The loan cap is a crude way of controlling lending, taking no account of course costs or capacity to repay."
SNT.34512.14201	He argues that the system should function more like commercial lending.
SNT.34512.14202	"A truly radical reform would make student loans mimic commercial loans: students with good earning prospects could borrow large sums, other students could borrow less, and some could not borrow at all," he said.
SNT.34512.14203	"Instead of denying or limiting loans to people doing high cost courses, as now occurs, the government could deny loans to people who are unlikely to repay."
SNT.34512.14204	The paper was criticised by Senator Kerry Nettle, Education Spokesperson for the Australian Greens.
SNT.34512.14205	She argued that the changes would mean an increase in costs to students already struggling to pay, and called on Education Minister Julie Bishop to rule out the changes.
SNT.34512.14206	"To consider refusing loans to those deemed less able to repay would further cut off higher education for Australians from low socio-economic backgrounds," she said.
SNT.34512.14207	"Julie Bishop should use her address to the National Press Club tomorrow to rule out any moves to further deregulate the HECS system."
SNT.34512.14208	"Student fees have spiralled upward under the Howard government and any further deregulation would just make a bad system worse," she added.
SNT.254611.14209	After an exhaustive two year, 20 million euro ($28 million) search, the final resting spot of Air France Flight 447 has been located.
SNT.254611.14210	The location of the wreckage is six miles north of the plane's last reported position off the coast of Brazil at a depth of 3,800 and 4,000 meters (2,070 to 2,190 fathoms or 12,467 feet and 13,123 feet).
SNT.254611.14211	The wreckage of the Airbus A330-200, was found Sunday by a team from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, using a Remus robotic submarine and its side-scan sonar.
SNT.254611.14212	After the wreckage was found, another Remus robot submarine with cameras was sent down to the site, where it filmed bodies in the wreckage.
SNT.254611.14213	Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet, France's Ministry of Ecology, Energy, Sustainable Development and Sea, confirmed to reporters: "Bodies were found."
SNT.254611.14214	"We are now confronted with another trauma," Robert Soulas, vice president of Entraide et Solidarité AF447, a support group for families of victims of the crash, said.
SNT.254611.14215	Soulas lost his daughter and son-in-law, who were on board the flight when it crashed.
SNT.254611.14216	"For me, personally I would like to leave the bodies of my children, my two children, on the seabed."
SNT.254611.14217	The remains of the plane, which were concentrated in a 600 metres by 200 metres (1,968 feet by 656 feet) area, appear to be relatively intact which leads investigators to believe that the plane hit the water intact and did not explode mid-air.
SNT.254611.14218	Around 50 bodies of the 228 passengers and crew on board and parts of the plane were found shortly after the crash in 2009.
SNT.254611.14219	According to Jean-Paul Troadec, the head of France's Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), the accident investigation body for aircraft overseeing the operation and investigation, the wreckage and bodies will be bought to surface and then sent to France for investigation.
SNT.254611.14220	The salvage operation, which will cost around 5 million euros ($7.1 million) according to estimates, will be financed by the French government.
SNT.254611.14221	Three salvage companies who are bidding to recover the wreck have until afternoon on Thursday to submit proposals.
SNT.254611.14222	The operation should take between three weeks to a month.
SNT.254611.14223	On raising the remains of the plane Troadec said: "We want to know what happened in this accident, most particularly so it never happens again."
SNT.254611.14224	Some family members agreed saying such as Michael Gaignard, whose sister was on board the plane said, "We want to know what happened in that plane."
SNT.254611.14225	An attorney for several families said some had yet to come to terms with loss of loved ones, saying "There's been no burial, no goodbye ... just lots and lots of suffering."
SNT.254611.14226	However, despite the discovery of the wreckage, the plane's two flight recorders, the flight data recorder (FDR) and the cockpit voice recorder (CVR) have yet to be found at the crash site.
SNT.254611.14227	Alain Bouillard, who is in charge of BEA's recovery effort said, "It's still a jigsaw puzzle."
SNT.254611.14228	There are concerns that the two-year length the recorders have been submerged in seawater along with enormous pressure located at the depth of the wreck, that the data on the recorders might be unreadable.
SNT.254611.14229	Bouillard said it is possible the recorders were damaged, but had "great confidence" in their robustness.
SNT.254611.14230	Without the recovery of the recorders, investigators may be unable to determine the cause of the crash.
SNT.254611.14231	The leading theory at the moment is that the crew received incorrect air speed readings from the aircraft's pitot tubes, devices which measure how fast the aircraft is travelling.
SNT.254611.14232	Experts say the tubes may have become iced over, causing the crash.
SNT.254611.14233	The plane's Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System (ACARS) sent out 24 messages over a four-minute long period stating numerous problems and warnings, including incorrect air speed warnings occurring aboard the aircraft, just prior to it going down.
SNT.113686.14234	Archaeologists Timothy Darvill of Bournemouth University and Geoff Wainwright, President of the Society of Antiquaries, claimed to have found evidence that Stonehenge was once a center of healing.
SNT.113686.14235	In an excavation conducted at the site, a large number of human remains were found that display signs of physical injury or disease.
SNT.113686.14236	Study of the teeth from the skeletons indicates that about half of them were from outside the area.
SNT.113686.14237	A large number of bluestone or spotted Preseli dolerite chips found during the excavation led the researchers to conclude the stones were venerated for their healing properties.
SNT.113686.14238	It is believed that about 80 of such bluestone blocks were transported from the Preseli Hills in Pembrokeshire, Wales to the Salisbury plains.
SNT.113686.14239	The inner circle of bluestones are the earliest stone structures found in this site.
SNT.113686.14240	Later bluestones were encircled by the imposing sandstone monoliths of sarsen stones.
SNT.113686.14241	"It could be that people were flaking off pieces of bluestone, in order to create little bits to take away... as lucky amulets," said Professor Darvill.
SNT.113686.14242	Radiocarbon dating indicates that the original bluestone circle was built around 2300 BC.
SNT.113686.14243	This date coincides with the burial of "Amesbury Archer", whose tomb was discovered near Stonehenge.
SNT.113686.14244	The skeleton of this man reveals that he had serious knee injury and tooth problems.
SNT.113686.14245	Researchers therefore conclude that the Archer came to Stonehenge to be healed.
SNT.113686.14246	Dating of charcoal fragments revealed that the site was inhabited as early as 7200 BC by groups of hunter-gatherers.
SNT.113686.14247	This is more than 3500 years earlier than previously known.

SNT.109332.14258	Bertha became the first hurricane of the 2008 Atlantic hurricane season Monday, after strengthening from a tropical storm overnight.
SNT.109332.14259	As of 11:00 am EDT, the Category 1 hurricane is located in the mid-Atlantic ocean, about 775 miles east of the Leeward Islands, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami, Florida.
SNT.109332.14260	It has maximum sustained winds of 90 miles per hour, with higher gusts, and it is moving west-northwest at 15 miles per hour.
SNT.109332.14261	The storm is expected to strengthen over the next 24 hours, with a possibility of intensifying into a Category 2 hurricane later today.
SNT.109332.14262	The National Hurricane Center sees "no apparent environmental factors" to inhibit Bertha's intensification into a Category 2 storm.
SNT.109332.14263	Over the next few days, it is projected to gradually turn towards the northwest, while reducing in forward speed.
SNT.109332.14264	The National Hurricane Center has not said whether Bertha will affect any land areas.
SNT.109332.14265	However, a five-day forecast map shows Bertha passing near Bermuda around Saturday.
SNT.109332.14266	"While the degree of the turn has important implications regarding potential impacts to Bermuda," the National Hurricane Center said, "it is much too early to determine if Bertha will actually threaten that island."
SNT.109332.14267	Coincidentally, Bertha was also the name of a 1996 hurricane, which formed exactly 12 years ago on July 7.

SNT.247020.14288	At 4:53 p.m. (EDT), Space Shuttle Discovery took off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on its final mission, STS-133.
SNT.247020.14289	Its mission is to deliver and install onto the International Space Station (ISS), the Permanent Multipurpose Module Leonardo, the ExPRESS Logistics Carrier-4 and provide critical spare components for the station.
SNT.247020.14290	Six astronauts, Steve Lindsey, Eric Boe, Alvin Drew, Nicole Stott, Michael Barratt, and Steve Bowen, are participating in the mission.
SNT.247020.14291	The shuttle is also carrying Robonaut2, the first dexterous humanoid robot to be in space.
SNT.247020.14292	Although its first priority will be to test its operation in microgravity, upgrades could eventually allow it to fulfill its ultimate purpose of becoming an astronaut helper on boring or dangerous tasks.
SNT.247020.14293	The launch of Discovery, which was supposed to occur at 4:50 p.m., was delayed for three minutes due to a technical problem in the shuttle's command system and a chipped heat shield tile near the crew hatch which needed to be patched.
SNT.247020.14294	The launch was also repeatedly postponed since November 1 due to various technical problems with the shuttle's systems and a hydrogen leak in the fuel tank along with cracks and bad weather.
SNT.247020.14295	A small piece of foam broke off during the launch but NASA has reported that it is unlikely to cause problems.
SNT.247020.14296	Discovery and the crew of STS-133 are scheduled to spend about two weeks in space and aboard the ISS, logging 4.5 million additional miles of flight.
SNT.247020.14297	The launch comes just hours after an unmanned automated European cargo spacecraft, ATV-2, docked with the orbiting outpost to deliver supplies and equipment to the crew.
SNT.247020.14298	STS-133 is scheduled to be the final mission of Discovery, with its first being STS-41-D in 1984.
SNT.247020.14299	Discovery flew 39 flights in its operational history, including the current mission, delivering several payloads to space including the Hubble Space Telescope and visiting two different space stations: Mir and the ISS.
SNT.247020.14300	STS-133 is the 133rd shuttle mission and the 35th mission to the ISS.
SNT.247020.14301	Discovery is the oldest surviving shuttle, and has flown more missions than any other shuttle.
SNT.247020.14302	It was also the first shuttle to fly after the Challenger disaster and was the first shuttle to fly after the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster.
SNT.247020.14303	Later, Discovery became the first shuttle to fly a Russian cosmonaut.
SNT.247020.14304	After the current mission, there will be at most two remaining shuttle flights.
SNT.247020.14305	Endeavor has one more mission remaining, and if an emergency rescue is needed or more funding is secured, Atlantis will also fly once more before the entire fleet is retired.
SNT.247020.14306	"The shuttle has provided an amazing capacity for this country to gather data."
SNT.247020.14307	"I think we’re still sorting through a lot of it, trying to figure out what all we’ve learned from it."
SNT.247020.14308	"This chapter in our space history known as the space shuttle has been incredible," said Bryan Lunney, lead space shuttle flight director for the mission.

SNT.454206.14373	A new study by Duke University in the US suggests depressed adolescents who respond to treatment within twelve weeks are at a reduced risk of drug abuse later in their lives.
SNT.454206.14374	The research followed about half of a pool of 439 adolescents who had received treatment for major depression and volunteered for Duke University research.
SNT.454206.14375	At the five-year study's conclusion the participants were aged 17–23.
SNT.454206.14376	Of those who had experienced a reduction in depressive symptoms within twelve weeks of treatment, ten percent went on to have drug abuse problems.
SNT.454206.14377	Alcohol use problems, however, were equally prevalent regardless of treatment outcome.
SNT.454206.14378	The study was run by Dr. John Curry, a professor of neuroscience and psychology.
SNT.454206.14379	Curry noted that the results for those treated successfully held true "whatever they responded to — cognitive-behavioral therapy, Prozac, both treatments, or a placebo".
SNT.454206.14380	The study has called for treatments to take possible alcohol and drug use into account.
SNT.454206.14381	Said Curry, "When the teenagers got over the depression, about half of them stayed well for the whole five-year period, but almost half of them had a second episode of depression... what we found out was that, for those who had both alcohol disorder and another depression, the alcohol disorder almost always came first".
SNT.454206.14382	He also said the study had "a take-home message" in "that alcohol use disorders are very prevalent during that particular age period and there’s a need for a lot of prevention and education for college students to avoid getting into heavy drinking and then the beginnings of an alcohol disorder".
SNT.454206.14383	Curry, alongside Dr. Susan Silva, a co-author, want more research using larger groups.
SNT.454206.14384	They also say work towards a comparison with non-depressed individuals is needed.

SNT.21322.14436	In order to find P-2 level officers for the United Nations Secretariat, the international organization is holding competitive recruitment competitions in 42 countries.
SNT.21322.14437	Six occupational groups are being sought: Architecture, Demography, Library, Security, Science and Technology, and Statistics.
SNT.21322.14438	There will be a written examination (both a general paper and a specialised paper) and an interview.
SNT.21322.14439	The written examination questions are given in English and French, the two working languages of the Secretariat.
SNT.21322.14440	Candidates must write their answers for the general paper in English or French.
SNT.21322.14441	However, they may write their answers for the specialized paper in English, French, or any of the other four official languages of the Secretariat, i.e., Arabic, Chinese, Russian, or Spanish.
SNT.21322.14442	The examinations will take place on February 28, 2006 in New York, Addis Ababa, Andorra La Vella, Athens, Bangkok, Beirut, Geneva, Monaco, Nairobi, Santiago, Vaduz, Valletta, and Vienna.
SNT.21322.14443	According to the UN, applicants "should hold at least a first-level university degree relevant to the occupational group in which they would like to take the examination."
SNT.21322.14444	"Furthermore, applicants should not be more than 32 years old on 31 December, 2006 …"
SNT.21322.14445	The following countries have been selected for the 2006 competition: Andorra, Angola, Antigua and Barbuda, Saudi Arabia, Barbados, Botswana, Brunei Darussalam, Cabo Verde, Comores, Republic of Korea, Gambia, Japan, Greece, Grenada, Guatemala, Equatorial Guinea, Israel, Kiribati, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Liechtenstein, Maldives, Malta, San Marino, Marshall Islands, Mauritius, Mexico, Micronesia, Moldova, Monaco, Norway, Oman, Panama, Portugal, Saint Lucia, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Switzerland, Tajikistan, Tonga, Tuvalu, USA, and Vietnam.

SNT.21322.14447	The United Nations Secretariat is one of the principal organs of the United Nations and it is headed by the United Nations Secretary General and assisted by a staff of international civil servants worldwide.
SNT.21322.14448	It provides studies, information, and facilities needed by United Nations bodies for their meetings.
SNT.21322.14449	It also carries out tasks as directed by the UN Security Council, the UN General Assembly, the UN Economic and Social Council, and other UN bodies.
SNT.21322.14450	The United Nations Charter provides that the staff be chosen by application of the "highest standards of efficiency, competence, and integrity," with due regard for the importance of recruiting on a wide geographical basis.

SNT.119744.14452	Dr. Manmohan Singh is the 17th and current Prime Minister of the Republic of India.
SNT.119744.14453	He also serves as the Union Minister for Finance, succeeding P. Chidambaram.
SNT.119744.14454	According to critical care specialist Dr. Vijay D'Silva, who has been entrusted with his post-operative care, Singh has been given a liquid diet since morning including a cup of tea, and was speaking to doctors after the procedure.
SNT.119744.14455	"The way you [doctors] are taking care of me, you should also take care of other people", Dr. D'Silva, who received his basic medical training in Nagpur and headed the ICU at Mumbai's Jaslok and Lilavati Hospitals before he helped set up the ICU at the ultra-modern Asian Heart Institute, quoted Singh as saying.
SNT.119744.14456	"The second operation always takes longer and makes it difficult to reach the heart."
SNT.119744.14457	"We did a total of five by-passes to clear multiple blockages in his arteries."
SNT.119744.14458	"Surgery was the long term answer since there were many blockages."

SNT.119744.14462	"PM was sent back to the ICU at 8:55 pm," said Dr. Reddy.
SNT.119744.14463	"The team has brought about 20 boxes of special equipment with it."
SNT.119744.14464	"Earlier, Dr. K. S. Reddy had discussions with Dr. Panda in connection with the line of treatment to be followed," the team of 11 doctors said.
SNT.119744.14465	The team of surgeons made a 6 to 7 inch incision along the scar that marked the PM's 1990 bypass operation, and he was given five grafts.
SNT.119744.14466	"The new grafts, all 3 mm long, will last the PM the rest of his life," said Dr. Pradyot Kumar Rath from the Asian Heart Institute.
SNT.119744.14467	"If the PM could have been so active with all the blockages, he can be even more active now," Dr Panda said.

SNT.119744.14469	The tests results revealed multiple arterial blockages and Singh returned to hospital on Friday for pre-surgery tests.

SNT.285315.14498	The UN has certified that the Delhi Metro has aided in the reduction of greenhouse gases, earning 'carbon credits'.
SNT.285315.14499	This makes the Delhi Metro the first of its kind in the world to do so.
SNT.285315.14500	This comes under the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) of the UN under the Kyoto Protocol.
SNT.285315.14501	The UN said the rail based system has helped to save 630,000 tonnes of pollution a year.
SNT.285315.14502	The credits to the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) are worth $9.5 million for each of the next seven years.
SNT.285315.14503	More credits would be given for more passengers on the system.
SNT.285315.14504	The credits are designed as a financial incentive for developing countries to reduce greenhouse emissions.
SNT.285315.14505	According to the DMRC, it has reduced road traffic by more than 91,000 vehicles per day.
SNT.53578.14506	Studies conducted by a team of physicists at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) conclude that new synthetic NBA basketballs are less lively, more slippery when damp, and bounce more erratically than the traditional leather balls.
SNT.53578.14507	James Horwitz, Chairman of the UTA Department of Physics was contacted by the Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban to study the new ball.
SNT.53578.14508	Horwitz asked UTA physics professor Kaushik De to lead the project.
SNT.53578.14509	De's team found that the new balls are tackier when dry, but become much more slippery than leather balls when they get damp.
SNT.53578.14510	Traditional leather basketballs provide more grip when they are slightly wet.
SNT.53578.14511	The synthetic balls bounce 30% more sporadically, possibly due to deep embossing, and are less lively than leather basketballs.
SNT.53578.14512	Some of these issues could be fixed with a variety of methods, including modification of the embossing, increasing the air pressure in the balls beyond the regulation 8.5 psi, and constantly drying the balls with towels during the game or frequently replacing them with fresh basketballs, say De and Horwitz.

SNT.143040.14514	Areas in Nigeria have been subject to damages caused by increasing erosion for over 50 years.
SNT.143040.14515	This issue has grown over the past years, and responsibility has been pointed at a lack of national policy.

SNT.143040.14519	"And this waste combined with the force of the flood and trying to erode the soil and sometimes they actually block the channel that has been created for flood dispersion and the floods come back and actually destroy their homes, and at that point they call on government," he added.

SNT.8075.14574	The United States Marshals Service working together with nearly 960 other law enforcement agencies recently concluded a week-long operation, Operation FALCON, which succeeded in the arrest of 10,340 fugitives across the United States and elsewhere.
SNT.8075.14575	Other regional sweeps have been conducted before; but this was the first of its kind at the national level and resulted in the highest number of arrests ever recorded in a single operation.
SNT.8075.14576	Operation FALCON, which stands for "Federal And Local Cops Organized Nationally", received the cooperation of more than 3,000 law enforcement agents from the US Marshals, state, county and city level, and other US agencies.
SNT.8075.14577	Operations were also coordinated internationally with INTERPOL and the US State Department, resulting in the detainment of 16 foreign and international fugitives.
SNT.8075.14578	Operation FALCON was conducted during a one week period, April 4-10, 2005, chosen to coincide with National Crime Victim's Rights Week, April 10-16, the dates being chosen to "honor the victims" of violent crime in America.
SNT.8075.14579	“By taking violent fugitives off the streets and putting them behind bars where they belong,” said Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, “we've honored the victims and made our streets safer.”
SNT.8075.14580	The focus of Operation FALCON was on apprehending fugitives wanted for violent crimes, gang activities, drug trafficking, and sex-related offenses.
SNT.8075.14581	Arrests were made in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Guam, Puerto Rico, and in several International locales.
SNT.8075.14582	“I applaud the achievements of every Deputy Marshal, police officer, detective, trooper, investigator, deputy sheriff, and special agent who hit the street virtually around-the-clock for seven days,” said Robert J. Finan II, the Marshals Service’s Assistant Director for Investigative Services.
SNT.8075.14583	He continued, “Also of note is that during the course of this initiative, there were no serious incidents or serious injuries to either law enforcement officers or those who were taken into custody.”

SNT.15773.14620	The same May survey indicated that duck habitats, specifically ponds, had declined more than 35 percent from the historical average.

SNT.15773.14622	The figures are used to set duck-hunting limits for the fall season, which begins in August.
