SNT.101994.14634	The announcement Friday by the British government came after the European Parliament urged a resolution to the case and said that Iran has a history of torturing and executing homosexuals.
SNT.101994.14635	Britain had initially rejected an asylum request by 19-year-old Mehdi Kazemi, and Kazemi fled to the Netherlands, where his case was turned down and he returned to Britain.
SNT.101994.14636	British Home Secretary Jacqui Smith released a statement on the case: "Following representations made on behalf of Mehdi Kazemi, and in the light of new circumstances since the original decision was made, I have decided that Mr. Kazemi's case should be reconsidered on his return to the UK from the Netherlands."
SNT.101994.14637	Eighty members of Britain's upper house of Parliament sent a letter to Jacqui Smith, appealing to the government to "show compassion and allow Mr. Kazemi to have a safe haven in the United Kingdom."
SNT.101994.14638	Roger Roberts of the House of Lords initiated the petition, and stated: "There is no doubt that he will be persecuted and possibly face state-sanctioned murder if he is forced to return."
SNT.101994.14639	Simon Hughes, Member of Parliament for North Southwark and Bermondsey, said he would support Kazemi if he returns to the United Kingdom: "I hope Mr Kazemi will now come back to Britain where arrangements are already in place for an urgent meeting with him, his family, specialist lawyers and myself to prepare a new application to the Home Office."
SNT.101994.14640	Gay rights advocate and spokesman for the British gay rights group OutRage!, David Allison commented "It's cruel to even suggest sending him back …"
SNT.101994.14641	Ben Summerskill of the British gay rights organization, Stonewall, said: "We are obviously delighted that the home secretary has listened to the representations that were made in this case …"
SNT.101994.14642	"There are overwhelming reasons why people should not be deported to Iran in the current circumstances, and it is important that Britain is seen as a safe haven."
SNT.101994.14643	His uncle spoke with CNN on condition of anonymity, and said that his nephew was studying in Britain in 2006 when his partner in Iran was arrested and hanged after being charged with sodomy.
SNT.101994.14644	Kazemi's uncle told CNN: "Under torture and pressure, (the partner) revealed Mehdi's name as his boyfriend."
SNT.101994.14645	Gay sex is considered a crime in Iran, and is punishable by death.
SNT.101994.14646	After Britain's Home Office initially denied Kazemi's asylum application, he fled to Canada and then the Netherlands, where he was detained.
SNT.101994.14647	Kazemi faces deportation from the Netherlands to Britain, after their highest court rejected his plea on Tuesday.
SNT.101994.14648	The Netherlands' highest court rejected the case, citing EU law that Kazemi's case was the responsibility of the country where he first requested asylum.
SNT.101994.14649	A resolution passed by the European Parliament Thursday asked EU states "to find a common solution to ensure that Mehdi Kazemi is granted asylum or protection on EU soil and not sent back to Iran."
SNT.101994.14650	The resolution also stated that Iranian authorities "routinely detain, torture and execute persons, notably homosexuals" and that "Mehdi's partner has already been executed, while his father has threatened him with death."
SNT.101994.14651	In a September 2007 speech at Columbia University, Iranian president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was challenged by University president Lee Bollinger for Iran's treatment of gays.
SNT.101994.14652	Ahmadinejad stated that "In Iran we don't have homosexuals like in your country," drawing laughter from the audience.
SNT.101994.14653	"In Iran we do not have this phenomenon, I don't know who has told you that we have it."
SNT.101994.14654	According to Iranian human rights activists, over 4,000 gay men and lesbians have been executed since the Iranian Revolution of 1979.

SNT.155407.14656	Other reports suggest that the death toll could be as high as 25.
SNT.155407.14657	More than 125 passengers are reported injured, 11 of them "very seriously".
SNT.155407.14658	Rescuers were still trying to free bodies from the wreckage of the trains more than eight hours after the crash, which occurred in snowy conditions at 08:28 local time (0728 UTC) near the station of Buizingen in the municipality of Halle, about 15 kilometres southwest of the Belgian capital.
SNT.155407.14659	The collision saw the first two carriages of one train being forced upwards into the air over the first carriage of the second train.
SNT.155407.14660	Eyewitnesses described the collision as "brutal", with passengers being thrown "violently" around the carriages.
SNT.155407.14661	Television footage showed the two smashed locomotives forced up in the air, with passenger cars strewn over a wide area and dazed survivors wandering at the crash site.
SNT.155407.14662	Train speed at the time of the crash was not immediately known.
SNT.155407.14663	There are reports that one of the trains ran a stop signal.
SNT.155407.14664	Initial reports suggest that the Leuven–Braine-le-Comte train was on the wrong line.
SNT.155407.14665	It is not known if the train went through a red signal or if there was a problem with the signalling.
SNT.155407.14666	A "well informed source" quoted by French-language daily Le Soir suggested that there might have been an electrical failure in the signalling system.
SNT.155407.14667	The collision occurred on one of the main access lines to Brussels-South station, about 14 kilometres (9 miles) from the Belgian capital.
SNT.155407.14668	It caused "major damage" to overhead power cables, especially on the Brussels–Mons and Brussels–Tournai lines, and high speed rail services between Brussels and France and the UK have been suspended.
SNT.155407.14669	Thalys services were temporarily halted due to the accident, with four of its trains in the region being diverted to alternative stations.
SNT.155407.14670	Thalys services between Brussels and Cologne have now resumed, but services to Amsterdam and Paris are still suspended.

SNT.77827.14693	An Australia-wide ban on the movement of horses, donkeys and mules which was due to expire on Wednesday has been extended until Friday.
SNT.77827.14694	So far the virus only appears to have infected horses in NSW and Queensland, with 51 confirmed cases and another 400 suspected.
SNT.77827.14695	So far all those infected appear to be horses used for recreational purposes and not thoroughbred race horses.
SNT.77827.14696	Despite the bans on racing and horse movements, track work will recommence in NSW and Queensland today.
SNT.77827.14697	It had been feared yesterday that four race horses at Randwick Racecourse in Sydney had been struck down by the virus, but the horses later tested negative to the virus.
SNT.77827.14698	If an outbreak were to occur at Randwick it could affect up to 700 race horses stabled there.
SNT.77827.14699	The outbreak comes at a bad time for the industry, as it prepares for the lucrative spring racing season in Sydney and Melbourne.
SNT.77827.14700	The AUD$1 million Golden Rose event at Rosehill has been cancelled, although it is expected that Melbourne's spring racing carnival will resume on Saturday as no cases of the flu have been seen in Victoria.
SNT.77827.14701	Racing Victoria has also said the Melbourne Cup will go ahead as planned despite the outbreak, even if no interstate or international horses can attend.
SNT.77827.14702	Despite fines of up to $44,000 and 12 months imprisonment in NSW there have been reports that more than 100 horse owners have been caught moving their horses.
SNT.77827.14703	The NSW Primary Industries Minister Ian Macdonald, said it was "absolutely vital that no-one moves a horse in this state".
SNT.77827.14704	"We will be working with police to ensure horses are at a standstill," he said.

SNT.77827.14706	Tabcorp expects to lose around $150 million in turnover this week.
SNT.77827.14707	Tattersall's has also said it expects to lose around $2 million in revenue per week due to the outbreak.
SNT.77827.14708	Investors reacted to the news, slashing 3 percent of the price of Tattersall's shares and over 4 percent of those of Tabcorp.

SNT.73471.14730	With the announcement Monday of €2 million in new funding from the European Union (EU), the Republic of Djibouti's Ministry of Agriculture hopes to provide some relief to an estimated 25,000 rural inhabitants suffering through severe drought conditions.
SNT.73471.14731	The money, to be channeled through UNICEF for its water and sanitation program, will be used to develop new wells and improve existing ones.
SNT.73471.14732	UNICEF is to contribute a further €60,000, as well as technical expertise to the Ministry of Agriculture, who will carry out the bulk of the work.
SNT.73471.14733	At the same time, the UN aid agency World Food Program (WFP) indicated that it is working with the Ministry of Agriculture and UNICEF to gradually shift Djibouti's reliance on emergency aid to a Food for Work program, which it hopes will assist nomadic herders in Djibouti with long-term sustainability.
SNT.73471.14734	"What we are trying to do together with the Ministry of Agriculture and UNICEF is, for example to dig wells so that despite drought, these herders will be able to irrigate their fields," said Simon Pluess, WFP spokesman.
SNT.73471.14735	"And, together with the UN Food and Agriculture Organization, we will try and promote vegetable gardens."
SNT.73471.14736	Djibouti has survived harsh drought conditions for the past 5 years.
SNT.73471.14737	Groundwater is the primary source of water for drinking and irrigation, but has been difficult to exploit and is often contaminated.
SNT.73471.14738	Almost 50 percent of people in rural Djibouti do not have ready access to properly developed source of drinking water.
SNT.73471.14739	And, due to the ongoing drought, water availability for livestock is limited.
SNT.73471.14740	Livestock have shown signs of distress and, subsequently, milk production is down substantially.
SNT.73471.14741	Nearly half of all families in Djibouti's northwest were forced to migrate to find pasture for their livestock.
SNT.73471.14742	As the droughts continue, the importance of properly maintained wells has become apparent.
SNT.73471.14743	Years ago there were more rains and also more pastureland for cattle.
SNT.73471.14744	"Now it is good for us to have functioning wells so that we can keep cattle here," said Anou Amada, farmer in the village of Andoli.
SNT.73471.14745	A 2006 survey indicated that only 15 percent of wells in Djibouti were equipped with a protective concrete wall to prevent contamination.
SNT.73471.14746	Andoli's well is one of many undergoing repair through WFP's Food for Work project.
SNT.73471.14747	“WFP couldn’t do this alone, so we work with the Ministry of Agriculture and UNICEF to dig wells and the UN Food and Agriculture Organization for vegetable gardens,” said Benoit Thiry, Director, WFP in Djibouti.
SNT.73471.14748	When the project is completed in 2008, it will have increased Djibouti's water pump capacity by adding 25 solar-power pumps, which would compliment the current 61 diesel-powered pumps.
SNT.73471.14749	"The advantage of solar...is that it is much cheaper and requires less maintenance," said Omar Habib, UNICEF communication specialist.
SNT.73471.14750	"We want the people to participate and to appropriate these pumping stations."
SNT.73471.14751	"The government’s role in the long term should be as restricted as possible," he added.
SNT.128011.14752	NASA launched the Lunar Precursor Robotic Program space probes, the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) and the Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite (LCROSS) on board the Atlas V rocket at 5:32 p.m. EDT (2132 GMT) from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.
SNT.128011.14753	Due to nearby thunderstorms the launch was delayed about 20 minutes from the scheduled launch time of 5.12 p.m. EDT (2112 GMT).
SNT.128011.14754	The mission will be NASA's first unmanned rocket expedition to the moon in a decade.
SNT.128011.14755	The aim of the LRO mission is to spend at least a year in a low polar orbit above the surface of the moon to gather neccesary data for future missions and longer lunar expeditions.
SNT.128011.14756	It will be orbiting approximately 30 miles (48 km) above the moon, trying to find safe landing sites, locating potential resources, characterizing the radiation environment and testing new technology.
SNT.128011.14757	The 2,300 pounds (1,043 kg) spent upper stage Centaur motor of the Atlas V launch vehicle will strike the surface of the moon at 9,000 km/h (5,600 mph) resulting in a 350 ton (317 metric ton) plume of debris rising between 6 to 30 miles (10 to 48 km) above the moon's surface.
SNT.128011.14758	From this impact, scientists hope to be able to detect any water ice or vapor using the LCROSS satellite which will crash land nearby four minutes later.
SNT.128011.14759	Astronomers who own amateur-class telescopes with apertures as small as 10 to 12 inches may be able to sight the ejecta cloud as it will have a period of brightness about one minute after impact.
SNT.128011.14760	The launch was originally planned for yesterday, but delayed for the launch of the Space Shuttle Endeavour, which was itself later delayed again due to another hydrogen fuel leak.

SNT.103804.14770	Featured articles (FAs) meet Wikipedia's highest standards for quality, accuracy, neutrality, completeness, and style, and thus are considered the best articles on Wikipedia.
SNT.103804.14771	The Wikipedia team that carries out the assessment and quality control before conferring the status of featured articles promoted five articles to FA status at the same time: Walter de Coventre, Maximian, El Señor Presidente, Lord of the Universe, and Red-billed Chough.
SNT.103804.14772	With five promoted at the same time, conferring the status of 2,000th on one is an arbitrary decision and in some respects any of these articles could actually make a claim to the honour.

SNT.9609.14791	On the same day that the Yad Vashem Holocaust History Museum was opened this year, a lesser-known museum and educational center was opened by a Muslim man in the Israeli town of Nazareth.
SNT.9609.14792	This unique museum, intended to raise awareness of past Jewish suffering in the eyes of Palestinians through historical photographs and Arabic-language educational materials, is believed to be the first-ever Arab holocaust museum.
SNT.9609.14793	Nazareth is of course well-known to Christians as the site where Joseph and Mary brought up the child Jesus.
SNT.9609.14794	In modern times, Nazareth is the largest Arab town in Israel, having many self-proclaimed Palestinians, a Muslim majority, and a 35% Arab-Christian minority.
SNT.9609.14795	The museum's owner Khaleed Mahameed, a 43-year old lawyer, husband, and father of two, said that he learned about the holocaust during his time at Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
SNT.9609.14796	He spent about 20,000 shekels (US$4,500) of his own money in order to create the museum, despite the alienation of his own brother, the rejection of the Arab news media, and a public that is slow to accept his ideas.
SNT.9609.14797	Mahameed purchased about 80 photographs from the more well-known museum at Yad Vashem in Jerusalem, site of Israel's national memorial to the Shoah (holocaust), located on the Har Hazikaron (Mount of Remembrance).
SNT.9609.14798	The newly enlarged Israeli museum at Yad Vashem, opened March 15 with the attendance of President Moshe Katsav, replaced what was the world's first holocaust museum, established in 1972.
SNT.9609.14799	As part of his effort to educate Palestinians, Mahameed has printed 2,000 booklets in Arabic describing photographs of Nazi horrors, offered stipends to Arab students of the subject, and started a new museum website (Alkaritha.org) with some translations offered in English, Arabic, and Hebrew.
SNT.9609.14800	Mahameed believes contributions such as his are necessary to the Mideast peace effort.
SNT.9609.14801	"Understanding this and the fact that personal security is perhaps the major concern of Jews in Israel and elsewhere, as a direct outcome of the Holocaust and the feelings of persecution, is extremely important."
SNT.9609.14802	"If we, as Arabs, can dissipate these concerns and show understanding over what happened it will help create the climate for real dialogue in which Israeli Jews and especially decision-makers will be able to have a greater understanding of the suffering of Arab citizens and the Palestinians."
SNT.9609.14803	"This, in turn, would hopefully lead towards a peaceful resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and an end to discriminatory policies towards Arab citizens and the acceptance that they deserve equal rights."
SNT.9609.14804	Mahameed is not without his critics, not only among Arabs who say that Mahameed should do more to draw attention to the situation of present-day Palestinians, but also representatives of the Israel office of the Jewish Anti-Defamation League (ADL), who have stated without visiting the museum that they consider some of the attitudes expressed on Mahameed's website to be anti-Semitic.
SNT.9609.14805	"The establishment of the first Holocaust museum for the Arabic-speaking public can be an important first step in educating the Arab world on the unique horrors of the destruction of European Jewry."
SNT.9609.14806	"Particularly now, at a time when Holocaust denial is rife both within and outside of the Arab world, the attempt to teach young Arabs about the Holocaust and to learn moral and ethical lessons from it is a worthy pursuit."
SNT.9609.14807	"If however, the Arab Institute for Holocaust Research and Education is, as noted on its Web site, ideologically grounded in the belief that it was the Palestinian people who paid the price for European guilt over the Holocaust by imposing what they believe is an illegitimate Jewish state in the heart of the Arab world then the institute will merely propagate the classic anti-Israel use of the Holocaust and promote anti-Semitism."
SNT.9609.14808	Friday was Yom Hashoah, or Holocaust Remembrance Day in Israel, a day of solemn reflection on the loss of 5 to 7 million Jewish lives due to unprovoked Nazi aggression in World War II.
SNT.9609.14809	Images, films and documentaries of the Holocaust are typically broadcast throughout the Israeli news media on that day, deeply affecting the survivors and their children.
SNT.9609.14810	However, these images do not typically reach a Palestinian audience, according to museum visitor Mufeed Khattib last month.
SNT.9609.14811	"Perhaps I didn't see it well because it was on Israeli TV," he said.
SNT.9609.14812	"It is different for me that an Arab man did this."

SNT.61027.14825	Flights from Auckland to Vancouver will operate three times a week between November and March, to coincide with the peak travel season between the two destinations, as Canadians escape winter and New Zealand skiers head to the Canadian slopes.
SNT.61027.14826	46,000 Canadians visit New Zealand and 16,000 New Zealanders visit Canada each year, starting at the end of this year.
SNT.61027.14827	The reinstatement of the Vancouver link restores a route phased out in the 1990s.
SNT.61027.14828	Canadian visitors make up two percent of international visitor arrivals, however they stay longer and spend more in New Zealand than many other visitors spent an average of 29 days in New Zealand in 2006, and spent almost $3400 each.
SNT.61027.14829	In total, they contributed $136 million to New Zealand's economy.
SNT.61027.14830	Tourism New Zealand chief executive, George Hickton has said that the direct flights will make New Zealand look much more appealing to the Canadian market.
SNT.61027.14831	The Tourism Industry Association New Zealand say that the new route has the added benefit of freeing up seats on Air New Zealand's busy routes from San Francisco and Los Angeles.
SNT.23826.14832	This unusual hurricane season, one of the most active in history, has produced another strange storm.
SNT.23826.14833	Category 1 Hurricane Vince, which was formed from a non-tropical low today, is forecast to head east towards Portugal, rather than west as is usual.
SNT.23826.14834	Vince caught forecasters by surprise, since the waters in the area are around 25ºC.
SNT.23826.14835	Few expected Vince to even form in the cool waters, much less to become a hurricane.
SNT.23826.14836	Forecasters at the National Hurricane Center do not expect Vince to be a hurricane for long.
SNT.23826.14837	It is forecast to weaken as it moves towards Portugal, and to finally become extratropical.
SNT.23826.14838	In about 48 hours, they believe Vince will be absorbed by a front in Portugal or Spain.
SNT.190839.14839	A rescue operation is underway after sixteen-year-old American Abby Sunderland, attempting to sail around the world by herself, lost contact with her family while in the Indian Ocean.
SNT.190839.14840	Sunderland, from Thousand Oaks, California, had originally hoped to become the youngest person to sail around the world nonstop by herself.
SNT.190839.14841	She departed from Marina del Rey, California on January 23, 2010 and was about halfway through the attempt when Sunderland's family lost communication with her Thursday morning.
SNT.190839.14842	That night, an Australian plane was able to locate her 40-foot (12.2-metre) long boat, Wild Eyes, which had lost its mast earlier.
SNT.190839.14843	Sunderland had been sailing amid a rough storm in the Indian Ocean early Thursday when her boat was flipped over.
SNT.190839.14844	After losing contact, the teenager activated two manual distress radiobeacons, or EPIRBs, and a search-and-rescue operation was formed.
SNT.190839.14845	As part of the operation, a Qantas Airways Airbus A330 was sent over the ocean by Australian authorities.
SNT.190839.14846	The plane's crew was able to make radio contact with Sunderland, and confirmed that she was not injured and that her boat was upright, but was unable to continue sailing.
SNT.190839.14847	The closest rescue boat, a French fishing ship, was about 24 hours away from Sunderland's location when she was found, and is expected to meet her later today.
SNT.190839.14848	She was stranded about 2000 miles (3218.7 kilometres) southwest of Australia's coast.
SNT.190839.14849	Near the beginning of the voyage, she made a stop at Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, after the boat's generators were not producing enough power.
SNT.190839.14850	She resumed the attempt in February, but autopilot problems forced another stop at Cape Town, South Africa for repairs in April, and she had to give up going for the unassisted record.
SNT.190839.14851	Sunderland's parents, Laurence and Marianne, have vigorously defended against claims that their daughter was too young to be attempting such a feat.
SNT.190839.14852	They have also been criticized for allowing her to depart the United States at the beginning of the year, because Sunderland would likely arrive in the Indian Ocean during the region's winter.
SNT.190839.14853	Marianne Sunderland has said that Abby would likely not try "something of this magnitude again."
SNT.190839.14854	Last year, her brother Zac had completed a circumnavigation when he sailed solo around the world at the age of seventeen.
SNT.190839.14855	She had begun preparing for this journey at the age of thirteen.

SNT.248548.14857	On a new website, "The Internet Explorer 6 Countdown", Microsoft has launched an aggressive campaign to persuade users to stop using IE6 and update to a newer IE.
SNT.248548.14858	Its goal is to decrease IE6 users to less than one percent.
SNT.248548.14859	IE's various versions accounted for 70 percent of the market in 2009; this has dropped to approximately 56 percent today.
SNT.248548.14860	Mozilla Firefox, its main rival, has been actively increasing its market share while the recently released Google Chrome is also quickly gaining users.
SNT.248548.14861	PC World's recent analysis of its own web traffic statistics concluded, "Usually, Internet Explorer is the #2 browser after Firefox, but over the past 30 days it's been #3, a couple of points behind Safari-and nearly tied with Chrome."
SNT.248548.14862	"But if it isn't, and Chrome continues to surge, IE could fall to fourth place."
SNT.248548.14863	As they design their web pages for the newer browsers with advanced web technology and geared to the newest web core markup language HTML 5, they are forced to accommodate older out-of-date technology to support IE6 users.
SNT.248548.14864	Also, not mentioned on Microsoft's "The Internet Explorer 6 Countdown" site, are the numerous security vulnerabilities putting the browser at risk of being hacked.
SNT.248548.14865	The Internet security firm Secunia.com, has said that as of March 4, 2011, IE6 has 277 vulnerabilities; 39 percent of these are rated "highly critical".
SNT.248548.14866	Microsoft says that the latest versions of Internet Explorer provide the user with enhanced protection from these attacks and threats.
SNT.248548.14867	Microsoft's Internet Explorer 6 is one of the most successful software products ever as measured by its durability and the massive numbers of people who have used it.
SNT.248548.14868	But it has outlived its usefulness, and Microsoft no longer wants to support it.

SNT.111633.14883	During the forum the candidates were each individually asked a series of identical questions by the pastor, with Senator Barack Obama going first and Senator John McCain taking his turn second.
SNT.111633.14884	Senator McCain traveled to the church and waited in a green room while Obama was speaking, and by agreement did not listen to the questions or Senator Obama's responses.
SNT.111633.14885	When asked whom they believed were the three wisest people to rely on as president, Obama answered that his wife and grandmother were at the top of his list along with a mix of Republican and Democratic Senators.
SNT.111633.14886	McCain comprised his list of a range of people: the architect of the troop surge in Iraq, General David Petraeus; Democratic Congressman and civil rights leader John Lewis; and the former CEO of eBay, Meg Whitman.
SNT.111633.14887	In response to being questioned about their toughest decisions in life, Obama answered that deciding to oppose the Iraq War in 2002 was his toughest, while McCain cited his refusal to leave his men behind in a POW camp in Vietnam when given the chance.
SNT.111633.14888	On some philosophical questions the candidates differed in their moral stances.
SNT.111633.14889	When asked when they believed individuals should be given human rights, Obama responded that the question was "above [his] pay grade" while McCain decisively replied that he believed it should occur "at the moment of conception."
SNT.111633.14890	On the concept of evil, Obama related it to the situation in Darfur and on America's streets.
SNT.111633.14891	McCain related it to radical Islamic extremism relaying that he believed evil should be "defeated."
SNT.111633.14892	He then promised that as president he would hunt Osama bin Laden to the "gates of hell."
SNT.111633.14893	They both answered that the biggest moral dilemmas in their lives were personal mistakes they had made when they were younger.
SNT.111633.14894	For Obama, it was his drug use, for McCain it was his failed first marriage.
SNT.111633.14895	Both candidates were on the stage together briefly between the interviews and shook hands and hugged in a moment symbolic of Warren's call for civility at the beginning and end of the forum.

SNT.123362.14897	The WHO said that "while data collection and verification remain a challenge throughout the country with the effect that weekly statistics are not always accurate or complete, the overall trend over the last 2 months is of a decreasing number of cases and deaths."
SNT.123362.14898	"The overall trend over the last two months is of a decreasing number of cases and deaths," the WHO said.
SNT.123362.14899	The number of new cholera cases in the week ending March 14 was 2,076, almost half of the 3,812 infections reported the week before, and 8,000 per week in the beginning of February.
SNT.123362.14900	The WHO stated that the fatality rate per week dropped from a peak of 6% in January to 2.3% this month.
SNT.123362.14901	91,164 total cases were reported as of March 17 since the epidemic started in August of last year, with a total of 4,307 deaths.
SNT.123362.14902	The cholera epidemic is the deadliest in Africa for a decade and a half.

SNT.58151.14928	Prince Laurent of Belgium, the youngest son of King Albert II of Belgium, has been questioned last night by the federal police and is attending today's court session in Hasselt in a marine fraud case that has gripped Belgian media since last December.
SNT.58151.14929	He arrived in a Smart car and was accompanied by his lawyer and former politician Fred Erdman.
SNT.58151.14930	The case turns around funds of the Belgian Navy that have been used to beautify the Prince's villa in Tervuren.
SNT.58151.14931	In total, € 2.2 million was supposedly diverted from the marine's purchasing services using false invoices.
SNT.58151.14932	Roughly € 185 000 was allegedly used to paint the Prince's villa, install lights in the garden, for the purchase of carpet and furniture, and for his secretariat and for animal clinics the Prince supports via his Foundation.
SNT.58151.14933	Twelve marine officers and contractors are being accused of document fraud, collusion, bribery, embezzlement of government money etc. and could face 10 years in prison.
SNT.58151.14934	The money was part of the budget that wasn't spent at the end of the year, and which would flow back to the government if the army didn't spend it.
SNT.58151.14935	The Prince, who is also an officer in the navy, is being treated only as a witness in this case, there have been no charges against him.
SNT.58151.14936	The Attorney General in Hasselt Marc Rubens has said that there are no elements in the investigation that point to the fact that Laurent was aware of the affair, however several accused have contested this in the press.
SNT.58151.14937	Technically, the villa is not the property of the Prince himself, but of the Royal Gift, which manages the real property of the Royal Family.
SNT.58151.14938	During his interview by the police last night, Prince Laurent stated that he needed funds to renovate his villa, and that Noël Vaessen, his adviser, told him the Navy could help him.
SNT.58151.14939	The Prince stated that he thought it was legal, and that he had no reason to doubt his adviser.
SNT.58151.14940	Vaessen has declared in the media during the last month that the Prince actively participated in the fraud, and that he fears a cover-up.
SNT.58151.14941	He said that the Prince was a demanding party in the operation, and that "he knew that we were arranging things to make his life and his work as comfortable as possible."
SNT.58151.14942	According to Vaessen, the Prince was in need of money to support a royal lifestyle, and "didn't even have enough money to buy food."
SNT.58151.14943	In 2001, Vaessen was discharged with honour from the army "for medical reasons", but Defence Minister André Flahaut is investigating if there was no agreement to give him his pension in exchange for the fact that he wouldn't incriminate the Prince.
SNT.58151.14944	Vaessen also accused the Prince of other things, such as racing against the high-speed train TGV on a French highway.
SNT.58151.14945	Captain Johan Claeys, one of the accused, studied with the Prince and worked at the facturation services of the Navy in 1998 and 1999.
SNT.58151.14946	One of the accused contractors, Marc Luypaerts, has told the press that the judge responsible for the investigation in Hasselt had forbidden him to speak about Prince Laurent.
SNT.58151.14947	Laurent's status as a Prince has several judicial consequences for the trial.
SNT.58151.14948	In Belgium, it's against the law to incriminate the Royal Family during a trial.
SNT.58151.14949	Also, the Prince is protected from judicial pursuit because he is also a Senator by law.
SNT.58151.14950	Justice Minister Laurette Onkelinx has issued a Royal Decrete, which the King has signed while on holiday in Napels, which would make it possible for Princes to testify in a trial.
SNT.58151.14951	However, Public Prosecutor Erwin Steyls has chosen to have Laurent interrogated by the police last night in Hasselt.
SNT.58151.14952	This was the first time during the last six years of the inquiry that the Prince was questioned.
SNT.58151.14953	Today in the court, the Prosecutor defended the act of having him questioned outside the trial, saying that there were several procedural issues.
SNT.58151.14954	First, the subpoena for the Prince wasn't issued in time to be legal.
SNT.58151.14955	Second, the details of the protocol to hear the Prince in court were not explained in the recent Royal Decrete, making it worthless -something Minister Onkelickx denied.
SNT.58151.14956	Thirdly, nobody can be forced to testify against himself, and if the Prince were to make false statements under oath, he could only be sued for perjury.
SNT.58151.14957	However, the court has decided to let him testify anyway this afternoon.
SNT.58151.14958	During the last month, the case has caused a several spin-off discussions in Belgium.
SNT.58151.14959	One of the surprises during this period was the King's Christmas Message, in which he referred to the case.
SNT.58151.14960	The regional governments are now investigating and discussing their donations to the IRGT/KINT, an environmental organisation supported by Prince Laurent.
SNT.58151.14961	But there is also an ongoing debate over the position of the Monarchy in Belgium.
SNT.58151.14962	Some politicians are suggesting to limit the role of the Monarchy, and other think that only the King and Queen, the Crown Prince or Princess and the widow(er) of the King or Queen should receive state funding.

SNT.159837.14967	According to senior officials in the Obama administration, the U.S. is to significantly and permanently reduce its stockpile of nuclear weapons by thousands of weapons as part of a major rethinking of American nuclear policy.
SNT.159837.14968	The move is coming as part of a major policy review intended to stop the proliferation of nuclear weapons around the world.
SNT.159837.14969	According to an unnamed official, the review "will point to dramatic reductions in the stockpile, while maintaining a strong and reliable deterrent."
SNT.159837.14970	As part of the new policy, conventional weapons will have a greater role in the future.
SNT.159837.14971	According to officials, there are thousands of weapons that could be retired, largely by eliminating those currently stored.
SNT.159837.14972	The move comes as a significant step towards Obama's stated goal of reducing and eventually ending the spread of nuclear weapons worldwide.
SNT.159837.14973	The policy changes come as part of the Nuclear Posture Review, a document which is undertaken by all presidents.
SNT.159837.14974	In addition to the reduction of nuclear weapons, Obama's review will also adjust the United States' defense towards non-nuclear options, including missile defense, largely within striking distance of the Persian Gulf to reduce the threat posed by countries such as Iran.
SNT.159837.14975	A centerpiece of the new policy is a new plan called the "Prompt Global Strike," which involves a new type of conventional weapon that could be fired from the U.S. and reach anywhere in the world within an hour, providing an effective option for attacks worldwide, such as against a missile launch from North Korea or a strike against Al-Qaeda in Pakistan.
SNT.159837.14976	The new weapons would achieve the same effects as nuclear weapons, without the threat of conventional war escalating into nuclear war.
SNT.159837.14977	The changes reflect a new focus on nonproliferation and arms control by the Obama administration, policies that were largely dismissed by the Bush administration.
SNT.159837.14978	In conjunction with new domestic policies, the Obama administration is trying to win passage of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which would ban all nuclear explosions for any purposes.
SNT.159837.14979	The treaty was defeated in the 1990s, during the Clinton presidency, and still faces strong resistance in the U.S. Senate.
SNT.159837.14980	The Obama administration is also trying to revise the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty to close loopholes that have been exploited by North Korea and Iran.
SNT.159837.14981	The administration has also been pressured to redefine the role of America's nuclear arsenal.
SNT.159837.14982	Democrats have been pressuring the administration to formally declare that the role of America's nuclear weapons is solely to deter nuclear attack on the United States.
SNT.159837.14983	American military officials, as well as some officials within the White House, however, have urged the administration to retain more ambiguous wording from the Bush era, which says that nuclear deterrence is only the primary role of American nuclear weapons, which would leave open the option of using nuclear weapons against enemies that threaten the US with chemical or biological weapons.

SNT.121110.15016	A team of scientists at Stanford University claim to have detected a subtle, missing element of Einstein's theory of relativity.
SNT.121110.15017	In a press release dated February 16th, Robert Kahn, Stanford University's Public Affairs Coordinator, announced the experimental confirmation of frame dragging, an effect in which the presence of a rotating body causes space itself to be pulled along as the body rotates.
SNT.121110.15018	While the effect was theorized by Josef Lense and Hans Thirring as far back as 1918, the small scale of the effect, as little as one part in a trillion for a satellite orbiting the Earth, made detecting the effect difficult.
SNT.121110.15019	The observation was made by the Gravity Probe B satellite, which carries finely-machined gyroscopes.
SNT.121110.15020	Scientists looked for small changes in the motion of the gyroscopes to detect the frame dragging effect, as well as the much larger geodetic effect – small corrections to the Earth's gravitational field due to differences between Einstein's and Newton's theories of gravity.
SNT.121110.15021	The experiment was conducted on the satellite from 2004 to 2005.
SNT.121110.15022	However, the complexity of the data analysis along with unforeseen engineering problems have made finding the effect in the experiment's results difficult.
SNT.121110.15023	In particular, the presence of small electrical charges on the gyroscopes interfered with their results.
SNT.121110.15024	Francis Everitt, the experiment's Principal Investigator, stresses in an interview with the New York Times that their announcement is only preliminary and that, with further analysis, they hope to improve the precision of their results; currently, they say they have only detected the frame dragging effect to within plus or minus fifteen percent of its expected value.
SNT.121110.15025	The theory of general relativity was developed by Albert Einstein in the early 20th century to explain the behavior of moving objects in space, after the discovery that the speed of light was always the same no matter how the person measuring it was moving.
SNT.121110.15026	While it successfully explains many strange behaviors in space, such as the slow shifting of the orbit of Mercury and the bending of light by massive objects such as black holes, testing the theory on Earth has always been difficult due to the small scale of relativity's effects in everyday life.
SNT.112703.15027	The 'Invitational Games for the Deaf, Taipei 2008' started yesterday in Taipei, Taiwan.
SNT.112703.15028	After table tennis and soccer, events from martial arts including karate, judo, and taekwondo were featured mainly in the 2nd matchday.
SNT.112703.15029	Unlike the taekwondo event which applied a single elimination rule, events from karate and judo applied round robin rules in their competitions.
SNT.125464.15030	A University of Georgia marketing professor has allegedly killed three people and injured two others today in the southeastern United States.
SNT.125464.15031	The shooting took place approximately 12:25 p.m around the Athens Community Theater in the Athens-Clarke County, in the northeast part of Georgia.
SNT.125464.15032	Authorities suspect George Zinkhan in the shooting and have issued a nationwide alert for him and his 2005 red Jeep Liberty with Georgia license plate AIX1376.
SNT.125464.15033	The Atlanta Journal Constitution (AJC) reports that two handguns were found at the scene.
SNT.125464.15034	Athens-Clarke County Police Captain Clarence Holeman reported that two others were injured by shrapnel, and the extent of their injuries is unknown.
SNT.125464.15035	A discussion took place before an evening performance between the alleged shooter and one of the victims.
SNT.125464.15036	The AJC reports that the victims were Marie Bruce, 47, Ben Teague, 63, and Tom Tanner, 40.
SNT.125464.15037	Clarke County coroner Sonny Wilson said Saturday night that all three were shot multiple times.
SNT.125464.15038	Bruce was the wife of the alleged shooter and president of the theater company, while the others were part of a production of Sherlock Holmes: The Final Adventure.
SNT.125464.15039	Tanner was performing in the production, and Teague was a member of the production crew.
SNT.125464.15040	Police also report that Zinkhan was involved in an argument with an unidentified man before the shooting occurred.
SNT.125464.15041	According to Capt. Clarence Holeman of the Athens-Clarke County Police Dept., the two people wounded suffered non-life-threatening injuries and were taken to St. Mary's Hospital in Athens.
SNT.125464.15042	Holeman also confirmed that both victims were injured by ricochet: one in the leg and one in the foot.
SNT.125464.15043	Zinkhan is reported to have left his two youngest children in the car while at theater, and then left to drop them off at the home of his his neighbor Robert Covington.
SNT.125464.15044	Zinkhan reportedly told Covington that there had been an emergency and would be gone for about an hour.
SNT.125464.15045	"Our first thoughts are for safety of the university community and for prompt apprehension of the person responsible."
SNT.125464.15046	"Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of all those who have been affected," University of Georgia President Michael F. Adams said in an official statement.
SNT.125464.15047	Matt Hardy, 22 years old, was at the scene of the crime, and had seen his friend Tom Tanner being shot twice.
SNT.125464.15048	His father John Hardy commented to reporters that "at 22 you're not supposed to watch people die."
SNT.125464.15049	Matt Hardy spoke to investigators and departed with his parents.
SNT.125464.15050	The university sent text messages and e-mails to students advising them of the potentially dangerous situation.
SNT.125464.15051	Police are requesting that anyone who comes in contact with the suspect dial 911 and exercise extreme caution.
SNT.125464.15052	Zinkhan has been described as a 57-year-old Caucasian with a goatee-style beard and full mustache.
SNT.125464.15053	He has blue eyes and brown hair worn above the ear according to his most recent photograph.
SNT.125464.15054	He was reported to have been wearing blue shorts with a polo shirt at the time of the shooting, and he may be driving the red Jeep.
SNT.104553.15055	The BBC has reported that 8000 schools have been fully or partially closed by today’s national UK teachers strike.
SNT.104553.15056	The majority of state schools in the city of Bristol are closing for the strike, although many of the schools for students age 16+ are expected to remain open.
SNT.104553.15057	Some schools that originally said they would be closed have made the decision not to close for the strike.
SNT.104553.15058	The Guardian reports that the strike, which is expected to take place on Thursday, will be the first national teachers' strike in 21 years.
SNT.104553.15059	Earlier this week, John Dunford from the Association of School and College Leaders told The Guardian that: "Most secondary schools will be partially closed; a thousand could close."
SNT.2756.15060	Republicans and lobbyists close to President George W. Bush have reported that the White House will propose changing the formula for establishing initial Social Security benefit levels in order to cut guaranteed expenditures on future retirees, according to today's Washington Post.
SNT.2756.15061	The Social Security Administration would no longer use the increase in wages over a worker’s lifetime to calculate retirees’ first-year benefits but would use inflation rates instead.
SNT.2756.15062	The new “price indexing” formula will reduce individual benefits and overall Social Security outlays because the inflation rate typically is much lower than the rise in wages.
SNT.2756.15063	The full impact of the change will be felt in the middle of the century.
SNT.2756.15064	The Bush Administration proposal, which will be offered to Congress in February or March 2005, is part of an overall Social Security reform package that also would create “personal investment accounts” into which individual taxpayers could divert part of their payroll taxes.
SNT.2756.15065	The White House believes that the shortfall in benefits created by the adoption of price indexing would be made up by capital gains from the stocks and bonds held by individual taxpayers in their personal investment accounts.
SNT.2756.15066	The move is akin to the private sector's migration from defined benefit retirement plans to defined contribution benefit plans such as 401(k)s as almost half of a worker’s benefits will not be guaranteed by the year 2075.
SNT.2756.15067	President Bush will support the move to price indexing for calculating initial benefits by pointing out that it was the approach recommended by his 2001 Commission to Strengthen Social Security.
SNT.2756.15068	Benefits currently are calculated by averaging a worker’s earnings in their 35 highest-paid years and adjusting earnings to factor in cost of living standards at the worker’s retirement age.
SNT.2756.15069	Under the Bush proposal, rather than adjusting benefits on the basis of earnings growth, the calculation would be based on the increase in the consumer price index over those years.
SNT.2756.15070	The implementation of "price indexing" would cut future Social Security costs by trillions of dollars.
SNT.2756.15071	However, the cuts in guaranteed benefits for middle-class and some high-income workers would be substantial: 9.9% for workers retiring in 2022, over 25% for workers retiring in 2042, and 46% for workers retiring in 2075.
SNT.2756.15072	Opponents of the price-indexing proposal point out that inflation-based calculations of benefits, by linking benefits to prices but not wage levels, would cut retirees out from future increases in living standards since it is wages and not prices that determine standards of living.
SNT.2756.15073	While American Association of Retired Persons (AARP) Policy Director John Rother concedes that many of the arguments of opponents are valid, price indexing is inevitable and must be viewed in the context of President Bush’s total reform package.
SNT.2756.15074	Rother points out that Social Security benefits, which currently equal 42 percent of the earnings of an average worker retiring at age 65, would be reduced to 20% of pre-retirement earnings for future retirees, thus potentially freezing retirees into today’s standard of living.
SNT.2756.15075	However, Rother says that price indexing has to be linked to Bush’s private investment accounts as income from the accounts give retirees the chance to make up the shortfalls.
SNT.9259.15076	International Labor Day, or May Day, has been marked by protests throughout Switzerland.
SNT.9259.15077	Roughly 12,000 protesters organized across the country, rallying against the dismantling of social welfare, as well as wage dumping and the large salaries of top company officials.
SNT.9259.15078	The protests were peaceful, although minor skirmishes did occur in Zurich and Lucerne.
SNT.9259.15079	These usually involved clashes between left and right extremists rather than with authorities.
SNT.9259.15080	In one case, bottles and fireworks were used as weapons, but no injuries were reported.
SNT.9259.15081	Protesters in Geneva demand reform regarding illegal immigration, and equality for men and women.
SNT.9259.15082	In Zurich trade unions urged the free movement of people, as well as an ending to the pressure on salaries.
SNT.9259.15083	Vasco Pedrina, Co-president of the union Unia, called the difference between high and low incomes a "existential and human tragedy".
SNT.9259.15084	Pedrina and others, including Bern mayor Alexander Tschäppät, spoke out during the Saturday and Sunday period of protests.
SNT.275116.15085	A recently published nationwide survey of US teenagers indicates boys tend to masturbate more — and start younger — than girls.
SNT.275116.15086	It also finds boys who masturbate are more likely to engage in safe sex than boys who don't.
SNT.275116.15087	Dr. Cynthia L. Robbins, the study's lead author from Indiana University in Indianapolis, spoke of the need for the academic community to focus more on masturbation.
SNT.275116.15088	"Many adolescent boys and girls masturbate, and among sexually active teens masturbation is associated with other sexual behaviors and condom use."
SNT.275116.15089	"It is important to recognize that masturbation is an important and normal component of adolescent sexual development."
SNT.275116.15090	The survey, named the National Survey of Sexual Health and Behavior (NSSHB), was supported by Church & Dwight, which makes Trojan condoms.
SNT.275116.15091	A representative nationwide sample of 820 teens 14–17 years old participated in the study with parental permission.
SNT.275116.15092	The findings were published Monday in the Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine.
SNT.275116.15093	Male and female respondents were asked to note how frequently they masturbated in the past three months, the past year, and throughout their lifetime.
SNT.275116.15094	They were also asked to recall whether they masturbated alone or with a partner, and also how often they used condoms.
SNT.275116.15095	Nearly three-fourths of boys reported having masturbated, compared to only less than half of girls.
SNT.275116.15096	About half of boys reported masturbating twice or more per week, also higher than the 23 percent of girls.
SNT.275116.15097	Masturbation rates for both genders increased along with age, though only boys were more likely to report having "recently" engaged in the activity as they grew older.
SNT.275116.15098	Among adolescents who engage in oral or vaginal sex, boys who masturbate were eight times more likely to use a condom than boys who don't.
SNT.275116.15099	The researchers who conducted the study urge more open and educational discussion of this highly stigmatized topic.
SNT.275116.15100	"The findings of this study together with existing publications on masturbation should be used by health care providers to inform, educate and reassure adolescents about masturbation to provide competent and comprehensive sexuality education in the clinical setting".
SNT.10698.15101	May 27, 2005 Mount Qomolangma, known in the west as Mount Everest, may be taller than ever, and a group of 24 Chinese researchers have scaled the peak and made observations they hope will document its current height.
SNT.10698.15102	In 1975 the peak was surveyed at a height of 8 848 metres, in line with previous calculations, but a U.S. survey team in 1999 measured it at 8 850m.
SNT.10698.15103	The growth to some extent fits current theories regarding the geology of the region, a region with crustal upthrust.
SNT.10698.15104	The growth may also be due in part to rapid glacier retreat on the peak's slopes, and the mountain springing back as the weight of snow melts and runs off.
SNT.10698.15105	At the same time, recent theories suggest the mountain is also shrinking.
SNT.10698.15106	The peak may be getting smaller from subsidence as it reaches extreme heights, and again the glaciers and snow help to stabilize and expand the mountain itself.
SNT.10698.15107	There is some disagreement regarding the methods of measurement used previously, so the researchers spent an hour at the summit taking measurements using radar, satellite, and other methods on 6 points.
SNT.10698.15108	The average of the measurements will be used to make the official Chinese measurement, which remains at 8 848.
SNT.10698.15109	Results of the expedition are expected to be available in August.
SNT.10698.15110	A previous measurement team from Italy also used the radar methodology in 2004, but their results have not yet been published.
SNT.10698.15111	The mountain straddles the border between Tibet and Nepal, and is known by several names.
SNT.10698.15112	In Chinese, 珠穆朗瑪峰 (pinyin: Zhūmùlǎngmǎ Fēng); Tibetan Qomolangma ("Mother of the Universe"); in Nepal Sagarmatha ("Forehead of the Sky"); and in English named after Sir George Everest.
SNT.54350.15113	In a conscience vote last night, Wednesday, parliament decided that the alcohol purchasing for New Zealanders will not be raised to 20 but instead will stay at the current age of 18.
SNT.54350.15114	The vote was 72-49 with the noes as the majority, a conscience vote is where the individual Member of Parliament (MP) votes instead of the party and their policies.
SNT.54350.15115	The bill was brought before Parliament with the intent of placing the drinking age back at 20 following its lowering to 18 in 1999.
SNT.54350.15116	It was first drafted by Matt Robson of the NZ Progressive Party, and was then taken on by Martin Gallagher from the New Zealand Labour Party.
SNT.54350.15117	However, the Labour-led government is being attacked for interfering with the liquor purchase age bill.
SNT.54350.15118	Before the debate on the bill, two ministers who are against raising the age, justice minister Mark Burton and associate health minister, Damien O'Conner both announced that they would fully review the sale/supply of liquor to people below the age of 18, regardless of whether the bill were passed or not.
SNT.54350.15119	The review will most likely look at how many off-licence outlets there are and increased law enforcement of the drink age.
SNT.54350.15120	Mr Burton said that he did not pre-empt the bill voting, he said: "It was important to ensure all options were on the table before the vote."
SNT.54350.15121	"What we are saying is you can have confidence that if the bill doesn't proceed there will be an alternative vehicle for addressing the issues immediately thereafter."
SNT.54350.15122	Many MPs said that it was unorthodox to intrude in such a manner in the voting process.
SNT.54350.15123	Leader of Jim Anderton's Progressive coalition and supporter of the bill, Jim Anderton, said: "Making a last-minute plea to MPs is not to be fooled by the promise of the unnecessary review."
SNT.54350.15124	"This is the review you have when you want to give parliamentarians a soft option."
SNT.54350.15125	"And I hear that sigh of relief in many places, 'oh gosh you've got a review so we don't have to make a hard decision'."
SNT.54350.15126	"Well this is the place for hard decisions and this is where the buck stops."
SNT.54350.15127	Christopher Bishop, a spokesman for the Keep it 18 campaign, said: "We welcome the Government's moves to review the supply of alcohol to minors in the likely event that the Sale of Liquor Amendment Bill is defeated today."
SNT.54350.15128	"Raising the drinking age is never going to work as a way of dealing with New Zealand's drinking culture."
SNT.54350.15129	"It is a simplistic and knee-jerk solution – a legislative sledgehammer."
SNT.54350.15130	Chester Burrows, National MP, said: "My experience is I've seen too many pissed young people, raped young people, assaulted young people."
SNT.54350.15131	Gordon Copeland, United Future MP, who also preferred the split age, said he had "no doubt the move would influence the way people voted."
SNT.54350.15132	Ron Mark, New Zealand First MP, said: "Are we going to do something, or are we going to do nothing?" asked New Zealand First list MP Ron Mark.
SNT.54350.15133	"We can at least let this bill go through to the next stage."
SNT.54350.15134	Ross Bell, spokesman for the Drug Foundation, said: "Not only is such a review too narrow, it also seemed to pre-empt the outcome of Wednesday's debate."
SNT.54350.15135	"A cynical person might think the announcement gave MPs an excuse not to support the bill."
SNT.54350.15136	"That review has already been looked at by the Law and Order Select Committee, and what is needed is a review of price and availability of alcohol."
SNT.54350.15137	However it has been suggested by the select committee previously researching the drinking problem in New Zealand that there is little hard evidence 18 & 19 year olds are buying alcohol for minors, with the largest problem instead being the purchasing of alcohol by parents for their children.
SNT.61887.15138	A rupture in the underground stormwater drain system opened a huge sinkhole on February 23, killing three people and bringing down twelve houses in Guatemala City.
SNT.61887.15139	Teenagers Irma and David Soyos and their father, 53-year old Domingo Soyos were killed when their house collapsed into the sinkhole.
SNT.61887.15140	Nearly a thousand people were evacuated from the San Antonio neighborhood after the collapse.
SNT.61887.15141	Wikinews interviewed Eric Haddox, a civil engineer who has visited the site of the sinkhole and spoken to the engineers working on fixing the drain.
SNT.61887.15142	Mr. Haddox, who specialises in the building of earthworks, roads, water supply and sewage systems, and is working as a missionary in Guatemala, visited the site following the collapse to help in the recovery effort.
SNT.61887.15143	Mr. Haddox told us that the size of the hole is much smaller than the 330 feet depth originally reported and that the erosion causing the collapse is believed to have happened over a long time, and not just during the recent rains as initially suspected.
SNT.61887.15144	There are also concerns that a four-story building less than a metre from the edge of the hole may collapse as the earth under the building continues to be eroded.
SNT.68018.15145	The Scottish National Party (SNP), which supports Scottish independence from the UK, has pulled off a historic, albeit narrow, victory in yesterday's Scottish elections.
SNT.68018.15146	In the third Scottish election since the opening of the Scottish Parliament in 1999, the left of centre SNP beat the ruling Labour Party by a single seat.
SNT.68018.15147	It won 47 seats, while Labour won 46, down from the current 50.
SNT.68018.15148	It is the first time since the parliament opened that Labour has been beaten, and the first time in fifty years that they have not had a majority of Scottish constituency seats in any election.
SNT.68018.15149	SNP leader Alex Salmond declared: "Scotland has changed for good and forever."
SNT.68018.15150	He added that the Labour Party had "lost the moral authority to govern Scotland."
SNT.68018.15151	The current First Minister of Scotland, Jack McConnell of Labour said: "While I recognise that the SNP are the largest party by the narrowest of margins, Alex Salmond must himself recognise that he does not have a majority in the Scottish Parliament or anywhere near a majority of the vote."
SNT.68018.15152	It is believed that many factors caused the Labour vote to slump and the SNP vote to rise, including the war in Iraq and the renewal of Trident, which are both unpopular in Scotland.
SNT.68018.15153	The election also raises a serious dilemma for the Labour party's Gordon Brown, a Scotsman widely tipped to succeed Tony Blair as the next prime minister of the United Kingdom.
SNT.68018.15154	Brown is vehement in his support of the Union, and is a Westminster (London parliament) MP for Kirkcaldy.
SNT.68018.15155	An SNP government in Scotland will find itself facing the very Labour party it beat in power in London.

SNT.122789.15160	Flooding has also reached neighbouring Angola, where nineteen people have died, according to the Red Cross.

SNT.37496.15170	Fighting words were exchanged in the Australian House of Representatives over the matter of the division of Medicare safety net payments per electorate.
SNT.37496.15171	The Minister for Health and Ageing Tony Abbott (Liberal, Warringah) had introduced a policy that the Government would pay Medicare users up to a fixed amount — the safety net — to help in addressing "gaps" in certain payments which Medicare would not cover, such as certain hospital payments.
SNT.37496.15172	The Opposition was opposed to the idea on efficacy counts.
SNT.37496.15173	Abbott was asked a Dorothy Dixer in Question Time today about the benefits of the safety net.
SNT.37496.15174	He alleged that criticism by the Opposition Health spokeswoman Julia Gillard (Labor, Lalor) that the safety net favoured Liberal/National Party coalition electorates was misleading as it was a Labor electorate, Grayndler that received the "highest safety net benefits per electorate".
SNT.37496.15175	This led Gillard to make a personal explanation after Question Time, stating that "the top four electorates receiving money under the Medicare safety net are Wentworth, North Sydney, Bradfield and Warringah" — all coalition electorates.
SNT.37496.15176	The Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley (Labor, Brand), put a question to the Speaker of the House, David Hawker (Liberal, Wannon) asking of the Speaker his "assurance that no person is being deliberately misled by the actions of any other person".
SNT.37496.15177	Abbott had then interjected towards Beazley, saying "You big bellowing cow"; the Speaker asked Abbott to withdraw, but Abbott mentioned that "the Leader of the Opposition regularly interjects 'pompous ass' and 'goose', but I am happy to withdraw".
SNT.37496.15178	Beazley then responded through the Speaker saying of Abbott, "I think that he is a sleazy, dummy-spitting, little git."
SNT.37496.15179	Abbott then made a personal explanation of his own, saying "The safety net benefit per person in the electorate of the member for Grayndler was $591, the highest in New South Wales...the safety net benefit in the electorate of Sydney was $589, the second highest...the benefit in the electorate of Lowe was $458, the third highest".
SNT.37496.15180	The matter was not further raised at the time, but after the Matter of Public Importance debate, Gillard moved a motion to suspend standing orders which would prevent Abbott from explaining his earlier claim "when this claim is totally untrue", to correct the "grossly inaccurate and misleading statement", to "apologise to all Members in this place" and to "apologize to the Member for Grayndler and his constituents".
SNT.37496.15181	Gillard also listed the amounts of payments "released by the Minister himself", that Wentworth received $7.8 million, North Sydney received $7.5 million, Bradfield received $6.9 million, Warringah received $6.3 million; whereas Grayndler received only $3.6 million.
SNT.37496.15182	She attempted to debate the motion but a gag motion to silence Gillard was moved and won because of Government numbers.
SNT.37496.15183	Anthony Albanese, the Labor member for Grayndler attempted to second the motion but the gag was moved on him as well.
SNT.37496.15184	The final vote on the motion was lost 55 to 79.
SNT.452286.15185	In the gold medal match at water polo's FINA World League Final tonight between the Australia Stingers and United States women's national water polo team, Australia lost 4–6 to the USA in the last major competition before the 2012 Summer Olympics.
SNT.452286.15186	The victory made for seven World League Super Final titles for Team USA.
SNT.452286.15187	At 7:00 p.m. Chinese local time, 9:00 p.m. Australian local time, the game got under way, with a Tweet from Australian Water Polo for fans at home who could not watch the game live.
SNT.452286.15188	The Australians were down at quarter time, 1–2 with the team's only goal coming from Bronwen Knox off a pass by Kate Gynther.
SNT.452286.15189	By half time, Australia had battled back to take the lead 4–3, only to finish the third period tied 4–4 with the United States, and eventually lose 4–6.
SNT.452286.15190	In the lead up to the World League Final, the Australians spent time in Singapore before departing for China.
SNT.452286.15191	While in Singapore, players had an opportunity to relax at the pool and several, including Knox, Rowena Webster, Nicola Zagame, and Melissa Rippon were very active on Twitter.
SNT.452286.15192	The team arrived in Shanghai and the Shanghai Institute of Sport a week before the start of the FINA Super League Finals.
SNT.452286.15193	During their week-long preparation, they worked on strength and fitness training.
SNT.452286.15194	When away from the pool, they did not have access to Twitter, Facebook, or television and had to entertain themselves using other means.
SNT.452286.15195	Players finally explored the city six days after their arrival.
SNT.452286.15196	With limited opportunities for amusement in the hotel room during the competition, assistant coach Ryan Moar updated his Twitter account and played with a toy helicopter.
SNT.452286.15197	Several of the players who were active on Twitter before departing for China stopped updating, including Webster, Rippon, and Zagame.
SNT.452286.15198	Knox and Moran continued to provide updates on Twitter and Instagram throughout the competition.
SNT.452286.15199	Australian game days during the tournament included warming up poolside before the start of their games, and cooling down in the pool after them.
SNT.452286.15200	Going into their match against the USA, they notched an 8–7 victory over China, an 18 to nil victory against Germany, and a 9–7 overtime shootout win against Russia.
SNT.452286.15201	On gold medal game day, Jane Moran updated her Twitter account to say "Final of World League Super Finals today v USA - goooo Stingers! ‪#stingerspride".
SNT.452286.15202	About eight hours prior to game time, the team finished their final training session.
SNT.452286.15203	Earlier in the afternoon, prior to game time in Australia, Channel 9 ran a feature on the team.
SNT.452286.15204	Prior to the start of the game, the Australian Stingers official team Twitter account mocked Team USA for their team-branded k tape.
SNT.452286.15205	During the pre-game warm up, team members did a variety of things including playing with their phones, warming up, and getting their arms taped.
SNT.452286.15206	It was business as usual for the team that had beaten the United States the previous month at the VISA Water Polo International.

SNT.17046.15212	However, NASA has announced the grounding of all further planned Shuttle launches until they have a firm understanding of why the foam comes away, and what to do about it.

SNT.10431.15224	In an effort to ease complaints by the U.S. and Europe about a heavy influx of low priced Chinese goods, China will raise export tariffs on 74 categories of textile products in June.
SNT.10431.15225	This follows plans from the U.S. to impose quotas on Chinese textiles and clothing.
SNT.10431.15226	Products likely to see an increase from the Chinese move include synthetic fiber shirts, trousers, knit shirts and blouses, cotton shirts, and combined cotton yarn.
SNT.10431.15227	Last week, similar restrictions were imposed by the U.S. on cotton trousers, knit shirts, and underwear.
SNT.10431.15228	Currently, a 2.5 cent charge per item is imposed; the new tariff will raise this to the equivalent of 12 cents per piece now.
SNT.10431.15229	While this is a fourfold increase, it is not expected to affect consumer prices.
SNT.10431.15230	Because of this, some doubt the tariff will have any effect on correcting the trade imbalance.
SNT.10431.15231	This move is in response to U.S. trade quotas imposed due to concerns that increased Chinese goods would put U.S. textile manufacturers out of business.
SNT.10431.15232	According to Auggie Tantillo, executive director of the American Manufacturing Trade Action Coalition, a textile industry group in the U.S., the move will preserve 10,000 U.S. jobs.
SNT.10431.15233	The new U.S. trade quota will limit the growth of Chinese textile imports to 7.5 percent compared with shipments over the past year.
SNT.10431.15234	Prior to January 1, a global quota system helped regulate the trade.
SNT.10431.15235	With the quota system gone, fears have arisen that a flood of Chinese goods could undercut U.S. competitiveness in the market.
SNT.10431.15236	China is able to market its goods cheaply due to an artificially weak yuan.
SNT.10431.15237	The U.S. Treasury criticized the China yuan policy as "highly distortionary", posing a major risk to China's economy itself and to global economic growth.
SNT.10431.15238	They challenged China to revalue its currency to bring it to a level they believe will allow fairer competition between global manufacturers.
SNT.10431.15239	Chinese Commerce Minister Bo Xilai said, "I believe they are not reasonable".
SNT.10431.15240	Laura Jones, a representative of large retailers, also criticized the move, saying "These restrictions on imports from China will do absolutely nothing to help the U.S. textile industry -- and the government knows it."

SNT.659423.15294	A main belt asteroid, No. 274301, has been named after Wikipedia, a free encyclopedia.
SNT.659423.15295	The information became available on the Minor Planet Center's website yesterday.
SNT.659423.15296	The decision of the Committee for Small Body Nomenclature to assign the name "Wikipedia" to the asteroid was published in the Minor Planet Circular of January 27, published online yesterday, page 82403.
SNT.659423.15297	It was submitted to the Committee by the head of the Andrushivka Astronomical Observatory in Ukraine, Yuri Ivashchenko.
SNT.659423.15298	The asteroid 274301 Wikipedia was discovered by the team of astronomers of Andrushivka Astronomical Observatory.
SNT.659423.15299	At first it was observed by that team on August 25, 2008 at 22:47 (UTC).
SNT.659423.15300	It was also observed on the next night and two weeks later on September 6.
SNT.659423.15301	Accurate calculation of its orbit showed asteroid 2008 QH24 is the same as 1997 RO4 and 2007 FK34.
SNT.659423.15302	The asteroid had been previously spotted by observatories including Caussols-ODAS in France, and Mt. Lemmon Survey and Steward Observatory in Arizona, US.
SNT.659423.15303	On April 18, 2011 the minor planet received the number 274301.

SNT.143327.15320	The ice that was present in 1912 gradually decreased by 85% by 2000, and by 2007 another 26% of the amount in 2000.
SNT.143327.15321	This was the first time that the volume of the ice in Kilimanjaro was measured.
SNT.143327.15322	The tests were conducted by Lonnie Thompson, a professor at Ohio University.
SNT.143327.15323	"The fact that so many glaciers throughout the tropics and subtropics are showing similar responses suggests an underlying common cause," Thompson said.
SNT.143327.15324	Change in cloudiness and weather could have also been factors in the retreat of the ice, especially in recent decades, scientists said.
SNT.143327.15325	These findings were first published in the journal proceedings of United States National Academy of Sciences (NAS) on Monday.

SNT.80941.15364	Canada has a budget surplus of CA$13.8 billion for the 2006–2007 fiscal year, totaling 1% of Canada's gross domestic product (GDP), Finance Minister Jim Flaherty announced today.
SNT.80941.15365	The record surplus was boosted by revenue from government corporations to $14.2 billion, far exceeding the government's projections of $9.2 billion and surpassing the record set by the previous year's $13.2 billion surplus.
SNT.80941.15366	By federal law, all surplus must be used to pay down Canada's debt, and is not available for spending.
SNT.80941.15367	$90 billion in debt payments over the last ten years have reduced its debt to $467 billion or 32.3% of national GDP, its lowest level in a quarter century.
SNT.80941.15368	The announced debt payment is the largest in Canadian history.
SNT.80941.15369	The payment also reduced Canada's annual interest payments by $725 million, which the government pledged to pass on to taxpayers through tax returns and reduced income taxes.
SNT.80941.15370	The Conservative's "Tax Back Guarantee", proposed in the March budget, promises that money saved on interest payments will be deducted from Canadians' taxes.
SNT.80941.15371	The Globe and Mail predicts the tax returns will be 30–40 dollars per taxpayer.
SNT.80941.15372	Canada has posted ten consecutive budget surpluses in the last decade.
SNT.80941.15373	The Canadian economy, the 8th largest in the world, has benefited from rising global demand for its export commodities, particularly oil and copper, as well as record corporate profits.
SNT.80941.15374	This surplus was further increased by a $700 million drop from expected government spending.
SNT.80941.15375	Prime Minister Stephen Harper cautioned that the Canadian economy is still facing "tough times" in its forestry, manufacturing, and some export industries.
SNT.80941.15376	Critics point out that the Conservative government had said Canadians were overtaxed when they took office, and had vowed to eliminate "surplus surprises".
SNT.16801.15377	Charles Chibitty, the last surviving member of the group of 17 who served in World War II as the Comanche "code talkers" died in a Tulsa, Oklahoma nursing home July 20.
SNT.16801.15378	Chibitty was among the 14 Comanches who landed with the D-Day invasion of Normandy Beaches where they reported by radio to division headquarters on the progress of the landings.
SNT.16801.15379	The Comanche were dubbed code talkers because the American Indian language has no written record, and it was never broken by the Germans during the war.
SNT.16801.15380	One of the first messages transmitted in Comanche language during the landings was "right beach, wrong place".
SNT.16801.15381	It warned soldiers they landed about a half mile from their intended target.
SNT.16801.15382	Chibitty served with a unit that landed on Utah Beach on June 6, 1944.
SNT.16801.15383	Mr.Chibitty served with the rank of a Corporal in the 4th Infantry Division that engaged in the breakthrough of the Siegfried line in Hurtgen Forest.
SNT.16801.15384	His division also saw action in the Battle of the Bulge and the rescue of the "Lost Battalion".
SNT.16801.15385	His division was among the first to undertake the liberation of Paris.
SNT.16801.15386	Then later, the 4th Infantry was the first to enter Germany.
SNT.16801.15387	The Comanches, who came from the Lawton area in Oklahoma, heard rumors of a military plan to organize a native speaking unit.
SNT.16801.15388	He enlisted in 1941, and along with 19 others, they were trained for special duty by the U.S. Army Signal Corps.
SNT.16801.15389	All were sent to Fort Benning, but three remained state-side because they had dependents and deployment in the mission was dangerous.
SNT.16801.15390	The French Government gave special honors to the Comanches by bestowing them with the Chevalier of the National Order of Merit in 1989.
SNT.16801.15391	Mr. Chibitty was honored in 1999 when the Pentagon bestowed on him the Knowlton Award.
SNT.16801.15392	In a 1999 interview with the Armed Forces Information Center, Chibitty said: "The Navajo did the same thing."
SNT.16801.15393	"The Navajos became code talkers about a year after the Comanches, but there were over a hundred of them because they had so much territory [in the Pacific Theater] to cover."
SNT.16801.15394	Joe Holley of the Washington Post recalled this quote from Mr. Chibitty in 2002: "It’s strange, but growing up as a child I was forbidden speak my native language at school."
SNT.16801.15395	My language helped win the war, and that makes me very proud.
