SNT.500589.18289	Officials in Dallas county have declared a public health emergency.
SNT.500589.18290	Officials there have requested use of five planes, intended to spray most of North Dallas, as well as other sections of the city.
SNT.500589.18291	Tim Whitley, a city official in Malakoff, told Wikinews his city has begun using a pesticide specialist to spray two times weekly.
SNT.500589.18292	According to Whitley, certain atmospheric conditions, such as wind speed and humidity, must be right before the large scale treatments can occur.
SNT.500589.18293	He explained two treatments per week is more often than usual for the city.
SNT.500589.18294	"With the concerns in Dallas, we're taking it seriously", Whitley added.
SNT.500589.18295	Even in the drier climate found in Abilene, mosquitos recently tested were carrying the virus.
SNT.500589.18296	As a result, that city has increased its pesticide treatments.
SNT.500589.18297	Media sources indicate well over 80 cases of West Nile virus have been reported this year in Dallas county alone.
SNT.500589.18298	A top-ranking Dallas county official told media he views the problem with serious concern.
SNT.500589.18299	There have been nine cases of West Nile virus in the Houston region, with one of those resulting in death.
SNT.500589.18300	A New Jersey woman who is a former resident of Lubbock told media earlier this month she'd contracted the virus and believed she'd been bitten while visiting Austin.
SNT.500589.18301	About 60 percent of West Nile cases in the U.S. happen in Texas.
SNT.500589.18302	Historically, there have been some objections raised over aerial spraying and the potential health hazards distributing such chemicals may pose.
SNT.500589.18303	A California study, however, showed evidence that in areas where aerial spraying occurred, infection was six times less likely to occur.
SNT.500589.18304	The earliest cases of the virus appeared in the U.S. in the late 1990s.

SNT.99997.18318	At least three people have been killed and several buildings have been damaged.

SNT.99997.18325	Budi Waluyo, an official at the National Meteorology and Geophysics Agency said the quake occurred about 30 kilometres beneath the ground.
SNT.99997.18326	The US Geological Survey measured the quake at 7.6 on the Richter scale.
SNT.99997.18327	"The quake has no tsunami potential because it's happening under the ground, not the sea," Waluyo said.

SNT.189815.18330	Lead poisoning has taken the lives of at least 163 individuals in the northern Nigerian state of Zamfara in recent weeks.
SNT.189815.18331	Sometime during March residents of remote villages began illegally mining gold in areas of high lead concentration.
SNT.189815.18332	There have been a total of 355 reported cases, setting the fatality rate at 46%.
SNT.189815.18333	According to Henry Akpan, chief epidemiologist at Nigeria's Ministry of Health, 111 of the 163 recorded deaths have been children, many only several years old.
SNT.189815.18334	Akpan further said that officials had seen young children playing in contaminated water located near the mining sites.
SNT.189815.18335	The government had found through their yearly immunization program that there were almost no children living in the villages of Zamfara.
SNT.189815.18336	Adults from the area reported that the children had died of malaria.
SNT.189815.18337	However, after an investigation, health officials concluded that there was an abnormally large amount of lead circulating in the villagers' bodies.
SNT.189815.18338	Nigeria's government has requested assistance from international organizations, including the World Health Organization and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in averting a widespread outbreak.
SNT.189815.18339	The Ministry has meanwhile organized two camps for villagers suffering from the poison.

SNT.29797.18352	According to the Bureau of Meteorology, (BOM) 2005 was the hottest year since reliable, widespread temperature observations became available in 1910.
SNT.29797.18353	Data collected by the Bureau show Australia's annual mean temperature for 2005 was 1.09°C above the standard 1961-90 average.
SNT.29797.18354	The Bureau of Meteorology says the result is more evidence of climate change.
SNT.29797.18355	The Bureau's Blair Trewin said: "We've seen things like the general retreat of the winter snow line."
SNT.29797.18356	"We've seen a marked decrease in the frequency of frost, especially in inland Queensland," Dr Trewin said.
SNT.29797.18357	"We've seen an increase in the number of extreme hot days."
SNT.29797.18358	"All the projections we have from climate models we would expect to see continued warming through the 21st century," he said.
SNT.29797.18359	"Numbers like this ... are another piece of evidence that climate change is real and it's a real issue."
SNT.29797.18360	Despite unseasonably cool weather in the South West of Western Australia, 2005 was a hot year over most of the nation, with the Northern Territory (NT) bearing the brunt.
SNT.29797.18361	The NT area-average maximum temperature was 1.45°C above the long-term mean, the largest anomaly of any state or territory.
SNT.29797.18362	The Bureau says that while these temperature departures may seem relatively small, a 1°C increase in mean temperatures is equivalent to many southern Australian towns shifting northward by about 100km.
SNT.29797.18363	All States and Territories, apart from Victoria and Tasmania, recorded 2005 mean temperatures amongst their top two warmest years on record.
SNT.29797.18364	The only region recording a cooler than normal year was a coastal strip of Western Australia extending from Cape Leeuwin to Carnarvon.
SNT.29797.18365	Australia's previous warmest years on record were influenced by significant El Niño events, say the Bureau.
SNT.29797.18366	However, no such event occurred in 2005, making the record warmth even more unusual.
SNT.29797.18367	Since 1979, all but four years have been warmer than average in Australia.
SNT.29797.18368	Australian temperatures have increased by approximately 0.9ºC since 1910 - consistent with global warming trends.
SNT.29797.18369	Scientific studies have linked global and Australian temperature increases to the enhanced greenhouse effect.
SNT.29797.18370	The early months of 2005 were also very dry over much of Australia with the January-May period being the 2nd driest on record.
SNT.29797.18371	Australia's area-averaged rainfall is calculated from a network of around 5000 rainfall stations.
SNT.29797.18372	Observations from this network reveal that, when compared to historical records, Tasmania was the wettest State in 2005, while Queensland and Western Australia were the driest.
SNT.29797.18373	Over the New Year bushfires have caused havoc in many parts of Australia, with houses, farm stock devastated.
SNT.29797.18374	Thousands of hectares of bushland and farmland have been burnt out.
SNT.29797.18375	Environmentalists say the weather is a precursor of things to come: "2005 gave us a little taste of what life will be like if we fail to tackle climate change," Greenpeace's Catherine Fitzpatrick said.
SNT.29797.18376	"The extreme heat and bushfires of New Year's Day 2006 showed that it isn't going to be fun."
SNT.29797.18377	"If action isn't taken soon to avoid catastrophic climate change, Australians will have John Howard to blame for failing to act when he had the chance."
SNT.29797.18378	Ms Fitzpatrick said the Federal Government was as beholden to the coal and aluminium industries as the Japanese government was to whaling companies, and with far more devastating impacts.
SNT.29797.18379	"Today's figures should spur our Environment Minister ... to real action – ratify Kyoto, quit coal and move towards clean, renewable energy," Ms Fitzpatrick said.
SNT.29797.18380	Federal Environment Minister Ian Campbell said he recognised climate change was the biggest modern-day environmental challenge.
SNT.29797.18381	"I think that climate change is alarming," he said on ABC radio.
SNT.29797.18382	"I regard climate change as the number one environmental challenge …"
SNT.29797.18383	"These figures add to the weight of evidence that climate change is real and it's a problem that the world needs to work together to seek to solve."
SNT.29797.18384	Australia and the United States are the only developed nations to have refused to sign the Kyoto Protocol, which calls on countries to cut greenhouse emissions by 5.2 per cent below 1990 levels by 2012.
SNT.29797.18385	The Government argues Kyoto will not work because it does not commit developing nations to reducing emissions.
SNT.29797.18386	"It only covers just over a third of the countries of the world and ... we need something that includes all countries of the world," said Senator Campbell.
SNT.29797.18387	Many regions across the globe also reported an exceptionally warm year.
SNT.29797.18388	According to a preliminary estimate released by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), the global mean temperature for 2005 was about 0.48°C above normal, putting 2005 amongst the four warmest years globally since records commenced in 1861.

SNT.115141.18410	Financial experts believe that next year, the deficit will reach over $700 billion, while the National Debt Clock has recently run out of digits to record over $10 trillion in national debt.
SNT.115141.18411	The deficit is now equivalent to 3.2% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of the United States, with the government's total income being 17.8% of GDP, and total outlays being equivalent to 21% of GDP.
SNT.115141.18412	Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson blamed the deficit on the housing market, related markets, and slow growth.
SNT.115141.18413	He said the news would "reinforce the need to not only address short-term challenges, but pursue policies that promote economic growth and fiscal responsibility, and address entitlement reform".
SNT.115141.18414	Democrats like Senator Kent Conrad, however, placed the blame on "President Bush's failed policies".
SNT.115141.18415	"The reality is that the next president will be inheriting a fiscal and economic mess of historic proportions," said Conrad, adding that "it will take years to dig our way out".
SNT.115141.18416	Another Democrat, House Budget Committee Chairman John Spratt, also blamed the Bush administration.
SNT.115141.18417	"The eight years of this administration will include the five biggest budget deficits in history," he said.
SNT.115141.18418	"The resulting debt will be passed to our children and grandchildren."
SNT.115141.18419	Jim Nussle, director of the Office of Management and Budget said that he believes that the deficit will start to decline.
SNT.115141.18420	"The bipartisan stimulus bill and the slow economy are the primary reasons for the increase in deficit as reflected in this year's budget results."
SNT.115141.18421	"This increase reinforces the need to adopt and maintain policies that promote economic growth and fiscal responsibility, including entitlement reform and pro-growth tax policies."
SNT.115141.18422	"I am confident the economy can return to stronger growth with a declining deficit—after working through current challenges if Congress limits wasteful and excessive spending."

SNT.504776.18439	London, England — Yesterday Wikinews had the opportunity to tour the Ottobrock wheelchair repair workshops at the Paralympic Village in London.
SNT.504776.18440	It is one of a network of workshops at every Paralympic venue.
SNT.504776.18441	They are run by Ottobrock, which has been repairing wheelchairs at the Paralympics since 1988.
SNT.504776.18442	The workshop opened on August 22 and will remain until September 10.
SNT.504776.18443	They liken themselves to the pit crew of motor sport — except that they have no idea what sort of equipment they will have to work with.
SNT.504776.18444	The store room contains 15,000 spare parts, with everything from spare carbon fibre running blades to spare tyres — over 2,000 of them.
SNT.504776.18445	They stock Ottobrock parts and their competitors' too, as they have no idea what will arrive at the workshop next.
SNT.504776.18446	Athletes from around the world bring in all manner of equipment.
SNT.504776.18447	The prosthetic technicians have to deal with everything from flat tyres to broken spokes to full-scale rebuilds.
SNT.504776.18448	They frequently collaborate on determining how best to effect a repair.
SNT.504776.18449	The objective is to get the wheelchair repaired and back in service as soon as possible.
SNT.504776.18450	Those for wheelchair basketball and rugby have cambered wheels so they can spin around.
SNT.504776.18451	Ottobrock has a welding workshop where frames are repaired; the teams' equipment managers understandably cannot bring such heavy equipment with them to the games, so they rely on the workshops.
SNT.504776.18452	When a repair job is required, it is often required in a hurry.

SNT.125417.18459	The rebels have now been forced back to a small coastal strip, where about fifty thousand people have been trapped after the area was evacuated of 100,000 people.
SNT.125417.18460	Thangamuttu Sathyamurthi, a government health official in the war zone, reported that people were dying of starvation, and that there was a large deficit of medicine and food.
SNT.125417.18461	According to the medical relief group Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors without Borders), many of the people who had fled the conflict zone had gunshot and blast wounds.

SNT.125417.18465	On average, 33 civilians were killed per day at the end of January.
SNT.125417.18466	The number has now increased to an average 116 per day.

SNT.204267.18482	In the video sent to the BBC, ETA stated that, while the autonomy framework enshrined in the Spanish constitution is "not the way to satisfy the wishes of the Basque people", the organisation was committed to finding a democratic solution to the conflict.
SNT.204267.18483	Several analysts have suggested that this most recent ceasefire is based on ETA's tactics causing their support in the Basque region to plummet.

SNT.204267.18485	The BBC's Sarah Rainsford said that ETA is at the weakest point in its 51-year history and that the ceasefire may just be a ploy to disguise that weakness.
SNT.204267.18486	The group, which is listed as a terrorist organization by the European Union and the United States, have declared ceasefires several times before, which have all ended in a resumption of violence.
SNT.204267.18487	The most recent ceasefire, in 2006, led to peace talks between the group and the Spanish government, but they were interrupted by a car-bombing at Madrid's Barajas Airport.
SNT.204267.18488	The bombing was frowned upon by all involved in the peace process, including other Basque separatist parties in the region.

SNT.187266.18585	Canadian researchers from C-crest Laboratories have discovered an "unusually high" amount of bacteria in bottled water.
SNT.187266.18586	Researchers don't blame specific brands, but bottled water in general.
SNT.187266.18587	A random study found unusually high rates of heterotrophic bacteria in the bottled water, more than 500 cfu, the legal limit set by United States Pharmacopeia on how much bacteria should be present in drinking water in Canada.
SNT.187266.18588	Unusually high amounts of bacteria were present in 70% of the test samples across several brands of bottled water.
SNT.187266.18589	“Heterotrophic bacteria counts in some of the bottles were found to be in revolting figures of (100) times more than the permitted limit,” said Sonish Azam, a Canadian researcher involved in the study, “This amount of bacteria is alarming, as if we are ingesting a cup of culture.” 
SNT.187266.18589-1	“Microbiologically speaking,” she said, “tap water is purer than bottled water — most bottled water.
SNT.187266.18590	The bacteria are not very harmful to an average person, but many sensitive groups, such as the young, sick or elderly, could get sick from it.
SNT.187266.18591	"Heterotrophic bacteria counts in drinking water are not a health concern to the general public," was the concluding analyses of a recent study by the World Health Organization.

SNT.30061.18634	A woman in Australia has been killed in a shark attack.
SNT.30061.18635	The attack occurred at 5pm (Local Time) just off Amity Point, North Stradbroke Island, south-east of Brisbane.
SNT.30061.18636	The woman, described as 21, had lost both arms up to the elbow and sustained severe wounds to her torso and legs.
SNT.30061.18637	She was carried to shore by friends and was then flown by rescue helicopter to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane.
SNT.30061.18638	The woman was holidaying from Brisbane with a church camp and attempts to contact her family have been made.
SNT.30061.18639	Emergency Services Rescue Helicopter crew officer Rod Morgan said the woman had suffered massive blood loss.
SNT.30061.18640	"She was very pale" he said, "We were diverted right away and were able to be on the scene within minutes and were able to have the patient at hospital within an hour of the attack."
SNT.30061.18641	"She had life threatening injuries she had lost significant amounts of blood and the patient had what we would call an altered level of consciousness where it wasn't able to communicate directly with the patient" said Queensland Ambulance paramedic Lachlan Parker.
SNT.30061.18642	There were many witnesses at the scene and they are now being interviewed by Police at Amity Point.
SNT.30061.18643	One witness, who asks to not be identified, described that the victim was swimming in the sea with her Border Collie.
SNT.30061.18644	When the attack happened, the dog ran home to raise the alarm.
SNT.30061.18645	"I was across the road from where she was staying and I saw the dog come flying up the road all wet and shivering and whimpering," she said, "Then a little boy came running up and said the girl had lost her leg and her arm and everyone ran out of the house towards the beach."
SNT.30061.18646	"It was just a little black-and-white dog but he was crazy so I locked him under the house."
SNT.30061.18647	Other reports claim that the woman had been scuba diving in murky shallow water approximately 15 metres from the shore.
SNT.30061.18648	The woman is believed to be from McDowall in Brisbane, but her name has not yet been released.
SNT.30061.18649	A resident of Amity Point for 20 years, Brad Ross, said tourists visiting the area have been warned of potential attacks; "The shore just falls away into 30m of water and there are plenty of bull sharks out there."
SNT.30061.18650	"People know when they enter the water there they're stepping into a shark habitat."
SNT.30061.18651	Other beaches on the island are protected by drum lines.
SNT.30061.18652	Queensland state police inspector Peter Harding believes from the severity of the woman's injuries that she was attacked by a group of bull sharks, a species known for aggressive behavior this time of year.

SNT.98473.18748	Some flu viruses in the United States and Canada have shown increased levels of resistance to the antiviral drug Tamiflu (oseltamivir), the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.
SNT.98473.18749	Tamiflu is currently the recommended treatment for humans infected with bird flu, and governments worldwide have been stockpiling the drug in case of a flu pandemic.
SNT.98473.18750	The drug resistance appears to be limited to the H1N1 variant which causes seasonal flu, while H3N2 or influenza B strains and the H5N1 strain that causes bird flu did not show increased resistance.
SNT.98473.18751	While previous studies showed resistance levels below 1%, samples tested by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now showed around 5% resistance, and in a Canadian survey of 81 samples, 8 showed resistance.
SNT.98473.18752	The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control found 19 cases of resistance among 148 samples from last November.
SNT.98473.18753	In a wider study of 437 H1N1 isolates from 19 countries, the European agency found 59 resistant samples from 9 countries.
SNT.98473.18754	Resistance has not been shown to increase in Japan or Hong Kong.
SNT.98473.18755	The WHO is now contacting national authorities to get more data on flu resistance.
SNT.98473.18756	These viruses have acquired a mutation that makes them resistant, and the WHO statement said that a resistant strain has probably emerged spontaneously.
SNT.98473.18757	The statement added that these mutations would most likely render Tamiflu ineffective for the prevention or treatment of flu caused by resistant H1N1 viruses.
SNT.98473.18758	The WHO also stated that this phenomenon does not influence the effectiveness of flu immunizations.
SNT.98473.18759	Resistant strains have shown no evidence of causing more severe disease or being more easily transmissible.

SNT.55305.18761	Although there have been reports that planning and design work on replacement vessels and new designs of nuclear war heads has been proceeding for some years, the first Cabinet meeting to consider this pledge will take place tomorrow.

SNT.55305.18763	A further Cabinet meeting is to be held prior to the publication of a White Paper just before Christmas.

SNT.55305.18765	It is reported that some Cabinet Ministers have reservations about the prudence of maintaining the nuclear deterrent when the apparent threats are from saboteurs and suicide bombers.
SNT.55305.18766	They also have doubts about the legality of adding to the stock of nuclear warheads contrary to the spirit of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and about the way that the decision is being pushed through without consultation with the Labour Party.

SNT.55305.18770	Their reasons include keeping the country's seat at the top table of international politics.

SNT.55305.18772	The current Trident system cost £12.6 Bn to introduce at 1996 prices, and requires £280m a year to maintain.
SNT.55305.18773	Replacements for the smaller nuclear-powered w:attack submarines are under construction and will be armed with Tomahawk missile tactical missile systems.

SNT.602338.18854	The constitutional decree made November 22 by Morsi protected the constitution drafting body of Egypt from dissolution and also protected executive decisions from being overturned.
SNT.602338.18855	The decree has sparked protests and strikes reminiscent of protests which eventually toppled the then president Hosni Mubarak.

SNT.602338.18857	Morsi opposed the ruling, threatening action, but later respected the decision.

SNT.60342.18861	Honey-bee decline has accelerated in North America beyond the steady attrition of the past 25 years according to scientists and farmers.
SNT.60342.18862	A relatively new term - "Colony Collapse Disorder" is being used to describe this poorly understood phenomenon.
SNT.60342.18863	Colony Collapse Disorder (or CCD) is a syndrome evidenced by massive die-off affecting an entire insect population.
SNT.60342.18864	The cause of the syndrome is not yet well understood.
SNT.60342.18865	CCD may be caused by mites or associated diseases or unknown pathogens.
SNT.60342.18866	CCD is possibly linked to pesticide use though several studies have found no common environmental factors between unrelated outbreaks studied.
SNT.60342.18867	According to Dennis vanEngelsdorp, a bee specialist with the Pennsylvania State Department of Agriculture, "We are pretty sure, but not certain, that it is a contagious disease."
SNT.60342.18868	Honey-bees are responsible for approximately one third of the United States crop pollination including such species as: peaches, soybeans, apples, pears, pumpkins, cucumbers, cherries, raspberries, blackberries and strawberries.
SNT.60342.18869	From 1971 to 2006, approximately one half of the U.S. honey-bee colonies vanished.
SNT.60342.18870	The rate of attrition reached new proportions in the year 2006, which were alarming to many farmers and honey-bee scientists.
SNT.60342.18871	At least eleven different states as well as portions of Canada are known to have been affected by colony collapse disorder.
SNT.60342.18872	The disorder has been identified in a geographically diverse group of states including Georgia, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and California.
SNT.60342.18873	In some states the loss of honey-bee colonies is estimated as high as 75 percent of the population.
SNT.60342.18874	The phenomenon is particularly important for crops such as almond growing in California, where honey-bees are the predominant pollinator and the crop value is $US 1.5 billion.
SNT.60342.18875	Total U.S. crops that are wholly dependent on the honey-bee are known to exceed $US 15 billion.
SNT.60342.18876	In a related development on January 17, 2007, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has drastically tightened use rules on some of the chief pesticides used on apples, blueberries, grapes, peaches, pears and other fruits pollenized by honey-bees.
SNT.60342.18877	Citing general environmental protection and farmworker safety, the EPA recently announced the tightening of use or phaseout of the highly toxic pesticides phosmet and Azinphos methyl.
SNT.60342.18878	Under these rule changes the use of these organophosphate pesticide would be allowed continued use for five years but have somewhat reduced dosage limits.
SNT.60342.18879	Azinphos methyl is a dangerous neurotoxin derived from nerve agents used during World War II.
SNT.190592.18880	South Korea has lost contact with its Naro-1 rocket, just 137 seconds after take-off.
SNT.190592.18881	Korea Aerospace Research Institute (KARI) and Khrunichev State Research and Production Space Center had hoped to use a Naro-1, South Korea's first carrier rocket, to launch a STSAT-2B satellite.
SNT.190592.18882	South Korea had postponed the launch on Wednesday due to problems with the rocket's fire extinguisher system.
SNT.190592.18883	Science Ministry spokesman Pyun Kyung-bum said, "We expect that it will be difficult to launch today".
SNT.190592.18884	The rocket lifted off from Goheung's Naro Space Centre at 1701 (0801 GMT) today.
SNT.190592.18885	The rocket apparently exploded 137 seconds after launch, when a flash was seen from an on-board camera and communication was lost.
SNT.190592.18886	The loss of communication occurred when the rocket had achieved an altitude of around 70 kilometers (43 mi).
SNT.190592.18887	Television cameras captured a white speck, presumably part of the rocket, falling into the sea.
SNT.190592.18888	Analysts say the failure is a setback for South Korea.
SNT.190592.18889	If it had been successful, it would have been the first Naro-1 launch to reach orbit.
SNT.190592.18890	The launch cost South Korea an estimated US$400 million, and if successful, would have launched a satellite called the STSAT-2B into orbit.
SNT.190592.18891	The satellite was designed to examine climate change and its effects.
SNT.190592.18892	The incident is seen as a major setback for South Korea's space program, which had been aiming to become the 10th country to achieve the capability to launch satellites, and the fourth Asian country, after China, Japan, and India.
SNT.190592.18893	A successful launch would have helped South Korea to become a player in commercial space launches, an industry valued at around US$250 billion.
SNT.190592.18894	Since 1992, South Korea has launched 11 satellites from overseas sites with foreign-made rockets.

SNT.57162.18896	The head of the earthquake monitoring agency in the Philippines disputed the Japanese agency's warnings, however.

SNT.57162.18899	Nevertheless, Solidum said that residents in low-lying areas in the Philippines should, as a precaution, move to higher ground.

SNT.57162.18902	Home users are experiencing severe connection issues, with timeouts becoming very common.
SNT.57162.18903	The Internet Storm Center is reporting a 100% packet loss on certain routers.

SNT.57162.18906	Repairing the lines "is not a matter of days," says Hong Seoung-Yong, a ministry official from South Korea handling the problem.
SNT.57162.18907	Taiwan's internet capacity has dropped to 40%, and consequently the networks there are jammed.
SNT.57162.18908	Service providers may choose to bypass those lines in favour of European ones, say a spokesman for Japanese telecoms firm KDDI Corp, Satoru Ito.

SNT.5475.18912	On June 2, 2000, a serious accident in the province of Cajamarca, in Peru, poisoned many residents with mercury, a highly toxic heavy metal.
SNT.5475.18913	A truck from Newmont Mining Company dumped two metal canisters of mercury along an Andean highway, in the communities of San Juan, Choropampa, and Magdalena.
SNT.5475.18914	Curious townspeople (mostly children) picked up the silvery droplets, and some even drank some of it.
SNT.5475.18915	Some of those who came in contact with the mercury suffered blindness, and one even had a purplish rash on her body.
SNT.5475.18916	Over 300 people directly suffered the effects of mercury poisoning.
SNT.5475.18917	As the owners of the Yanacocha mine which produced the mercury, Newmont Mining offered up to US$6 thousand to more than 700 local residents, but over 1,100 others are still engaged in a legal battle with Newmont over the case.
SNT.5475.18918	In today's global economy, many international businesses have looked overseas to maintain their profits, but environmental law professor James Otto is asking about the cost to the environment and public health.
SNT.5475.18919	"Any company that wants to mine internationally now must not only have the legal right to mine but also a 'social license' to operate," he said.

SNT.5475.18921	After the breakdown of mediation talks with Newmont on January 20, the residents and their lawyer decided to stop negotiating behind closed doors and take their case to the public.
SNT.5475.18922	Last Saturday, March 5, 2005, they announced that they are bringing their suit before Denver District Judge Robert Hyatt.
SNT.5475.18923	This is not the first time Newmont Mining has had trouble with an emerging Third World environmental movement.
SNT.5475.18924	Recently, in August 2004, a US$543 million lawsuit was filed against Newmont Mining by the Indonesian Environmental Ministry and local villagers.
SNT.5475.18925	They claim that pollution caused by the company’s mining activities has caused serious illnesses and other health problems, including skin disease, tumors, birth defects, and a decline in fish stocks, a staple food.
SNT.5475.18926	One particular mining practice used frequently by Newmont Mining in Indonesia is submarine tailings disposal, a waste disposal method for mercury and arsenic that is outlawed in the United States.
SNT.5475.18927	At least six Newmont Mining managers, including an American and an Australian, face up to 15 years in a Jakarta prison for environmental and corporate crime in that case.

SNT.5475.18929	Thousands of local townspeople protested against the Yanacocha mine last fall, demanding protection for the local water supply.
SNT.5475.18930	Newmont Mining officials have blamed the June 2000 mercury spill on a contractor, and have lost the battle to keep the case out of the American court system.

SNT.80864.18946	At least 11 new species of life have been discovered in the rainforests of Thua Thien-Hue Province in Vietnam in a region of the forest described as the "Green Corridor."
SNT.80864.18947	The discovery was made by researchers from the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF).
SNT.80864.18948	Among the new species are five orchids and at least three other species of plants, two butterflies and a snake.
SNT.80864.18949	At least ten more species of plants are believed to be new species but are still being studied.
SNT.80864.18950	"You only discover so many new species in very special places, and the Green Corridor is one of them."
SNT.80864.18951	"Several large mammal species were discovered in the 1990s in the same forests, which means that these latest discoveries could be just the tip of the iceberg," said a technical adviser in Vietnam for the WWF, Chris Dickinson.
SNT.80864.18952	The new species of life are exclusive to the rainforest in Thua Thien-Hue Province.
SNT.80864.18953	The new snake, which can grow to 80 centimeters long, has been given the name white-lipped keelback because of a yellow-white stripe on the top of its head and makes its home near small streams and feeds on small animals and frogs.
SNT.80864.18954	The new species of butterflies are one subfamily of the Satyrinae species and the other a species of the Skipper butterfly.
SNT.80864.18955	The orchids, all of which are considered very rare because they were found to have no leaves whatsoever on the plant, grow in "matter" that is rotting and also contain no chlorophyll.
SNT.80864.18956	The other two new plant species are of Arum and Aspidistra.
SNT.80864.18957	The WWF is concerned that civilization may move closer into the rainforest, destroying the homes of these new species, but the government of Thua Thien-Hue Province says it's dedicated to making sure that they are protected, along with the rainforest.
SNT.80864.18958	"The area is extremely important for conservation and the province wants to protect the forests and their environmental services, as well as contribute to sustainable development," said Provincial Forest Protection Department Director for the province, Hoang Ngoc Khanh.
SNT.80864.18959	The species were found in the rainforest in 2005 and 2006.

SNT.111975.19057	Large herd animals may have the ability to detect earth's magnetic field, concluded scientists in Germany in a report published in this week's Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences after performing studies of cattle and deer grazing and sleeping patterns.
SNT.111975.19058	The animals tended to face north-south oriented toward the earth's magnetic poles.
SNT.111975.19059	Hynek Burda of the University of Duisburg-Essen in Germany led the team that announced the unconfirmed study.
SNT.111975.19060	Burda and his team gathered cattle data via analysis of Google Earth images.
SNT.111975.19061	The team originally intended to test for possible human magnetic field detection by studying the orientation of sleeping bags in outdoor campers, but it proved difficult to obtain data because humans usually slept under tents.
SNT.111975.19062	Cattle were easier to observe, and 8,510 head of cattle at 308 locations demonstrated a strong tendency to align body orientation in accordance with the earth's magnetic field.
SNT.111975.19063	Other possible factors such as wind or sunlight direction did not supply a better explanation for the behavior.
SNT.111975.19064	To compare against a second large species, Burda and his team analyzed data on 2,974 deer studied through photography, direct observation, and snow imprints.
SNT.111975.19065	"I think the really amazing thing is that hunters and herdsmen and farmers didn't notice it," said Burda according to a National Public Radio report.
SNT.111975.19066	Peter August of the University of Rhode Island in Kingston, commented: "I was really amazed at the consistency with which they found north-facing cows and deer."
SNT.111975.19067	No independent study has yet confirmed the Duisburg-Essen team's findings.
SNT.111975.19068	This is the first study that indicates magnetic field detection in large mammals.
SNT.111975.19069	Burda's previous research involves naked mole rats, a small blind mammal species whose behavior indicates an internal magnetic compass.
SNT.111975.19070	According to a report by Jeremy Hsu at MSNBC, "Previous research has shown that animals such as birds, turtles and salmon migrate using a sense of magnetic direction, and small mammals such as rodents and one bat species also have a magnetic compass."

SNT.78504.19080	Two men have been charged with starting the Zaca Fire, the second-largest wildfire in the history of California.
SNT.78504.19081	The fire is continuing to burn through the Los Padres National Forest, and has consumed a total of 240,000 acres, having started on July 4.
SNT.78504.19082	However, the fire is now under control, and is expected to be contained by September 4.
SNT.78504.19083	Jose Jesus Cabrera of Santa Ynez, 38, Santiago Iniguez Cervantes of Santa Maria, 46, and the company of Rancho La Laguna, whom they worked for, have all been charged with six counts of felony in relation to starting the fire.
SNT.78504.19084	Three of the charges are for "recklessly causing a fire that caused great bodily injury".
SNT.78504.19085	Two counts of this stem from the crash of a helicopter that was fighting the fires, and the other from a separate incident when a third firefighter was seriously wounded while battling the flames.
SNT.78504.19086	The other three counts are for recklessly causing a structure or forest fire, carelessness with a flaming substance and for not having the required permit to operate equipment capable of starting a fire.
SNT.78504.19087	The fire started when equipment being used on a blocked water line sparked.
SNT.78504.19088	58 firefighters were injured in total by the blaze, although no life-threatening injuries were sustained.
SNT.78504.19089	Currently, 1,800 people are involved in firefighting efforts, which have cost a total of $114 million.
SNT.78504.19090	A lawyer for the men said he felt the charges were excessive considering the circumstances.
SNT.78504.19091	"We have a couple of hard working guys who go out to take care of a water pipe or some cattle on a very hot day on the Fourth of July and they took precautions and despite the precautions an accident happened and a fire started," said Attorney Robert Sanger.
SNT.78504.19092	If convicted, the men could face up to nine years imprisonment.
SNT.78504.19093	There is also the possibility of fines and action to recover the costs of the fire.

SNT.168976.19109	After a year of turbulent weather in Mexico and destruction of their habitat, the Monarch butterfly (Danaus plexippus) population could be down by as much as 50% to 60% this year, experts say.
SNT.168976.19110	A gathering area for the butterflies northwest of Mexico City was affected particularly hard by severe weather this winter, which killed 50 people in the region.
SNT.168976.19111	According to Lincoln Brower, a monarch expert with Sweet Briar College in Virginia, "things are in pretty bad shape."
SNT.168976.19112	The southbound migration was already the smallest in recorded history, and with the destructive winter, over half of the species' population might have been killed.
SNT.168976.19113	"This means the numbers going to Texas are going to be down", said Chip Taylor, a professor of entomology at the University of Kansas-Lawrence.
SNT.168976.19114	He believes it could take years for the Monarchs to repopulate.
SNT.168976.19115	Taylor also said that "We’re talking about significant degradation at overwintering sites; the loss of habitat in the United States and Canada and climate change in Mexico."
SNT.168976.19116	"We’ve had three major killing winter storms in the last decade that have never been seen previously."
SNT.168976.19117	"We’re dealing with something new here, and that’s consistent with climate change."
SNT.168976.19118	Illegal logging in Mexico and a lack of milkweed in the Midwest United States for the butterflies to lay their eggs in has also taken a toll on the Monarchs' population.
SNT.43916.19119	Research published in the journal the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) suggests a link between male sexuality and conditions in the womb.
SNT.43916.19120	Initial research by Dr. Anthony F. Bogaert and his colleagues at Brock University, Ontario revealed a possible link between the number of elder brothers a boy has and the likelihood he is to be gay.
SNT.43916.19121	Whether this correlation be attributed to nature through the prenatal effects of the womb or to nurture through the psychosocial effects of growing up with elder siblings, however, remained unclear.
SNT.43916.19122	To further his research Bogaert studied 944 heterosexual and homosexual men.
SNT.43916.19123	The men were either "biological" brothers and shared the same mother or "non-biological" brothers through adoption or as half or step siblings.
SNT.43916.19124	Boegart reasoned that if the link between homosexuality and elder brothers was due to the nurturing effects of the family environment it would show regardless of any biological relationship.
SNT.43916.19125	The study showed, however, that the link was found only in biological brothers.
SNT.43916.19126	The amount of time an individual spent being raised with elder brothers had no bearing on sexual orientation; the relationship was even found to be true in brothers who were raised apart from one another.
SNT.43916.19127	Bogaert writes in this month's PNAS: "These results support a prenatal origin to sexual orientation development in men and indicate that the fraternal birth-order effect is probably the result of a maternal 'memory' for male gestations or births."
SNT.43916.19128	He suggests that each male foetus prompts a progressively stronger immune reaction in the mother's body.
SNT.43916.19129	The antibodies that are produced by this reaction may account for sexual differentiation of the brain.
SNT.43916.19130	Scientists from Michigan State University added in an accompanying article: "These data strengthen the notion that the common denominator between biological brothers, the mother, provides a prenatal environment that fosters homosexuality in her younger sons."
SNT.43916.19131	"Increasingly, credible evidence appears to indicate that being gay is genetically determined rather than being a so-called lifestyle choice."
SNT.43916.19132	It adds further weight to the argument that lesbian and gay people should be treated equally in society and not discriminated against for something that's just as inherent as skin colour," said Andy Forrest, a spokesman for gay rights group Stonewall.
SNT.43916.19133	However; Dr. Bogaert's study made no explanation for the origin of lesbianism.
SNT.270358.19134	Only 44.47 percent of Romanian high school students passed last week's 2011 baccalaureate exam, according to the results published by Romanian education authorities on Sunday.
SNT.270358.19135	The baccalaureate exam in Romania is the secondary school educational qualification test, and passing it attests that a student has graduated high school and may be admitted to a university.
SNT.270358.19136	This is dramatically different from 69.3 percent last year and 81.4 percent in 2009.
SNT.270358.19137	Sunday's passing figures are a record low since the exam was introduced in Romania and comes after new anti-fraud measures cut back on student cheating.
SNT.270358.19138	These included installing cameras in examination centres and forbidding students from paying teachers to obtain higher scores.
SNT.270358.19139	For this exam, 665 high school students were caught cheating, double the number from last year, and at one high school it was found that the exam answers were given to 111 pupils prior to the exam.
SNT.270358.19140	Caras Severin County reported the lowest rate with 24.82 percent graduation, and Suceava reported the highest with 65.03 percent, down from 87.39 percent in 2010.
SNT.270358.19141	In Bucharest the rate was 42.03 percent, the lowest since the 1989 revolution.
SNT.270358.19142	The release of the results started a national debate on the possible causes of the drastic drop in scores, from the failure of parental participation, poor teacher pay and pay cuts, to student disinterest and lack of motivation.
SNT.270358.19143	Critics say the educational system depends on rote learning and students are not taught to think independently.
SNT.270358.19144	At a press conference on Monday, Education minister Daniel Funeriu said, "These results are a mirror of our society."
SNT.270358.19145	"Romania is now at a crossroads...".
SNT.270358.19145-1	"The nation should choose to encourage people who like to work rather than those who prefer cheating".
SNT.270358.19146	Cristian Alexandrescu, chief education inspector for Bucharest, argued that the exam was not taken seriously by students and the results prove that a student cannot obtain a diploma without effort.
SNT.270358.19147	"The moment of truth has come," Liliana Romanciuc, a school inspector in north-eastern Romania, told Mediafax.

SNT.125188.19153	Ballard died on Sunday after a long battle with prostate cancer.
SNT.125188.19154	According to a spokesperson, Ballard had been sick "for several years" and that it was "with great sadness" to have to make the announcement of his death.
SNT.125188.19155	Ballard is best known for writing the novels Crash in 1973 and Empire of the Sun in 1984 which won the James Tait Black Memorial Prize.
SNT.125188.19156	"He had grown up in Shanghai and had very good manners."
SNT.125188.19157	"He was very generous and polite and it took a long while before he would do anything that wasn’t very controlled," said friend and author Iain Sinclair to The Times.
SNT.125188.19158	Ballard was born in Shanghai, China in the Shanghai International Settlement in 1930.
SNT.125188.19159	When he was 12, he and his family were forced to live in a camp run by Japanese forces during World War II.
SNT.125188.19160	Ballard says that he won't say happy things about his experience in the camp, but also no unpleasant ones either.
SNT.125188.19161	In an interview with BBC News, Ballard said "I remember a lot of the casual brutality and beatings-up that went on, but at the same time we children were playing a hundred and one games all the time."
SNT.125188.19162	In 1946 he moved to the UK with his sister and mother where he began to write.
SNT.125188.19163	Twenty years later, in the 1960's, he employed himself as a full time writer.
SNT.125188.19164	He produced his first novel in 1961 titled The Wind from Nowhere and The Drowned World just a year later.

SNT.56689.19190	High winds and heavy rains have left 4 people dead, and much of the Seattle, Washington area is without electrical power.
SNT.56689.19191	A number of large trees have been downed and heavy rains have caused minor flooding in many areas of the city.
SNT.56689.19192	According to first-hand reports as many as 1 million people and several large organizations such as Microsoft are without power this morning.
SNT.56689.19193	Flood, storm, and strong wind watches were in effect last night as a rare thunderstorm system moved into the Pacific Northwest region, hitting areas from Seattle to Portland with high winds and heavy rains.
SNT.56689.19194	Interstate 5 through Seattle was closed at its intersection with Mercer Street due to standing water.
SNT.56689.19195	The State Route 520 floating bridge, a major conduit across Lake Washington to the technology-rich Eastside was closed and its drawspan opened to protect it from storm damage well into Friday.
SNT.56689.19196	Local roads throughout the region were strewn with debris, especially evergreen branches and leaves.
SNT.56689.19197	Four deaths were reported in connection with the storm as of Friday.
SNT.56689.19198	A Seattle woman died in the basement of her home after floodwaters caused the basement door to close and jam shut.
SNT.56689.19199	Two others died in outlying areas after tall Northwest evergreens fell on their vehicles, and a man in Grays Harbor, near the Pacific coast, died in his sleep after a tree fell on his mobile home.
SNT.56689.19200	KOMO news reported a caller saying a 100-foot evergreen had fallen into his house.
SNT.56689.19201	Downed trees and high winds also brought down powerlines throughout Western Washington.
SNT.56689.19202	Seattle City Light, the municipal electric utility for the city, reported a peak of 175,000 customers without power, most in the north and south ends of the city, as well as the east edge of town and the Green Lake area.
SNT.56689.19203	Puget Sound Energy, the electric utility for much of the Seattle metro area, reported 700,000 customers (over 66%) without power, with the area around Seattle the worst hit.
SNT.56689.19204	PSE, which had already enlisted additional powerline workers from neighboring states, did not send crews out until mid Friday morning due to continued high winds.
SNT.56689.19205	Estimates for power restoration were anywhere from a few days to over a week.
SNT.56689.19206	Island County, at the mouth of Puget Sound, was completely without power.
SNT.56689.19207	Schools in Seattle and throughout its suburbs were closed Friday, many due to power outages.
SNT.56689.19208	The city of Mercer Island, connected to the mainland only by Interstate 90, is reportedly inaccessible.
SNT.56689.19209	The Seattle Post-Intelligencer failed to print due to power failures at the printing facility, which had redundant power feeds from both the Seattle utility as well as PSE.
SNT.56689.19210	It is the first time in 70 years that the paper has not been printed.
SNT.56689.19211	The Seattle Times, a competing paper under a joint operating agreement, managed to print only 13,000 copies of its regular circulation of over 200,000.
SNT.56689.19212	The papers located alternate facilities to print a reduced version of their Saturday editions, and their joint Sunday issue was also expected to be reduced.
SNT.56689.19213	At Sea-Tac Airport, three terminals were shut down overnight due to the storm.
SNT.56689.19214	Concourse A and the South Satellite terminal lost power, and a blown-out window caused Concourse C to also close.
SNT.56689.19215	All terminals were back in working order by midday Friday.
SNT.56689.19216	Likewise, in Oregon, Portland International Airport reported at least 40 flights cancelled.
SNT.56689.19217	At Seattle's Boeing Field, winds flipped a private plane over, colliding with another plane.
SNT.56689.19218	The Seattle Seahawks vs. San Francisco 49ers football game was delayed 15 minutes.
SNT.56689.19219	A pre-game power surge temporarily took the Qwest Field's video displays offline.
SNT.56689.19220	The gridiron was plagued by standing water, as the stadium's loudspeakers played "Who'll Stop The Rain?" shortly before kickoff.
SNT.56689.19221	Thursday night's storm comes after a previous regional storm in the Seattle area earlier in the week, in which trees in a few Seattle suburbs fell onto roads, powerlines, and two school buses.
SNT.56689.19222	In those incidents no one was hurt, and there were a few spotty power outages.
SNT.56689.19223	This is the second serious storm to hit the Northwest since Thanksgiving, In late November, record-setting snowfall had a similar disabling effect on the region.

SNT.15551.19225	The Daily Mirror claims that the bombers brought return rail tickets to Luton, and that they purchased pay and display car park tickets before boarding the train at Luton Station.
SNT.15551.19226	The tabloid paper also states how the bombers all had personal items on their person at the time of the attacks, such as wallets, driving licences and bank cards.
SNT.15551.19227	It also states how they were carrying large rucksacks which could be easily dumped, instead of having the explosives strapped to their bodies, as would be expected of a suicide bomber.
SNT.15551.19228	It also points to evidence from the bombers' families, where two of the men had pregnant wives.
SNT.15551.19229	From this evidence, the paper draws the conclusion that the four men were not told the bombs would detonate straight away, and that the men thought they would be able to escape unscathed.
SNT.15551.19230	This was probably done to protect their master's identity, the paper suggested, since there was a high probability the bombers would be caught had they lived.

SNT.144830.19260	King Abdullah has now disbanded the parliament two times since he came to power in 1999.

SNT.9449.19270	Former Russian nuclear energy minister Yevgeny Adamov was arrested on Monday by Swiss authorities.
SNT.9449.19271	The arrest came at the request of U.S. officials who claim he stole more than nine million dollars allocated by Washington to help improve Russian nuclear safety.
SNT.9449.19272	The Ministry of Justice in Switzerland said Adamov will be extradited to the US.
SNT.9449.19273	The warrant allowing this states that he is charged with diverting money from the U.S. Department of Energy to several companies he controls.
SNT.9449.19274	Adamov's lead lawyer said he will fight the extradition warrant and called the accusations "baseless".
SNT.9449.19275	Adamov, who has on a number of occasions been investigated for his financial dealing by the U.S. and Russia alike, said he was being punished for his help in building a nuclear plant in Iran.
SNT.9449.19276	The U.S. now has 60 days to present a formal request, after which a Swiss court will make a ruling.
SNT.9449.19277	Swiss officials said it is common for this process to take several months.
SNT.9449.19278	Adamov's U.S. lawyer, Larry Breur, said Adamov admitted to depositing the money into a personal account, but then he used that account to dispense the money to Russian agencies and nuclear scientists.
SNT.9449.19279	Breur said the process was common in Russia to avoid hypertaxation.
SNT.9449.19280	Yevgeny Adamov was a minister in Boris Yeltsin's government, but was removed from power by Vladimir Putin in an effort to remove corruption.
SNT.9449.19281	Adamov was in Bern attempting to unblock bank accounts belonging to his daughter.

SNT.73874.19299	Dutch adventurer Ralph Tuijn has reached the halfway point of his attempt to be the first person to row across the Pacific Ocean unaided.
SNT.73874.19300	The 16,000 kilometre journey from the coast of Peru to the seaside city of Brisbane, Australia, the widest section of the Pacific, has never been crossed absolutely unaided by a rower, and Tuijn says just nine people have rowed it even with assistance.
SNT.73874.19301	Tuijn reached the central point of his crossing, an insignificant point of water in the ocean, 111 days after setting off from Peru in March.
SNT.73874.19302	He has been making good progress, and has since cut his estimated time of arrival in Brisbane by a month.
SNT.73874.19303	The Dutchman, who now expects to reach his destination on October 20, has kept in touch with those tracking his movements through daily internet postings from his laptop computer, including his wife Winnie.
SNT.73874.19304	His boat, the Zeeman Challenger, is a seven-metre custom plywood vessel.
SNT.73874.19305	Tuijn has overcome a variety of obstacles to reach the halfway point.
SNT.73874.19306	He is suffering from the constant attention of sharks, who often bump his boat and disrupt his attempts at sleep.
SNT.73874.19307	One particular shark, dubbed 'Gomulka' by Tuijn, has been trailing the adventurer's boat for extended periods.
SNT.73874.19308	He has also accidentally burnt himself when he spilled hot water on his foot whilst trying to make coffee, apparently also from a shark 'bump'.
SNT.73874.19309	He is also forced to manually pump water for cooking and drinking after his automatic water pump broke down not long into his journey.
SNT.73874.19310	His vessel has no motors or sails, but relies on his physical rowing power to move.
SNT.73874.19311	The boat does have a solar power system to provide energy for his laptop, a telephone and a global positioning system.
SNT.73874.19312	Tujin, who is raising money for a children's home in Mumbai, India, is rowing at an average speed of 58 kilometres each day.
SNT.73874.19313	His diet consists of freeze-dried foods and fish, which are keeping him physically well-conditioned despite tiring mentally.
SNT.73874.19314	He has rowed across the Atlantic Ocean and the North Sea, as well as cycled across Russia and the icy terrain of Greenland.

SNT.609824.19340	TransCanada, which owns the pipeline, stopped construction once the protest began.
SNT.609824.19341	"TransCanada Corporation didn't bother to ask the people of this neighborhood if they wanted to have millions of gallons of poisonous tar sands pumped through their backyards," said one of the protesters inside the pipeline, Matt Almonte in a statement posted to the group's website.

SNT.609824.19344	According to their website www.tarsandsblockade.org, Almonte and Collins entered the pipeline prior to about 7:30 a.m. local time.
SNT.609824.19345	They went 25 feet into the pipeline and took with them two barrels filled with cement, weighing 600 pounds each and locked themselves in between them.
SNT.609824.19346	At around noon, police on scene entered the section of pipe, only to emerge a few minutes later without the protesters.
SNT.609824.19347	At 12:30, after an ambulance arrived on scene, police once again entered the pipe and began to pull on one of the barrels.
SNT.609824.19348	They were successfully removed and both Almonte and Collins were arrested.
SNT.609824.19349	A short time later a third protester, identified as Isabel Indigo Brooks, was also arrested.

SNT.24868.19373	This is in response to a board of experts who have been investigating the succession issue.
SNT.24868.19374	The experts' Board on the Imperial Household Act, personally appointed by the Prime Minister, reached an agreement on the issue that an Empress should be accepted.
SNT.24868.19375	Implementation of their recommendations would mean that succession to the highest position in Japanese society would occur without a gender bias.
SNT.24868.19376	At the present time, the Japanese imperial household has no male member under the age of 20; present law only allows male descendants to ascend to the Chrysanthemum Throne.
SNT.24868.19377	The proposed solution would put Princess Aiko, the sole child of Crown Prince Naruhito and Crown Princess Masako in place as the most likely to inherit the position of monarch, following behind would be Princess Sayako who will leave the Imperial Household due to her planned marriage with a commoner.
SNT.24868.19378	Present law in Japan defines the succession as favouring male children; the last time the country had an Empress was in 1771, when Empress Go-Sakuramachi abdicated to her nephew.
SNT.24868.19379	Despite the fact that there is precedent for an Empress, some scholars have suggested family members who previously broke ties with the recognised royal family following the end of World War II should be considered for the succession, opening up the field of candidates even more.
SNT.24868.19380	The group of scholars proposing this solution have stressed that their solution is aimed at maintaining the tradition of a male heir.

SNT.8658.19556	Queensland Australia's Sir Joh Bjelke Petersen, a controversial figure who served as the State's Premier for 19 years and reigned over the government that later became the subject of the Fitzgerald Inquiry, has died in hospital at Kingaroy, aged 94.
SNT.8658.19557	"By any measurement, Sir Joh was an exceptional state builder who will be remembered for consistently placing Queensland first," said the Australian Governor General, Major General Jeffery, in a statement.
SNT.8658.19558	Australian Prime Minister, John Howard: "He was certainly a strong political figure and I extend my condolences to his wife and his family."
SNT.8658.19559	But not all voices were sympathetic, prominent Queensland Aboriginal activist Sam Watson for example: "Aboriginal people will always remember him as a racist, a thug and a dictator."
SNT.8658.19560	Having suffered severe ill-health for some weeks, and declining health for years, Sir Joh passed away at around 6pm AEST.
SNT.8658.19561	He was surrounded by his family, who had been summoned yesterday by Lady Flo, his wife and one-time Senator, for final goodbyes.
SNT.8658.19562	Phrases such as "Don't you worry about that" and "Goodness gracious me" were like trademarks to the maverick leader.
SNT.8658.19563	Known simply as 'Joh' to many, he would famously describe press conferences as 'feeding the chooks'.
SNT.8658.19564	Today Kingaroy locals taunted waiting press with cries from "You're chooks, you're chooks, ha ha" to "Go home, ya vultures", and some obscenities, reported the Courier-Mail of Brisbane.
SNT.8658.19565	His fall from power at the end of the 80s was surrounded in controversy, with the state embroiled in corruption findings going to the level of his deputies, and Bjelke Petersen's claims of ignorance coming under challenge with charges of perjury.
SNT.8658.19566	The case was never heard due to a controversial hung jury: the foreman of the jury, Luke Shaw, had been an office-bearer of the Young Nationals — an arm of Bjelke Petersen's National Party — as well as a member of a group calling themselves 'Friends of Joh'.
SNT.8658.19567	Having had his start in life as a peanut farmer in remote Kingaroy, the former Premier was fit up until the very end, but palsy was paralyzing his muscles and organs, to which he eventually succumbed.
SNT.8658.19568	"Throughout his life Sir Joh combined enormous energy, vision and an immense capacity for hard work, most especially during his 19-year term as Premier of Queensland," the Governor General said.
SNT.8658.19569	"What looked to us to be huge risks at the time turned out to be nation building," said Bob Katter, a former minister of Joh's Government, who credited Sir Joh with starting the Queensland coal, aluminum and tourism industries.
SNT.8658.19570	He is also remembered for dismantling many of the State's unions, and for a somewhat totalitarian and heavy handed style of keeping control.
SNT.8658.19571	Under Joh, street protests were banned and Special Branch monitored extensively those the authoritarian leader saw as subversives, measures prompting Queenslander, Australian Civil Liberties Council, Terry O'Gorman, to comment Sir Joh was "the most appalling premier Queensland has ever had in terms of civil liberties and human rights".
SNT.8658.19572	Joh was also influential in the famous case of the Dismissal by the Governor General of then-Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, in 1975.
SNT.8658.19573	In his last years as Premier, he had taken his cause to the nation's capital, with the "Joh for PM" campaign.
SNT.8658.19574	But this distraction has been credited with the downfall of his government, with corruption investigations at last being conducted by his stand-in, Bill Gunn.
SNT.8658.19575	The body of Sir Joh, who was of Lutheran faith, is to be buried at Bethany, the family property near Kingaroy.

SNT.263969.19627	Navi Pillay, the UN's Human Rights watchdog, was particularly critical of Prime Minister Julia Gillard's asylum seeker trade deal with Malaysia.
SNT.263969.19628	This bilateral agreement, if signed, would see 800 refugees attempting to get to Australia by boat immediately transported to Malaysia instead.
SNT.263969.19629	In return, Australia would take 4,000 genuine refugees from Malaysia over a space of four years.
SNT.263969.19630	However, Malaysia has not signed either the international Refugee Convention, or the Convention Against Torture.
SNT.263969.19631	In an interview with the ABC, Ms Pillay voiced concern over this, stating that Australia may "violate refugee law" by sending asylum seekers to a country where no laws are in place to protect them.
SNT.263969.19632	Pillay, a South African former anti-apartheid protester, also voiced distress over the omnipresence of political "demonising" of these asylum seekers stating, "[t]he consequence of the constant political refrain that Australia is being 'flooded' by people who are 'queue jumpers' has resulted in a stigmatisation of an entire group of people, irrespective of where they have come from or what dangers they have fled".
SNT.263969.19633	In her six-day trip to Australia, the UN Human Rights Commissioner visited two detention centres and said she was overwhelmed with the "grim despondency" of asylum seekers, many of whom wait over 18 months to have their case assessed.
SNT.263969.19634	The mistreatment of refugees was today reinforced with the release of an Australian Rights Commission report, which revealed extensive problems of self-harm and depression among detainees at the Villawood Detention Centre in Sydney.

SNT.42590.19636	The bill was defeated 48 to 49 and did not receive the minimum amount of 60 votes to that would allow the bill to be taken to the full Senate.
SNT.42590.19637	The bill fell 18 votes short of the 67 that were needed for approval.
SNT.42590.19638	In order for the bill to become part of the U.S. Constitution, this bill would have had to be approved by a two-thirds majority in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, then be approved by the legislatures of three fourths (that is, 38) of the States.
SNT.42590.19639	However, Senator David Vitter, R-LA, who is a supporter of the bill says, "we're building votes."
SNT.42590.19640	"Most Americans are not yet convinced that their elected representatives or the judiciary are likely to expand decisively the definition of marriage to include same-sex couples," said John McCain (R-AZ) who opposed the bill.
SNT.42590.19641	"A vote for it is a vote against civil unions, against domestic partnership, against all other efforts for states to treat gays and lesbians fairly under the law," said Massachusetts Senator Edward Kennedy.
SNT.42590.19642	The bill would define marriage as between a man and a woman, and would preclude the official recognizing of same-sex marriages.
SNT.42590.19643	The bill is expected to be taken back to the Senate in July.

SNT.255184.19645	The agreement, announced just one hour before the shutdown was to occur, includes US$38.5 billion in budget reductions.
SNT.255184.19646	Earlier on Friday, US legislators deflected claims that a midnight deal was being worked out, but Republican Party sources later reported that a deal was likely to be reached.
SNT.255184.19647	The deal was apparently reached after disputes over government funding for organizations such as Planned Parenthood were resolved.
SNT.255184.19648	Boehner said both sides decided on a six-day extension, or "bridge," of government funding, which would allow Congress to work out a final solution to last the remainder of the 2011 fiscal year, which ends in September.
SNT.255184.19649	Voting for the resulting agreement will take place some time next week, according to Boehner.
SNT.255184.19650	The last complete US government shutdown occurred in 1995, during the administration of Bill Clinton, lasting five days; it was proceeded by a 21-day partial shutdown.
SNT.255184.19651	In the event of a government shutdown, essential federal employees are still required to work, but nonessential personnel are placed on unpaid furloughs.
SNT.255184.19652	Essential staff include military personnel, air traffic controllers, emergency officials, and intelligence officials.

SNT.42176.19699	The Australian federal and New South Wales governments will not be selling their shares in Snowy Hydro Limited (the owner and operator of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme).
SNT.42176.19700	Snowy Hydro Limited's major shareholder is the NSW government with a 58 percent shareholding.
SNT.42176.19701	The Victorian government owns 29 percent and the federal government has a 13 percent stake.
SNT.42176.19702	NSW Premier Morris Iemma announced in December 2005 that he wished to sell the state's share in Snowy Hydro that caused the federal and Victorian governments to follow.
SNT.42176.19703	The proposed sale has attracted immense criticism by those who believed that the sale would affect the environment and water supplies along the Snowy River, this was reinforced yesterday when 58 eminent Australians presented a petition to the government opposing the sale.
SNT.42176.19704	Prime Minister John Howard announced today that the federal government would not be selling its 13 percent share of Snowy Hydro following what he calls "intense community reaction".
SNT.42176.19705	In a statement, Mr Howard said, "This decision to sell the Snowy Hydro has created significant unhappiness, concern and unrest throughout the Australian community."
SNT.42176.19706	Mr Howard said that the sale was not an election promise by his government and that the federal government failed to see any long-term benefits from the sale.
SNT.42176.19707	He also said that the government needed to "safeguard the interests of all those dependent on Australia's iconic water resources".
SNT.42176.19708	The federal government has however stated that despite refusing to sell its share in Snowy Hydro that it will not be purchasing additional shares if NSW and Victoria push ahead with the sale of their shareholdings.
SNT.42176.19709	Despite telling Macquarie Radio earlier this morning that his government would be pushing ahead with the sale as it was in the best "interests of NSW", Premier Iemma announced shortly after Mr Howard's release, that the NSW government would be withdrawing its shares from sale.
SNT.42176.19710	Mr Iemma conceded that the sale would be extremely difficult with the federal government withdrawing its 13 percent from sale.
SNT.42176.19711	"The Prime Minister has pulled the rug out from under the sale," Mr Iemma said.
SNT.42176.19712	"The Commonwealth decision makes it extremely difficult for NSW to proceed," he conceded.
SNT.42176.19713	Victoria is yet to announce whether or not it will be withdrawing its shares from sale.
SNT.48834.19714	Scientists using NASA's Swift Satellite and other telescopes have observed a supernova in near real time occurring in the constellation of Aries.
SNT.48834.19715	The explosion is said to be the most powerful explosion known to scientists, which consists of a gamma-ray burst or an x-ray blast.
SNT.48834.19716	Scientists say that bursts signal the beginning of a star's death.
SNT.48834.19717	Swift first detected the explosion on February 18 (it was given a designation GRB 060218), which allowed telescopes and satellites to watch the event as it happened.
SNT.48834.19718	The blast lasted for more than 2,000 seconds (33 minutes).
SNT.48834.19719	"This is the type of unscripted event in our nearby universe that we hoped Swift could catch," said Neil Gehrels, Swift principal investigator at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.
SNT.48834.19720	"Those observations capture the time when the star collapsed, ejected its outer envelope and most of its mass and left a compact remnant behind."
SNT.48834.19721	"And we think that compact remnant is a neutron star," said an author writing for journal Nature, where the report will be published on Thursday.
SNT.48834.19722	Scientists are also planning on using the Hubble Space Telescope and the Chandra X-ray Observatory in an attempt to get more images of the event.
SNT.48834.19723	The star is at least 440 million light years from Earth.
SNT.48834.19724	The group of scientists was led by Sergio Campana of the Italian National Institute for Astrophysics and Alicia Soderberg, a graduate student at Caltech in Pasadena, California.
SNT.59537.19725	The primary camera on the Hubble Space Telescope has shut down and is likely to only be restored to partial functionality, according to reports from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).
SNT.59537.19726	The camera on the telescope, known as the "Advanced Camera for Surveys" or ACS, can be reactivated but will be restored to only one-third of its operating capacity.
SNT.59537.19727	The camera shut down over the weekend, probably due to a failure of its backup power supply.
SNT.59537.19728	It was the third such shutdown of the camera in the past calendar year.
SNT.59537.19729	The camera had been operating on its backup power since June 30, 2006, when engineers switched from the primary power supply ("Side A") to the backup ("Side B") due to a malfunction.
SNT.59537.19730	A review board was convened on January 29 to assess all options and to decide on a course of action.
SNT.59537.19731	Their findings will be reported to NASA on March 2, 2007.
SNT.59537.19732	The ACS, developed jointly by four American agencies, was installed in March of 2002.
SNT.59537.19733	It is a system of three cameras, filters, and dispersers which act to detect wavelengths of light ranging from near-infrared to ultraviolet.
SNT.59537.19734	It is a system that was designed to last five years, according to Preston Burch, associate director and program manager for the Hubble Space Telescope.
SNT.59537.19735	NASA also indicated that the other four main systems on the telescope remain unaffected and functioning normally.
SNT.59537.19736	A scheduled mission to the space telescope in 2008 is expected to deliver instruments to further upgrade the capabilities of the telescope.
SNT.59537.19737	It is not known what the effect of the ACS failure will have on the scheduled mission.
SNT.59537.19738	Burch said in a press release posted on the NASA main website, "It is important that the review board conduct a thorough investigation that will allow us to determine if there are any changes needed in the new instruments that will be installed on the upcoming servicing mission so that we can be sure of maximizing the telescope's scientific output."
SNT.59537.19739	"We are continuing to make excellent progress in our preparations for the servicing mission, which is presently targeted to fly in September 2008."

SNT.255835.19741	The police later claimed that the women were arrested for taking part in an unauthorized protest, not because they were wearing veils.

SNT.6452.19829	IBM's T.J. Watson Research Center in Cambridge released a free tool March 25 for visualizing the changing history of a document or directory of documents, called history flow.
SNT.6452.19830	The tool offers a variety of views of document histories, including a view that gives each revision equal importance, and a timeline view which displays each revision proportionally to how long it remained current.
SNT.6452.19831	Each different editor who makes changes to the article has a distinct color, allowing for that editor's text to be tracked over time.
SNT.6452.19832	The tool was first developed in 2003 by a collaboration between Fernanda B. Viégas of the MIT Media Lab and Martin Wattenberg and Kushal Dave of IBM.
SNT.6452.19833	It was initially tested out on a large subset of the pages of Wikipedia, a free online encyclopedia project which preserves every change made to each of its articles.
SNT.6452.19834	The resulting paper was drafted in the winter of 2003 and presented at a conference in April 2004; it remains the most comprehensive overview of the lifecycle of articles in an active wiki community.
SNT.6452.19835	A year later, the history flow paper is still the most frequently cited source of statistics about the reversion of vandalism on Wikipedia.
SNT.6452.19836	The current tool is maintained by Martin Wattenberg and Jonathan Feinberg at IBM.
SNT.6452.19837	It allows users to download the text and histories of the contents of any MoinMoin wiki, or to view the history of the contents of an entire directory of documents.
SNT.6452.19838	The tool is free to download and use, but its code is not open source.
SNT.6452.19839	The support for MoinMoin wikis comes via a plugin, so the tool may be extensible to the native interfaces of other wiki engines in the future.

SNT.323922.19855	Gingrich, former Speaker of the United States House of Representatives and Perry, Governor of Texas, did not submit the 10,000 signatures, with at least 400 from each of the state's eleven congressional districts, to the state's board of elections before the 5:00 PM deadline last Thursday required to gain ballot access, according to the Republican Party of Virginia.
SNT.323922.19856	Gingrich's and Perry's campaigns both claimed to have more signatures than needed, 11,050 and 11,911 respectively.
SNT.323922.19857	Volunteers spent last night reviewing the submitted petitions and validating signatures.
SNT.323922.19858	Reportedly Rick Perry is considering an appeal of the assessment.
SNT.323922.19859	Among other major candidates for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, former Governor of Massachusetts Mitt Romney and Texas congressman Ron Paul submitted the required petition and qualified for the ballot.
SNT.323922.19860	On Thursday, it was disclosed that candidates Michele Bachmann and Rick Santorum also failed to gain ballot access.
SNT.323922.19861	According to the manager of the Gingrich campaign, Michael Krull, the former House Speaker plans to compete in the Virginia primary, despite not gaining ballot access, as a write-in candidate.
SNT.323922.19862	Krull blamed a "failed system" for the campaign's inability to gain ballot access.
SNT.323922.19863	Rick Perry's campaign manager said he was disappointed by that campaign's failure to qualify for the ballot.
SNT.323922.19864	According to a recent poll of 489 Republican voters by Quinnipiac University, Gingrich leads in the state with 30% of support, followed by Mitt Romney at 25% and Ron Paul at 9%.
SNT.323922.19865	As Virginia's delegates to the Republican National Convention are not awarded on a winner-take-all basis, candidates other than the winner of the state's primary could also gain delegates from the state.

SNT.9797.19867	The rods could be reprocessed for several months to extract weapons-grade plutonium.
SNT.9797.19868	Officials say the rods could be able to provide enough plutonium to make two nuclear bombs.
SNT.9797.19869	This could possibly signal that North Korea is preparing for a nuclear arms test.
SNT.9797.19870	North Korea may already have enough materials to make six nuclear bombs.
SNT.9797.19871	North Korea has also announced plans to continue operating the Yongbyon facility, as well as to begin construction on a larger reactor.

SNT.51992.19878	An engine failure forced Schumacher to park his car after the tunnel on lap 36 and the Spaniard rushed to his seventh victory in this season.

SNT.190499.19886	A circus elephant managed to escape from her handler on Sunday night in the city of Zurich, Switzerland before being recaptured by local police and circus animal keepers.
SNT.190499.19887	The 26-year-old female elephant, named Sabu, is from Switzerland's Zirkus Knie.
SNT.190499.19888	She was able to make her escape just before being put into a trailer, while the keeper was not paying attention.
SNT.190499.19889	Around 1930 local time (1730 UTC), Sabu was seen wading in Lake Zurich for a short time before walking back onto city streets.
SNT.190499.19890	Zurich police said that Sabu wandered along the Bahnhofstrasse avenue of Zurich, which is known as the city's most exclusive shopping street.
SNT.190499.19891	She also passed by Zürich Hauptbahnhof (the city's main rail station) and Paradeplatz, a square of Bahnhofstrasse, where both Credit Suisse Group AG and UBS AG have headquarters.
SNT.190499.19892	For nearly an hour, police chased the elephant around the city before she was finally peacefully recaptured in the Talstrasse section of Zurich.
SNT.190499.19893	Circus officials and police followed Sabu, but a circus spokesperson said that she did not respond to their calls.
SNT.190499.19894	Sabu was also said to have been moving so fast that police had difficulty keeping up with her.
SNT.190499.19895	At about 2000 local time (1900 UTC), a keeper was able to control the animal and load her onto a truck to take her to Winterthur, where the other circus animals were.
SNT.190499.19896	There were no reports of any damage or injuries during the incident, and although police held back onlookers, at least one bystander managed to capture video of the event.
SNT.190499.19897	The circus said that Sabu may have escaped after being frightened by storms near Zurich.
SNT.190499.19898	After returning to the circus, she was said to be tired, but "pleased to be back."
